The possibility of a strike in the ladies' garment industry in this city as a result of threatened dislocation of contractual relations between employers' associations in the industry and the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union developed yesterday.

Tom Weatherly announced yesterday that Broadway could expect an intimate revue from him late this season -- a revue which he would place in rehearsal about May 1 and which he will present by himself. The result will take its general cue from the three "Little Shows" with which he was associated, but will have a different title, not yet selected.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, issued a statement today that appears to be the first move toward reinstatement of Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler as director of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra despite his disagreement with Nazi ideas about art as expressed in an article last November on Paul Hindemith's music.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The program of the unofficial world economic conference opening here Tuesday and the identity of the participants were revealed today by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which is sponsoring the conference.

Announcement was made yesterday of the formation of a protective committee for holders of the Baldwin Locomotive Works five-year 6 per cent Consolidated Mortgage Bonds, due in 1938. The Baldwin Locomotive Works filed a petition last Monday for reorganization under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- By defeating G. Stahlberg, the Swedish champion, in the tenth round today, Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia took possession of second place in the international chess masters tournament at the Museum Beaux Arts, Flohr played the Indian defense and won in 31 moves.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The rights of labor under Section 7a of the National Industrial Recovery Act suffered another blow yesterday when the National Labor Relations Board in Washington ruled that this section, assuring workers of the right of collective bargaining, does not apply to uncodified industries nor to activities prior to the adoption of a code by an industry.

The most cheerful news in the papers the last two or three weeks has been connected with fires, storms, shipwrecks, automobile accidents, thefts, divorces, business losses and heavy expenditures. They are the items which have been appearing in a box at the top of the page day after day under the general heading of allowable income-tax deductions.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 28. -- Brown defeated Dartmouth, 37 to 34, in swimming tonight. Captain Fred Lee of the Bruins overcame the two-yard lead held by Bill Crouse in the final relay leg, to finish in a dead heat, and the split points gave Brown her victory.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- Joseph Stalin's right-hand man, Lazar M. Kaganovitch, who built the Moscow subway against terrific difficulties, was appointed today Commissar for Transportation in place of Andrei A. Andreyeff.

A slim, dark-haired young woman who performed her part coolly and with expertness helped two thugs to hold up a Brooklyn attorney and a friend early yesterday, robbing them of $500. The girl was described as less than 18 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The long-sought investigation of the National Recovery Administration was voted by the Senate today, but its conduct was entrusted to friends of the President.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War in the Hoover administration, said tonight that "the Republican party will make a mistake if it attempts to assimilate either of the extremes of the Democratic party."

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- About half of Great Britain's exports to Poland, which last year amounted to $3,000,000, will benefit from tariff concessions under the terms of the new Anglo-Polish trade agreement published tonight.

The necessity of Catholic leadership which should be national rather than parochial was stressed last night by Colonel William J. Donovan, speaking at the second annual dinner of the Centre Club, an organization of 1,200 Catholic college graduates, at the club, 120 Central Park South.
The National Association of Real Estate Boards has drafted a proposed bill for creating within the Federal Reserve System a Federal mortgage agency with the right to discount mortgages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 27 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,453,000,000, a decrease of $13,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and of $121,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Mrs. Raymond von Hofmannsthal, the former Alice Astor, will sail for Europe tonight on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic with her husband and their daughters, Romana and Sylvia. Others sailing on the ship for Cherbourg and Southampton include:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28. -- There's one major problem involving Babe Ruth that worries Bill McKechnie, manager of the Braves, now that he has acquired the greatest slugger in baseball history. What position will Ruth play?
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

OTTAWA, Feb. 28. -- To what extent the new grain board will supersede present machinery for crop disposal has not been disclosed. It may take over entire marketing of the crop and abolish options, turning all production into cash grain, and sell wherever the most advantageous price could be secured.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28. -- There's one major problem involving Babe Ruth that worries Bill McKechnie, manager of the Braves, now that he has acquired the greatest slugger in baseball history. What position will Ruth play?
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

OTTAWA, Feb. 28. -- To what extent the new grain board will supersede present machinery for crop disposal has not been disclosed. It may take over entire marketing of the crop and abolish options, turning all production into cash grain, and sell wherever the most advantageous price could be secured.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine took issue yesterday with Dean Charles K. Burdick of the Cornell Law School, a member of the Law Revision Committee, on the proposed public-enemy laws.
HELSINGFORS, Feb. 28. -- Finland inaugurated today a nationwide festival to last four days in celebration of the first centenary of the first edition of the Kalevala, Finland's famous national epic.

Only one seeded player remained in the running for the title at the conclusion of yesterday's quarterfinal matches in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B singles championship at the Harvard Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A group of Senators acting for the Senate Finance Committee virtually dared the House today to pass a measure repealing the income tax publicity provisions of the Revenue Act. They warned a subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee that if this were done, the Senate would replace the provisions with the original La Follette amendment to the Revenue Act.

BOSTON, March 1 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Sales of some ten million pounds of wool are fair to predict for the transactions of the current week, taking the first four days as a basis. Of the total, probably 85 to 90 per cent comprised fine and fine medium territory wools and that mostly of the average to poor descriptions to be used in government contracts.

Pending the receipt of new revenues from the city's relief tax program, the Board of Estimate authorized the issuance of $25,000,000 in temporary certificates of indebtedness yesterday for interim relief financing.

The American Museum of Natural History in cooperation with the Palisades Interstate Park Commission has for eight years been maintaining little museums by the side of trails at Bear Mountain and making the trails themselves open-air halls where the plants, flowers, trees and stones do their own lecturing for the most part.

In the two weeks since his arrival from Chicago, Alfred Manning, 22 years old, of 574 West 130th Street, has committed fifteen hold-ups, including two on Thursday morning of United Cigar stores in the Times Square area, according to an admission he is said to have made to the police yesterday.

The National Broadcasting Company has leased a floor in 711 Fifth Avenue to Prince Matchabelli Perfumery, Inc., now at 160 East Fifty-sixth Street, The avenue building, at the northeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street, formerly housed the lessor's studios.

Abram Chasins, pianist and composer, gave a recital last evening in Carnegie Hall, where he had first appeared three years ago, to the day, and where some of his works !have also been performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony under Toscanini.

Historically, Rossini's "Moses," given at the Hippodrome last night for what the producers believed a "first time in America," certainly the first of current memory, has its roots deep in an antiquity that is far beyond its music's mere 117 years. Here is a story another Moses, in "The Green Pastures" of Broadway, could tell in few words of the spiritual, "Let My People Go."

BATON ROUGE, La., March 1. -The State Senate tonight recessed to permit United States Senator Huey P. Long to reply to an attack made on him on the floor of the Senate by State Senator W. Scott Heywood of Jefferson Davis Parish, vice chairman of the Louisiana Tax Reform Commission.
Properties Sold and Leased in Metropolitan Zone. Several Jersey City housing properties were among the New Jersey conveyances reported yesterday.

Bishop William T. Manning will deliver the sermon tomorrow at the 11 A.M. service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It will be a charge not only to the congregation but to the entire Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York on the observance of Lent, which begins Wednesday.

MADRID, March 1. -- The Cortes adjourned tonight until March 12 so all the Deputies may remain in their home districts to participate in this week's carnival festivities, which are to be revived in Spain this year with all their old pre-republican splendor.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -President Roosevelt bought the Treasury's first six baby bonds, and conferred with Governor General Murphy of the Philippines. He paid tribute to Mr. Murphy's work in the islands.
ATHENS, Saturday, March 2. -- A revolt led by Venizelist army and navy officers broke out at three places in Athens at 6:30 last night. Martial law was declared throughout Greece at 9:20 P.M.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1. -The initial performance of the Junior League revue was given in the Shubert Theatre here tonight. Many dinners preceded it. Major and Mrs. Phelps Montgomery entertained a company of twenty. Among others who entertained were Dr. and Mrs. Orville Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. F. Thatcher Lane and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Armstrong.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Sentiment for early abolition of double liability of holders of national bank stock developed in the House Banking and Currency Committee today at hearings on the administration's proposed Banking Act of 1935, which provides that such liability cease on July 1, 1937.

ST. SAUVEUR, Que., March 1 (Canadian Press). -- Dashing down a precipitous Z-shaped course amid blinding snow, McGill racers today won the downhill race by placing four men in the first seven, to forge to the front in the team standing of the International Intercollegiate Ski Union championships.

Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York, declared yesterday that he was investigating reports from the Consul General in Boston containing "additional information about the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby for which Bruno Richard Hauptmann has been sentenced to death.
The status of the money continued unchanged. Demand for credit was small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

The city's attempt to levy taxes on some properties used exclusively for religious purposes but not hitherto subjected to taxation has been held invalid by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

E. Walter King, 43 years old, who described himself as a former securities salesman, living at 48 West Forty-fifth Street, was discharged by Magistrate August Dreyer in the Tombs Court yesterday when arraigned as a fugitive from Durham, N.C.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Relief Administration figures showed today that the total cost of relief during 1934 was $1,479,339,603, of which the Federal Government put up $1,069,333,771, or 72.3 per cent; State governments, $186,109,391, or 12.6 per cent, and communities, $223,896,441, or 15.1 per cent.

James Butler Jr., president of the James Butler Grocery Company, was the principal witness at a closed hearing held yesterday at 45 Broadway by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, State NRA Compliance Director, on the complaint by the Chain Grocery Stores Executives and Employes Association that the grocery chain has violated the Wholesale and Retail Grocery Code.
ISTANBUL, March 1. -- The fifth Grand National Assembly of Turkey met in Angora today under the presidency of its oldest member and the 386 deputies present took the oath.

George Sheinberg, City College captain, captured three first places in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet with Columbia last night in the C.C.N.Y. pool, but they were the only events won by the Beavers and Columbia took the team honors by a 45-26 margin.

PITTSBURGH, March 1. -- Andrew W. Mellon resumed the offensive this afternoon in his fight to win a $139,000 income tax refund from the government, which seeks to exact from him more than $3,000,000 in extra taxes and penalties for alleged fraud.

The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows only a trifling fractional change in the index number during February. The small fractional advance, however, leaves the March 1 average at the highest since May 1, 1930.

Leading at half time by 16 -- 7, the basketball team of the Barnard School for Boys conquered Collegiate School, 35 -- 23, at Barnard yesterday in non-league competition. Beckmann, left forward for the winners, led the attack with nine points.

Moscow sees the United States about to fall before a Red Revolution. The facts in support of this belief come from America itself. Has not a Congressional committee discovered a widespread propaganda by American Communists? Do not officials of the American Army anal Navy report a secret distribution of tracts and pamphlets among their enlisted men, urging them to revolt and take over the Government?

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Speaking in symbols, there is blood on the Capitol dome which overhangs the rotunda that marks the half-way point between the House and the Senate chambers. It is the sign of growing irritation between the two branches of the National Legislature.

With the State of New York offering $45,025,000 of long-term serial bonds for award on Tuesday, new State and municipal bonds in the amount of $52,495,824 will be up for bids next week. This total will represent the requirements of fifty-three communities.

After months of negotiation a reciprocal trade agreement has been concluded between the United States and Belgium. Reports of it from Washington state that we have granted tariff concessions on forty-seven Belgian products, while Belgium has granted us forty-five concessions in return.

LONDON, March 1. -- Prime Minister MacDonald wrote a surprising letter to David Lloyd George today, asking him to submit details of his "New Deal" plans for the cure of unemployment to the Cabinet for its consideration. The Prime Minister promised in his letter immediate and careful consideration of the proposals.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1. -- Finance Minister Frederico Pinedo has issued a statement explaining that the government's gold revaluation scheme, in connection with its central bank project, will provide a gold reserve of 103 1\2 per cent for Argentina's currency. This will give Argentine the currency highest gold backing in the world.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. have purchased the 29,485 shares of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., held by the Pittsburgh Aviation Industries Corporation. The stock was obtained by the latter company last December, when Transcontinental and Western Air was organized to unify the operations of Transcontinental Air Transport, Inc., and Western Air Express between New York and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -Insistent that the States do their share in providing relief funds, the Federal Relief Administration today informed Minnesota, Idaho and Washington that their March allotments would be held up until they provide the sums demanded.
The Metropolitan Museum of Artresumes its free orchestra concertstonight with a program from Bach,Beethoven, Brahms, Wagner, Debussy and Dukas.

BERLIN, March 1. -- Speeches, blaring bands and yet more speeches roared out in a mighty "welcome home" of the Saar throughout Germany today and nightfall saw the trail of festivities illumined by the flare of countless torchlight parades.

The eleventh annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will get under way on Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Professor Frederic M. Thrasher of the School of Education of New York University will preside at the opening session.

DETROIT, March 1. -- The National Council of United Automobile Workers issued a call today for a vote among the 176 local unions of the American Federation of Labor in the automobile industry to ascertain whether or not there was any sentiment for a strike.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1. -More than 300 persons, members of the Committee of One Hundred of Miami Beach and their guests, today joined in the annual stag picnic and outing of the committee on Cocolobo Cay, island rendezvous thirty miles down the coast, years ago the haunt of Black Caesar, notorious Negro pirate chief, and in later years home of the smart Cocolobo Cay Club.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Governor Lehman reported "progress" tonight in his conferences with Democratic leaders to achieve a reapportionment of Congressional and legislative districts. The statement was made as the leaders departed from Albany.

PARIS, March 1. -- Premier PierreEtienne Flandin gave Parliament and the country a vigorous warning today that, while he continues to struggle with the difficulties of France's economic position, he is also going to govern energetically and without fear.

In reply to the "inside" cloak and ladies' garment manufacturers who have announced that they will not renew the labor agreement expiring on June 1, the board of directors of the Joint Board of the Cloakmakers Unions, affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, voted a defense fund of $500,000 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -Cash income from the sale of farm products during January was estimated today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to have totaled $428,000,000. This compared with, S435,000,000 in December and $425,000,000 in January, 1934.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Paul P. Foster, librarian of The Philadelphia Inquirer, writing in the March number of Wilson Bulletin for Librarians, urges public libraries throughout the country to undertake the collecting and indexing of newspaper articles on local history.

The application of Angelo Conti, naval architect, for a Federal loan to finance the construction of five freight ships for the intercoastal trade, has been withdrawn. The Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce made the announcement in a brief statement at Washington, to which Mr. Conti added his personal comment at his office here, 11 Broadway.

With the international sailing dinghy match arranged, the general committee of the North America Dinghy Association met at the Princeton Club yesterday to consider proposed changes in the rules for Class B boats. They will be the craft used in the match.

Harlem's spectacular Negro "Messiah," Major M. J. Divine, deified by adulant and trustful thousands, proved yesterday afternoon to be merely a mortal unprotected by celestial grace against the ire of an earthly court.

MOSCOW, March 1. -- Keeping up his fine work in the international chess masters tournament at the Museum Beaux Arts, Mischa Botwinnik, young Soviet champion, gained another victory in the eleventh round today. Again his opponent was a Russian, V. Ragosin, who was unable to make headway against his countryman.

The main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was thronged last night for the second and last in the Winter Series of Sutton Dinner Dances. These entertainments, which will be continued next season, are given to raise funds for the maintenance of the Sutton Playground, a recreational centre for children of the upper East Side.

H. G. Wells sailed from Southampton yesterday aboard the Bremen and will arrive here on Tuesday. He will make a "formal study of the New Deal" for Collier's Weekly, and appointments are being arranged in New York and Washington.

MIAMI BEACH. Fla., March 1. -The business of whipping the Giants into shape for their 1935 pennant quest took on an even more serious aspect today when members of the second squad trooped into camp to raise the total of players under Manager Bill Terry's command to almost forty.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 1. -- Miss Johanna Long, 73 years old, and her sister, Miss Catherine Long, 86, retired Philadelphia school teachers, were found dead of carbon monoxide gas poisoning and exposure in their home at 16 Mason Terrace here this afternoon by Mary Flanagan, 12-year-old daughter of a neighbor.

NANKING, China, March 1. -- The United States Legation has notified the authorities of Kansu and Shensi Provinces that the interests of Americans must be protected during the present Communist threat and the Chinese authorities concerned have acknowledged the communication and promised to take the necessary steps.

CHURCHILL, Man., March 1 (Canadian Press). -- A young camera-carrying adventurer, laid up at Baker Lake, N.W.T., after two years in the Arctic country, today contemplated a long journey home to his parents at Grand Rapids, Mich.

SAARBRUECKEN, March 1. -Adolf Hitler, amid such storms of cheering as even he has seldom heard, welcomed the Saar back to Germany today after fifteen years of foreign control. In a speech this evening he termed the day happy "not only for Germany but for all Europe."
MOSCOW, March 1. -- The appointment of Lazar M. Kaganovitch as Commissar for Transportation means that the Soviet Government is determined to solve the railroad problem -- at long last.
May I comment on several points which appeared in the letter of W. H. Matthews, Director Department of Family Welfare, Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor?

Although the run-up in the stocks of mining enterprises was accompanied yesterday by renewed discussion of the possibility of inflation of the currency, Wall Street seemed not to be particularly interested. Most tape-watchers were inclined to look upon the mild boom in the metal shares as merely a reflection of the hope that rising prices for gold and silver will mean larger profits in the ordinary course of business.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- James J. (Boss) McLaughlin, gambler and politician, and thirty-nine others were named today in a blanket indictment charging them with conspiracy to dispose of bonds and securities stolen in the $237,000 mail robbery which took place at Clark and Adams Streets on Dec. 6, 1932.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A compromise proposal on relief wages, reported to have originated with President Roosevelt and promising payment of "prevailing" scales on projects that come in direct competition with private industry, was circulated today at the Capitol among a limited group of Senators.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- With physicians and close friends shaking their heads over the serious condition of Oliver Wendell Holmes, former justice of the Supreme Court, he tonight characteristically rendered a dissenting opinion.
HAVANA, March 1. -- While radical student and labor leaders continued attempts today to provoke a general strike, government officials appeared optimistic over the prospect of avoiding it.
LONDON, March 1. -- King Prajadhipok is expected to communicate his abdication to the Siamese Legation in London within the next three days.

Publishing last week its yearly estimate on Great Britain's foreign trade, during the preceding twelvemonth, the British Board of Trade computed for 1934 a deficit on all accounts of 1,000,000. The "visible debits," meaning the excess of merchandise and silver imports over exports, were almost balanced by the estimated "invisible credits" -- meaning income from short loans and investments abroad, plus revenue from abroad earned by British shipping and other services.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 1 (AP). -- Solicitor Roland Pruett of Wadesboro today began a personal investigation into the mysterious death of Mrs. H. Bradley Davidson Jr., 22-year-old heiress of the late E. M. Statler, hotel magnate, declaring he was not satisfied with the evidence.

CINCINNATI, March 1. -- Everett Reese, whose work in rehabilitation of delinquent boys brought him national recognition, committed suicide today on his farm at Shandon, near Hamilton, Ohio. He was 77 years old.

Speedy repeal of the city income tax of 15 per cent of amounts paid here as Federal income tax was forecast by a majority of members of the Board of Estimate yesterday, when they extended the effective date of the measure from March 15 to June 1.

GREAT authors with shadowy backgrounds are dangerous biographical subjects for a number of reasons, one of the most important of which is that the greater they are the more awed their biographers are likely to be. For just as a bank clerk adores a millionaire and a child loves a champion, the essayist saves his profoundest admiration for Montaigne, and the dramatist saves his for Shakespeare.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 (AP). -- A young Swiss school teacher and his sweetheart leaped to their deaths from an airplane today, apparently to escape possible disgrace growing out of his alleged misuse of school funds.

Net earnings of $2,129,896 in 1934 were reported yesterday by the Diamond Match Company. This sum was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.76 a share earned on 700,000 common shares. It compared with $2,054,510, or $1.58 a share, giving effect to participating provisions of the preferred stock in 1933.

Reversing the trend of the last few days, United States Government bonds rallied briskly yesterday under the impetus of heavy buying, closing up 12-32 to down 2-32 point on the Stock Exchange. Total transactions in long-term government issues reached $6,045,300, or nearly half of the total trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange.

BERLIN, March 1. -- The speech of Dr. Julius Lippert, National Socialist Commissar for Berlin, before the American Chamber of Commerce, asserting that economically Jews had equal rights in Germany, has aroused the greatest attention among German Jews.

A ten-year-old world's record was shattered when Ted Ellison, De Witt Clinton sprint star, was clocked in 22.2 seconds for the 220-yard dash at the Columbia University interscholastic indoor track and field meet last night at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- Miss Marion Miley, Kentucky titleholder, and Miss Jean Bauer, Providence star, the outstanding players in women's golf in the South this season, today advanced to the final of the South Atlantic championship.

Representatives of approximately 100 members of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms met yesterday afternoon to consider the effect on their business of the restrictions upon brokerage wire systems imposed by the proposed code of fair competition for the communications companies.

The General Electric Company had a net profit in 1934 of $17,151,000. After all prior deductions it was equal to 59 cents a share on 28,845,927 no-par shares of stock, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday, and compared with $10,854,682, or 38 cents a share, in 1933.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1. -Two Harvard players, Germaine Gilder and F. H. Glidden; Baldwin Terry of Yale and Sheldon Stephens of Princeton reached the semifinals in the intercollegiate squash racquets tournament today.

MOSCOW, March 1 (AP). -- The official newspaper Pravda, in a dispatch from its New York correspondent, said the Communist party's increasing prestige and popularity in the United States had placed it in a position where it was not necessary to try to assume the initiative in a number of ripening class struggles.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

LIVINGSTONE, Northern Rhodesia, March 1. -- Lady Young, wife of the Governor of Northern Rhodesia, and her physician were lost in an African jungle tonight many hours after their airplane had been forced down.

VIENNA, March 1. -- All Vienna is tense in expectation of revelations at the trial of Dr. Anton Rintelen, former Austrian Minister to Rome, beginning tomorrow, of something of the background of the Nazi attempt to seize power on July 25 which resulted in the murder of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss.

LA GRANGE, Ga., March 1 (AP). -Organized labor served notice of a nation-wide fight on a French system of speeding up textile mill work today as six mills here ran with reduced crews due to a walkout in protest against the system.

TORONTO, March 1 (AP) -- Mayor James Simpson, faced with emphatic warning that Toronto police would strike tomorrow at midnight unless their grievances were adjusted, moved tonight to prevent paralysis of the city's police service.

TRENTON, March 1. -- Coincident with the receipt by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of a message from the Federal Emergency Relief Administration that funds will be made available for only the first fifteen days of this month unless New Jersey supplied $2,000,000 a month thereafter, the new administrative council of the State Emergency Relief Administration organized at the Capitol today.

BRUSSELS, March 1. -- News of the signing of a Belgo-American commercial agreement has been received here with satisfaction. A concession is understood to have been made to Belgium in duties on automobile parts imported by American firms in Belgium, enabling the great American assembling and fitting works at Antwerp to continue.

Approximately 3,300 applications for admission to the Citizens Military Training Camps of the Second Corps Area of the United States Army this Summer were received at C.M.T.C. headquarters at Governors Island yesterday, the first day of enrolment. The applications came from New York State, New Jersey and Delaware, the States in the area.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Reports of Japanese plans for giving financial aid to China were discussed at a long conference today by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, and William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Taking $113 in cash from a trouser pocket, President Roosevelt bought at the White House this morning six of the Treasury's new "baby bonds," one for himself and one for each of his five grandchildren. He received 50 cents in change.

The ever colorful Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships, always a high spot in any year, will present the picked varsity athletes from twenty-eight colleges at Madison Square Garden tonight in the wild scramble for the eleven individual titles and the even more important team crown.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., March 1. -This village had commercial banking facilities today for the first time since January, 1933, when the County Trust Company of White Plains opened at 8:30 A.M. a branch in the $250,000 modern building once occupied by the First National Bank in Mamaroneck, now in liquidation.
After visiting the various museums of the city, it is noticeable that the collections of Spanish colonial culture are not as complete as those of other branches of antiquity.

THE indoor intercollegiates are on tap and this is a track and field meet just a bit out of the ordinary run. "In the first place, Glenn Cunningham and Bill Bonthron will not toe the mark in a feature race. Galloping Glenn will not be there at all, and if Bounding Bill shows up, it will be in a seat somewhere along the sideline.

The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston reported yesterday for 1934 a net income of $5,187,790 after taxes, charges and depreciation, equivalent to $9.70 a share on 535,875 shares of $100-par capital stock, comparing with $5,365,671, or $10.03 a share, for 1933.

A plan to turn the Manhattan Congregational Church, Broadway at Seventy-sixth Street, into a movingpicture theatre, with an adjoining cafe where a bar would be installed and liquor sold, was outlined yesterday to Judge John C. Knox in the Federal court.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., March 1. -- The aerial fighting forces of the United States Army were put under the command of a single leader today as the General Headquarters Air Force moved into this huge air station, situated within easy striking distance of New England, the Florida Coast or New Orleans.

It remained for the directors of the Madison Square Boys Club to embark on an archaeological quest which the scientists have strangely neglected. This is nothing less than an inquiry into the contents of the average boys' pockets.

KANSAS CITY, March 1 (AP). -Midwesterners who thought that nature had given them a full round of experience in the last year or two, what with floods, blizzards, insect pests, dust storms, tornadoes and drought, found today that the elements had another trick in their repertory when four States were shaken by an earthquake.

Lou Ambers can go the championship distance and he can take a punch. The Herkimer Hurricane demonstrated this last night at Madison Square Garden as he advanced another step on the path he hopes will lead to the lightweight championship.

The legislative program contemplated by the La Guardia administration, in its efforts to bring about the unification of all rapid transit lines, would eliminate from the existing law the requirement that a valuation be made of all physical properties, leasehold rights and contract values associated with the problem, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Governor General Frank Murphy's work in the Philippines was highly commended by President Roosevelt today after he had received a personal report from Mr. Murphy, who came here on leave from his duties at Manila.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous decision yesterday, upheld the 554-page, 134,000-word decision of former Surrogate John P. O'Brien declaring Charlotte Fixel Erlanger to be the common law wife and surviving widow of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical producer.

It is an advantage to have the terms of the proposed purchase of the B.M.T. rapid transit lines by the city subjected to impartial analysis at the hands of Mr. HAROLD RIEGELMAN of the Citizens Budget Commission. Over the radio last night he explained that when the company's 293 miles of track is added to the city's own independent subway, unification will be a little more than 50 per cent complete.

The New York University women's basketball team withstood a fourth-quarter rally to defeat the William and Mary College squad, 21 to 17, yesterday on the School of Education gymnasium court before a large crowd. This was the seventh victory in as many starts for the Violet team.

The New York Athletic Club's polo team will take the Squadron A Challenge Cup, which goes with the championship in the Metropolitan League, tonight in the feature of the games to the played at the Squadron A Armory. The Athletic Club has already won the cup and is making its last appearance in league competition tonight, facing the strong Winged Foot trio organized by Arthur Borden.

The directors of the North American Company declared yesterday dividends of 75 cents a share on the preferred stock and 25 cents on the common, payable on April 1, the same as three months ago. Dividends had been 12 cents in cash and 1 per cent in common stock on the common quarterly.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Receipts of hogs here are the smallest on record for this season of the year. Arrivals of 343,000 head in February were below those in any previous year. The trade expects receipts to continue light, but because of the high prices and the resistance shown by consumers some smaller packers are said to have threatened to cease hog-killing operations until conditions improve.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A move to break the legislative stalemate in Congress was made today by House leaders, with a decision to open hearings Monday on the twenty-five bonus bills pending before the Ways and Means Committee

George W. Russell, Irish poet and ardent advocate of the rural way of life, who signs his works "AE," sailed yesterday for home on the Aurania of the Cunard White Star Line, after spending two months in this country. He spent much of his time here visiting his old friend, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture.

ALBANY, March 1. -- A bill which would prevent any increase in the five-cent fare in New York City, even on municipally operated lines, was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Moran, Brooklyn Democrat.

It is not surprising that in making any report on the New York debut of the new American Ballet last night at the Adelphi Theatre, it should be necessary to temper the wind somewhat to the shorn lamb. The surprising thing is that not nearly so much tempering is called for as might reasonably have been expected.

LONDON, March 1. -- A new youth movement, non-militaristic but social, is to be inaugurated in Great Britain as "a permanent and living memorial of the King's silver jubilee year." The Prince of Wales used this phrase today when revealing to a vast audience of Mayors and civic authorities assembled at St. James's Palace his plan for one great national thanks offering for his father's twenty-five year reign.
TRENTON, March 1. -- Two thousand delegates participated here today in a State-wide conference called by Governor Harold G. Hoffman to lay the foundation for a major offensive against crime.

Athletic-Hamilton Club and Milton Baron of the City A.C., the two seeded players who saw action last night as the national squash tennis championship got under way at the Columbia University Club, came through their first-round matches with victories in straight games.

The professionals' championship -- one of golf's longest and most difficult grinds -- will admit sixty-four players instead of the customary thirty-two to match play this year. The first two rounds of match play will be reduced from thirty-six to eighteen holes.
Restoration of salaries of policemen and firemen to 1932 levels moved forward a step yesterday when the Board of Aldermen voted to ask Mayor La Guardia to obtain State legislation toward that end.

PARIS, March 1. -- As a result of a singularly incoherent debate in the Chamber of Deputies today the French woman suffrage movement won what appears on the face of it a smashing victory. At the same time Parliament's final word remains to be given.

PARIS, March 1. -- Indications that the Polish inventor Jan Dunikowski has invented an improved method of extracting gold from "dirt" were given today by an expert chemist, Albert Bonn, who recently at San Remo conducted controlled experiments with M. Dunikowski's "Z rays."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 1. -- On the verge of disaster at 1 -- 5 in the third set, Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France staged a remarkable rally to take six games and defeat Miss Jane Sharp, the American national indoor champion, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, in the semi-final of the Bermuda tennis champinships today.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, at a meeting yesterday in the headquarters of the council, 105 East Twenty-second Street, adopted resolutions opposing the resolution offered by Senator William E. Borah for an investigation of the religious situation in Mexico.

SHANGHAI, March 1. -- "If China decides on economic and political cooperation with Japan, there will be no disposition on the part of Japan to bar the United States and Europe from sharing the prosperity certain to follow large-scale development," declared Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, chief of the Japanese general staff in Manchukuo, in an exclusive interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Some time next season, under the patronage of Delos Chappell, a local boy will come theatrically home. William Bonney of Brooklyn, who made good in the Southwest under the name of Billy the Kid, is the hero -- or at least the principal character -- of a play by Edwin Corle....

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Cardinal Dougherty announced today in his Lenten pastoral that his ban on movie theatres in the Philadelphia Archdiocese would remain "until they are transformed." He declared the ban last May prior to his departure for Rome.

Vernon Gomez, star of the Yankees' hurling staff and leading pitcher in the American League last year, arrived home on the White Star liner Majestic yesterday at the conclusion of his world tour and immediately became a determined hold-out.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Contracts covering the 1935 acreage control program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration were mailed today to cotton producers in nineteen States who signed contracts in 1934.
ALBANY, March 1. -- The State Banking Department announced today the following authorizations:

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP). -Agents of the Federal Division of Investigation today announced the arrest of five men in connection with a reported widespread plot to swindle banks of cash and securities.

An exhibition devoted to Italian Renaissance sculpture opens with a private view this afternoon at the A. S. Drey Galleries, 680 Fifth Avenue. Beginning Monday and until March 20 the exhibition may be visited by the public. It is being held for the benefit of the Girls' Branch, Public Schools Athletic League of the City of New York.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Proper housing for families of low income cannot be supplied on a self-liquidating basis and government subsidy appears to be the inevitable and feasible means of rebuilding slum areas, Charles F. Palmer of Atlanta, Ga., told the members of the New York Building Congress at their luncheon meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, March 1. -- Speaking to the Association of American Correspondents here today, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler asserted that labor unions in the United States were trying to usurp the place held by big business before the arrival of the New Deal.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers.

Miss Edna V. O'Brien, 48 years old, who formerly was an investment adviser to many prominent women, with an office at 551 Fifth Avenue and an elaborate home, Rosedale, in Tarrytown, was found guilty by a General Sessions jury of grand larceny in the first degree at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
The city's basic tax rate for 1935 was fixed by the Board of Aldermen yesterday at $2.71 on each $100 of assessed valuation, an increase of fifteen points over the 1934 base rate.

At the signing of the National Industrial Recovery Act on June 16, 1933, President Roosevelt said: "This is not a law to foment discord and it will not be executed as such. This is a time for mutual confidence and help, and we can safely rely on the sense of fair play among all Americans."

TOKYO, March 1. -- Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, today stated that Shanghai reports that concrete measures for Japanese economic cooperation with China were being discussed were "entirely groundless."

Testimony purporting to connect Mrs. Wilma E. Gould's earlier life with the night life of Chicago was introduced yesterday by the defendants in her $500,000 conspiracy suit, after Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer had reserved decision on the defense motion to dismiss the suit.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered that registration of the following securities on the New York Stock Exchange be made effective:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 1. -- Rutgers University awards of bronze medals and citations were presented tonight to Dean Walter T. Marvin and Professor Thomas J. Headlee at the annual dinner in the gymnasium by the board of trustees to members of the university faculty.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1. -- The much improved racer St. Moritz, which is owned, trained and ridden by the veteran A. J. (Whitey) Abel, again was a victor at Hialeah Park today, scoring in the featured Fort Dallas Park Purse. The son of St. James won by two lengths, while Billy Bee ran second and Sun Fairplay third

ORLANDO, Fla., March 1. -- When a Brooklyn pitcher steps to the plate on April 16 or thereafter with orders to sacrifice a runner to second base and fails, it won't be because he has lacked instructions and practice.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Harry L. Hopkins, the Federal Relief Administrator, predicted in an address before the Executives Club today that $5,000,000,000 annually of the national income would be required in the near future for unemployment relief and social security costs.
HOUSTON, Texas, March 1 (AP). -Marmara, chestnut gelding, owned by L. J. Marks, was given a clever ride by Jockey Dabson to win the featured fifth race at Epsom Downs today.

Semi-final round brackets were filled yesterday in the national racquets championship on the courts of the Racquet and Tennis Club. Both E. M. Edwards of New York, the defending champion, and H. D. Sheldon of Philadelphia, runner-up the past season, remain in the field in opposite halves of the draw.

Gains occurred yesterday in most commodity futures' markets here. Rubber and silk were the exceptions. Trading was moderately heavy in most markets. On the cash markets, wheat, rye, eggs, lard, tin and cotton advanced, and butter and printcloths declined.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 1 (AP). -- Preliminary to signing a formal decree, Judge W. I. Grubb in United States District Court said today he would annul in its entirety a contract between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Alabama Power Company for the transfer of the utility's transmission lines in North Alabama.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board has allowed the cost mark-up provision of the Retail Lumber Code to lapse without prejudice to submission by the industry of proposals for loss leader limitation provisions or extension of the use of the open price provision, the NRA Administrative Officer, W. A. Harriman, stated today.
Two Broadway stores were held up within an hour early last evening, apparently by the same two men, according to descriptions furnished to the police.

PARIS, March 1. -- Amid mounting nervousness, the pound passed another milestone today on its downward path, closing at 72.83 francs, against yesterday's 73. However, the chief sensation of the day was the disassociation of the dollar from the pound.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood of Brooklyn chided Mayor La Guardia yesterday as the possessor of an "ungovernable temper" and an "unbridled tongue" when his wishes, whether right or wrong, are thwarted.
KANSAS CITY, March 1. -- The memory of Notre Dame's immortal "Rock" will be honored by loyal sons scattered from coast to coast on the birthday anniversary of the great football coach next Monday.

If a bank does not receive the proceeds of a fraudulent transaction by its officers, the person defrauded cannot recover damages from it, Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore ruled yesterday in dismissing a suit brought by Louis A. Jaskow against the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Strikes in some key plans making automobile parts and accessories, designed to cripple the assembly lines of the large automobile manufacturers, may be ordered before the end of this month in a test of the American Federation of Labor's strength in the industry, it was indicated today at federation headquarters.
PRAGUE, March 1. -- Czechoslovakia elapped ten officials into jail today as investigation of the arrest of three Germans last night led to the very doors of an alleged espionage ring.

Six subsidiaries of the Atlas Corporation issued yesterday their annual reports for 1934. Each statement contained a list of securities in the company's portfolio on Dec. 31, 1934, and was certified by Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, accountants.

A West Bronx building operation was announced yesterday by brokers who have just sold a large plot in the Riverdale section to a builder. The property consists of sixteen lots on Arlington Avenue, between 252d and 254th Streets, and was sold by the Emer Holding Corporation.
Borough President Harvey is correct in saying that the Budget Commission's statement is "the finest argument for decentralization of the city government."

REIT.T. March 1.--The IoerseIwas inactive but firm today. Heavy lindustrials were quiet. Potashesscored slight gains, Ialichemie rising point. Electricals were firm, iA. E. G. gaining 1/ point. Textilesiwere mixed, with a tendency!to weakness.

After several hours of inactive trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday and ended with gains of 5 to 10 points. A record price for gold in London, weakness in sterling and the sharpest rise in cotton in several months caused further inflation talk and turned an early slight loss into a 10-point improvement.

New Yorkers bought $350,000 of the United States Government's "baby bonds" yesterday at branch postoffices as the nation-wide sale was begun. The showing was considered favorable because yesterday was rent day for most persons and the day for paying February's accumulated bills.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Renewed efforts to effect a compromise of the Work Relief Bill were decided upon tonight by Democratic supporters of the McCarran "prevailing wage" amendment.

UFFALO, N. Y., March / CzP).-Joe McCarthy, manager of the NewYork Yankees, departed in highspirits tonight for the team's training camp at St. Petersburg, Fla.,but he was still chary about disCussing the deal which sent BabeRuth to the Boston Braves."

There was a gathering of the deep-sea fishing clans in this city Thursday night. The occasion for the reunion was the first annual anglers' dinner of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, held in the Empire Room of the Hotel Lexington.

Myron Mittleman, 16-year-old Brooklyn high school boy who has been collecting snakes and reptiles since he was 11 years old, was bitten shortly after midnight last night by a pet Gila monster, a twofoot poisonous lizard, while he was attempting to feed it forcibly in the kitchen of his home at 650 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.
ALBANY, March 1. -- Governor Lehman left tonight for a weekend visit in Washington, where it is likely he will meet with President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, March 1. -- A general overhauling of the law affecting time off for prisoners for good behavior, to provide a maximum reduction in sentence of ten days a month or four months a year, was recommended today by the law revision commission in a report to Governor Lehman, which he in turn submitted to the Legislature.

With the exception of one rainy day, when volume fell behind last year, local retail trade gave a fairly good account of itself during the week. Activity was largely concentrated on the main floors, but departmental promotions evoked considerable response.

The agreement establishing peace between the Building Service Employes International Union and building owners in the garment, fur and millinery area was signed at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the office of Mayor La Guardia by representatives of the union and the building owners.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that departmental charges will be preferred against Captain George M. Renselaer, in charge of the Oak Street station, in connection with the destruction of evidence in the case of Henry Miro, an employe of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, former head of the policy racket.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Pledging a "vigorous" administration, Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson assumed office today as chairman of the American Red Cross, a post to which he was appointed two weeks ago by President Roosevelt.

The Mack committee investigating public utilities turned its spotlight yesterday on Westchester County and found write-ups in valuation of property, and questionable land deals, coupled with high rates.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Bearish sentiment predominated in grains on the Board of Trade early today, wheat and corn each easing about 3/4 cent a bushel from Thursday's finish. Later, however, outside interest increased on the buying side of wheat and the market rallied, led by the May, which closed at the top at a net gain of 1/2 cent, as the new crop months declined 1/8 to 1/4 cent.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1. -Mrs. Isaac Starr and Mrs. Samuel P. Rotan of Philadelphia were honored by Wilson Prichett today at a tea on the roof garden of Brazilian Court. Other guests included:

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Repeal of the "pink slip" income publicity clause of the Revenue Act of 1934, contained in Section 55b, will be proposed to the House by Thursday, Democratic leaders decided today.

LONDON, March 1. -- Charles B. Cochran, one of London's leading producers, made a dramatic move today in his dispute with British Equity, announcing that he had called off plans on six new productions

James Madison and Manual Training High Schools created a triple deadlock with New Utrecht for first place in the Brooklyn P.S. A.L. basketball championship race by recording victories yesterday. Madison crushed Boys High, 40 -- 20, on the latter's court and Manual halted Brooklyn Tech, 35 -- 25, on the former's floor.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A provision to give President Roosevelt authority to increase the strength of the army from 118,500 to 165,000 men was eliminated by the Senate Appropriations Committee today in reporting to the Senate the $375,074,654 Army Appropriation Bill.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP). -A House Military subcommittee was urged today by army and navy spokesmen to act against an increasing flow of propaganda seeking to enlist American soldiers and sailors in the ranks of communism.
Collection of the 2 per cent city sales tax started yesterday. Only a few returns were received, however, most retailers apparently having decided to wait until March 30, the final day for payments.

Henry C. Blackiston has resigned as director of Furness, Withy Co. in the United States and Canada, effective April 30, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Blackiston will be succeeded by Henry Smurthwaite, who has been a London director of the Furness intefests since 1920.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The Lehman administration bill to create a State system of unemployment insurance was amended today to put it in line with the Washington legislation on national unemployment insurance.

Massing the same strength in the distance events which it hopes will gain the I.C.A.A.A.A. title tonight, Manhattan College ran off with the junior varsity team honors in the first junior intercollegiate track and field championships yesterday afternoon at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

United States Government bonds in the investment market and mining shares in the speculative market displayed activity and strength yesterday, but otherwise the trading conformed to the familiar dull pattern. The price status of agricultural commodities did not change appreciably.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- With the first quarterly instalment of Federal income taxes due on March 15, the Internal Revenue Bureau is making a drive to remind taxpayers that they will be subject to penalties if they do not make returns and to check up on those suspected of delinquency.

ALBANY, March 1. -- A detailed study of the effect of the New Deal on the nation has been started by a group of New York Republicans as the basis for framing party policy in opposition to the Roosevelt administration, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, revealed today.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., March 1. -- Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis today defeated Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia for the New York State squash racquets championship, 15 -- 6, 16 -- 13, 11 -- 15, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 10, thereby depriving the defending titleholder of her laurels and climaxing a week of brilliant play at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

ATLANTA, March I (P).--Thedeal that sent Babe Ruth to theBoston Braves is "the finest thingthat could happen to baseball, especially the National League," saidColonel Tillinghast L. Huston, theman who put a Yankee uniform onthe Babe, today.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, March 1. -- The Saar became German again today amid a frenzy of enthusiasm rarely seen even in the old Germany, amid a forest of flags and in streets decorated with greenery, and to the accompaniment of day-long cheering such as one might expect would leave every Saarlander voiceless for a week.

LONDON, March 1. -- The stock markets here were generally cheerful today with business progressing again. The greatest activity was in the gold mine shares as the result of a further depreciation of sterling and a rise in the price of gold to a new high record at 145s 1d an ounce.

As a compromise measure to appease the advocates of a four-mile distance, the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. varsity cross-country championship run was reduced from six miles to five last night. The new rule will go in effect this year. This was decided at the convention of the I.C.A.A.A.A. at the Columbia University Club.

OTTAWA, March 1. -- A steadily growing tide of currency reform and currency inflation sentiment in Canada washed over into the Dominion Parliament this week when Ian MacKenzie, a Liberal and a former ex-Minister, proposed a $430,000,000 enlargement of the currency to relieve unemployment.

BEGINNING in 1916 and closing in 1931, Miss Strobel's new novel covers an exceptionally interesting period of the world's history. But though the period is interesting, the book is dull. It unfolds at what seems to the reader very great length the experiences of the Amblers, apparently intended as a typical American family, and especially of Isobel, the prettier of the two Ambler sisters.

LONDON, -- It is not long since a shrewd American observer of the course of European affairs remarked to me: "You need not insist to me on the necessity for a good understanding between England and France, for I have long since remarked that when England and France are agreed the world advances and that when they differ no progress is made."
Five companies whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they would submit to stockholders plans for options and bonuses at their meetings this month.
BOSTON, March 1. -- Business in New England in the past week did not respond to the extent expected as a result of the removal of the uncertainty caused by the gold-clause cases.

TORONTO, Ont., March 2. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs swamped the New York Americans, 6 -- 0, in a quiet and orderly National Hockey League game tonight. The defeat practically ruined the New York team's final hopes of gaining a play-off berth. A crowd of 10,500 watched the uninteresting contest.

Beside Hell Gate two giant steel towers have risen in recent months. Visible for miles in their red-lead coats, lacking only their ornamental tops to be complete, they stand as signs that the Triborough Bridge is growing steadily toward reality.
A growing interest in the sciences as fields of specialization was revealed in the semi-annual survey of the freshman class at Hunter College, according to the responses of 857 of the 1,200 students.

By a planned democracy, says Mr. Holcombe, Professor of Government in Harvard University and author of a previous volume in this same series. "The New Party Politics," those who think it must be an early development do not mean a finished arrangement of governmental forms and practices that has to be established once for all time and thereafter preserved inviolate.

VISITORS who wander through Franklin Institute and its technical museum stand enthralled before three "invisible" murals which were painted by Charles Bittinger and which depict scenes from the life of Ben Franklin. No one would guess what the murals are under ordinary light.
LONDON, March 2. -- Sterling today took one of its heaviest falls since the days following abandonment of the gold standard in 1931.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission by a new rule today prescribed certain conditions under which data need be submitted only as of a date within six months of the date of filing a registration statement.

ATHENS, March 2. -- Details of the naval revolt which terrified the arsenal town of Salamis last night and led to air and sea warfare today amid islands between here and Crete were disclosed tonight. The number of dead and injured, however, was undetermined.

CLINTON, Okla., March 2 (AP). -- Three desperate fugitive, convicts vanished in Northwestern Oklahoma tonight after having seized a doctor as hostage and playing a grim game of hide-and-seek all day with hundreds of posse members guided by an airplane.

UNION CITY, N.J., March 2. -- Under the direction of the Rev. Conrad Eiben, who with a colleague planned the American Passion play a quarter-century ago in a Pittsburgh monastery, the opening performance of the twenty-first season of "Veronica's Veil" will be held in St. Joseph's auditorium here Sunday evening, March 10.

The investigation by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation into a terminal and real estate transaction between the Alleghany Corporation and the Missouri Pacific Railroad, which it controls, is expected in railroad circles to establish precedents to be followed by the Interstate Commerce Commission in the allocation of railroad terminals.

MANY gardeners have come to realize that the most economical method of obtaining a good supply of plants is to raise them from seed. A highly satisfactory aid in such work is a coldframe, which fulfills many useful purposes.

NOW that he has had about fourteen months in which to collect his thoughts, Joseph Verner Reed has written a comic book about his four years as a producer. To some of the people who swirl and flutter through its mad pages "The Curtain Falls" (Harcourt, Brace) may not seem comic.

With the approach of Lent, which begins next Wednesday, many members of society are turning their attention to philanthropic activities, chief among which are the Lenten sewing classes, for which invitations were sent out a few days ago.
The slums must go. Jacob Riis said so thirty-five years ago, and now for the first time in the history of our country practical steps are being taken to wipe out the shame of our cities.

ATHENS, March 2. -- Four rebel-manned Greek warships arrived tonight at Suedia, on the northern coast of Syria. It was not told in messages from Aleppo and Beirut whether the French mandatory authorities had been asked by the Tsaldaris government to arrest the mutineers.
Helen Yorke, a young soprano from Augusta, Me., is to make her local opera debut at the Hippodrome tonight as Musetta in "La Boheme."

YOU look for it vainly in indexes of the "Only Yesterday" type of history, but it is to he surmised that Harry Leon Wilson's best-known tale yet enjoys a life well this side of oblivion. It undergoes reissuings. Abroad you encounter it in the Tauschnitz lists and paper-bound on the railway stalls, alongside "Dodo" and "Bootles' Baby."

Swooping down on the picket lines established by striking employes of the James Butler Grocery Company in front of a Butler store at 385 Sixth Avenue early last evening, the police arrested six en men and women on charges of disorderly conduct.

ATLANTA, Feb. 28. -- What with organizations of every kind, from Save - the - Aryans to Don't - Drop-Banana-Peelings, it is no surprise that at least two others -- the Anti-Carpetbagger Association and the Anti-Scalawag Society -- more or less loomed for a while on the Georgia horizon.

May I point out to Arthur Elliott Sproul and to those who think with him that "simplicity" in writing can be every whit as much an affectation as topheavy ornament? I am quite sure that there are few things that have done more harm to American literature than the everlasting ingemination over here about being "brief and simple."

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, J.H. Wantling took the high-overall honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the Class A competition T.H. Lawrence and D.L. Taylor each had a gross card of 99. The shoot-off went to Lawrence.

THE railroads are down on the government's memorandum pad for early attention. They are suffering from the hard times; they are hurt also by new competition more or less free from public regulation; and since they play a vital part in the American economy, their ill health affects the national welfare.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area maintained a fair pace last week. Main-floor offerings attracted most shoppers' attention, although in some instances good response to departmental offerings, particularly home wares, was noted. Early promotions of women's Spring apparel and accessories met with somewhat broader buying interest.

Floor coverings manufacturers and jobbers as well sought means yesterday of checking the number of auctions held annually in this market, following the sales this week of rug stocks from a Pittsburgh jobber's warehouse. Convinced, after discussions earlier in the week, that no remedy exists in the Carpet and Rug Code, producers turned to the idea of a general agreement by manufacturers to control the time and place of future auctions.

WE had been living six weeks in Tenerife, one of the Canary Islands, before coming upon their greatest thrill. An eighty-volume Spanish encyclopedia was an odd place in which to find it. "One of the peculiarities of Gomera," we read, "is its language without words.

THERE are prospects of an active season of soaring activity. Lieut. Commander Ralph S. Barnaby, newly elected president of the Soaring Society of America, is now busily at work with gliders in training activities for the navy at Pensacola.

AMONG the organizations fighting what is considered an excessive gasoline tax and diversion in New York is the Automobile Merchants Association, which announced last week that it was now "taking action to eliminate exemptions from the State's emergency gasoline tax."

LONDON. THE future government of India is one of the principal affairs occupying the attention of Parliament in the present session. Our publishers have seen to it that there shall be no lack of material for the guidance of British public opinion on this subject.

Unleashing a burst of speed on the last lap, Charles (Chuck) Hornbostel, Indiana University graduate student, captured the Kosciuszko 600-Yard Special Invitation run at the annual Polish Falcons track and field games at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Radoye Yankovitch, Consul General of Yugoslavia in New York, denied categorically yesterday reports of internal strife, communism or dissatisfaction in his country. M. Yankovitch, who has just returned from an extended visit to Yugoslavia, deplored certain reports of disorders, especially since the assassination of King Alexander at Marseilles.

TRENTON, March 2. -- An unexpected resolution urging legislation to establish birth-control clinics in areas of congested population interrupted Governor Harold G. Hoffman's carefully planned crime conference here today as it was on the verge of adjournment.

FROM the moment that Detective Larose of Scotland Yard arrives at Southdown Court to investigate the murder there of Hector Dane all circumstances are leagued against him to prevent a successful solution of the crime. One of the fourteen house guests, Dane, a thoroughly objectionable person and false friend of Sir James, recently married young owner of the court, had been mortally sapped by a poker in the baronet's billiard room.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Richard Jervis, for the last twenty years chief of the White House Secret Service detail and a familiar figure with Presidents on their tours, was succeeded today by Colonel Edward W. Starling, for many years assistant chief.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the slowest for a Saturday in four months. The turnover of 279,000 shares compared with 536,000 shares on the previous Saturday. Wall Street offered the usual comment that the market's "undertone was firm," which is the faintest of praise.

ENGLAND has a glass house, or rather a glass hotel -- a new architectural experiment. The building is in the village of Doncaster, not far from London, and, according to the designers, demonstrates the possibilities of glass as a construction material.

ARTHUR HOPKINS, producer of "Redemption," "Anna Christie," "The Hairy Ape," "The Old Soak," "What Price Glory?" "Machinal," "Paris Bound" and a score of other dramatic successes, turns his hand to a prose interpretation of humanity's achievements and failures.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- Two guards of the Essex County House of Detention were beaten at 1:30 o'clock this morning when a dozen young men inmates attempted to escape. The prisoners were quickly subdued by police reserves and guards from the Essex County Jail across the street.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 2. -- R.J. Jowsey, president of God's Lake Gold Mines, Ltd., said in his annual report for 1934 that the first unit of a mill of 150 tons daily capacity was being taken to the camp over the Winter road and would be erected next Summer and be ready for production by next Fall.

The estate of Mrs. Almy Gallatin Pell, a descendant of an early Colonial family, was left in trust to members of her immediate family, according to her will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court. The estate was valued formally at "more than $20,000."

AFTER all the many volumes filled with the writings of George Washington and all the shelves upon shelves of books written about him, there still has remained the opportunity and the need for the unique work that Edward C. Boykin has contributed to the extensive collection of our Washingtoniana.

LONDON, March 2. -- A political intrigue by which the ruling princes of the independent Indian States were persuaded to play the game of Tory die-hards in London was the cause of this week's hitch in the British Government's parliamentary progress toward a new Constitution for India.

Declaring that Washington trends indicate the need for stronger union among business men, Benjamin Schwartz, director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel and associated with several other private and code groups, yesterday called for reorganization and strengthening of trade associations along the lines of "selected and qualified membership."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Two years of President Roosevelt and the New Deal are drawing to a close, and, according to civilized custom, reviews, appraisals and forecasts will appear bountifully in the press and salt the dinner-talk of America and the world.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer entertained tonight with a dinner for a company of sixty-five at Sea Side Cottage, including their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer, Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams and their guests.

VIENNA, March 1. -- The old prayer "Save me from my friends, I can settle my enemies myself," might well be adopted by the warrior races of Yugoslavia as a national motto but with implications quite other than those usually associated with this prayer.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- The Arena was the scene of a veritable "Night in Vienna" this evening when the Philadelphia Skating Club and the Humane Society, assisted by a committee headed by Miss Katherine King, gave its ice carnival for the benefit of the Volunteer Service Bureau.

Convinced they have discovered a weak point by which they can void the Belgian treaty before Fall, high tariff advocates were jubilant yesterday as they prepared to press a Congressional fight to discredit the reciprocal tariff policy of the administration.

SHANGHAI, March 2. -- The proposed international loan to China is regarded in Shanghai's foreign circles with unconcealed relief, for it is considered such a development would prevent Japan's attaining a dominant position in Chinese markets, which would be certain to follow a purely Japanese advance in China's financial crisis.

After she had been buffeted by howling gales and huge seas all the way across the Atlantic, the Albert Ballin of the Hamburg-American Line arrived last night at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street from the Channel ports, thirty hours late, with 250 passengers.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 2. -- Students from Yale and Princeton and several of the preparatory schools, about eighty in number, were guests tonight at the mid-Winter dance given by the older girls of Rosemary Hall School.
PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- Bail of $25,000 each was set today for three alleged conspirators arrested here in a plot to swindle banks in eastern cities of millions of dollars.
Edward M. Edwards of Philadelphia and Huntington D. Sheldon of New York reached the final round in the national singles racquets championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.

Music-loving Americans may have listened-in for Lily Pons's last word of "La Sonnambula" yesterday, the bright "Ah non giunge" air, with a new understanding of one of the world's rare geniuses of melody. In the theatre, the "happy ending" of the sleep-walker's broken romance carried many curtain calls.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- The combination of better shopping weather and a highly advertised special sale brought a successful conclusion to a somewhat unsatisfactory week in retail trade. The retail turnover for February as a whole was probably about on a level with the same month in 1934 or possibly a little better.

BALTIMORE, March 2 (AP). -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut today approved the petition of the Kelly Springfield Tire Company to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law and appointed Thomas B. Finan of Cumberland, Md., and Edmund L. Burke as temporary trustees.

IN spite of past disillusionments, the dancers are still undefeated in their determination to secure for themselves the advantages of organization which have so obviously accrued to other artists. The newest attempt calls itself the Dance Guild and has quite evidently studied not only the necessities of the field but also the efforts of its predecessors and the successes and failures that have followed them.

BOSTON, March 2. -- The big event of the week here is the annexation of Babe Ruth by the Boston National League Club. The announcement alone verified his amazing popularity. In and out of fandom his transfer from New York and the American League has been discussed for several days, in the main not only with approval but with enthusiasm.

AMONG the provocative contributions to the current (February) number of the American Magazine of Art is the first of three articles by E.M. Benson, in which he discusses and compares forms of art, paying his respects meanwhile to the pigeonholing pedants who have written so much that stands in the way of creative appreciation.

A riveting crew, comprising Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll, officials of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn and business leaders of the borough, will drive the first rivets in the keel of the new cruiser Brooklyn, at the keel-laying ceremonies to be held on Tuesday, March 12, at the navy yard.

Excited movements in foreign exchange obscured routine market developments elsewhere yesterday. Business on the Stock Exchange was at low ebb, in both stocks and bonds, and there was no noteworthy change in the general price position.

Relief, recovery and reform are the announced objectives of the Roosevelt administration. With the intent of insuring to workers a share of recovery and reform, Section 7a (providing for collective bargaining) was inserted in the NIRA two years ago. Last week a Federal judge in Wilmington, Del., handed down a decision striking at the heart of that two-R program for labor.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Vice President's wife acknowledged a bit of jealousy today, until she found out that a bouquet and a tender poem sent to Mr. Garner by a young lady was only a gesture to commemorate Texas Independence Day.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- The establishment of "unemployment reserves" by corporations in behalf of their employes is recommended in a report issued by the committee on industrial relations of the National Metal Trades Association. The report opposes any plan for government controlled unemployment insurance, contending that such legislation has proved unsuccessful in other nations.

ALFRED KREYMBORG, Lewis Mumford and Paul Rosenfeld are planning to issue a new yearbook to be called "Foreground: A Preview of American Literature." It will appear in the Fall of 1936 and will attempt to focus the vital and integrating forces of present-day America.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Open-air concerts such as have become a popular institution in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and St. Louis will be given here next Summer by the National Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Hans Kindler, the conductor, said today.

OMAHA, March 1. -- Whatever change of fortune two years of the New Deal, complicated by a Summer of drought, have brought to the Corn Belt, farm recovery has not been sufficiently advanced or general enough to give farm mortgage creditors carte blanche to press for collection in the normal way through the courts.

THE records show that Gary Cooper is 6 feet 4 inches tall. He attempts to cut that down a bit by stooping when he walks. The fact remains that one -- particularly a one who is just a fraction over 5 feet 9 -- is likely to get a crick in his neck if he attempts to do a standing or a walking interview with Mr. Cooper.

Miss Carolyn Blair heads a group of young women who will act as hostesses and assist in the sale of tickets at the exhibition of Renoir's paintings in behalf of Hope Farm to be held from March 11 to 30 at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Five matches in both the first and second rounds of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association singles championships, Group II, were played on the courts of the City Athletic Club yesterday.
