It must be evident to any intelligent person that the cinema is a superior form of dramatic art and that it makes the legitimate stage seem awkward, unsubtle and outmoded in its methods. I never see a play without realizing how much more satisfactory it would be as a picture.

FOR the first time in their history, perhaps, American school superintendents last week took part of the time of a national convention to consider the American baby. A main session of the department of superintendence of the National Education Association at Atlantic City was devoted to hearing a college president urge the necessity to our civilization of nursery schools for the pre-school child.

If a new dance invades the ballrooms of the city, it probably will be the fault of Alfred E. Smith, former Governor. To the tune of "The Sidewalks of New York," he did it last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Columbia University will open its thirty-sixth Summer session on July 8, it was announced yesterday by Director John J. Coss. The enrolment for the six-week session is expected to exceed that of last year, he said, when the registration reached 10,281, an increase of 10 per cent over 1933.
In what appears to be a major monetary adjustment, the pound sterling and the currencies joined to it in the "sterling group" fell further yesterday to record levels of depreciation.

ROME, Jan. 30, 1935. ILDEBRANDO PIZZETTI'S "Fedra," on Gabriele d'Annunzio's dramatic poem, has been given its first performance in Rome, as the second novelty' of Tullio Serafin's Royal Opera season. It is just twenty years since this work, Pizzetti's first opera, had its memorable baptism at La Scala.

Depressing effects on the Liverpool market of the decline in sterlling kept prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here below Friday's closing level, but a late recovery left the list only unchanged to 3 points lower on the day.

After being a hold-out for less than twenty-four hours, Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, ace of the Yankees' pitching staff, came to terms with the management of the club yesterday, thus leaving Colonel Jacob Ruppert with only one player, Charlie Ruffing, to be signed.
PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Slowly but inevitably France seems to be going from one year to two years of compulsory military service.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The question whether control over false advertising under Federal pure food and drug laws shall be retained with the Federal Trade Commission or transferred to the Agriculture Department's Food and Drug Administration, as proposed in the Copeland bill, was argued today as hearings began on the measure, which urges further government supervision of food, drugs and cosmetics.

One of "popular" opera's largest audiences of the year applauded vociferously last night's second representation at the Hippodrome of Rossini's "Moses" in its revised or Paris version, which had been billed the night before as a first production in America.

New regulations for the annual International Lifeboat Race to be held next Labor Day were adopted yesterday at a meeting of directors of the International Lifeboat Racing Association at the Downtown Athletic Club. The most radical change in the regulations is contained in the provision specifying the type of boat to be used.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., March 2. -- Preliminary to an effort to demonstrate to the general staff of the army and to the nation that the new air command of the general headquarters air force constitutes potentially the most destructive weapon in modern warfare, Brig. Gen. Frank M. Andrews today completed inspection of the ten fast bombing planes that he has ordered on a one-stop flight from Washington to Panama.
PALM BEACH. -- Attention will centre here this week on two large social affairs, one of which is also a charity benefit.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- A disposition developed on the Board of Trade today to do nothing until results disclose more accurately the effects on the grain markets of the advance in gold and silver prices in London and the drop in sterling exchange. Both wheat and corn held within a range of less than one cent a bushel.

The revelations in the Blanshard investigation of the close connection between the game of policy and the bail bond racket, with the statement that the policy racket makes $100,000,000 a year in New York, have served to bring from under cover again the most common form of betting in the city.

Japan is not trying to persuade China to leave the League. Japan is not urging China to dismiss foreign advisers. Japan is not forcing China into an Asiatic bloc in return for financial assistance. That was the content of a statement issued in Tokyo last week by Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman.

WHEN John Strachey's "The Coming Struggle for Power" appeared in this country about two years ago it created a mild sensation. Here was a Communist who not only knew his belles-lettres but, unlike most of his colleagues, seemed to know his economics and his politics, too.

ALBANY, March 2. -- With the 1935 session of the New York State Legislature two months old and ready now for the final drive, Governor Herbert H. Lehman is putting the last touches to his costume and getting his final cues as he prepares to act out his role of a quiet but effective political Simon Legree.
Richard B. Harrison, "De Lawd" of "Green Pastures," missed his first performance yesterday afternoon.

THIS novel goes on for 400 pages. We know what it is all about and what is to be the upshot of it after the first fifty pages. It should find an audience with many wives of husbands immersed, successfully, in business or the professions in New York or Chicago or three or four other big cities.

LAST year the eighty-two inch glass pancake which is to become the mirror of McDonald Observatory's reflecting telescope was cast in Corning, N. Y. After slowly cooling to avoid unequal internal strains, which would surely have resulted in a rupture, the pancake was sent last October to Cleveland, Ohio.

PARIS, March 2. -- The heavy fall in the pound sterling depressed the Bourse today. Business, however was restricted to a minimum and changes were slight. Publication of the end-of-February positions-showing an increase in the short and a decrease in the long accounts also contributed to the pessimism.

Justice Rowland Davis of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn signed an order yesterday directing Christian Loos, a taxpayer, to appear tomorrow to show cause why there should not be an immediate argument of the city's appeal from a recent ruling by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood enjoining the Green Bus Lines, Inc., from operating on six routes in central Queens.

THE "Zephyr" of the Burlington Railway, the Union Pacific's aluminum vehicle and the dozen or more high-speed, Diesel-powered "neo-trains" now being built for the railways in various parts of the country are creating a spectacular amount of interest.

THE conquest of the North Pole." by J. Gordon Hayes, assumes that no explorer has reached the North Pole -- the author rules Peary out of the honor. The title is a misnomer in the sense that a considerable number of the adventurers he writes about did not have the Pole as their objective.

ORLAN'DO, Fla., March 2. -- Competition is the best conditioner of baseball players, a fact well known to the astute Charles Dillon Stengel, better known as Casey. Spring training, as he is keenly aware, can be very much of a routine matter to a fellow sure of his position as a regular.

SENSITIVE and scrupulous in its handling of a melodramatic theme, "Follow the Furies" is the story of a girl who was self-deceived and self-destroyed. Without taking sides, or completely defining her own viewpoint, Miss Chilton raises some difficult ethical questions in this very unusual novel.

ATHENS, March 2. -- Five Greek warships held by revolutionaries were bombarded by nine government planes today near the Island of Hydra. The planes dropped sixteen fifty-four-pound bombs aboard the cruiser Averoff, badly damaging that ship.
Two church groups are protesting against the proposed manoeuvres of the United States fleet in the Pacific next May, which they consider "threaten world peace."
Samuel Goldwyn, who helped make Hollywood what it is today, has a one-word answer for the perennial question, What's wrong with Hollywood?

With shelves cleared of Winter goods for the most part, retailers are now concentrating on new Spring merchandise in their drive for volume, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

BERLIN, March 2. -- The Boerse was generally firm but quiet today. Heavy industrials were inactive, with some signs of weakness, and potashes were stagnant. Electricals were irregular, A.E.G. gaining one-quarter point. Chemicals also were irregular with I.G. Farben showing resistance.

TOKYO, March 2. -- Japanese officials receive with marked skepticism reports that Great Britain proposes a big international loan to China. They refuse to believe Britain and the United States are seeking to obstruct Chino-Japanese rapprochement.

THERE is a seductive softness about the sun in late Winter, even though it shines upon discolored snow, slush and mud. It awakens within us a consciousness of the stirring of life underground, the near coming of pink-flushed arbutus blossoms, of unfolding hepatica buds and of the pure white blooms of the blood-root.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 2. -- Kimberly School of Montclair made a clean sweep of the first three places in the horsemanship team competition for teams of three, which was one of the features of the fourth annual Montclair Horse Show, held this afternoon and evening at the Montclair Riding Club.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- In a hard-fought indoor polo game today Yale defeated the Princeton trio, 12 1/2 to 10, before a large crowd.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- For the second time in two years the University of Wisconsin is to be put on the anxious bench by a legislative commission of inquiry. State Senator Brunette heads a group of his colleagues charged with the duty of discovering to what extent, if any, atheism, agnosticism, communism and other "perversive" doctrines are taught in the university class rooms.

There is a bill pending in Albany to allow Sunday legitimate performances. Dr. Robert Searles, executive secretary of the Greater Federation of New York Churches, and Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance, and many ministers are opposing the passage of this bill.

WASHINGTON. -- As the Roosevelt administration enters on its third year in office it is brought face to face with a grave crisis affecting its relations to organized labor as represented by the American Federation of Labor.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, March 2. -- The organized celebration inside Germany over the return of the Saar was impressive as a panoramic picture of a nation on the march, but it lacked altogether the spontaneous exuberance manifested by the Saarlanders themselves following the plebiscite.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, March 3 (AP). -- Physicians attending Oliver Wendell Holmes clearly indicated last night their fears for the life of the retired Justice of the Supreme Court and his condition was reported as unchanged at an early hour this morning.

International conflicts brewing on the Swiss borders and the increasing technical complexity of modern warfare led to the ratification in Switzerland last Sunday of a law extending by twenty-three days the annual period of compulsory military service.

Furniture and decorations, mainly early American and eighteenth-century English, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. next Friday and Saturday afternoons.

The special committee of six men appointed a few weeks ago to consider five suggested changes in the trading contract in use on the New York Cotton Exchange has submitted majority and minority reports. A meeting of the members of the Exchange has been called for March 11 for discussion of the reports.

THIS is a first-rate and distinctive first novel of a kind which is old in literature. It is an adventure story; it treats of a man's world; it is fundamentally romantic, but by no means sentimental; it has a plot which is not extraneous to the meaning; it has action; it knows whereof it speaks -- which is to say its realism is without reproach.
BOSTON, March 2 (AP). -- Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma predicted today a government bond decline if the present governmental bond-selling, borrowing and spending continued.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:
Seeing the big city is more involved than Woodrow Wilkins, 22-year-old mechanic, and his bride of five months, Henrietta, 18, had anticipated, they discovered yesterday -- especially without cash.

The report of the closing of the American Church in Berlin, while not unexpected by members of the American colony who knew the situation since Hitler came to power, will be received with deep regret by thousands of former members of that colony and by tens of thousands of transient American visitors to Berlin.

The fast-riding and accurate-shooting Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club team scored an impressive 14 1/2-to-9 1/2 triumph over Squadron C in the feature indoor polo match last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

THIS is the third in a group of four novels dealing with the sources and life story of Giles Dabney. "The Firemakers" and "Toward Romance" have told how the elder Dabneys were lured from Virginia to a coal-mining settlement in the Ohio hills and left stranded there when the coal played out.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- Unknown to the crowd of 50,000 or more lining Daytona's shining sands, Sir Malcolm Campbell played a tight little drama with death in the cockpit of mighty Bluebird today and came out shaken, bruised, but still determined to smash tomorrow his own speed record of 272 miles an hour.

A simple and seemingly satisfactory solution of the vexatious problem of late entries to dog shows has been suggested by James W. Spring of Boston, counsel to the American Kennel Club. Details are yet to be worked out and a rule formulated to be submitted to the board of directors for approval and in due course presented to the delegates.

STARS of the Metropolitan have volunteered their services for a special gala performance on Tuesday evening, March 12, "in commemoration of Giulio Gatti-Casazza's final season as manager." Mr. Gatti himself has announced that the proceeds will be given to the Fund to Maintain Metropolitan Opera.

PARIS, Feb. 6. IN Paris a play may be considered to be reasonably successful with a run so short that it would be a failure in London and a disaster in New York. The result is that many more plays are produced, or if there are no new plays ready to take their turn, managers must fall back on revivals.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2. -- The Paraguayan Second Army Corps made a surprise appearance far north of the Chaco yesterday and arrived within 100 miles of the important Bolivian city of Santa Cruz, capital of the rich agricultural province of the same name, according to today's communique of the Asuncion War Office.

An increase in State aid for education, "to the extent at least of $200,000,000 a year," was favored yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the School of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, in an address at the joint luncheon of the High School Teachers Association and the High School Principals Association in the Hotel Commodore.

AMONG the newcomers to the New York exhibition field this week is Percy Albee, whose oils and dry-points are being shown at the galleries of Cronyn Lowndes. Mr. Albee, after working in murals for some time, studied in Paris for several years.

When the people of the United States forsook the tenets laid down by the framers of the Federal Constitution and lost sight of the fact that each State is sovereign in its own right and began to amend that Constitution with all sorts of provisions the bases of which are not comprehended by the document itself, not only did the dignity of the Senate begin to disappear but liberty began to fade out also.

It is an old political custom, and not a bad one, to review the achievements and estimate the position of a President midway in his first term. Such judgments are fallible but interesting. By 1903, for example, it was certain that THEODORE ROOSEVELT was successful and popular and would probably be elected in 1904.

The Textile High School team swept to a 9-to-0 victory over Townsend Harris High in one of the eight matches of the Public Schools Athletic League fencing tournament staged at Washington Irving High School yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 2. -- More than 1,500 New York school children agree with their contemporaries in the Scarsdale schools that the experimental radio broadcast of the Scarsdale Woman's Club Feb. 19 was interesting, and most of them asked for a continuance of similar programs.

IT was all the fault of Mr. John Chapman, the czar of the bike world. Mr. Chapman told his stout henchman, Mr. Harry Mendel, to break up the team of M'sieu Alfred Letourneur and M'sieu Gerard Debaets in the six-day whirls.
Varied and conflicting opinions were brought forward yesterday on the question as to what the final decision might be in the case of Louis S. Posner, deposed member of the Board of Education.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Members of the Tin Whistle Golfing Society will hold two traditional tournaments this week, the James W. Barber Memorial Trophy tournament tomorrow, and the club championship, starting on Saturday.

Assistant Dean Palmer H. Graham, chairman of the scholarship committee at the New York University Washington Square College, announced yesterday that 196 students have been commended for high scholarship during the first semester of the current academic year.

MOBILE, Ala. BLOOMS are bursting along the Azalea Trail and hundreds of visitors from Northern States are driving its twenty-five varied miles. The volume of tourists is expected to grow through the Mardi Gras celebration, which reaches its climax on Tuesday.

Revival of interest in the writings and personality of CHARLES DICKENS, attested by the series of new books published about him as well as by the successful presentation of his best stories on the moving picture screen, is in a way one of the oddities of the time.
MANILA. -- Governor General Frank Murphy has outlined a three-year economic program for the Philippine Islands designed to meet the stress of the transition of the commonwealth government.

The National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, comprising more than 300 recognized leaders in religion and welfare work, organized under the chairmanship of Walter W. Head, issued yesterday "a call, a program and a calendar for religion and welfare recovery for 1935."

RUMSON, N.J., March 2. -- A dinner dance was held at the Rumson Country Club tonight to benefit the Fitkin Memorial Hospital of Neptune. Mrs. Robert Illsley, president of the Rumson Middletown Auxiliary, was general chairman, assisted by Mrs. J. Sanford Shanley, reservations chairman, and Mrs. Louis Hague, fashion show chairman.

Intercession on the part of Mayor La Guardia has resulted in Miss Florence Nathanson, a young woman neighbor, being assigned to surgical work at Bellevue Hospital after the hospital medical board, against her wishes, had made her an interne on the medical staff.

LION FEUCHTWANGER has hitherto published no fiction save his massive, bulky novels, which have a habit of running to seven or eight hundred closely printed pages. Consequently it is with some astonishment that we discover in this slim volume a collection of eight brilliant, jewel-polished short stories.

Day before yesterday the Saar came back under German rule, and there will be few to disagree with HITLER that the event makes for better relations between France and Germany and for peace in Europe; provided, that is, HITLER really wants peace. The territory had to go back to Germany because it is an overwhelmingly German land and because its return, subject to a plebiscite, was promised in the peace treaty.

A FORGOTTEN book of Sir Richard Francis Burton, explorer, Orientalist and pilgrim to Mecca, was entitled "Letters From the Battlefields of Paraguay." It was written toward the end of his consulship at Santos, Brazil. In that country he had lived five years. He was attracted to the conflict between little Paraguay and Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay, one of the most tragic wars in history.

Vulnerable penalties will be drastically reduced -- on an average of about 50 per cent -- when the new international code of contract bridge rules goes into effect on April 1, it was learned yesterday. Formal announcement of the new code will be made here on March 18 by the Whist Club of New York, the governing body.

Bessemer converters, which in 1875 accounted for 86 per cent of the nation's output of steel, produced only 8 per cent of the total last year, while open-hearth plants turned out 90 per cent, according to the American Iron Steel Institute.

THE recent dog shows in and near New York have left in their wake many new pets. City dwellers as well as suburbanites often succumb to the appeal of a puppy after visiting a show, hence to many a household a scampering canine has been added.
LANSING, Mich., March 2 (AP). -- More than 2,750,000 taxpayers were technically liable to arrest today because they failed to pay a $2 head tax for support of old-age pensions.

CAMDEN, S.C -- A feature of the Spring rally of the Kershaw County Fish and Game Association to be held on Wednesday and Thursday, March 13 and 14, will be a dog show in the armory on Wednesday. Prizes and ribbons will be given in the following classes: Shooting dogs, pointers and setters, Spaniels, police dogs, fox terriers, bulldogs, hounds and miscellaneous.

DURING the past year or two the name of the energetic, modernized version of Sherlock Holmes who directs the activities of the division of investigation of the United States Department of Justice has been coming more and more often into the public prints.
CHICAGO, March 2. -- Let Germany and the Fascist nations try their political experiments in sterilization on a pseudo-scientific basis.

With seven weeks now remaining before Easter, retailers are entering upon the critical portion of the season with a heavy barrage of Spring offerings. Consumer response to these promotions will be a factor in the showings of both wholesale and retail trade for the first half of the year.

ASUNCION. -- The Paraguayans have now driven the Bolivians northwest as far as Longitude 63 and maintain their right to keep all the territory they have captured. A year ago they never anticipated the possibility of being able to drive the Bolivians so far north and west, but now that they have done so they have no intention of letting the rich petroleum district to the north of Villa Montes escape from their possession.

Debutantes headed by Miss Emmy Jo Schweizer are helping in the sale of seats for the performance of "De Luxe" on the night of March 14 at the Booth Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the Woman's Board of the Babies Hospital of the City of New York to raise funds for the hospital.

HAVING submitted Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing!" the Group Theatre has skipped over a couple of other matters and simply nominated Mr. Odets as its No. 1 playwright. The next step is this: some time this month, in a theatre away from Broadway, a twin bill will offer "Waiting for Lefty," Mr. Odets's acclaimed one-act play about the taxi strike; and with it another oneacter by the same author, an anti-Nazi work entitled "Paradise Lost."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- With a brisk workout in the morning and a still brisker one in the afternoon. Manager Bill Terry today brought to a close the first week of the Giants' current training campaign with the feeling that, on the whole, much satisfactory work already has been accomplished.

Approval of the welfare phases of the Knights of Columbus Mobilization for Catholic Action has been expressed by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, William Edwin Hall, president of the Boys Club of America, and Frederic R. Kellogg, national president of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday at the headquarters in the Empire State Building.
SHERIDAN, Wyo., March 2. -- And now there's talk in these parts of a forty-ninth State, which some would name -- of all names -- Absaroka.

PARIS. PARIS couturiers have created a great many of their new models with their minds' eyes fixed on the Near East. Mainbocher, Schiaparelli and Alix have all succeeded in making variations taken from Oriental themes smart and modern.
PARIS. -- "YOU take a book, and then you make a building around it."
MONTPELIER, Vt., March 2. -- If the Mattison family should depart suddenly from Glastenbury there would be no election there Tuesday, town meeting day throughout Vermont.

Agricultural Adjustment Act amendments designed to consolidate and perpetuate the gains which have been won in American agriculture the last two years have been submitted to Congress by Secretary Wallace.

BOSTON, March 2. -- Harvard's freshman and junior varsity hockey teams defeated their Yale rivals in a double-header at the Arena today. The freshman team came through in the final period to win, 3 to 2, on a goal by George Roberts. The jayvees triumphed in overtime, 4 -- 3.

Montclair, N.J., March 2. -- A capacity crowd of 800 attended the fourth annual Montclair Midwinter Horse Show, held this afternoon and evening, in the indoor ring of the Montclair Riding Club, Children's horsemanship featured the exhibition, the proceeds of which were donated to the Family Welfare Society of Montclair.

I come from the country which Americans call Abyssinia, a name given to it by the Moslems which means, in English, mixture, mongrel. We call ourselves Ethiopians, and our land Ethiopia. We are Negroes, the oldest Christian nation, now more than 1,400 years old. We have seen the burial of Rome and of Constantinople, and to us the governments of Europe were born but yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 1. -- Soviet opinion is gratified by statements by infuential foreign newspapers and public men that the Soviet Union is regarded as a factor of great and growing importance in plans for the maintenance of the European status quo.

IF not packed with a triumphant succession of shows, to each of which one's instant homage must be paid, this late Winter phase of the art season yet cannot be called barren of incident. The air is pleasantly astir with developments of a less insistently "current" category, and spiced with arresting adumbrations.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 28 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The Provident Loan Society of New York made 69,626 loans last year, the largest number in its forty-year history, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This compared with 604,452 in 1933. More than 375,000 of the advances last year were for less than $35 each.

An infrequently employed device of detective fiction is used with fresh kinks in this short, fast-moving, hut execrably written mystery novel. We refer to the stunt of calling in the sleuth prior to the commission of an expected crime, for defensive measures.

IT seems natural that the men who most revered the word of God should want to emphasize the spiritual beauty of divine text with the luminous beauty of gold leaf and paint. It was not enough for the scribe to present the holy word in calligraphic art.

A one-year survey of the reading habits of 22,401 New York families conducted under the direction of Professor Hugh Agnew, New York University School of Commerce, shows that general news and advertisements are the most widely read items in metropolitan daily newspapers, it was announced yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 2. -- Berkeley Bell of New York and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., today won the Bermuda tennis doubles championship, defeating Bryan M. Grant of Atlanta and Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers, N.Y., in the final, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Senator Black of Alabama served notice today that he would continue his fight to block confirmation of Major Gen. John H. Russell as a permanent major general in the Marine Corps. His opposition is based largely on the allegation that, through General Russell's influence, the promotion board of the marines has been unfair in advancing officers.

THAT the hope of reward may accomplish more in the reduction of accidents than the fear of punishment by injury in the accidents themselves is indicated in a recent report by Frank V. Hicks, engineer of the Union Pacific Coal Company of Superior, Wyoming, to the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- The Araho Stable's Howard, a 5-2 shot, raced to a new mile and a quarter track record before 12,000 persons at Hialeah Park today when he came from behind a fast pace to win the Jockey Club Handicap by a neck in 2:02 1-5.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 27, which included only five business days, aggregated $6,634,000,000, or 13 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 6 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days.

Whatever the President may have been thinking, he was unhurried. His train, drawn by a new electric locomotive, arrived in Washington at 7:55 A.M. It was half an hour before he appeared (there was no one to meet him except the usual guard and some railroad officials) and posed on the platform for photographers.

Cut-out books, as a rule, offer no more than temporary occupation and entertainment, but Gordon Grant's name on any book of ship pictures is an earnest of accuracy and beauty. Five ships, the Santa Maria, Mayflower, Constitution, a New Bedford whaler and the clipper ship Flying Cloud, appear to sail over the waves under a windswept sky.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 2. -- Three Kentucky Derby nominees dominated the Santa Catalina $2,500 handicap of mile and a sixteenth today as Bluebeard, owned by William R. Coe, won the 3-year-old event by a neck from Sound Advice, with Pitter Pat third.
ST. SAUVEUR, Que., March 2. -- Dartmouth today won the International Intercollegiate Skiing Union championship and the Dartmouth Cup, emblematic of the title, the fifth consecutive time.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Democratic leaders of the State prepared today to clear the decks for the expected battle on reapportionment, as it was announced that Governor Lehman had signed the Byrne Bill, dealing with figures gathered for the redistricting measure.

The managing and editorial staffs of seven undergraduate publications at City College have been completed for the Spring term, it was announced yesterday. The publications and their staffs are as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 2. -- Princeton continues to lead all the universities in the United States in the number of fellowships granted by the National Research Council of Washington, according to an analysis by The Princeton Alumni Weekly of the list of past and active holders of the awards.

SANDOVAL COUNTY contained the hangout of Ike Darby's band of outlaws who were protected by the crooked Sheriff with whom they shared their loot. Some sixty miles from the county seat of Breckenridge lay the huge and rich El Rancho de la Estrella Sola, now more familiarly known as Lone Star Ranch.

DANGER that the awkward, shambling alligator might become extinct stirred Floridians to set aside a national park for his protection. Congress has passed the necessary enabling act. The area chosen takes in the entire southern tip of the State, some 2,000 square miles, and includes the present Royal Palm Park.

THE close connection between interior decoration and women's dress runs through many periods. Decorative fabrics and wall finishes have been especially sensitive to this influence, even the shape of furniture being modified by the costumes of women.

The widespread vogue for tailored suits and separate blouses has given great impetus to the tailored shirt and has made it the outstanding blouse fashion of the Spring season, Tobe, style authority and merchandising counselor, says in a report prepared especially for THE TIMES.

A strike of 30,000 service employes in 1,800 buildings in Brooklyn and Queens is set for tomorrow, unless Mayor La Guardia steps in, as he has in other boroughs, and halts it. The call for a walkout was issued yesterday by Local 51 of the Building Service Employes International Union.

The following monthly reports of holdings of stocks were filed yesterday with the New York Stock Exchange by officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed companies in compliance with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934:
President Roosevelt will complete the second year of his administration tomorrow. In the ten chapters that follow, the highlights of twenty-four critical months are set out.

The eighth annual celebration of Parents' Day will be held on the Mall in Central Park on Sunday, May 12, at 2:30 P.M., according to an announcement yesterday by Uncle Robert, originator of the celebration.

Mrs. Betty Rottenberg's big gray mare Blue Bonnet gave a first-class performance yesterday to win the sweepstakes, the leading jumping event on the program of the horse show and riding competition given under the joint auspices of the Riding and Driving Club and the Brooklyn Riding Academy in Prospect Park Plaza.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Social and sports events will vie for the interest of St. Petersburg Winter visitors this week.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 1. -- The first full week since the gold-clause decision found a moderate increase in heavy industries and in long-term commitments here. Buying of flour increased and four mills booked an average of 50 per cent of capacity, compared with 42 per cent in the preceding week and 40 per cent a year ago.

GENEVA, March 2. -- The United States moved today to meet the neutrality issue raised by Italy and to keep its arms traffic treaty from prejudicing either way its own neutrality policy. It submitted two amendments to the treaty to this end. One adds a second paragraph to Article 2, so it reads in full:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 2. -- The idea of undergraduates carrying their political activities beyond the college campus, as did Vassar students in opposing the Nunan bill at Albany last week, was carried into the Vassar Experimental Theatre when "The Question Before the House" was presented at a matinee today and another performance tonight.

Alfred E. Smith remarked last week that "what with funerals, wakes and consecrations to attend," he gets about New York as much as the next one, and on those trips the only "under way" relief jobs that he sees are those of the Park Department.

WASHINGTON. -- The revival of an old proposal -- to permit Cabinet members to join in Senate and House debate -- has claimed special interest in Washington in view of recent friction which has indicated the need of closer contact between the legislative and executive branches of the government.

MOBILE, Ala. WATCHING a Mardi Gras pageant in Mobile the average tourist does not realize that he is on historic ground in so far as the American carnival is concerned. One hundred years ago the mystic or masked form of celebration which is the chief feature of Mardi Gras festivities along the Southern Coast was inaugurated in this city.

LEIPZIG, March 2. -- The Leipzig Spring fair, which in the first year of Hitler rule shrank to less than one-half its normal size, although still the greatest merchandise market in the world, will open tomorrow with signs of continued recovery.

BEHIND the immortal figure of the gaunt and gallant Don there looms the shadowy legend of a man called Cervantes. He was a contemporary of Shakespeare and we know almost as little about his life. On any given detail of it there is enough controversy to set shoals of scholarly pundits racing over the evidence.

THE Institute of Foreign Travel recently undertook a survey to determine the importance of the American as a traveler, and the data uncovered support the frequently expressed opinion of American ship lines that the United States is the most important source of travel income in the world.

LONDON, March 2. -- It was officially confirmed here today that the feasibility of a four-power loan to China formed one subject of yesterday's talk in Washington between Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, and Acting Secretary of State Phillips.

LONDON, March 2. -- With the Stock Exchange closed, sterling's rapid fall monopolized the city's attention today. The money markets were comparatively unaffected, and week-end credit was plentiful at as low as one-quarter of 1 per cent.

AFTER getting off to a poor start and wandering rather disconcertingly through the first few chapters. Jackson Gregory, author of many Westerns, finally hits his stride in this latest tale from his prolific pen and achieves a romance of high and wild adventure that is quite as swift, tense and exciting as any of its predecessors.

BOSTON, March 2. -- A goal in the overtime period of a closely fought, hard-checking contest enabled the Yale hockey team to defeat Harvard's fast-skating sextet in the first game of their annual series at the Boston Garden tonight. The score was 3 to 2.

At a meeting of the council of the American Power Boat Association, to be held in the Hotel Lexington on March 26, a request will be made for approval of the completed plan for the structural reorganization of the association on a regional basis, which has been detailed by the committee headed by John A. Remon of Washington.
The New York University fencing team halted the Fencers Club, 15 -- 12, in a three-weapon match on the winner's strips yesterday.

The exhibition of Italian Renaissance Sculpture of the thirteenth, fourteenth and fifteenth centuries for the benefit of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League, which opened recently at the A.S. Drey Art Gallery, 680 Fifth Avenue, will continue there until March 20.

ST. LOUIS, March 1. -- Inclement weather slackened a fair trade in Spring goods in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. The general retail situation, however, is fairly satisfactory. Clothing concerns report demand excellent. The trade level is estimated at about 14 per cent above that of a year ago in the cities and considerably more in rural centres, where the impact of farm betterment is felt.

NEWARK, N.J. -- The average New Jersey working girl prefers to ply a stenographer's pencil in a business office, to operate a machine in a factory, even to accept a dole from the government, rather than perform the tasks of a housemaid, but here and there a college graduate is beginning to find in household service her answer to unemployment.

CHATTANOOGA, March 1. -- Chattanooga's battle over the question of private ownership of its power distribution system as against municipal power purchased from the Tennessee Valley Authority has gathered force with the passing days.
German-American commercial relations as reflected by the practice of a German lawyer handling American affairs may be classified into three different phases.

There is increasingly good reason to believe that President ROOSEVELT'S budget message overshot the Federal deficit for the current year. He predicted that by June 30 the excess of the Government's expenditures over its receipts would amount to $4,869,000,000. With four months still to go, the deficit now stands at a little less than $2,300,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The question whether a satisfactory solution will be found soon to the wage sections of the $4,880,000,000 relief resolution was put squarely up to the friends of labor today by Senate leaders.

LONDON, March 2. -- Babe Ruth, the man who did more than any other to make baseball salaries what they are today, has started a red-hot movement to improve the financial lot of England's professional athletes.

Frank R. Hope, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, and Raoul E. Desvernine, attorney for the association, will appear before the Federal Communications Commission in Washington on March 11 to present the protests of leading wire houses against Article 7 of the proposed code of fair competition for communications companies.

TORONTO, Ont., March 2. -- A police strike in Toronto is unlikely, Mayor James Simpson said today following a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners and leaders of the Police Association. He stated that a special meeting of the Board of Control would be called for Monday should the Police Association request it.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 2 (AP). -- After twenty-four hours of investigating the mysterious death of Mrs. H. Bradley Davidson Jr., one of the heiresses of the late E.M. Statler, Solicitor Roland Pruett said tonight that he had evidence indicating "either murder or suicide," and that he had discarded the possibility of an accident.

Alexander D. Livingston, master of the new United Fruit liner Veragua, comes from a family whose hands and brains were devoted to the sea and seafaring trades for generations; his father built his own sailing ships and every one of his eight sons eventually went to sea.

Notwithstanding the controversy between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Harold L. Ickes, who has demanded that he drop either his park commissionership or the chairmanship of the Triborough Bridge Authority, the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works is advertising bids for the steel work of the Triborough Bridge.

Reporting that most of the primary dry goods lines have become unstable to an alarming degree, wholesalers declared here yesterday that they were withdrawing from the market for the time being and would not place any sizable business until prices stabilized.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Adjusted indices of steel and automobile production declined somewhat in the week ended on Feb. 23, but otherwise the level of business activity showed little change, with industrial output about the same as earlier in the month, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of the domestic field.

NEW YORK society has been taking some bad beatings lately. On the heels of Cornelius Vanderbilt comes Arthur Train with a rowdy farcical satire on one family's rise to the rotogravures. J.H. Bates -- born Joshua Hiram -- is a millionaire manufacturer of patent medicines and proprietor of Bates's Animal Elixir.

NEW GUINEA laughs at bored travelers who say, "There is nothing new; we have done everything." So little known and so darkly mysterious is this South Seas realm that it successfully hid more than 200,000 of its people from sight of the white man until the present decade, as readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES have recently been told.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- A newspaper photograph of Miss Ethel du Pont of Wilmington, Del., found in the possession of a man arrested here today on an extortion charge, led to a police investigation to determine whether Miss du Pont was the intended victim of a kidnapping or blackmail plot.

WITH two of the mightiest bridges in the world thrusting out piers northward and eastward, the one across the Golden Gate, the other across the bay to Oakland, the sea-born city of San Francisco will soon have a long-wanted opportunity to stretch.

A rather thin story of a trip to Bali made by an American family who have been living in Surabaya for a year. On the journey they meet a Dutch archaeologist and his wife, an American boy who is traveling for a year before settling down in his father's factory at home in the United States and a young Hollander, just out of college, who volunteers to act as their guide on the island.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- More than 389 tests of New Deal legislation were reported today to be pending in the Federal courts. The National Recovery Act, which suffered two adverse rulings at the hands of Federal judges this week, is the subject of 332 actions.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- Vincent Braun of St. Benedict's Prep, one-mile national interscholastic champion, smashed a national record in the New Jersey State title school meet tonight when he stepped the mile in 4:29 3-5, bettering the former mark, held by John McKenna, also of St. Benedict's by one-fifth of a second.

VIENNA, March 2. -- The Nazi putsch of last July, in which Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss was slain, brought to the bar of justice today Dr. Anton Rintelen, former Austrian Minister to Rome and once powerful Governor of Styria.

Industry's fight against the McCarran amendment calling for the prevailing wage scale on relief projects conceals a broader attack on wage scales generally, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, warned last night.

Only $208.10 in sales tax receipts was paid into the city treasury yesterday, City Collector William Reid Jr. reported. This brought the total receipts to date to $4,994.82, which includes payments received before they were due.

HOULTON, Me., Feb. 28. -- Maine potato growers, hard hit by economic trends, are supporting legislative efforts, at Washington and at Augusta, intended to advance their interests. They are heartily supporting the Warren Potato Control Bill recently introduced in Congress, which would give each State an allotment determined by the average annual acreage harvested, the highest average yield per acre and the average annual percentage of the yield sold during the years 1927-33 inclusive.

May I use your columns to say a few words concerning the New Theatre of Philadelphia? Since its inception in September, 1934, its membership has grown to 200 sincere young men and women, who are determined to create a theatre whose fundamental aim is a theatre for the broad masses of the people, such as the Theatre Union and the Group Theatre of New York.

THE virtual extinction of the old-fashioned London music hall, despite repeated attempts to revive it in the last few years, is having results that extend far outside the theatre. Vaudeville in New York suffered from the movies and from the change in public taste which the movies brought about; but in New York the humor which once flourished in vaudeville flourishes now other forms.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Secretary Ickes said today that President Roosevelt's order impounding $238,000,000 in public works fund was not "intended in any way" to coerce Senators into voting for the $4,880,000,000 works relief bill.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the approach of the Lenten season, social activities in Augusta are confined to small gatherings of various kinds, and Winter visitors are turning almost wholly to sports.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2. -- Ship tonnage movement in and out of San Francisco Harbor during the month of February was rather disappointing in comparison with January and the month of February a year ago, according to Chamber of Commerce figures.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (AP). -- In a court room bristling with armed guards, one man was sentenced to prison, another pleaded guilty and the trial of twelve other defendants was set for March 18 as the government moved today against alleged aides of the slain gangster, George (Baby Face) Nelson.

LAST week saw a long step forward toward the realization of the comprehensive plans of Mayor La Guardia and his two commissioners concerned with aviation, John McKenzie, Dock Commissioner, and F William Zelcer, his deputy for air matters, for modernizing New York's flying facilities.
SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, March 2. -- With Chancellor Hitler's departure from Saarbruecken immediately after his speech last night the cream of the whole "Saar Liberation Festival" had gone.

Women who long have been interested in the work accomplished by the Barat Settlement are active in behalf of the dinner dance in aid of that organization to be held tomorrow at the Central Park Casino. An elaborate entertainment will be given during the evening by stars of the theatre and screen, headed by Ethel Merman of the cast of "Anything Goes."
PARIS, Feb. 28. -- One tiny bow, feather or flower placed among curls rolled toward the front over the forehead is the latest evening coiffure ornament.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Feb. 16 there appeared an article by Walter Duranty entitled "Bolshevism Marches Toward Its Goal." Referring to the heavy progressive income tax during the NEP period, Mr. Duranty considers that now "this tax * * * became less important."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2. -- Eighty undergraduates of Rutgers University have been admitted to membership in the Honor School of the College of Arts and Sciences for the second semester, it was announced today by Dean Walter T. Marvin.

DAYS that are gradually growing longer and warmer invite the gardener to give his attention to outdoor tasks. But on stormy days there are still things to be done inside, and one of these is going over all Winter-stored roots, corms and bulbs -- such as dahlias, gladiolus, cannas, Summer-hyacinths, tuberoses and tuberous begonias -- and getting them ready for planting or for starting indoors.

PLANT CITY, Fla. -- The sixth' annual Florida strawberry festival, which opens here tomorrow to continue through Saturday, is expected to exceed in importance and attendance the similar events tha have gone before. I-Iundreds will motor from all parts of the west coast and from many of the east coast resort centres.

A thrilling victory in the 200-yard free style relay, the final event on the program, enabled the unbeaten Penn Hall School women's swimming team of Chambersburg, Pa., to score its twentieth straight triumph since 1932 at the London Terrace pool yesterday by defeating New York University and the Savage School of Physical Education.

ACCORDING to the box-office accountants, "Sequoia" is only one-half as meritorious as "Rumba," since its "biz," as Variety calls it, did not entitle it to a second week at the Capitol. By almost any other standard except the self-conscious dilettantism of the town's elegantes, this is February's most distinguished contribution to the 1935 cinema.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Corporations may not engage in the practice of optometry, Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck ruled today in an action brought by Madeline B. Stern of New York City. She moved for a mandamus to compel Secretary of State Flynn to accept for filing a certificate of corporation of F.A. O'Keefe, Inc.

A TWO-HOUR dramatic review, "Of the People, By the People, For the People," will be broadcast by WABC in a coast-to-coast network tomorrow afternoon beginning at 2:30 o'clock, celebrating the first two years of the Roosevelt administration.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 2 (AP). -- Ohio collegiate fencers engaged in an impromptu match with sabers last night, and today one of them. Robert Zolg of the University of Dayton, was believed near death. His opponent's saber, hospital attendants reported, went through his chest puncturing one lung.

An entertainment in Mecca Temple last night that had been announced as a concert of compositions by Hanns Eisler, a recent arrival from Central Europe, took on the aspects of an anti-Nazi and anti-Fascist protest meeting, but not to the exclusion of Mr. Eisler's music.
PARIS, March 2. -- The pound sterling took an astonishing drop of 1 franc 7 centimes today, closing at 71.77, against a par value of 124.21.

The author has made diligent search in collections of the folklore of different parts of Great Britain. with the result that her book contains a fresh and interesting selecition of stories that range from the Suffolk version of "Tom Tit Tot" to the Devonshire tale of "The Old Woman Who Went to Market at Midnight."

SIX concerts are announced by Charles A. Sink, president of the University Musical Society, for the forty-second May festival, in the Hill Auditorium, Ann Arbor, May 15, 16, 17 and 18. The opening on Wednesday, May 15, is designated as artists' concert; Thursday evening, choral concert; Friday afternoon, young people's concert; Friday evening, artists' concert; Saturday afternoon, symphony concert, and Saturday evening, choral concert.

Work relief with the prevailing wage as opposed to the dole was endorsed in a statement sent to President Roosevelt and members of the United States Senate yesterday by a group of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish clergymen who explained that the statement expressed their personal views.

Jules Bender and Leo Merson each scored 12 points as Long Island University crushed the Wagner College quintet, 56 to 24, last night in the Wagner gymnasium at Grymes Hill, S.I. The outcome raised the victors point total to 1,355 this season and gave the Blackbirds their twenty-fourth victory in twenty-six starts.

MISS SOKOLOFF has considerable gifts as a romantic novelist which she contrives to use with telling effect on a theme and background seemingly hostile to them. Somehow one does not associate Red Russia of the early Twenties -- with its reign of hunger, of civil war, of rapine, of lawlessness, of the sadism of the Cheka (Miss Sokoloff uses the later name of Ogpu) -- with the glamour of romance.

The Pan-American Medical Association, whose membership includes the leading physicians and surgeons on the Western Hemisphere, has announced its sixth scientific congress to be held this Summer in the form of a cruise to Brazil and the West Indies.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A Federal deficit of $2,249,923,235 was reported by the Treasury today in its month-end statement covering the first eight months of the fiscal year. Expenditures exceeded receipts during the period by a ratio of two to one, but the deficit was somewhat less than for the corresponding period last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28. -- When a 5-year-old boy, under the influence of "a mischevous devil," slashed his baby brother with a butcher knife last week in a backwoods district of Central Pennsylvania, investigators started a periodic search for pow-wow doctors, ever present rivals of the medical profession in several counties of this Commonwealth.

ROME, March 1. -- Never have rumors been so rife in Italy as at the present moment. At a time when troops are on the move to Africa, and it is natural to suppose that colonial matters are absorbing the whole attention of the country, the thoughts of most Italians turn northward, particularly toward Central Europe.

Confronted with one of the most difficult merchandising problems they have faced since the depression began, manufacturers and distributers of food products were divided in their views here yesterday regarding the likely trends in food prices this Spring and Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Philippine problems occupied the attention of President Roosevelt principally today through a continuation of conferences begun yesterday with Frank Murphy, Governor General of the Islands, who returned here at Mr. Roosevelt's request to report in detail on the insular questions, particularly in the light of the steps taken toward preparing for independence.

ALMOST on the first anniversary of Postmaster General Farley's cancellation of the air mail contracts Representative James M. Mead (Democrat) of Buffalo has introduced in Congress an air mail bill. This proposed legislation follows a study of months by the Howell Commission, recommendations resulting from that study that the commercial

Mrs. W.M Hosken, a quiet-voiced woman who is accustomed to dealing in locomotives and airplanes as casually as the average housewife deals in linens and groceries, told yesterday of her plans for construction of an ice-skating rink in sunny Shanghai.

Struck by a stolen automobile, the driver of which sped from the scene, a man later identified as William Jordan, 36 years old, of 1,806 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, was injured critically at 6 o'clock last night in front of 137-65 Queens Boulevard, near 137th Street, Jamaica, Queens.

Recent surveys having provided assurance that the early morning clump, clump, clump of the milkman's horse will continue to resound through New York streets, notes on the status of the horse are being revised. Despite popular belief that automobiles have done for patient Dobbin, New York goes on using him to deliver milk, bread and various merchandise.

DE LUXE" is not at all a new play. It was first written five years ago under the title of "Fun" and as such was the last scheduled production of the Provincetown Players. The sets were designed, the costumes sketched and the play partly cast when the money gave out.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- With 11,124 Public Works Administration projects finished and in use, Iowa, with ninety-five jobs, leads all other States in the number of local public improvements completed with the assistance of PWA loans and grants, it was said today by Secretary Ickes.

The first report of the newly created House committee on conservation of wild-life resources, filed recently at Washington, discloses that fish, birds and mammals have an annual value to the nation of $1,500,000,000.

After a lapse of two weeks in which, because of holidays, the number of calls had been curtailed, notices received last week of bonds to be redeemed before their dates of maturity made the largest total for a week in several months. They included many issues called in their entirety.

SHORT-WAVE Stations W3XE and W3XAL, which relay programs of the WEAF-WJZ networks from Bound Brook, N.J., have been reconstructed to improve reception abroad. The improvement in signal strength in some locations is reported as high as 60 per cent.

THE changes in the curriculum of Vassar College, just announced, are an attempt to correct the mistake of trying to keep new wine in old bottles. The weekly classroom schedule of fifteen class meetings with additional laboratory and studio periods had remained unchanged for forty years, while new courses of study and new methods of instruction had been added to the curriculum until the schedule was no longer a workable one.

HILLSIDE, N.J., March 2. -- Ten boys, ranging in age from 11 to 15 years, were playing in two groups on opposite sides of the Elizabeth River, just above Ursino Lake here, at 11:30 o'clock this morning, when sudden screams of terror startled the lads who were safe on the banks.

The women's division of the Metropolitan Badminton Association has enjoyed an active interteam match program, and although all the points have not yet been played off, the team winners in each section have been established without a possibility of error.

The large subscription for the dinner cabaret in behalf of the Scholarship Fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre which will take place tonight in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria, indicates that the funds for aiding talented and needy young students of dramatic art will be substantially augmented.

Sales of the United States Government "baby bonds" yesterday at the fifty-two postoffices and stations in Manhattan and the Bronx totaled about $226,000, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced last night. The sale in these two boroughs on Friday, the first day of the sale, amounted to $349,025, and for the two days the total is more than $575,000.

Probably it'was the taste of movie fame that caused Shorty, chimpanzee who has been acting quite frequently of late on the motion-pieture lots, to become temperamental yesterday and repudiate his press agent, who said he could write his own name, drive an automobile, play a bugle, beat a drum and smoke a cigar.

IN the long and surprisingly violent history of American imperialism few chapters are more colorful than that which describes the war with Mexico -- though many, perhaps, make pleasanter reading and are easier to condone on moral grounds. The Spanish-American civilization of the Southwest -- though it may have been lazy and poverty-ridden and inefficient -- was not lacking in grace and spaciousness.

Formation of the Conference on Port Development of the City of New York, an organization representative of a "cross section" of the city's business men, was announced yesterday by Walter J.L. Banham, chairman. The function of the group, he explained, will be to study means by which local interests can offset and prevent "inroads" here by other Atlantic seaboard ports.

I was somewhat amused by the inconsistencies in Mr. C.H. Connaughton's letter which appeared in these columns recently. The writer admits, first of all, that he has gone to see the five "artistic" films condemned by the Legion of Decency and has, with the exception of "Queen Christina," found them artistically and intelligently conceived.

HERE is a group of studies of the lives and personalities of famous men made chaffy from the spiritual viewpoint. The author, A.J. Russell, is an editor of an important London daily newspaper and he is also one of the moving spirits in that religious movement known in England as the Oxford Group and in America more frequently as Buchmanism, about which he has written two books highly esteemed by its converts.

LIKE Maurice O'Sullivan's "Twenty Years A-Growing," this book, also a translation from the Gaelic, is a personal record of life on the Blasket Islands off the Irish coast. Because Tomas O'Crohan never wandered from his native scene.

That over half of the 500,000 people in the District of Columbia are mainly dependent upon government employment for family support and that about 105,000 are actually in the Federal and District service make it a unique community among American cities. One phase of that uniqueness is that the officials and employes "constitute the "largest field of service for the "churches."

The spotlight has now been turned on the negotiations between Japan and China. These negotiations have been proceeding for some time, but they have remained obscure because they have been withdrawn from the open diplomacy of world politics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 2. -- San Francisco's official reception to the German cruiser Karlsruhe was marred this morning by a Communist-inspired half-hour strike at the dock and a fight which sent three persons to the hospital and one to jail.

LONDON. -- The air convention for Western Europe, in the general settlement now under discussion with Germany, is the thing which interests Great Britain most. It would be unfair to say that the British Government, in exchange for the convention, is ready to give up all other claims for security on the Continent.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 2. -- Reporting on "certain important features of the revolution of 1933-1934" a subcommittee on Federal laws of the Pennsylvania Bar Association today attacked President Roosevelt's policies, striking directly at the NRA emergency price fixing, nationalization of gold and silver and the much-disputed processing tax.
Henry J. Allen, former Governor and United States Senator from Kansas, ascribed Great Britain's industrial recovery yesterday to a balanced budget, a flexible tariff and a proper housing program.

WEATHER conditions held retail trade in check during the week, but despite this adverse influence a fair showing was made. Main-floor departments attracted the best response and activity also was reported in the housewares divisions.

The rapid growth of the Junior Inspectors Club, an organization of public school children, was celebrated at a meeting yesterday morning in the Theodore Roosevelt High School, Washington Avenue and Fordham Road, the Bronx.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion show to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Velvet Room of the House of Lords for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York.

In addition to exposing the extent of the policy game in the city his recent bail bond investigation proved that bail bondsmen committed frequent perjury in the criminal courts, Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard said yesterday in a preliminary report of the inquiry.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28. -- The predominantly rural and Republican House of the Connecticut General Assembly has decided that it wants none of the Federal Government's rural rehabilitation plan for this State. Even a bill to set up a corporation of strictly limited powers, so limited that it was declared unsatisfactory by Washington, was not risked by the House, which killed the proposal this week by vote of 180 to 67.

OFFICIALS of the automobile factories are elated over the current activity in production. With a total volume of better than 340,000 units for February, March is beginning with a projected rise in schedules that promises between 400,000 and 425,000 vehicles as the output for the month.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 2. -- Many dinner parties were given tonight before the performance of "Post Revel," sponsored by the Leonard S. Morange Post, American Legion, at the Siwanoy Country Club here.

LONDON, Feb. 10. HOW badly, in England, we need a Theatre Guild or an organization of the same kind, adapted to our national virtues and follies! We have publishers of the same rank and quality who, when an artist of genuine distinction writes a book, publish it in all honor, whether or not they think that this particular book will make money for them.

Everybody is talking Youth nowadays. The leaders of the Republican party say quite openly they must win the youth of the nation or perish. The fashion editors and style experts coming back from Paris say youth is the keynote of the Spring styles.

THIS new book by Dr. Knopf makes an interesting sequence to her former work, "The Art of Being a Woman," although it is very different in both viewpoint and content. The first volume, which appeared two or three years ago, was a generalized, broadly based study of the fundamentals of woman's nature and life in Western civilization.

The Republic of Colombia, in the appointment last week of Miguel Lopez Pumarejo, brother of the President, as Minister to the United States, has taken one of the first definite steps under its present administration to consider the external debt situation at an early date, Lawrence E. de S. Hoover said yesterday as secretary of the executive committee of the Joint Colombian Bondholders Committees.

AN exciting tale of those times, distant yet full of significance for our modern world, when Carthage and Rome faced each other in a battle to the death, Francis Gerard's novel leaves the reader with no doubt whatever as to the side with which he sympathizes.

A MAN and woman smartly dressed, descended the steps of a brownstone front in the upper Sixties, followed by a nurse carrying a baby. As they entered their car at the curb the woman, with a sudden, eager gesture, took the baby from the nurse and hugged it tenderly.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 2 (AP). -- Clicking off a brilliant 66, five strokes under par, for the second round, Paul Runyan, defending champion, set the pace for the field today in the annual Florida West Coast open golf, carding a 70, 66 -- 135 at the half-way mark.

Judging by the complaints coming in to Code Authorities, a bitter battle over all types of wage differentials in manufacturing codes will develop when Congress starts to discuss extension of the National Industrial Recovery Act, it was predicted here yesterday by code executives.

Outside of sugar and some metals, declines ruled yesterday in the markets of the Commodity Exchange, with transactions quite active for a short session. There were no important declines, however, and the undertone appeared firm at the close.

PROFESSOR RICHARDS is one of the foremost of the literary critics whose approach to letters is psychological. In this book he gives a complete analysis of Coleridge's critical works as the first to interpret the actual psychological processes of imagination, attempting to reconcile the seeming contradictions in Coleridge's own words, and asserting, against Professor Lowes, that, for Coleridge, imagination and fancy were two different activities of the mind.
With an entry of sixteen teams that includes many foreign riders making their debut here, the fifty-eighth international six-day bike race will get under way tonight at Madison Square Garden.

THE future of Josef von Sternberg, a matter of speculation to the townspeople and of concern to Paramount, seems to have been settled. Following the preview the other evening of "The Devil Is a Woman" -- previously identified as "Caprice Espagnole" -- the studio indicated that no attempt would be made to hold Mr. von Sternberg and that, in spite of certain financial loss, the film will be released in its present form without retakes.

Archie M. Andrews, chairman of the board of directors of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, announced yesterday a sales plan adopted by his company which provides for payments to owners of Hupmobiles who supply the names of new buyers.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 2. -- A last-period rally led by Lou Freed, forward, gave the Cornell basketball team a 30-25 victory over Princeton in the university gymnasium today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

DALLAS, March 1. -- A sharp upturn in construction activity and sustained volume of merchandise distribution are the features of the current week in the economic situation in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. Valuations expressed in building permits issued in the principal cities are the largest for any week since the middle of 1931.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Although exact information was not available, estimates in government quarters today indicated that persons on Federal payrolls last month, or who had received payments by virtue of the FERA, the AAA and the PWA laws, exceeded 17,600,000.

Entries totaling 110 have been made for the Kentucky Derby, best known horse race in America, scheduled to be run on May 4 at Churchill Downs in Kentucky, it was announced yesterday. The entry is the smallest since 1922 but the eligibles include every juvenile of last year which won top class ranking with the exception of Balladier.

CAMRRIDGE, Mass., March 2. -- The gravitational pull of the moon apparently creates tides in the solid earth which change the distance between North America and Europe as much as sixty-three feet, according to Dr. Harlan T. Stetson, visiting professor at the Harvard Institute of Geographical Exploration, and Dr. A.L. Loomis of the Loomis Laboratory at Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

LONDON, March 2. -- David Lloyd George followed up today his telephone call of last night with a friendly letter to Prime Minister MacDonald, gladly accepting the invitation to submit to the Cabinet his detailed schemes for a "New Deal."

PITTSBURGH, March 2. -- Andrew W. Mellon's attorneys said today that he would accept full responsibility on the witness stand for the 1931 income tax return which his employes prepared for him and which the government charges was designed to defraud the Treasury Department he formerly headed.

An isolationist policy based primarily upon economic nationalism was urged for the United States yesterday by Herbert Agar, author and former honorary attache of the American Embassy in London, at a luncheon meeting of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Leaders of the drive for regulation of utilities holding companies said today the administration contemplated a method under which holding companies that could show that their operations were in the public interest would not be abolished.

At 9:30 o'clock last night a friendly discussion between Vincent Padula and Augustino Chestori in the former's wine and liquor store at 421 Park Avenue, near Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, was brusquely interrupted.
HANOVER, N.H., March 2. -- Dartmouth defeated Princeton's sextet tonight in a Quadrangular League game, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Hailing a "great change" in the country's "thinking," to the end that "imperceptibly we have come to recognize that government has a responsibility to defend the weak," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has reviewed the first two years of the Roosevelt administration, whose anniversary will be Monday.

THE Associated Press last week spread abroad the gloomy news that some day the moon will come closer, and this on the strength of a lucid little article by Dr. Seth B. Nicholson in one of the excellent leaflets issued from time to time by the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.

Domestic bonds on the Stock Exchange ruled generally firm during the brief trading period yesterday. High-grade railroad issues gained ground, as did similarly rated public utility and industrial bonds. Lower-grade corporation issues, however, were irregular.

The concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, offered as a novelty the concerto for violoncello by Nicholai Berezowsky, with Gregor Piatigorsky as soloist. The program moved in a steady crescendo of effect from the classic composition of the pre-Haydn era to the superb concluding performance of Richard Strauss's "Don Quixote."

IT is no exaggeration to say that the Crippen murder case is without parallel in the annals of crime; which, no doubt, explains why Mrs. Meadows chose it as the subject of her novel, "Doctor Moon." Filson Young, in the preface to his report of the trial held in the Old Bailey Criminal Court, London, at the end of 1910, says "such a story can only be understood by the aid of the imagination."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 2. -- Entering an annulment to the contract for transfer of transmission' lines in North Alabama, Judge W. I. Grubb in Federal District Court drew up his final decree today in the suit of preferred stockholders of the Alabama Power Company against the Tennessee Valley Authority. He will sign it Monday.

ITS timeliness adds to the historical and religious interest of this new book by Dr. Walsh (who already has to his credit a long list of works, historical, philosophical, religious) for its help to celebrate the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Jesuit Order and the 300th of their landing with Lord Baltimore in Maryland.
With the Federal income tax deadline less than two weeks away, prospective taxpayers should begin to give serious thought to the preparation of their returns.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP). -- Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared today that war is closer to the United States than at any time since 1917.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- Yale's basketball team tonight broke Brown University's winning streak of ten games, scoring by 43 to 33. Yale led, 19 -- 13, at half-time.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N J., March 2. -- Blair Academy's well-rounded team won the fifteenth annual Rutgers interscholastic swimming meet today, piling up a total of 30 points and dethroning Lawrence-ville, the 1934 winner. Trenton High was second with 22 points and Columbia of South Orange third with 11.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 2. -- Yale University's mermen captured their one hundred and thirty-eighth consecutive dual meet and annexed the championship of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association for the eleventh straight year by routing Navy, 51 to 20, today.

A HUBSMING BIRD sings. The notes rise higher and higher. Suddenly they seem to stop. Yet the bird's mouth remains wide open as if he were still pouring forth melody in full-throated ease. There is but one conclusion. The bird is still singing, but at a pitch inaudible to our crude ears.

More than 11,000 persons annually are the victims of homicide in the United States, according to Dr. Louis I. Dublin, statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who with Bessie Bunzel presents the figures in the March issue of the Survey Graphic.

Judging from editorial comments and letters to the press, it would appear that the full significance of the Public Utility Act of 1935 is clearly misunderstood. It is perfectly true that under the bill, if it becomes law, public utility holding companies will be regulated or exterminated, but the act has far greater significance.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 2 (AP). -- Fears for the safety of Daniel L. Thrapp, a young scientist missing in the Utah canyons for almost two months, were dispelled today when The Deseret News in a copyrighted story said that he was in camp 100 miles west of Bluff.

Net income of the Borg-Warner Corporation and subsidiaries in 1934 was $3,750,576 after depreciation, interest, development expenses, subsidiary preferred dividends, Federal income and excess profit taxes and other charges. This was equivalent after dividends paid on the company's preferred stock, to $3.06 a share on 1,150,919 no-par shares of common stock, exclusive of Treasury shares.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 2. -- Alyce Jane McHenry, 10, and her best-liked doll, Patty Lou, were taken for a tour of the Charlton Memorial Surgery in the Truesdale Hospital today at the child's request.

Coming with a rush in the latter stages, Manhattan deftly turned aside the challenges of the old guard to retain its Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field team championship at Madison Square Garden last night. At the end, it was not even close.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Announcement in London that Great Britain had taken the lead in international consultations looking to possible financial assistance to China by several powers, instead of by Japan alone, was received with gratification here but there was no formal comment.

Only the opposition of the Transit Commission is keeping the La Guardia administration from submitting to the Legislature at once a bill designed to expedite the closing of a deal for the city's purchase of the B.M.T.'s rapid transit properties at a gross price of $192,500,000, Samuel Seabury, special counsel for the city, announced yesterday.

THERE are white elephants in Palm Beach. By a curious turn of fate some of those massive Mediterranean mansions that dominated the colony a few years ago stand vacant now, although new houses are being built.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The loss by the New Deal during the past week of the initial engagements in two important legal contests has aroused conjecture as to the final outcome of these judicial battles in the Supreme Court of the United States.

VIENNA, March 2. -- Professor Ernst Freund, Viennese cancer authority, said in a lecture before the Austrian Cancer Society today that he had consistently maintained that cancers were malignant expression of a general rather than a local malady.

SOMETHING new in the way of amateur programs will be introduced over WEVD on Friday when Sigmund Spaeth, popularly known as "the tune detective," turns "talent detective." He will trail newcomers who show promise of a musical future.
AN international program will be presented at this year's May Festival in Florence, Italy, to be held April 2 to June 4 under the patronage of the Princess Maria of Piedmont.

Every section of the United States showed improvement in municipal tax collections in 1934 over 1933, according to a report of a nationwide survey completed yesterday by Frank H. Morse of Lehman Brothers.
