Questionnaires were sent to the finance officers of the principal cities in each section of the country and the 106 replies received showed that eighty-two cities, or 77.3 per cent, made gains in 1934, while twenty-four, or 22.7 per cent, reported decreases.

With stockholders attending in greater numbers and expressing themselves frankly and pointedly, annual meetings of companies are no longer perfunctory. The officers of various organizations have had this fact brought home to them, to their embarrassment in some instances, in the present "meeting season." Formerly, the meetings were attended chiefly by tongue-tied stockholders, if at all.

SEVENTEEN performances of nine Wagner music-dramas and eleven of six Mozart operas are announced for the festival in Munich, to open on July 24 and continue through Aug. 27. These will be supplemented by five performances of stage wroks by Richard Strauss and three performances, each, of three plays, Goethe's "Goetz Von Berlichingen," Schiller's "Maria Stuart" and Shakespeare's "King Lear."

MAZUBUKA, Northern Rhodesia, Africa, March 2 (AP). -- Intensive search of Northern Rhodesia's hush country failed today to uncover any trace of Lady Young, wife of the Governor General, and her physician, Dr. J. Kerby, whose airplane was forced down Thursday.
LOS ANGELES, March 2. -- An army aviator and a rodeo champion were killed in accidents incident to a storm which struck Southern California today.

SINCE this Spring bids fair to being one of the biggest suit seasons in years, accessories play a role of ever-increasing importance in the fashion picture. Short jacketed suits lead in popularity and suits that are made with long coats and matching skirts are next in line.

While traffic moved along eighty feet above them, William McNamara, 15 years old, of 133 West Sixty-seventh Street and Oscar Brown, 17, of 159 West Sixty-sixth Street, stood at 5 P.M. yesterday beneath the Riverside Drive viaduct at 134th Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- Nobody remembers such another all-New England meeting as took place in Washington a few days ago. There were present three Governors in person and three by proxy, almost the entire delegation in Congress, and an important group of cotton textile men.

WHEN a play achieves an outstanding and memo-table success it is practically inevitable, I suppose, that any succeeding play springing from the same source should be compared with it. Five years ago plays based on the triumph of young love over parental opposition could not escape comparison with "Abie's Irish Rose" (which was slightly fresher in the general mind than "Romeo and Juliet").

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Senators in jovial cloakroom mood have said of their colleague Senator Capper of Kansas that he is probably the only man in the United States who can keep both ears to the ground at the same time.

Of late highly offensive personal remarks by certain members of the House of Commons have passed without interference from the Speaker. In some cases the record has been mutilated. In one case the Speaker curiously minimized the offense. An honorable member called another honorable member a "toady" and a "lickspittle."

Charles Schwartz, business man who in 1930 purchased the "House in the Air," a large three-story dwelling supported by concrete pillars over a slope off Riverside Drive at 178th Street, was found dead at 8:30 o'clock last night in a garage at the side of the house.
SPRAYING high-power radio waves over an area shaped like a kidney bean, tomorrow WOR will introduce a new 50,000-watt transmitter.
NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (AP). -- J.P. Macey's Learoyd, seldom out of the money, mainlined his consistent form today in winning the mile handicap at the Fair Grounds.

A meeting of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company has been called for tomorrow, while the Metropolitan Opera Association is to meet later this week, following the session of the parent body, it became known yesterday.

MAYOR LA GUARDIA does not spell "culture" with a capital C. He believes that culture may be as much the possession of the average man as of the descendant of Governor Bradford. It may be spontaneously acquired, if the Mayor has read the signs aright, and that is why he is trying to make people enthusiastic about art and music centres, and perhaps a municipal theatre and opera.

THE present season has witnessed an unexpected recrudescence of interest in caricature in its legitimate place as art. The two great classics, Daumier and Toulouse-Lautrec, have been shown in galleries long known for their fastidious and exacting taste and their leaning toward the conservative.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, 20-year-old Kentucky champion, is the new holder of the South Atlantic golf championship, succeeding Miss Virginia Van Wie, three times national titleholder. In the eighteen-hole final at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today Miss Miley defeated Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., 5 and 4.

J.D. Ross, superintendent of the municipal light and power system of Seattle, Wash., and author of a recent plan for acquisition of all electric properties of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company by the city of Seattle, told members of the Public Ownership League of America at their Washington convention last week that the Federal power plant program covers only four or five inches of the yardstick that they are intended to provide.

In conjunction with the 100th anniversary of the founding of the St. Nicholas Society, which celebrated its centenary at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last week, a chronological record has been published in a volume of more than 130 pages.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 2. -- Frank Wiley and his brother-in-law, Martin Farrell, members of the Mais "Tri-State gang" whose leaders were rounded up in New York in January, were convicted here tonight of the murder of William Weiss, kidnapped Philadelphia racketeer.

JOHN P. MARQUAND, whose versatility as a writer of adventure stories is already well known to readers of popular magazines, has taken modern China as the setting of his latest novel. Here, however, is no realistic China of Pearl Buck's peasants and priests and war lords; no complex commercial nation such as Mrs. Hobart portrayed in "Oil for the Lamps of China."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- The Yale Dramatic Association will be host to the New England Theatrical Association next Tuesday and Wednesday nights in observing the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Yale association. About twenty colleges and universities are expected to send representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The wife of the President disclosed today that she had turned into philanthropy from her commercial radio broadcasts alone within 7 1/2 months almost half as much money as the government paid Mr. Roosevelt for a year's work.

MANCHESTER, England, March 2. -- British justice was tempered with mercy today and frail, ailing Mrs. May Brownhill, who put her imbecile son Denis "to sleep" with 100 sedative tablets and gas, returned home to her 70-year-old husband.

FOR the last century or two the Prince of Wales has usually been the accepted leader of men's fashions, but the time now seems to have come when the influence of the present Prince in these matters has seriously to be thought about.

AT present Germany is the most powerful broadcasting country in Europe. She has increased the power of her main transmitters to 100 kilowatts, the limit permitted by international agreement, and by the end of 1935 she will have in operation seven 100-kilowatt stations and one 120-kilowatt long-wave station, which will replace the present 60-kilowatt Deutschlandsender.

Beginning at a Winter resort in the Austrian Tyrol where all the English principals are vacationing, the real dirty work of this crime tale starts after characters and scene have been transferred to London. While in the Tyrol with his girl cousin, Hugh Winslow, a young stockbroker, perceives strong reason to suspect that Lightfoot, one of his fellow-countrymen at the resort, is passing forged British banknotes.
Dust storms of terrific intensity sweeping across the Great Plains during recent days have again focused attention on the growing menace of wind erosion and the problem of its control.

RITA WEIMAN'S first novel is a story of love and of the theatre, twin subjects traditionally glamourous. Since her past writings include plays as well as popular short stories, her theme would seem well chosen. The plot is sound, well constructed and entertaining.

PARIS. AMONG the many problems which beset the American film producers in exploiting their pictures on the international market is the question of what type of film will suit any particular country. Here in France there is an import quota which limits the number of American films that can be shown, and to that must be added the necessity of "dubbing" the product into the French language.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Five visiting hockey teams and the Lake Placid Athletic Club team are competing here this weekend in a series of games at the indoor ice arena for the Adirondack Association A.A.U. championship title. The winning team will represent this section of the State at the national playoffs in New York City some time this month.

Ernie Miller, the young man who testified during the trial of Bruno Hauptmann that he was with Miss Violet Sharpe on the night the Lindbergh baby was kidnapped, yesterday sought a permit to carry a pistol as a result of threats on his life.

A radio appeal for blood donors last night brought between 75 and 100 offers of blood for 6-year-old Frank Barnett, osteomyelitis patient at Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, it was reported at the hospital late last night.

TWO great liners, each at least 100 feet longer and 20,000 tons heavier than the largest ship now in service, are moving steadily toward completion. In June, the Normandie, flying the French flag, will make her maiden voyage; a year later, the Queen Mary, her British rival, will go into service.

Immediate enactment of sound legislation for unemployment insurance without waiting for action by the Federal Government is urged upon Governor Lehman and the State Legislature by the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
ONE MAN shows by two leading Hungarian painters, Vilmos Aba-Novak and Bela Ivanyi-Griinwald, are being held, until March 9, at the E. A. Silberman Gallery. These were reviewed last Tuesday.

PHI Beta Kappa tomorrow enters the State of Florida, the Alpha chapter of that scholarship fraternity being installed at the Florida State College for Women. During the 158 years of its history this fraternity has extended chapters to only 119 institutions, and the college so honored is the first State college for women in the South to receive Phi Beta Kappa recognition.

Catholics, especially Catholic students in colleges and universities throughout the country, should participate more actively in the political thought of the present day, Dr. Ross S. Hoffman, Professor of History at New York University, declared yesterday afternoon.

Play in the second round of the national squash tennis championship continued yesterday on the courts of the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street, with the remaining seeded stars, including the defending champion, Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, in action.

Samuel Marcus, counsel of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, was sworn in yesterday as special Assistant District Attorney to take charge of the grand jury, investigation, which will begin tomorrow, into conditions revealed at the recent bail-bond hearings before Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard in the policy racket, commercialized vice and the narcotic traffic.

REALIZING that no old-age pension legislation can ignore the progress that science has made in prolonging human life, the administration requested the Committee on Economic Security to present figures to show what the country must face if it is to support those who attain the age of 65 and who are unable to support themselves in gainful occupations.

ROME, March 2 (AP). -- The steamers Campidoglio and Antonietta made ready to sail from Naples for East Africa tonight with sixty-six officers and 545 men aboard, lending new emphasis to the Ministry of Colonies' prediction that this year will be "historic in the life of Italy's African colonies."
Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Deeming gave a dinner last night at the Astor. Among their guests were:

IN these crystalline stammerings of the French Renaissance, naif, candid, half-blinded, as it were, by partial tears. Marguerite of Navarre, author of the "Heptameron," celebrates the single love of her odd life, for her brother, Francis I, the subject of Mr. Hackett's long-awaited biography.
PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- Penn's smooth-working basketball team moved right to the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League standing tonight by overwhelming Columbia, 34 to 22.

To prevent a rank injustice, it was perhaps providential that an old sailor's eye fell upon a picture in your issue of Feb. 18 showing Secretary Ickes holding a bottle of rum, dredged up in York River off Yorktown, Va. The caption alleged that it came from a British frigate sunk in the Revolution and as such would be presented to the President.

A CHOICE company of readers has welcomed the successive books of Charles S. Brooks, with their savory mixture of essay, travel, leisurely observation, genial comment, humorous appreciation, colorful description, and anything else it occurred to him to put in, all blended and flavored by his own personality -- a kind of book that demands a special kind of reader, but makes a great hit when it finds its predestined audience.
LONDON, March 2. -- Three strong favorites for the English Cup made their exit from the big soccer competition in sixth round games today.

Police Commissioner Valentine of New York City wants the "Public Enemy Law" altered so that his policemen may arrest any person "of evil reputation" who "consorts with thieves and criminals or frequents unlawful resorts." The State Law Revision Commission is unanimously opposed to the change.
The New York University swimming team conquered Manhattan, 39 -- 32, in the final meet for both teams in the De Witt Clinton High School pool yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 2. -- Additional gains in trade and employment were reported in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Spring buying in department stores exceeded expectations, the volume being estimated at 15 to 20 per cent greater than a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP). -- Edmund Soussa of Egypt continued his drive toward the national amateur 18.2 Balkline billiards championship today by conquering Percy Collins of Chicago, 1934 champion, 300 to 215, in twenty-seven innings.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2. -- The Chamber of Deputies last night passed the government's financial projects, establishing a central bank of issue and completely reorganizing the country's entire banking and monetary systems.

CHANGELESS amid all changes, the Sphinx, gazing serenely into space, asserts again his age-long spell over the imagination of mankind. Around the most ancient and famous of monuments an army of excavators are wielding the spade and apparently with important results.
GENEVA, March 2. -- Paraguay has left the League but has left it standing. It seems from this close distance to be standing still in a posture arousing jeers or tears rather than cheers.
AIKEN, S.C. -- The month of March always marks the height of the season at Aiken, and activities of all kinds will soon be in full swing.

THERE are two sides to every question, of course, but where there is no question there is only one side. This would seem to be the case concerning the advice to pedestrians to walk against, rather than with, traffic on rural roads.

Pre-Lenten sermons will be preached in the churches today because next Wednesday the penitential season will begin. Easter will be April 21. More denominational churches than in previous years will join with the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran communions in observing Lent, particularly by holding services on Ash Wednesday.

THE outcry following THE TIMES' disclosure of Fritz Kreisler's authorshop of fourteen compositions which had been published and played for more than a quarter of a century as "arrangements" by him of the works of old masters has involved some curious interpretations of the acts of Mr. Kreisler and his publishers.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Seventy-fourth Congress, checking up today on the record as it completed its second month of existence, found that of 8,464 bills introduced in its two branches only nineteen had become law thus far and of these only seven were of major importance.

WITH Wilhelm Furtwaengler, Sir Thomas Beecham and Robert Heger announced as conductors, the opera season to open at Covent Garden, London, on April 29 and continue until June 15 will present in its cast many artists well known to patrons of the Metropolitan in New York.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 2 (AP). -- Senator Long started for Washington tonight after his special legislative session had ended with twenty-four new laws of his dictation completed.

Five of Europe's foremost figure skaters, the Misses Vivi-Ann Hulten, Maxi Herber, Idi Papez and Karl Zwack and Ernst Baier, arrived yesterday aboard the Hamberg-American liner Albert Ballin for their scheduled tour.

KINGSTON, Ont., March 2. -- The United States Military Academy hockey team, playing its twelfth annual game with the Royal Military College six tonight, held the local cadets to a 4-to-4 tie before 1,500 fans.

BERLIN, March 2. -- A few days ago the National Socialist party celebrated the fifteenth anniversary of its foundation at the Hofbrauhaus in Munich, where on Feb. 24, 1920, Adolf Hitler proclaimed the twenty-five theses of the National Socialist program.

ONE of the measures taken to open new opportunities for the people of the Virgin Islands is revealed in a report recently submitted to Governor Pearson by George H. Ivins, Director of Education. A vocational institute has been established in connection with the Agricultural Experiment Station on the Island of St. Croix to give training in agriculture, handicraft and the manufacture of rum and bay rum.

MADRID, March 2. -- While various proposals for old-age relief are being studied in the United States, it is interesting to note what Spain is doing about this problem. Five million persons today are drawing small pensions provided by the Retired Workmen's Law, which made old-age insurance compulsory when it was enacted in 1921.

MOSCOW, March 2. -- Mischa Botwinnik, chess champion of the Soviet Union, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia held first and second places in the international masters tournament today after nine games of the twelfth round were completed.

Accused of stealing clothes from a blind man while posing as his friend, Pasquale Mascia, 28 years old, who said he had no home, was in Brooklyn city prison yesterday awaiting trial by the Court of Special Sessions on a charge of petit larceny.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 2. -- Seven bronze medals, found beneath the dusty eaves of New Bedford's century-old Custom House, turned light today on a glowing page of this old whaling capital's history.

SOME of the 3 halfpence Australian stamps commemorating Captain Charles Sturt, one of the earliest Australian explorers, now have a multiplied value as a result of an action in 1930 by the postmaster at Lord Howe Island. The island is about 400 miles east of New South Wales but is governed by that State and has representation in the State Parliament.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 2. -- Charges before the Mack Utility Investigating Committee that the Westchester Lighting Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas System, had overvalued its properties by as much as 400 per cent drew today from Dr. Eugene H. Lehman, president of the Westchester Council of Utility Rate Committees, a stinging attack upon the utility company and its parent concern.

For some years prior to his recent death it had seemed to his public that the late J.S. Fletcher, able mystery craftsman though he was at his best, nodded frequently over his job. The tendency is evident in this posthumously published story of theft and accidental murder in an old English cathedral town, a favorite locale of the author's.
MIAMI BEACH. -- Of outstanding interest this week is the fifth international tropical flower show opening in Miami Beach Garden Theatre on Thursday and continuing through next Sunday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, cornpare6 a follows, Quot,tlon are in cents:
HANOVER, N.H. March 2. -- The Dartmouth basketball team strengthened its hold on third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating Harvard tonight, 37 -- 24.

THE detailed program of the Salzburg festival, July 27 to Sept. 1, as announced by the management, lists one or more performances for every day, with nine operas, eight orchestral concerts, four serenades, two chamber music events, five cathedral concerts, a performance of Mozart's Mass in in St. Peter's Church, and six representations each of "Everyman" and "Faust," as produced by Max Reinhardt.

THE detailed program of the Salzburg festival, July 27 to Sept. 1, as announced by the management, lists one or more performances for every day, with nine operas, eight orchestral concerts, four serenades, two chamber music events, five cathedral concerts, a performance of Mozart's Mass in in St. Peter's Church, and six representations each of "Everyman" and "Faust," as produced by Max Reinhardt.

LITTLE ROCK, March 1. -- Each branch of the Arkansas General Assembly has passed a package-store liquor bill, after overcoming Governor J.M. Futrell's preference for State stores, and winning his support to this means for raising revenues for the State's eleemosynary institutions.

With George C. Sherman turning in a brilliant game at back, the New York Athletic Club polo team completed an undefeated season in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League last night with a victory over the Winged Foot team, 7 to 4 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Charging that the Roosevelt administration's policies have "cracked up" and that recovery has not been aided by "its panaceas," Representative Fish of New York predicted in a radio speech over a National Broadcasting Company network tonight that a Republican President would be elected in 1936.

MANY people believe that Mr. Roosevelt has changed markedly in his first two years in the Presidency. A few observers have already published their notions that a new Roosevelt may be evolving from the experiences and troubles of his initial adventures in reform.

IN British Columbia waters there is fish called the oulachon, or candle fish, because, when partly dried, it can be used for lighting purposes. Attention was drawn to this fish in a recent report of the Canadian Department of Fisheries.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 2. -- Army closed its swimming season today by defeating Fordham, 49 to 31, in a dual meet. The cadets won first places in six of the nine events contested.

THE emphasis Mrs. Riddell's title belongs on the "I." For it is an extremely personal narrative in which the reader is apparently supposed to be much more interested in the detailed and intimate accounts of what happened to the author and what she did and said and thought and felt than in what she saw.

James Marshall, who was appointed to the Board of Education by Mayor La Guardia to replace Louis S. Posner, will bring to the board the views of a liberal progressive who is not expected to agree always with his colleagues.

James Marshall, who was appointed to the Board of Education by Mayor La Guardia to replace Louis S. Posner, will bring to the board the views of a liberal progressive who is not expected to agree always with his colleagues.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP). -- Edmund Soussa, tall cue artist from Egypt, won his first national amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship tonight, conquering Edgar T. Appleby of New York, 300 to 295, in a brilliantly contested match.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its opposition to five bills pending in the Legislature to amend the election law. These include three bills of Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, Democrat, which the union declared would aid Tammany, hamper independent nominations, and make party insurgency in the primaries difficult.

E. S. S. Carroll and T. H. Lawrence, Class A gunners, and P. Sleppy, a Class B entrant, finished on even terms in the competition for the High-Over-All cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each had 95 out of 100 targets.

Graduated from the boy-prodigy stage to that of the youthful artist, Oskar Shumsky reappeared in the Town Hall last night to repeat the success of his introductory violin recital a year ago. In long trousers and the full dignity of the early 'teens, he gave an altogether serious account of himself in music that demanded of him a considerable mastery of the technique of his art, if not the greatest measure of interpretative individuality.

An eight-State teletype alarm for a blond woman known only as "Mazie," described as a prospective witness in the grand jury inquiry into the policy racket, narcotics and vice, which is to begin this morning, was broadcast from police headquarters yesterday.

L. Sylvester May, chairman of the nominating committee of the New York Curb Exchange Partners Association, which also includes C. F. Cushing, Alan L. Eggers, Harold A. Rouse and Vincent R. McSherry, has notified members that the committee has selected names for governors and a succeeding nominating committee of the association, to be elected at the annual meeting on March 22 at 3:30 P.M.

The New York Americans yesterday defeated the Brooklyn Celtics, 5 -- 1, before a crowd of 3,500 at Starlight Park in the third round of the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association. The victors qualified for the semi-finals of the Eastern division.

PITTSBURGH, March 3. -- National production of steel ingots last week is estimated here to have been at the rate of 49 per cent of capacity. The high level was 55 per cent, in the two weeks ended on Feb. 9. Declines weekly since then have been 4, 1 and 1 point, respectively.

Three new buildings in the Rockefeller Center development program, including a thirty-eight-story office structure to be known as the International Building, are being rushed to completion for occupancy on May 1.

Colonel Daniel W. MacCormack, United States Commissioner General of Immigration and Naturalization, warned advocates yesterday of a "liberalized" immigration policy to consider the national interest before seeking any retreat from the present quota limits.

Bishop Francis John McConnell, Resident Bishop of the New York Area, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the celebration of the centennial of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Eighty-sixth Street and West End Avenue, that separate denominations must cooperate to exert the influence of the Christian church as a whole on the nation.

Since the World War, and more especially since the disastrous Greco-Turkish war, which resulted in the debacle of the Greek forces and the fall of Smyrna, Greece has undergone a series of revolutions.

Until the government of the United States places its efforts for recovery on an international basis there will be only passing and minor relief from the depths of depression, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, says in his annual report as director of the division of intercourse and education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

The "autocratic procedure" of legislative leaders in refusing to hold public hearings on the budget at Albany is criticized in a report of the committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday.

The Reading Company reports current assets of $13,709,843 and current liabilities of $9,231,750 at the end of 1934, compared with $12,090,096 and $7,816,891, respectively, at the close of 1933. Cash amounted to $4,131,365 against $3,080,287. In the year the long-term debt was reduced $1,551,446 to $134,740,621.
MEMEL, March 3. -- This tiny strip of land along the Baltic with its 148,000 inhabitants has become a cockpit in which the spurred German eagle is battling the Lithuanian fighting cock.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 3. -- Relief from morning practice was the nearest to a day of rest Manager Stengel would give his battery men today. They were on Tinker Field at 1:30 P.M. and went through a two-hour drill to wind up the first seven days of intensive preliminary training.
ATHENS, March 3. -- The revolt in Greece has spread to Macedonia and other areas, and, with the entire Island of Crete in the hands of the revolutionaries, it has assumed the dimensions of civil war.

Federal and State agents seized forty-one stills in the New York area in February, it was disclosed yesterday by John H. Flynn, Supervisor of the Federal Alcohol Tax Unit. The stills had a capacity of 14,120 gallons a day.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- What many Republicans think has been a lack of affirmative minority leadership in the Senate during the first two years of Roosevelt administration promises to become stronger and more partisan as Congress proceeds, Republican leaders said tonight.

The brevity of the greetings presented by the delegates of twenty-five countries at the celebration in Helsingfors of the centenary of the publication of the Kalevala, the Finnish epic into which the early folk ballads were gathered and published in 1835, was hardly in character with the poem itself.

MEXICO, D.F., March 3. -- Enthusiastically cheered today by several thousand specators, the Arlington (Texas) polo team won the deciding encounter of its series with the Mexican civilian stars, 10 to 6.
ALBANY, March 3. -- A picture of the finances of the State in preparation for the sale on Tuesday of $45,025,000 in bonds was given today by Morris S. Tremaine, Controller.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The status of important legislation now before Congress is as follows:

Several measures, or parts of one large measure, affecting organized labor, are before the Senate. The chief dispute is over the question of authorizing the President to give employment during the emergency at less than the prevailing rate of wages. Apparently the Senate leaders are unable to reach a decision of their own.

A group of United States Secret Service agents from the Custom House here, assisted by State troopers, raided an abandoned farmhouse on the Robert Goelet estate three miles from Monroe, N.Y., at 5 A.M. yesterday, seized a fully equipped coin counterfeiting plant and arrested three men.

So far as the city is concerned, the financial emergency that prompted the reduction of salaries of policemen and firemen in 1933 still continues and should prevent rescinding of the pay cuts, Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.
A strike of 30,000 elevator operators and other building service employes was called yesterday for 8 A.M. today in the Bronx by Local 10 of the Building Service Employes Union.

The teachings in many modern colleges were attacked yesterday by the Rev. Selden P. Delany, former Protestant Episcopal rector who is now a Roman Catholic priest, in an address before more than 700 members of the Newman Clubs of the New York Province at their annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore.

Miss Dorothy Forbes of the Camden Y.W.C.A., Middle Atlantic A.A.U. titleholder, captured two events in the weekly A.A.U. swimming meet at the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday. The fifty-yard free-style and the fifty-yard backstroke finals went to the New Jersey star.

Thirty-nine certificated mortgage issues having an aggregate face value of $7,750,000, were reorganized in time courts last week under the Shackno Law, Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick announced yesterday. Title and mortgage guaranty companies in rehabilitation had guaranteed the mortgages.

A nervous and irregular price movement featured business in the foreign exchanges last week. So widespread were the fluctuations that it was a rare exception for any unit to escape either achieving a new high price for the year, and beyond, or slump to a new minimum.

The United Licensed Officers' Association yesterday asked President Roosevelt to recommend the payment of higher wages to merchant marine officers employed by ship lines receiving mail contracts, subsidies or other forms of government aid.

A committee of the House of Representatives will begin hearings today on twenty-five bills, all dealing with the soldiers' bonus. One is the Patman plan to issue enough greenback currency to pay at once an obligation which does not lawfully fall due until 1945.

There's just one opening tonight, that being "Petticoat Fever," a play by Mark Reed in which Dennis King has been touring the East since before Christmas. It will visit the Ritz and Mr. King is accompanied on the excursion by Ona Munson, Doris Dalton, Leo G. Carroll, Leo Curley and several more.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, March 3. -- Three persons were killed and seven wounded here today when university students clashed with Red Shirts, youthful supporters of the government, at a student demonstration against socialistic education.
Tenement houses formed the bulk of New Jersey realty conveyed over the week-end.

DUBLIN, March 3. -- The two transport strikes have completely disorganized business here. Dublin is bereft of its entire tramway and bus services as the result of a dispute between the tramway workers' union and the Dublin United Tramways Company following the dismissal of a bus driver.

A campaign for $200,000 to establish a hospital for the free treatment of "depression shock" and other mental ailments as an extension of the body-and-soul clinic founded by Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles fourteen years ago was announced yesterday by Stanley Howe, Deputy Welfare Commissioner.

MOSCOW, March 3. -- The newspaper Izvestia publishes today a powerful article, signed "Viator" -probably written by Karl Radek, but in any case by some one with high authority and knowledge -which expresses in no uncertain terms Soviet anxiety over and disapproval of the British attitude toward Germany in general and toward the Eastern European pact proposal in particular.
CRANLEIGH, Surrey, England, March 3. -- The text of the Act of Abdication signed by King Prajadhipok of Siam follows:

ATHENS, March 3. -- Greek Government planes bombed the home in Crete of former Premier Eleutherios Venizelos tonight in a grim effort to stamp out a fast-growing revolt which had spread to Thrace and Macedonia on the mainland.

In the Fall of 1933 I was invited by the Soviet Government to go to Moscow to advise with it as to the best methods to develop cultural relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, such as I had been instrumental in developing with many other European governments.

This business of having to obey five chaperoning sisters proved a bit trying for Dorothy Anne Murphy yesterday afternoon. As a consequence she undertook a half-mile stroll, which the police in Jersey City -- traffic being what it is -- considered nothing short of miraculous for a child of 2 years, going on 3.

The defense fund for Bruno Richard Hauptmann was increased by $1,200 in Passaic, N.J., yesterday by about 1,000 persons who heard Mrs. Anna Hauptmann plead for money which would aid her husband, she said, in getting a new trial.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 3. -Sverre Fredheim of Minneapolis, soaring out over the giant Ecker Hill slide for distances of 158 and 181 feet despite a severe crosswind, captured first place in the national Olympic ski jumping tryouts today.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

With the President's employment program being discussed by many Senators as if nothing but great detached moral principles were involved, the National Industrial Conference Board has done a useful service in pointing out what various types of program would cost.

A national advisory council has been formed to aid the American Veterans Association in decisions affecting its major policies, it was announced yesterday by Donald A. Hobart, National Commander. The council represents a cross-section of the country and includes twentyseven persons from New York City.

The business upswing which began last October is leveling off, the National City Bank says in its monthly letter, published today. When all figures for February are in, it is probable that they will show little or no gain in productive activity over the January rate, the bank adds.

Yale's fine hockey team stands within one victory of a straightgame triumph over Harvard and the championship of the Quadrangular League. The splendid defensive play of the Elis throttled Harvard's somewhat stronger attack in the Boston Garden Saturday night and enabled Yale to win by 3 to 2 in overtime for its fifth straight league victory.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Speculators who had been active on the buying side of corn for several weeks closed out their lines last week, as those who had profits were dissatisfied because of the limited general demand in most quarters of the country, and took profits. Cashlprices weakened in the closing days, Iand there was liquidation of futures Iby large local speculators who hadfavored the selling side for severalweeks.

With the tax levy budget enlarged to $553,433,000 and the basic tax rate fixed at $2.71 on each $100 of assessed valuation, city finances present several paradoxes. While the basic rate is fifteen points higher than last year, the total burden on real estate is actually slightly lower.
Race prejudice was condemned by two members of the Protestant clergy of New York City in their sermons yesterday morning.

PITTSBURGH, March 3. -- With the hearing of Andrew W. Mellon's appeal from the government's demand that he pay $3,089,261.24 in additional taxes and penalties for 1931 entering its third week tomorrow, attorneys in the case predicted today that it might last another month.
ROME, March 3. -- Details of the Italian Government's arrangements to replace the temporary quota system for imports that has been in force in Italy since Feb. 16 were revealed today.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Liberal selling of Argentine oats last week by importers who had bought cargoes from leading producing sections of Europe readily satisfied demand, and the close was 1/4 cent a bushel lower for May oats at 50 3/8 cents, July finishing 1/8 cent higher at 43 5/8 cents, with September 1/2 cent higher at 41 1/2 cents.

Defeating the visiting team of the Marshall Chess Club by the surprisingly one-sided score of 6 to 0, with two games unfinished, the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday successfully defended its right to the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League at its headquarters in the Hotel Alamac.

Mayor La Guardia's committee on city planning will submit to him today a report recommending that the tracts of land on Welfare Island, soon to be abandoned by the Department of Correction, be transferred to the Department of Hospitals.

A lottery that has an estimated "take" of $2,000,000 a week in the metropolitan area alone and that extends throughout the country has been operating for years with only slight hindrance from the police, persons familiar with it asserted yesterday.

Despite the social and economic ravages of the depression, health conditions in New York State never have been better and the mortality rate continues to fall, according to a report made yesterday by Dr. H. Jackson Davis, director of medical care for the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

ADDIS ABABA, Abyssinia, March 3 (By Wireless). -- The earnest desire of Abyssinia for peace with Italy was stressed by Emperor Haile Selassie in a long interview of international importance. This supreme ruler of the last remaining realm where the black man lives in independence stated fully the standpoint upon which Abyssinia relies in her dispute with Italy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3. -- While the Westchester Lighting Company was placing write-ups of 78 to 400 per cent in its property valuations, as disclosed by the Mack committee investigating public utilities, it adopted an electric rate schedule 400 per cent higher than ones used elsewhere in territory of similar character, the Westchester Council of Utility Rate Committees charged today in a statement.

Many tables have been reserved for the card party in behalf of the Leake and Watts Orphan House, which will take place this afternoon in the Seaglade of the St. Regis under the auspices of the Educational Auxillary of the organization. Proceeds will further the work of the orphan home, founded thirteen years ago for the purpose of aiding in the completion of the high school education of young persons over 16 years of age.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Speculation in German quarters upon the trend of the conversations that will engage Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Berlin this week takes full cognizance of the significance of that meeting and the immediate effect on European relationships.

Feodor Chaliapin, who gave what was announced as his only New York recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, remains one of the big individualities of our time. When he stepped out on the stage for the start of his concert, the huge audience received him with an enthusiastic ovation.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, in a radio address yesterday, expressed the opinion that "the most important challenge today to the ingenuity of the inventor, to the technology of the fabricator, to the wisdom of the financier, is to bring within the means of the average man a more comfortable and efficient home than now exists or can now be produced at any cost."

What is the matter with business? Lack of confidence. Why is there lack of confidence? Because business depends on precise reasoning and experience. Experience is only valuable if the same economic laws are allowed to function as in the past and if temporary artificial laws do not upset natural laws.

Brewing Corporation of Canada -Three months ended Jan. 31: Net loss after depreciation and charges, $79,994, against a loss of $219,149 in the same period last year; operating profit, $481,470, against $239,690. Twelve months ended Jan. 31: Net profit, $4,241, against net loss of $325,794 in the preceding year.

The Municipal Art Commission, arbiter in all matters artistic as far as city property is concerned, has decided that the statue, Civic Virtue, is not to be demoted from a place of prominence or exiled to an obscure part of a borough other than Manhattan, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public seven new securities registration statements representing proposed issues of $5,098,512.26. Commercial and industrial issues make up $3,329,508 of the total.

A master plan for the development and rezoning of New York is recommended for adoption by the city in a report to be presented Thursday to the State Chamber of Commerce. The report says the plan should provide for the rehabilitation of blighted areas and for large-scale, low-cost housing projects.

Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, announced yesterday the election of nine new members to the graduate faculty of the University in Exile, thus doubling its present membership.

Now in his fifth season as a concert pianist, Sidney Sukoenig, son of a New York cantor, played a program that was in some of its details an unconventional one, before an applausive audience in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Galilei and Frescobaldi were two names at the head of his list of composers that are rarely encountered in recital rooms.

Delay in the construction of adequate transportation facilities between Staten Island and Manhattan and Brooklyn is holding back the proper development of the Port of New York, according to a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia and made public yesterday by Eugene F. Moran, chairman of the rivers, harbors and piers committee of the Maritime Association.

All who aided the very Rev. Gabriel Ginard, rector of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Theresa of Avila, Broadway and 187th Street, which was damaged by fire Thursday morning, were thanked by him yesterday, at a mass celebrated at the James Torrens Democratic Association Headquarters, Broadway and 182d Street.

Conditions on the local commodity futures markets were mixed last week. With the gold-clause decisions fading into the background and the sharp decline in sterling too recent to have caused any definite market results, most staples appeared to be governed by their particular technical condition.

Two American citizens, one of them a baby born on March 1, were ordered to Ellis Island last night when the liner President Harding of the United States Lines reached New York from Hamburg, Le Havre, Southampton and Queenstown, two and one-half days late, after a stormy mid-Winter crossing.

Activity in the wholesale markets last week was featured by the large volume of requisitions for Spring merchandise received by mail from buyers who were here during recent weeks to view the new offerings. Although there was also a noticeable increase in the number of reorders received, particularly in the garment division, adverse weather conditions in various sections of the country retarded sales to some extent.

Flashing a brilliant passing attack in the final half after being held even during the first, the French Rugby Club rallied to defeat the Pilgrims Rugby Club at the Gas Companies Athletic Field in Astoria yesterday, 20 to 3.

The sight of a watchman staring through the front window of a bank in South Ozone Park, Queens, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, startled a young man from concentration on a safe in the rear of the bank and caused him to run from a rear door, leaving his shoes and several burglar tools behind.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- On the assumption that "the fostering of collective bargaining should be the keystone of the government's labor policy," the Twentieth Century Fund, of New York, today presented to President Roosevelt a four-point program to stabilize industrial relations.
DETROIT, March 3. -- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Americans, 3 -- 1, tonight in a colorless National Hockey League match. A slim crowd of 3,500 saw the game.
Members of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal faiths were charged yesterday with practices for Lent, which begins on Wednesday.
Organization of the Council for Moderation, with a program for a ten-year campaign of temperance education, concentrated in the beginning in the metropolitan area, was announced yesterday.

Professor Richard Gottheil, head of the Oriental department of Columbia University, was made an honorary fellow of the Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences last night at a convocation at the Jewish Centre, 131 West Eighty-sixth Street. Eleven other men were inducted as members.

Housing properties that can be altered for small apartments are proving attractive to buyers in the Yorkville area, according to Andresen Bremer, brokers. The latter, in conjunction with Arthur Lichtner, has just sold for the estate of Gustav Levor to a client of Samuel Sason the five-story double flat on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 215 East Eighty-ninth Street.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Reapportionment, unemployment insurance and pari-mutuel legislation will dominate the Albany scene this week.

A marked increase in the leasing of space in business buildings in this city was indicated in reports made by realty brokers and managing agents over the week-end. The large volume of renting in this branch of the real estate market covered a wide area.
Dr. Emerson Gilbert, a spiritualist, could not produce a ghost in his seance room on the tenth floor of 200 West Fifty-fourth Street last night for Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein.

LONDON, March 3. -- Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon will fly from London to Berlin Thursday upon what is perhaps the most important mission to the German capital undertaken by a British statesman since the memorable visit of Lord Haldane in 1912, to which it bears a curious analogy.

The recent rise in the price of Indian cotton relative to that of American staple as a consequence of reduced estimates of the Indian cotton crop, indicates an increase in consumption of American cotton in foreign countries in coming months, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

FISHKILL, N.Y., March 3. -Dashing down the slippery slide at breakneck speed and then soaring twice to record marks, sturdy Ottar Satre carried off the first-place laurels in Class A of the invitation ski-jumping tournament staged by the Norway Ski Club on its hill in the Fishkill Mountains today.

Gains of 5 to 8 points were recorded last week in cotton futures market here, with activity heavy on the early days owing to transference of contracts from March into later months. Trading then became dull as the uncertainty of the domestic cloth market affected buyers of cotton.

LONDON, March 2. -- The continued weakness of sterling is rather overshadowing the financial markets here. In terms of francs, the pound has reached a new low record of 71.70, and it automatically follows that it is also the lowest against other European gold currencies since their post-war revaluations.
A Miami physician, Dr. Fuad Hanna, was arrested upon his arrival here yesterday when a patient he had treated accused him of attempted extortion.

BOSTON, March 3. -- A guarantee that there will be no inflation under President Roosevelt during this administration or any succeeding Roosevelt administration was issued today by Donald R. Richberg, leading executive of the NRA, who came here to defend the New Deal in an address at the Old South Forum.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Another of the scientific world's "problems" dissolved today with the announcement by a pair of Chicago scientists that they had perfected a method of producing liquid copper after eight years of private research.

THERE were about 60,000 out to see us in one game in Osaka," said Don Vernon Gomez, the now satisfied senor of the Yankee pitching staff, "and 50,000 of them came on bicycles. Know how those autos are parked around the Yankee Stadium at a big game? That's the way the bicycles were stacked around the park at Osaka.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3. -- Trading in contracts on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange last week was light and confined mainly to moderate trade-buying and pricefixing, liquidation by tired longs and more or less ring scalping. The market lacked incentive, the general disposition being to hold off until something definite is known as to preparations for the new crop and plans of the government for control of it.
A two-hour broadcast, tracing the history of the New Deal, is scheduled for this afternoon, starting at 2:30 o'clock, over WABC and a nation-wide network.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -President Roosevelt completes tomorrow two years of his administration. The day will be used by the Cabinet and other members of the Democratic party in nation-wide radio addresses reviewing the accomplishments of the administration.

BERLIN, March 2. -- The official campaign for interest rate reduction reached a further stage this week with the conversion of the remaining 6 per cent Reich, State, provincial and municipal loans to a 4 1/2 per cent basis, followed by an immediate reduction of bank-interest rates.

The Chilean Debt Commission which arrived a few days ago called attention to the fact that Chile has in the past scrupulously fulfilled its obligations and says that its country is an honest debtor. It proposes to reduce the interest on the dollar loans from 6 and 7 per cent to one-half of 1 per cent per annum.

VATICAN CITY, March 3 (AP). -Pope Pius, prelates said today, is summoning a secret consistory April 1, to be followed by a public consistory four days later for final approval of the canonization of Thomas More, Henry VIII's Chancellor, who lost his head because he opposed Henry's divorce and marriage to Anne Boleyn.

Figures based on an independentconsumer survey of fifteen cities in the United States, which altogether account for $2,000,000,000 annually in retail sales, showed that more than 87 per cent of the families in these cities regularly read a newspaper, it was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The annual "Follies" show of the Dickenson High School of Jersey City, scheduled for early Spring, will be one to rate high on any one's white list, according to current developments. The exhibition of hosiery will be cut to a minimum and the script will be carefully censored.

BUENOS AIRES, March 3. -- Argentina increased its cotton production 33 per cent in 1934, compared with 1933, according to a report by the Bureau of Rural Statistics published today. This was the result of the "plant more cotton" campaign carried on by government agencies and the newspapers when it was learned that the United States Government was trying to reduce American cotton acreage by 25 per cent under the New Deal.

There is sentiment current in Washington to seek the aid of religion as an added force for recovery by setting apart a nationwide day of prayer, the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.

BERLIN, March 2. -- The Institute for Trade Research defends Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, against the accusation that his new plan has failed in its chief aim of preventing import surpluses. The institute insists that the recently unfavorable trade balances are due to disparities in dates and not to values of imports and exports.

Nearly 1,000 persons attending the first annual dinner of the Retail Kosher Meat Trade Code Authority last night at the Hotel Commodore heard Representative Emanuel Celler praise the NRA as having pulled the nation out of the "industrial doldrums."
S. S. Van Dine's next novel probably will be called "The Garden Murder Case." As planned now the scene of crime will be a penthouse garden, high above New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3. -The patio of their oceanfront residence, illuminated with colored lights and arranged with small flower-decorated tables, was the setting tonight for a large buffet supper preceded by motion pictures which Mr. and Mrs. Louis Santer Levy gave, honoring Mr. and Mrs. Grover A. Whalen.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Prices of hogs here advanced to $9.55 a hundredweight on Friday, that price being paid for one load of 230-pound butcher hogs. It was the highest level since October, 1930. There was a decline at midweek, followed by a rally, to $9.30 at the close. Theaverage for the week was $9.20,compared with $8.75 the previousweek and $4.55 a year ago.

Pressing a telegraph key in the White House, President Roosevelt will give the signal that will officially put into service WOR's new 50,000-watt transmitter at 3:30 P.M. today. Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey and Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark will head the speakers' list of this dedicatory program, which will be on the air for an hour.

A new gallery enters the local lists today. It is the Bignou Gallery, on the eighteenth floor of the RollsRoyce Building, 32 East Fiftyseventh Street; its proprietor, the well-known Paris dealer, Etienne Bignou, who has sold canvases that have entered important American museum and private collections, and who in the past has organized exhibitions of French painting for the Knoedler Galleries.
Eight persons were killed and more than a score injured yesterday in automobile accidents in and around New York. Two other persons died in hospitals of injuries suffered earlier in the week.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Lard stocks here decreased 3,750,000 pounds in February and are 61,750,000 pounds, compared with 115,300,000 a year ago. Aggregate lard stocks at seven leading cities are 72,364,000 pounds, compared with 134,900,000 pounds a year ago and 31,240,000 pounds two years ago.

Fenimore Cooper's story of early America, "Last of the Mohicans," will be brought to the screen by Reliance Pictures. Merle Oberon has been named for the leading feminine role. The film will be produced by Edward Small.

ROME, March 3. -- Despite Premier Mussolini's campaign for more population, despite all his propaganda, subsidies, gifts and decrees, Italy's birth rate is down heavily since 1922, the year of the advent of Fascism, figures revealed today.

Penn's successful bid for the pace-setter's position in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League provided the highlight of last week's competition in the annual title race, which found every member of the circuit in action at least once. Columbia was toppled from the lead, which it had held since early in February, when it lost to the Quakers, 34 to 22, at the Palestra Saturday.

Yale's 51-to-20 victory over Navy on Saturday gave the Elis the championship of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association for the eleventh year in a row and enabled them to retain their unbeaten record. They have not lost in dual competition in 138 consecutive meets.

BASTIA, Corsica, March 3. -- Andre Spada, the last Corsican bandit will go on trial here tomorrow before a jury of twelve of his island countrymen on seven counts charging eleven murders and two assaults with intent to kill.

A taxicab driver was shot and killed early yesterday morning in what the police charged was an attempt to silence a prospective witness in the sweeping inquiry into the policy, commercialized vice and narcotic rackets scheduled to be undertaken this morning by the March grand jury.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A financing program calling for the refunding of $1,850,000,000 of thirdcalled Fourth Liberty loan 4 1/4 per cent bonds and $528,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent Treasury notes at interest rates without precedent for comparable Government securities was announced today by the Treasury Department.

A good many people wondered, in the course of the Flemington trial, whether the tactics of the chief counsel for the defense were always the wisest. The same doubt attaches to Mr. REILLY'S public remarks since the trial.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,565,585,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
C.G. Blackwell Co., Inc., of Denver, Col., members of the Denver Stock Exchange, have opened an office at 42 Broadway under the management of S. L. Forst.
The writer of this letter is an oldtimer who is hopelessly muddled over the ethics, economics, benefits and results of the New Deal.

For a coach, Pete Waters has never been a particularly articulate dressing room orator. And when his Manhattan College track team began to collapse all around him early in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, Waters was able to do little more than chew nervously on his cigar.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 3. -The centre of attention in the Giant encampment today, though scarcely a wheel turned, was Dick Bartell, the peppery little shortstop for whose services The New York club parted with slightly more than $100,000 in cash and players this Winter in order to wrench him away from the Phillies.

New York City had a total funded or fixed debt of $2,308,116,020 outstanding on Dec. 31, 1933, according to a summary of the financial statistics of the city corporation for the fiscal year ended on that date, made public yesterday by the Bureau of the Census. Of that amount$1,172,137,551 was for public serviceenterprises and investments.

LONDON, March 2. -- It is reliably estimated that the gold holdings in London, excluding the reserve of 75,600,000 in the Bank of England, amount to about 30,000,000. Thanks to the more active state of trade in the last year, note circulation of the Bank is being maintained at high levels.
As if he were just an ordinary rookie and not the mighty home run king, Babe Ruth bade adieu to New York yesterday, all "pepped up" over his new job.

Congratulations on your intelligent editorials on the tariff. At a time when public indifference and ignorance about this question are widespread you have continued to sail under the banner of freer trade among the nations. Since the days of Grover Cleveland it has been the policy of your paper.

PARIS, March 2. -- The gold which has arrived at the Bank of France recently came partly from neighboring countries but chiefly from London, as the British equalization fund sold gold to the Bank of France in order to obtain francs with which to intervene on the market in support of sterling.

Interesting facts about New York's commercial buildings are contained in a report on the nonresidential survey of the Real Property Inventory made public yesterday by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 3 -In the first dinghy racing of weeks, with the harbor free from all ice, the Larchmont sailors had their hands full today with a puffy northwest wind. It would have been fine going for large craft, but the small ones found it difficult. Two boats capsized and two had their rudders broken.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 3 (AP). -- The story of how a Mexican youth, digging in the sands of Santa Margarita Island, uncovered a chest of supposed buccaneer treasure was told here today by crew members of the tuna boat Amor da Patria.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 3. -- Completing its legislative program for the present year, the State Law Revision Commission, of which Dean Charles K. Burdick of the Cornell Law School is chairman, has submitted directly to the Legislature eleven bills, the first providing for tightening of the perjury law.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Despite a stubborn Congress and court attacks on his New Deal projects, President Roosevelt today headed into the second half of his administration apparently confident that his major objectives and the country's good are synonymous.

That freckled tatterdemalion, Huckleberry Finn, ran a close second to his creator as a motif in 129 posters executed by New York high school students to be placed on exhibition today at the Museum of Natural History in connection with the Mark Twain Centennial.

MOSCOW, March 3. -- Fulfilling the prophecies of the experts and critics to the letter, Dr. Emanuel Lasker of England, former world chess champion today scored his adjourned game from the ninth round with Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, who took his title from him fourteen years ago at Havana.

DETROIT, Mich., March 3. -- Asserting that "you cannot have a new deal without a new deck," the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, radio priest, declared in his regular Sunday broadcast that every card dealt from the deck of the Roosevelt New Deal had been marked for "high finance" and "big business."

Demolition of the fifty-year-old extension of the Manhattan terminal of Brooklyn Bridge, now projecting over Park Row, Centre Street and part of City Hall Park, will be started soon after March 31, according to an announcement yesterday by Commissioner F. J. H. Kracke of the Department of Plant and Structures.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 3. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, prince of speed, went thundering up to the very edge of his 272-mile an hour record today, but old davil beach, the villain in the piece, still pursued him.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Father Coughlin's assertions in his radio address this afternoon that the New Deal had worked chiefly to the benefit of big business and big finance was generally termed by Democratic Senators and members of the Cabinet as too absurd to dignify with a reply.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 3. -The Leipzig Fair opened here today with nation-to-nation barter deals and government control of trade dominating the thoughts of both buyers and sellers. The fair, with 4,000 more foreign visitors than last year, and all the floor space of the great exhibition hall taken, promises to have considerable success.
Captain Herman Gray, owner of the famous fishing boat Orca, arrived in town Saturday on a flying trip from Palm Beach.

Police returns from the Chicago primary last week show that nearly 47 per cent of the registered vote was cast. Yet the weather was nasty. There had been no real contest. The result was certain. There had been no mass meetings. Those old familiar faces, "lethargy" and "apathy," seemed to be everywhere.

The first collective area agreement for this city involving maintenance and repair workers to be made part of a code has been approved by President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday. The agreement is between the Association of Master Painters and Decorators and District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers.
The first Sunday of March arrived in a lamb-like spirit yesterday with winds tempered by brilliant sunshine and moderate temperatures.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A test of leadership probably unequaled in many years because of the nature and number of issues involved faces the administration as President Roosevelt begins tomorrow his third full year in the White House and the Seventy-fourth Congress actually starts its third full month of operation.
CRANLEIGH, Surrey, England, March 3. -- King Prajadhipok of Siam abdicated at 1:45 yesterday afternoon. His abdication became effective the moment he affixed his signature to the formal act.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Fluctuations in sterling exchange, conflicts of opinions as to the future of gold in leading foreign markets and uncertainty as to weather and crop conditions in the Winter wheat sections of the Southwest, where rain is needed generally, are keeping grain traders most unsettled.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The grave condition of Oliver Wendell Holmes, 94-year-old retired justice of the Supreme Court, remained unchanged at a late hour tonight, with his physicians declining to predict the outcome.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 3 (AP). -- Solicitor Roland S. Pruett said today that testimony that Mrs. Elva Statler Davidson wept intermittently during a party with her husband and friends a few hours before her lifeless body was found in the family garage would be presented to a coroner's jury Tuesday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3. -- The Orange Blossom Special deposted a lot of Yankee baseball material when it arrived tonight at 5 o'clock. Manager Joe McCarthy, who joined the caravan at Washington last night, was in command of five young pitching hopefuls, assembled in New York and Baltimore.

Sixteen cyclists lined up on the banked track at Madison Square Garden last night and, after a few preliminary whirls around the saucer, shot away at a signal fired by Eddie Cantor to start the fiftyeighth six-day bicycle race.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 3 (AP). -Willie Macfarlane, the Scot from Tuckahoe, N.Y., who won the National Open championship in 1925, played subpar golf today to win the annual Florida West Coast Open title with a seventy-two-hole card of 282. With the crown went $450, first money.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Black-Connery bills imposing a thirty-hour week on industry were characterized by the American Liberty League today as based on "fallacious economic theories" and as of "questionable constitutionality."

ATHENS, March 3. -- An attempt to kill General George Kondylis, Minister of War and leader of the National Radical party, by bombing his home here during the night showed that the revolt had not been crushed in Athens itself, despite government assurances.

The late Speaker Rainey in an address on June 14, 1933 at Grove City, Pa., referred to the First Liberty Loan Act of April 24, 1917. A large part of the proceeds of this loan was advanced to foreign governments who gave the United States their bonds in equal amount.

LONDON, March 2. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of commodity prices in Great Britain, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Feb. 27 at 66.4, against 66.2 a fortnight before, 66.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, when the gold standard was abandoned.

Acts or scenes from five operas, Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," Verdi's "Otello," Bellini's "Norma," Massenet's "Manon" and Wagner's "Die Walkuere," will be included in the special gala performance to be given at the Metropolitan on Tuesday evening, March 19.
More than 14,000 taxicab drivers invited former Mayor James J. Walker yesterday to lead them in their struggle for better wages and working conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -One of the most controversial measures of the New Deal, the Frazier-Lemke Mortgage Moratorium Law, was added by the Supreme Court today to the accumulating list of administration acts which it has slated for review.

LAUSANNE, March 4. -- Prince Ananda Mahidol, 11-year-old heir presumptive to the throne of Siam, went to the playground of his school here unconcernedly today and as usual participated in the games of his schoolfellows. The routine of his school life was unchanged by the abdication of his uncle, former King Prajadhipok.

The marriage of Princess Emanuela de Dampierre to Don Jaime, second son of former King Alfonso of Spain, is of great interest here because of the bride's many American connections. Through her mother, Princess Vittoria Ruspoli, she is the granddaughter of Princess Emanuele Ruspoli di Poggio Suasa, whose home in Paris is at 2 Avenue Elisee-Reclus.

The local theatre has become, to all intents and purposes, a Louis Bromfield repertory circuit. Last week it was "Times Have Changed." This week, and tonight, it is "De Luxe," a little matter written by the novelist in conjunction with John Gearon.

John Lasinski of the Long Island City Moose Club scored the biggest upset recorded in the semi-final round of the annual Golden Gloves tournament of The Daily News A. A. last night at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of more than 5,000 spectators.

LONDON, March 4. -- The British Government today announced a new defense policy. From this the only inference to be drawn is that it has no faith left in any of the various existing or contemplated pacts for the peace or security of either Europe or Asia.

PARIS, March 4. -- Opinion here is divided as to whether and to what extent the decline in value of sterling is voluntary, and if speculative, whether speculators are already oversold. It was noted that less business was done in pounds today than on last Friday, and also that without any apparent intervention by the British Equalization Found there was relative steadiness.

BREST, France, March 4. -- Police quoted a beautiful blonde woman arrested as a spy as saying today she came to Brest in the service of Germany, but fell in love with a young French naval officer and refused to carry out her mission.

The Columbia Spectator, in a news article yesterday, cited the case of a student holding seven jobs, including a FERA job, and living in a rent-free room in a college dormitory. In an editorial the paper called for "a full statement of university's policy on loans, scholarships and jobs.

Daniel L. Haynes, who plays the parts of Adam and Hezdrel in "The Green Pastures," which reopened last month at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre after an absence of five years, stood accused yesterday under an indictment handed up to Federal Judge John C. Knox of having made false statements in bankruptcy proceedings.

The strike of elevator operators and other service employees in the Bronx will go into effect tomorrow at 8 A.M., according to an announcement made last night by Louis Cooper, president of the Bronx organization of the Building Service Employees Union.

ALBANY, March 4. -- The fate of Mrs. Eva Coo, 46-year-old Otsego County roadhouse proprietress, convicted of the murder of her handy man, Harry Wright, on June 14, and now in Sing Sing, awaiting execution, rests with the Court of Appeals, before which tribunal arguments were made today by Maxwell and David Slade in her behalf.

The Treasury's most recent offer -consisting of more than two billion dollars in bonds and notes -- is entirely a matter of refunding older issues and will add nothing to the national debt. On the 15th of this month $528,000,000 in 2 1/2 per cent notes mature. The Government offers either to redeem them in cash or to give in exchange for them new notes bearing 1 5/8 per cent and maturing in five years.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Treasury's $2,400,000,000 refunding program, announced yesterday, is meeting a favorable reception, with the market acting "extremely well," Secretary Morgenthau said today. Officials are confident that the operation will be successful.

Alexander Korda, production head of London Films, announces through the local United Artists office that the screen scrip of "Elephant Boy," which Robert Flaherty is filming in India, is based on "Toomai of the Elephants," one of the principal tales in Rudyard Kipling's "The Second Jungle Book."

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP). -After being close but never a winner in his last five starts, Broadstep from D. Sodders's stable today led a field of older platers in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Amelia Earhart revealed today that her Pacific flight had given rise to a voluminous correspondence on babies, based apparently on a misunderstanding of a remark made by her husband, George Palmer Putnam, after her take-off from Honolulu.
The Citizens Budget Commission asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to oppose two bills pending in the Legislature that would revise the teachers' pension system at a cost to the city of $3,000,000.

Remarking that today is the first anniversary date of Alexander Woollcott's "While Rome Burns," the Viking Press notes that the book is entering its second year with a rate of sale almost equal to the peak months of its first year. It passed the 100,000th copy mark four days ago, on the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Viking Press.

Samuel Goldwyn plans to produce a yearly film revue, "The Goldwyn Follies," in which he will dramatize the important and interesting news events of the season, he announced yesterday. The producer is arranging with writers to prepare topical sketches for the first of the series, which he hopes to place in production in September.

President ROOSEVELT'S message to Congress about subsidies for American shipping has at least one great merit. It is frank and truthful. It tears away the devices and subterfuges by which the attempt was made to deceive the country into thinking that it had no ship subsidies, although in fact it has.

Pictures of New York, from the subways to the skyline, make up the first art exhibition under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia's Municipal Art Committee to be opened to the public today in Hearn's Department Store, Fourteenth Street.

LOUIS I. DUBLIN and BESSIE BUNZEL, in the March Survey Graphic, have performed a useful service in bringing together in comprehensive form the major facts that are statistically known or ascertainable about the American homicide record. As even the casually informed know, that record is a shameful one.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Modification of the pending 1935 Banking Act to vest final authority over open-market operations with the Federal Reserve Board instead of the special committee of five, as originally proposed by the administration, was urged upon the House Banking and Currency Committee today by Marriner Eccles, Governor of the Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Application for permission to extend for five years a loan of $7,000,000 due to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on April 8, and authority to borrow for five years an additional $5,000,000 to meet equipment trust obligations maturing this year was put before the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company.
ALBANY, March 4. -- The Nunan bill to require students to take oaths of loyalty to State and Federal Constitutions was passed by the Senate tonight by a vote of 34 to 10.

LONDON, March 4. -- Gold mines soared on the Stock Exchange today on the rise in the price of gold to a new high record of 148s 10d an ounce, following further pronounced weakness in the pound sterling. Kaffirs were outstandingly active. The market otherwise was dull.

VIENNA, March 4. -- Dr. Anton Rintelen's examination continued at the resumption today of his trial on charges of high treason in the Nazi putsch of last July. The former Minister to Rome had recovered from his exhaustion of Saturday and excepting for occasional attacks of weakness, following outbursts of indignation, he survived fairly well, considering his crippled condition, the ordeal of the second day's trial.

The lowest death rate in the history of the city is reported for 1934 by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, in the latest issue of the Quarterly Bulletin, published by the Department of Health. He also reports an increase in the birth rate during the last eighteen weeks of the year over the corresponding period the year before for the first time since 1929 and a decline in many diseases during the year.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- The prince of speed put his foot down all the way today, not on the throttle of hard-pressed old Bluebird, but upon continuance of record runs until Daytona's sands definitely improve.
Gold bullion on the open London market, in terms of British currency, 1s 11 1/2d higher at 148s 10d per fine ounce. Price before British suspension of gold payments on Sept. 21, 1931, was 84s 9 3/4d.

The city's responsibility for the negligence of Federal relief employes assigned to city projects was presented for judicial determination for the first time yesterday before Municipal Court Justice Nicholas M. Pette.

BERLIN, March 4. -- Germany's solution of her economic difficulties as revealed by the shrinking of foreign trade and her answer to the new depreciation of the dollar and the pound, which is shaking the European gold bloc, will be neither deflation nor devaluation but further import restrictions and the organization of her entire industry for a concerted drive for increasing German exports.

The Power Authority, in a special report to the Governor and the Legislature made public yesterday, presented a detailed analysis of the financial structure of the electric utilities in New York City.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Nine Manhattan parcels, including flats, dwellings and loft structures, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. The results were as follows:

ORLANDO, Fla., March 4. -- The pitchers and catchers of the Dodgers may have thought they had been through a somewhat strenuous workout in the two-hour drill this morning, but they little knew how far the agile brain of their manager, Casey Stengel, could go in putting them through real legtesting and muscle-bending torture.
