An offering of $20,000,000 of Federal Intermediate Credit Banks 1 1/2 per cent debentures dated March 15 and due in three and six months was announced yesterday by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent for the banks. The debentures are priced on application.

Two boys accused by the police of having committed a series of twenty afternoon burglaries in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn in the last two months were captured yesterday after one of them, Frank Albi, 15 years old, of 148 Bay Twenty-sixth Street, had been shot twice in the left leg as he fled from two detectives.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
NEW ORLEANS, March 5. -- Hit and Run, the chestnut gelding from the Letellier Stable, finished first in the featured Mardi Gras Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Details of the employes' group insurance plan upon which stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation will vote at their annual meeting in Hoboken on April 1 have been sent to the stockholders with the notice of the meeting. They will vote also on the recall and abolition of the present profit-sharing plan and the employes' stock subscription plan.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Chicago Curb Exchange probably will file an application soon for registration as a national securities exchange, its representatives told the Securities and Exchange Commission today. They were informed, it is understood, that no action could be taken until the formal application was submitted and studied.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Probably the average politician in Washington would have given General Hugh Johnson the same advice that was offered by those with whom he conferred before he made his New York speech attacking Senator Long and Father Coughlin: "If you want to hang yourself, go to it."

Investors holding securities issued by S.W. Straus Co. stormed the public hearing held yesterday at 2 P.M. by Harry A. Gordon, referee, in the Straus Building, 565 Fifth Avenue, in their eagerness to testify, some of them, that the company had sold them bonds through fraud and misrepresentation.

Testimony on the "shadowing" in January and February, 1931, of Mrs. Wilma E. Gould and Harry Gerguson, better known as "Prince Michael Romanoff," was introduced by the defense yesterday in the trial of Mrs. Gould's $500,000 conspiracy suit. The trial is before Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer and a jury.

ROME, March 5. -- The chances for a peaceful settlement of the Italo-Abyssinian dispute were much improved today by the announcement that an agreement had been reached at Addis Ababa to establish a neutral zone along the disputed Italian Somaliland-Abyssinian frontier.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The proposed $50,000,000 rural rehabilitation program for New York State, part of the national drive to take the needy off relief and make them self-sustaining, was the object of a heavy attack at a public hearing today.
Ben Altheimer, retired banker, who is known nationally as the founder of Bundle Day and for his pioneer promotion of the observance of Flag Day, will be 85 years old today.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 5 (AP). -- Sir Malcolm Campbell said, "Yes, I run today," his wife said "No," and a family argument ensued. This time it probably saved the British speed champion's life.

A few scattered complaints from radio listeners yesterday that WOR's new 50,000-watt transmitter caused interference with WJZ were attributed by the engineers to old receiving sets. They explained that too long an antenna also might be blamed for broad tuning.

Edgar Tait, one of the lesser lights on the New York University squad, turned in a notable victory in the one-mile handicap run, one of the features of the Athletes Development meet of the Metropolitan A.A.U. at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

Mrs. Henry C. Taylor will give a luncheon today in the roof garden of the St. Regis for a group of women who are aiding in the sale of seats for the performance of "De Luxe" on the night of March 14 at the Booth Theatre for the benefit of the Babies Hospital.

Spring blooms from gardens in California decorated the tables arranged by members of the Federated Garden Clubs of New Jersey yesterday in the tri-State flower show in Horticultural Hall of Rockefeller Center.

Seventy-two hours after the events were run, the Kirby electric camera timer came along yesterday to change the finish of both the hurdles and sprint in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships and boost Cornell from fourth to second place in the final team standings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- The experiment of transforming Myril Hoag to a third baseman was reached today when the Californian arrived at Huggins Field almost a week ahead of time. Manager Joe McCarthy had the former outfielder cavorting around third base, where he intends playing Hoag during the coming season if he measures up to the job.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 5. -George W. Olvany, formerly Tammany Hall leader, testified for the State today in the trial of two lawyers and a woman jointly charged with attempted grand larceny and conspiracy in connection with the $1,000,000 estate of the late Antonin Chapal, fur dealer who died in 1928.

Samuel Marcus, counsel to the Society for the Prevention of Crime, announced yesterday that he was satisfied with his status as a Special Assistant District Attorney, although it does not permit him to appear before the grand jury and present the evidence he has gathered on the policy racket.

PARIS, March 5. -- Premier Pierre Etienne Flandin once more affirmed his intention to maintain the franc in a speech in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, defending various measures being taken by the government to meet the economic crisis.

LOS ANGELES, March 5 (AP). -- Mrs. R. Pollard's Onrush, conspicuously absent from the winning class since his victory on the second day of the meeting, took the $1,000 Lake Arrowhead Handicap of a mile at Santa Anita Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- One of the most scathing denunciations in the history of the Senate was delivered today by Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, who, following an attack on General Hugh S. Johnson, Bernard M. Baruch and President Roosevelt, by Senator Long, declared that the Louisiana Senator was "egotistical, arrogant and ignorant" and had just uttered the "ravings of a madman."

MADISON, Wis., March 5. -- The Wisconsin Recovery Act, patterned largely after the National Industrial Recovery Act, was declared unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court today on the ground that it unlawfully delegated legislative powers to industry. The decision makes invalid the twenty codes already adopted under the act.
MOSCOW, March 5. -- Attention here has been temporarily diverted from the British-Franco-German situation by significant diplomatic activity in the Near East.
NEW ORLEANS, March 5. -- Resplendent in his regal robes, Rex ruled the carnival in New Orleans today as tens of thousands made merry on the city's greatest playday.
LOS ANGELES, March 5 (AP). -- The acquisition of Babe Ruth by the Braves will help the National League immeasurably, Ford C. Frick, newly elected president of the circuit, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt accepted the resignation of S. Clay Williams as chairman of the NIRB, and conferred on the work relief program with building trades leaders.

Argentina, of late weeks, is one of the few nations that have been getting into the news mainly because she has been having good luck instead of bad. She did have a revolt at La Plata in February, but it was quickly put down. She seems on the verge of a renewed misunderstanding with Chile, just after it had been all nicely arranged for the Presidents of the two republics to meet and cement relationships.

There's a new cook up at the Bronx Zoo, a younger one with a new approach to things and a springier step, and he seems to be catching on. So far there have been no complaints from the animals, Dr. W. Reid Blair, the director, said yesterday. The world moves forward.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Customs collectors were instructed by the Treasury today that liquor hereafter would be included among the articles that travelers may bring into the country, up to the limit of $100, without paying customs duty.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- Tommy Goodwin of Mamaroneck, N.Y., the defending titleholder, and other favorites came through successfully in the first round of match play in the annual Palm Beach golf championship at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 5. -Isabelle Williams, 11 years old, of Yonkers, told Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley and a jury today that all she remembered of the Proctor's Theatre blast on South Broadway, Yonkers, on Feb. 23, 1934, was that she was looking at theatre posters when something went "boom" and she found herself in a hospital.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5. -- Speculation in many quarters was heard here today concerning the possible fate of the anti-Nazi measure which was passed by the House last night and is now headed for the Senate. It was recalled that a similar bill passed by the House last year never emerged from the Senate.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 5. -- Under a blazing sun that provided the hottest weather of the training season, Manager Casey Stengel drove his Dodgers through two strenuous workouts today.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The Nunan bill to require oaths of loyalty from students in institutions of higher learning supported in whole or in part by public funds ran into trouble today in the Assembly Education Committee.
Selling pressure on new crop deliveries increased yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 5 points on the day.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- Opponents of the Giants this year are due for a number of startling surprises and not the least of these will come when in rounding the bases at the Polo Grounds, they suddenly will find that they are no longer stalking through what in other years must have seemed a graveyard.

St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, which has stood for thirty-eight years on the northeast corner of West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, formally embarked upon its second century last night when about 300 members and friends assembled at a centennial dinner in the parish house which adjoins the church.
Irate at a ruling of Magistrate Leonard McGee, 125 Ohrbach picketers awaiting arraignment and about 1,500 sympathizers rioted yesterday in and around Essex Market court.

Our Washington correspondent predicts that General JOHNSON'S speech will release others from the sort of moral terrorism set up by HUEY LONG and Father COUGHLIN. It is devoutly to be wished that this prove true. Saying nothing of the merits of General JOHNSON'S argument, he at least led the way in breaking through censorship which was unofficial and invisible but very effective.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Giuseppe Bentonelli, tenor of the Chicago Grand Opera Company, was greeted by a capacity audience of 200 persons at the first of two concerts tonight at Vizcaya, home of the late James Deering, as guest of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey McCormick, the latter a niece of Mr. Deering.

The Macbeth Gallery reopened yesterday in its new quarters on the fifth floor at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. The rooms are fewer and smaller than at the former address (15 East Fifty-seventh), but for exhibition purposes they are well arranged and lighted and should serve admirably for the regime upon which the gallery has now launched.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The Schackno Act delegating legislative authority to the State Divisional Code Authority for the solid fuel industry was declared unconstitutional by the Appellate Division, Third Department, today. The court unanimously affirmed the two orders of Justice McNaught of Binghamton in a test case brought by Gustave C. Darweger of that city.
Business in money was small, chiefly replacements, while quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- A team of eighteen Yale swimmers tonight created a new American mark of 16 minutes 31 seconds for the mile relay in a special record attempt which featured the annual water carnival in the Eli pool.

April 1 and the Morosco Theatre are the time and place now listed for the opening of "The Face at the Window," which will undergo a second change of title before Lee Shubert finally brings it in. The cast, too, is somewhat altered -- Kate Mayhew has been added and Frank Wilcox has replaced Malcolm Duncan, who is ill.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- Babe Ruth's debut as a member of the Braves attracted more than the customary attendance today at Waterfront Park. The former Yankee received increased attention from autograph seekers, amateur and professional photographers and the fans in general.
Postcripts on a week-end jaunt to the Catskills for a glimpse of a few famous trout streams in their Winter garb:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Shorn of the "prevailing wage" amendment which caused its withdrawal from the Senate a week ago Friday, President Roosevelt's $4,880,000,000 work relief resolution was sent back to the floor today with a "rush order" for adoption.

A campaign to raise $500,000 by popular subscription to support the work of the Salvation Army throughout the city will be started early in April, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the civilian advisory board of the Army at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

TROY, N.Y., March 5. -- The "ride" victim found in a roadside ditch just over the Troy city line Sunday morning was identified by his wife today as Julius Martin of 116-26 222d Street, St. Albans, L.I., a taxicab body manufacturer. The Department of Justice at Washington identified him as Jules Magelfsky of New York, arrested on a charge of desertion June 2, 1917, from Fort Slocum and fingerprinted at that time.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Liquidation by Eastern and local longs on the Board of Trade today disclosed a lack of support, especially in corn. Stop-loss orders were uncovered on the drop and the finish was about the bottom.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5. -- The Argentine Foreign Office gave out a long statement tonight denying the charges made against Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedralamas yesterday by Augustin Edwards, a Chilean diplomat.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- A warning that commercial banks would soon be unable to justify their existence, unless Federal Reserve requirements were liberalized to enable them to extend longer term credit, was made before the House Banking and Currency Committee today by Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $25,352, 951 after all deductions for 1934. The profit was equivalent after preferred dividends to $2.82 a share on 5,503,193, no par, common and compared with $26,375,236, or $3 a share, on the common in 1933.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Known as the "Great Dissenter," Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes's philosophy was summed up in the words:

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Boerse was quiet and irregular today. Heavy industrials were inactive. Potashes were strong, Aschersleben gaining 2 points. Machineries were mixed and unstable, Berlin Karlsruhe rising 3/4 point. Electricals were fairly active without any significant changes in quotations, while chemicals were quiet and slightly weaker.

LONDON, March 5. -- Fluctuations in the foreign exchange market restricted business in the stock markets today. The tone generally was dull, with profit-taking in gold mines on the setback in the price of gold to 147s. 10 1/2d. an ounce.

Myrtle Leonard, contralto of the Metropolitan, appeared at the Town Hall last evening in her first New York recital, assisted at the piano by Mildred Brown. A native of St. Paul, Minn., the singer grew up in California, where schoolmates chose her for Santa Claus in their school's Christmas play "because of her deep voice."

Victories by Murray Vernon, E.W. Butler and F.R. Thoms in the first three matches gave the Crescent-Athletic Hamilton Club a 3-to-2 triumph over the New York Athletic Club on the Winged Foot courts yesterday, gaining for the Brooklyn team the Group I championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, with a record of eight victories and no defeats.
Plans of four six-story apartment houses to cost a total of $710,000 were filed in city building departments yesterday. Two of the houses will be in Brooklyn and one each in Manhattan and the Bronx.

LONDON, March 5. -- William Drogo Sturges Montagu, 26-year-old son of the Earl of Sandwich, married today at Caxton Hall registry office Mrs. Janet Aitken Campbell, daughter of Lord Beaverbrook. After the ceremony the pair left by airplane for a Continental wedding trip.

A total of 11,722 families were removed from the home relief rolls in January as a result of more careful sifting of relief clients, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare and chairman of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced last night.

The Transit Commission decided yesterday at a special meeting to forward today to Mayor La Guardia a statement of its position on the unification legislation which the city's transit advisers have submitted to it.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- C.H. Knebelkamp's King Saxon, making his first start since last October, was an easy winner of the featured event at Hialeah Park today. Runing over a fast track the 4-year-old Saxon colt was clocked in 1:11 flat for the six furlongs, one of the fastest performances of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Before crowded Senate galleries, an unusually large attendance of Senators and scores of House members, another attack was made on Senator Long today by administration forces. Senator McKellar branded as false statements made on the floor by the Louisianian, and Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, declared that if Mr. Long's Senate activities were indefinitely prolonged he would consider it a "godsend" himself to get out of the Senate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6 (AP). -- Charges that every step is being taken to "wipe God from the hearts of Mexican young people" and "communism is becoming deeply rooted" in Mexico were voiced in the Arizona Senate today. The situation was held up as a threat to the United States.

The defense of the five New York banks and the General Electric Company now being sued for $30,000,000 by 23,000 Insull investors was extended yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack along two new lines.

"The dignity of the Senate" long since became a bitter jest. Now it is necessary for the Democratic leader, Senator ROBINSON, to appeal to its manhood. He urged the members no longer to submit to the insults and flouting of Senator LONG. That gentleman had just resorted to his usual tactics.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Since the new charges brought against Postmaster General Farley by Senator Long involve the Department of Justice, the Department of Public Works and the RFC, the Senate Committee which is considering the allegations will request reports from those agencies before action is taken.

Phil Moore of the Columbia University Club gained the semi-final round of the national amateur squash tennis championship at the courts of his home club last night after a four-game duel with Arnold Wood Jr. of the Princeton Club.

Sharp declines occurred in all principal commodity markets here yesterday with the exception of sugar, coffee and hides. The volume of trading was heavy. In the cash markets, raw sugar rose 3 points to 3 cents a pound, but declines appeared in all the grains, cotton, dairy products, tin, silk and rubber.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Harvey S. Firestone heads the men's group on the advisory board for the fifth international tropical flower show opening in Garden Theatre tomorrow, to continue through Sunday, and the group of women on the board is headed by Mrs. Arthur Curtiss James, vice president.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6. -- Scoring in the semi-finals of the Connecticut Interscholastic Basketball Association tournament, Warren Harding High of Bridgeport and Meriden High tonight won the right to compete for the State title here on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- In answer to a question at his press conference this morning, the President offered a short philosophic observation on New Deal economics, repeating what he has often said before. But the times are such that violent, if temporary, repercussions swiftly followed.

Salvatore Canzoneri, a 26-year-old former convict, had an almost fool-proof method of passing $5 counterfeit notes, a ruse that involved an automobile, a boy passing by on the street, a minimum risk of detection and, if worse came to worst, a sturdy set of teeth.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 6. -- When the thirteen Dodger infielders and outfielders who are due tomorrow step to the plate for their first batting practice they probably will be blinking their eyes in astonishment and talking to themselves afterward.

Keeping abreast of the continually growing interest and popularity in the sport, the United States Golf Association expects to increase the number of sectional qualifying districts for the open and amateur championships and probably raise the qualifying quota for the amateur to 200.

ATHENS, March 6. -- General George Kondylis, War Minister, announced officially tonight that two government airplanes had bombed the rebel barracks, a railroad station and rebel troops at Seres, Macedonia, from a height of about sixty-five feet.

Henry W. Pollock, former State Senator, who was a director and associate counsel of the Bank of United States, was cleared in General Sessions yesterday on seven indictments, returned in 1931 against himself, Isidor J. Kresel and others of the bank's officers.

The new film opening this morning at the Radio City Music Hall is "Roberta," an adaptation of the musical play by Jerome Kern and Otto Harbach. Heading the east are Irene Dunne, Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, assisted by Helen Westley, Randolph Scott, Claire Dodd and Reginald Owen.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward at one time yesterday, only to reverse the trend and close with losses of 6 to 10 points on the day.

THE clubhouse man at the Yankee training camp, evidently a sentimental soul, filled Babe Ruth's old locker with kindling wood. At about the same time the Babe, making his debut in the uniform of the Boston Braves, filled Waterfront Park in St. Petersburg with some 3,000 spectators. If that's all right with Manager McCarthy of the Yankees, Judge Fuchs of the Braves is making no complaint.

Estimating the national average of steel production at 48 1/2 per cent of capacity, unchanged from a week before, The Iron Age concludes that the decline which set in during the second week of February has been arrested. This publication, in its weekly review, points out recessions in the Valleys, at Buffalo and at Detroit are offset by gains at Chicago and in the Philadelphia region.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6. -- Unless all signs are deceiving, one of the worries of Manager Joe McCarthy has been dissipated. For Johnny Allen, ace right-hander of the Yankee hurling line, apparently has completely recovered from the ailment which affected his pitching arm last year.

NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP). -- The front-running Figuriste from Mrs. S. Fisher's stable again set all the pace today to win the mile feature and chalk up his second straight victory at the Fair Grounds.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6. -- Harvard's varsity and freshmen swimming teams conquered Brown by 39 to 32 and 41 to 21, respectively, in the Crimson's pool to night.

PARIS, March 6. -- After heavy losses at the opening today, the stock market recovered somewhat during the midperiod and closed irregular. Despite the temporary improvement, a majority of the shares showed declines from yesterday's levels.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- In defiance of a warning given by the Senate, the Ways and Means Committee voted a favorable report today on the Doughton bill to repeal the part of the 1934 Revenue Act which would make public property of individual income figures after March 15.

With politicians, and especially Tammany politicians, economy never begins at home. No matter what their pretensions, when the actual vote is taken they will be found on the side of intrenched privilege. This prevailing political maxim found expression at Albany again this week in the refusal of the Tammany-controlled Assembly to vote out the Moffatt bills striking at some of the lesser county sinecures, such as the commissioners of records and the public administrators.

HAMBURG, March 6 (AP). -- Demonstrating fitness for his ten-round heavyweight match with Max Schmeling next Sunday, Steve Hamas battered three sparring partners in a six-round session today. They left the ring bruised and breathless after boxing two rounds each with the American fighter.
BERLIN, March 6 (AP). -- Two military men who were slain in Adolf Hitler's 1934 "purge" have been signally honored and in effect endorsed by 470 German army officers, it became known today.

To the most attentive onlookers in Wall Street yesterday the frantic efforts to judge the possible effect of what at one time seemed to be an inspired inflation movement did not make sense. Stocks, bonds and commodities raced about unreasonably, and there were moments of great excitement.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., March 6. -- Primo Carnera worked out before newspaper men at his training quarters today, convincing the onlookers that he was ready to launch the comeback trail, which he hopes will lead him to a return match with Max Baer.

LONDON, March 6. -- The American-born sculptor, Jacob Epstein, again has aroused a storm of controversy, this time with a colossal carving of Christ entitled "Behold the Man," the sensation of his exhibition shown to the press today.
With only twelve of the original sixteen starting teams left, the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden swept past the half-way mark last night.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- Deadlocked at the end of the third session, the Penn M.C. polo team tonight defeated Princeton, 14 1/2 to 8 1/2, with a barrage of six last-period goals.

Having been born in Munich, having left there as a "braumeister" and having recently read an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to Bock beer, I am prompted to write you a letter giving a Muenchner's description of Bock and Salvator beers.

ATHENS, March 6. -- Decisive defeat of the rebel forces in Northern Greece has been delayed only by bad weather and fog and will be accomplished as soon as conditions improve, General George Kondylis, War Minister, informed Premier Tsaldaris this evening in a report from Saloniki, where he is directing government operations in Greece's civil war.

Mrs. Henry C. Taylor, president of the Women's Board of the Babies Hospital, gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for women interested in the benefit performance of "De Luxe" on March 14 at the Booth Theatre in behalf of the hospital.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Prices of hogs made a strong start and a weak finish here today. Prices in the early trading ware 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, the top moving up that amount to $9.90, a new record for the season.

Despite the large surplus of unemployed workers, many have lost their skill and occupational fitness due to long enforced idleness, so that industry would be faced with a dearth of skilled labor if it were to return to the production basis of 1929.

Jack Wolff, mainstay of Manhattan's intercollegiate champion 1,600 -- meter relay team, will make his debut in cup race competition at the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, games at Madison Square Garden March 16. The Jasper star yesterday was added to the field for the Casey 600, one of the meet's fixtures.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 6. -- Carmanchita, Mrs. R.F. Carman Jr.'s 3-year-old filly, won the featured Culver City Handicap over the six-furlong route at the Santa Anita track today. The winner led Thomas C. Worden's Bert Reid by a length. W.A. Thomas's Lady Bowman was third.

Supplementing the courageous declaration of the Bank of France, which we recently cited, Premier FLANDIN yesterday set forth specifically to the Deputies the French Government's view regarding the past week's break in the pound sterling. He admitted that such evidences of international instability of a foreign currency increased the difficulties of industry.

Misunderstood reports of a statement by President Roosevelt at his press conference yesterday relative to the value of the dollar, falling upon a foreign exchange market already confused by the fall in sterling, disrupted orderly dealings and brought about as wild a day of fluctuations in exchange values as has been witnessed since the revaluation of the dollar.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Several pounds overweight but not lacking at all in personal assurance in his ability to take them off and prove his worth, Henry Leiber, called Hank, took the spotlight today as the Giants again went through two blistering workouts on Flamingo Field.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Mrs. Eben Howes Ellison gave a luncheon today at the Everglades Club. Her guests were:

HAVERFORD, Pa., March 6. -- The farewell appearance of the visiting English Wolf-Noel squash racquets team was crowned with success today, as the Hon. Anne Lytton-Milbanke, captain, and Mrs. Ian McKechnie, third ranking Britisher, swept through the semi-final and final round matches to annex the national doubles championship at the Merion Cricket Club.
CHICAGO, March 6. -- Plans for a permanent Chicago fair, to be built on the site of A Century of Progress in Burnham Park at a cost of $20,000,000, were announced today by Mayor Edward J. Kelly.

Commenting that the retirement of Giulio Gatti-Casazza from the management of the Metropolitan Opera marks the completion of an era, the Oxford University Press announces the preparation for Fall publication of a history of the institution from the construction of the theatre in 1883 down to the present day.

A program laid down by the Juilliard Musical Foundation as the basis of aid for the continuation of the Metropolitan Opera and which embraces an international season followed by a popular-priced season in English with young Americans, was approved yesterday by the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association.
A strike of elevator operators and other service employes in the Bronx is expected this morning unless a last-minute adjustment is brought about by Mayor La Guardia.

Market value on March 1 of the 1,535 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange was $41,111,937,232, compared with a par value of $45,032,755,233, according to a compilation given out by the Exchange yesterday. The average price of a bond was $91.29.

RENO, Nev., March 6. -- Divorces were granted today to Mrs. Elizabeth P. Lawson-Johnston, wife of John R. Lawson-Johnston of New York City, and to Mrs. Harriet W. Welwood, wife of John C. Welwood Jr., also of New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A bill to enable Supreme Court justices to retire on full pay at the age of seventy after ten years of service was rejected in the House today by vote of 207 to 144, after several speakers, including Chairman Sumners of the Judiciary Committee, had deplored the fact that Justice Holmes's salary had been reduced between the time of his resignation and his death.
Observers of phenomena involving tigers, red-winged blackbirds, squirrels, baby carriages, azaleas and thermometers reported yesterday that Spring had rounded the corner a fortnight too soon.

The "pin ball" or bagatelle games that gives prizes for high scores, which have been flourishing in the five boroughs, seemingly immune from the charge they comprise gambling, because the city accepts a $2 license fee for each machine, were declared to be gambling apparatus yesterday by Justices Kernochan, McAndrews and. Voorhees in Special Sessions.

BASLE, March 6. -- The pound's continued weakness is arousing some speculation in Europe as to whether it is deliberate and if so whether the aim may not be partly to bring a bad situation more rapidly to a head.

Next to the dispatch of Italian troops to Africa, the rebellious outbreak in Greece has been the most surprising and mysterious act of war. News of the actual hostilities has obviously been largely under a Government censorship for the past few days. Victories over the rebellious forces are reported, in the usual course, but there is no official explanation of the grievances which led to the revolt.

Three bondholders of the Majestic Hotel Corporation, owner of the Majestic Apartments, a twenty-nine-story structure at Seventy-second Street and Central Park West, filed a petition in the Federal district court hero yesterday under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, asking the court to authorize the reorganization of the corporation.

The first instance in more than 1,000 claims in which an investor in securities issued by S.W. Straus Co. was able to show a repurchase agreement in writing, signed by an official of the firm, developed yesterday at a public hearing before Harry A. Gordon, referee, in the Straus Building, 565 Fifth Avenue.
BASTIA, Corsica, March 6. -- Andre Spada, last of a long line of Corsican bandits, was condemned to the guillotine tonight for his many crimes.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 6. -- The government filed an antimonopoly suit in Federal court here today against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation and a group of individuals. The two corporations are chartered under Delaware laws and have their principal offices in New York.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- George Odom's Chancing was one of the big surprises at Hialeah Park today as favorites continued to go down to defeat with monotonous regularity. Chancing is the son of Chance Play, which was beaten about thirty lengths in his previous start after running up three victories in succession at this course.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses declined emphatically yesterday to classify the disposition of Civic Virtue, the long-disputed statue in City Hall Park, one of the major issues of his administration.

A 52-29 victory for Columbia over Harvard last night in the Morning-side Heights gymnasium enabled the Lions to deadlock Penn's defending champions for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Increasing support for the $4,880,000,000 work relief appropriation in a form desired by President Roosevelt was seen by administration leaders today as they prepared to call the measure up for action in the Senate tomorrow or Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- Outdoor workouts for Princeton's squad of varsity rowing candidates got under way today. Four varsity heavyweight crews participated in the initial practice on the waters of Lake Carnegie.

Former County Judge William R. Bayes of Brooklyn was appointed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a city magistrate to fill the unexpired term of the late Magistrate Frederick Hughes, who died in Miami last Saturday.

Pig iron production in February, according to The Iron Age, was 1,608,552 tons, or 57,448 tons daily, as against 1,477,336 tons, or 47,656 tons per day in January. The gain in daily rate was 20 1/2 per cent. There were 96 furnaces in blast March 1 compared with 90 on Feb. 1, a net gain of 6.

VIENNA, March 6. -- Steady fighting continued today in Greece between governmental and Venizelist forces, particularly in Macedonia, without any decisive battle. Both sides are busily recruiting their forces, preparing for the big struggle, which is expected to begin tomorrow.

Two Lenten sewing classes held their initial meetings for this season yesterday. The Manhattanville Alumnae Association met at the Carroll Club, and during the Lenten period the members will make first communion outfits for needy children.

The controversy over strict enforcement of the $3 fee demanded by the musicians union from every member of a band participating in a broadcast from a hotel or night club reached an impasse yesterday when a score of orchestra leaders conferred with the union officials at 1,267 Sixth Avenue.

Assailing the "extremely reckless spending program" of the national administration, James Truslow Adams, American historian, called upon the Federal Government yesterday afternoon to restore the "wavering" confidence of the nation in President Roosevelt's regime by taking immediate steps to balance the budget and to forestall inflation by stabilizing the currency with no further devaluation.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 6.-- Expressing the personal opinion that the entire National Industrial Recovery Act was unconstitutional, Judge Wayne G. Borah denied in the Federal Court today an application of the government for an injunction to restrain a box manufacturer from alleged violation of maximum hour and minimum wage provisions of the Lumber Code.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- One of the effects of the Bolshevist revolution was cited today by the newspaper Pravda, which reported that before the revolution only twenty-five forks were sold for every 100 knives, but now every one who buys a knife also wants a fork.

The defendants in Mrs. Wilma E. Gould's $500,000 conspiracy suit completed their case yesterday in the trial before Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer and a jury. Henry A. Uterhart, Mrs. Gould's counsel, then began his rebuttal by introducing character witnesses for his client to testify that she had a "good reputation" during her life in Chicago and Kansas City.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature tonight urging that President Roosevelt and Congress be memorialized for Federal milk-shed legislation to protect the New York dairy industry from "utter destruction and disintegration."

Production of steel ingots in the United States last month amounted to 2,742,125 gross tons, compared with 2,834,170 in January and 2,183, 160 in February, last year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Money market was dull. Except for replacements there was virtually no demand for fresh accommodations. Quotations for all classes remained unchanged.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 6. -- Through streets gay with innumerable flags, the Duke of Gloucester rode in procession here today, and was received by the Governor, officials and representatives of the Legislature.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- Cautious tactics again marked the play in the international chess masters' tournament as the fourteenth round was contested at the Museum Beaux Arts today, and only one of the six leaders -- G. Loewenfisch of Russia -- suffered defeat. He is now bracketed with Dr. Emanuel Lasker of England, former world champion in third place.

PITTSBURGH, March 6. -- Expected revelations about the part the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh played in establishing Andrew W. Mellon's huge losses on the sale of securities in 1931 were delayed today by an unexpected adjournment of the hearing of his income tax case before the Board of Tax Appeals.

WARSAW, March 6. -- Postponement of Sir John Simon's visit to Berlin, and consequently to Warsaw, has produced consternation here, and the situation is viewed with considerable anxiety. Germany's indicated refusal to accept Great Britain as European arbiter, it is held here, clearly shows she does not want serious disarmament conversations and again believes high-handed tactics bring better results than friendly talk.

The piano wizardry that abides in the fingers of Ignaz Friedman provided a stimulating and at times exciting demonstration of what a remarkable technique can mean, even in a day of widespread keyboard virtuosity, when the Polish pianist returned in recital to the Town Hall last night, after an absence of five years.

LONDON, March 6. -- The estimated expenditures of the British Navy for 1935 will be 60,050,000 [the pound closed at $4.74 3/4 yesterday], according to figures presented in the House of Commons today by Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty.
PARIS, March 6. -- Two fiery Corsican Deputies met on the "field of honor" in the early hours today and one of them was carried off at the duel's end with a bullet through his pistol arm.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- The honor roll for the first term of this academic year, made public today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of Princeton University, listed 571 students, or almost one-quarter of the entire undergraduate roster.
SHANGHAI, March 6. -- Pessimism over the possibility of concluding a relief loan for China is deepening.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

NEWARK, N.J., March 6. -- The Metropolitan Opera Association will present Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" at the Mosque Theatre here on March 28 under the auspices of the Contemporary of Newark for the benefit of the Newark Milk Fund.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The situation created by the sudden postponement of the visit of Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, to Berlin brought no new development today as far as German official quarters were concerned. Whether the invitation will be formally renewed by the Reich Government at a later period is a matter that apparently has not yet been considered.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Declaring that reciprocal trade agreements now being negotiated by the administration could not restore our foreign commerce in any marked degree during the next three years, Secretary Wallace today cited this fact as making imperative a continuance of Federal control of farm production under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 6 (AP). -- Unable to name a winner after all twenty-three contestants had performed, judges in the national bird dog championship field trials today designated three pointers and a setter to go through a run-off tomorrow.

Retail trade here showed improvement yesterday as the weather became springlike. Consumer interest in Spring suits increased, but it was still noticeable that main floor departments led by far in sales activity. Retail executives agreed that not one but several Spring days will be required for apparel purchasing to really hit its stride.

If one may trust the verdict of his ear, "Yes" is disappearing. Even its substitute "Yeh" or "Yeah" has been supplanted. "O.K.," "That's O.K. by me" is gaining rapidly. In a recent appeal case from Rangoon the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council decided that the words "O.K." on certain delivery orders and invoices, signed by a rice-mill manager, meant what he said they did, that the details in the documents were correct.
Writing in the current issue of the magazine Today, Professor Felix Frankfurter, a close friend of Oliver Wendell Holmes, says:

Greatly concerned over the littered condition of the streets, the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness asked Sanitation Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond yesterday why the streets were not being kept cleaner than they were under previous commissioners.

As a warning to those who wander afield in the Spring in search of wild animals to take home as pets, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of the New York State Conservation Department yesterday called attention to the fact that laws were passed in 1934 making it illegal to carry off small bear cubs.

PARIS, March 6. -- The tragic explanation of Maryse Wendling's determination to forsake forever the footlights of Paris and the acclaim of theatregoers to nurse the lepers in Polynesia has now been revealed.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The body of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, the man acclaimed as the "great liberal" in his twenty-nine years as a justice of the Supreme Court, remained in his unpretentious red brick home in I Street tonight.

The following monthly reports of holdings of stocks were filed yesterday with the New York Stock Exchange by officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed companies in compliance with the Securities Exchange Act of 1934:

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Modification of the administration's public utility legislation to permit holding-company operations after 1940 at the discretion of the Securities and Exchange Commission, instead of compelling their dissolution by that date, was proposed today by Robert E. Healy, member of the commission, before the House Interstate Committee.

Heavy trading in United States Government bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange sent the total of transactions to $26,990,800, the second biggest day of the year. The turnover of $15,814,800 in the long-term government issues was the largest since last August, and compared with $5,454,500 on Tuesday.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Amid cheers, the Assembly tonight adopted a resolution calling for final adjournment of the 1935 session of the Legislature on Friday, March 22. It was offered by Assemblyman Killgrew, Democratic leader.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Members of the Cabinet, Senate and House joined with others throughout the nation in paying tribute to the late Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes. Some of them were as follows:
Suspicion grows that the hidden hand behind disturbed air conditions in the United States is no other than the Western Union and the Postal Telegraph Company.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 6 (AP). -- Mrs. Elva Statler Davidson was pictured today as weeping and threatening to "get tight" at a late supper party a few hours before she was found dead in her garage last Wednesday morning.
An overflow crowd of 1,500 turned out for the benefit ice carnival at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night and the Val Bialas fund was enriched by approximately $300.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Moses-Ickes controversy was before the House today when a resolution which would direct Secretary Ickes, as PWA Administrator, to explain his ruling that would force Robert Moses off the Triborough Bridge Authority in New York was introduced by Representative Culkin, Republican, of New York.
George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who was secretary to Justice Holmes for a year, said yesterday:

The National City Bank, as head of the banking group that offered yesterday the new issue of $45,025,000 New York State 2 1/4 and 3 per cent bonds due in from one to fifty years, reported that all but about $5,000,000 had been sold out of the syndicate account.
ALBANY, March 6. -- Walter T. Brown, manager of the Albany Bureau of The Associated Press, was named today by Governor Lehman as his secretary at a salary of $12,000 a year.

LONDON, March 6. -- The stock markets generally were dull today, with further weakness in sterling and a sharp rise in the price of gold to a new record figure of 149s 4d an ounce. After opening weak on further forced selling owing to disappointing revenues and the Continental situation.
GENEVA, March 6. -- The first weakening in the British opposition to the American arms traffic treaty came today after an all-day committee discussion of Article VII.

BUDAPEST, March 8. -- Only 22 out of 140 members of the government party in Parliament answered the summons of the former Premier, Count Stephen Bethlen von Bethlen, to discuss the future attitude of the Bethlen wing of that party.

Lieut. Col. John W.N. Schulz, district army engineer, announced yesterday that the Park Department had applied for a permit to construct a bridge over the Harlem River at Spuyten Duyvil as part of the Henry Hudson Parkway. Protests from the standpoint of navigation should be filed by March 20, he said.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Charges that Postmaster General Farley intervened to save interests involving Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at Large, and Mr. Davis's brother, Paul N. Davis, from prosecution by the Department of Justice in Tennessee, and again at the request of Tom Pendergast, Democratic leader of Kansas City, to save persons there from similar prosecution, were made today by Senator Long.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Oliver Wendell Holmes, retired Justice of the Supreme Court, was mourned by high and low today in the capital of the nation he served with distinction for three-quarters of a century.

An inkwell hurled through a plate-glass window gave an alarm that resulted yesterday morning in the capture of three young thugs after they had held up twenty employes of the Consolidated Home Equipment Company at 120 East Sixteenth Street, near the Washington Irving High School at Irving Place.

LONDON, March 6. -- There was a brisk debate just before the House of Commons rose last night on the attitude taken by Earl Stanhope on behalf of the British Government in the Geneva commission that is dealing with the proposals of the United States regarding the manufacture of armaments.
Two boys tossing a soft ball back and forth on the shore of Indian Lake in Crotona Park, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, apparently had not developed mid-season control.

Subpoenas were issued yesterday for thirteen persons, including two lawyers, in connection with charges by Magistrate Anna M. Kross that a "vice ring" is operating among women arraigned in the Women's Court on charges of prostitution.

OTTAWA, March 6. -- A Canadian butter surplus, estimated at 12,500,000 to 15,000,000 pounds, has mysteriously disappeared, and rumors are rife in parliamentary circles that most of it has been bootlegged into the United States.

Counsel for the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding group, have plans by which its recapitalization would be completed immediately as a result of recent developments in its bankruptcy action, it was disclosed yesterday.
Wagner's "Parsifal" will be sung this afternoon, beginning at 1 P.M., for the ninety-fifth time at the Metropolitan and the seventieth under the direction of Gatti-Casazza.

GUEVGUELI, Greek-Yugoslav Frontier, March 6. -- Despite the announcement of the Athens government that it has the situation in hand and expects soon to crush the revolution, Americans in Greece tonight considered the situation highly dangerous.

Mr. and Mrs. Warren Leslie Jr. gave a dinner last night at the Place Piquale for Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Elliman, Mr. and Mrs. Ward Cheney, Mrs. Julien St. C. Chaqueneau, Mrs. Joseph Bryan, Miss Virginia Cowles, Prince Serge Obolensky, Charles S. Payson and Conde Nast.

When it became the duty of Mr. Justice HOLMES to announce to the Supreme Court on the same day the death of Chief Justice TAFT and that of Mr. Justice SANFORD, he merely added: "In the presence of such events we can only stand in awe." A like spirit of reticence and reverence should mark every comment on the great judge who has now gone to his rest.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms mailed to its members yesterday a copy of Section 3 of the proposed communications companies' code of fair competition which, it is said, would seriously restrict the use of wire facilities by brokerage houses.

A recent press dispatch states that 3,000,000 people in the cleaning, dyeing, tailoring, barbering, laundering, hairdressing, shoe repairing and similar service trades are again to receive the attention of the NRA, and that W. Averell Harriman has appointed Mark Eisner to conduct an inquiry into these "troublesome trades."

VIENNA, March 6. -- For the first time since the opening of his treason trial in connection with the Nazi "putsch" that resulted in the murder of Chancellor Dollfuss, Dr. Anton Rintelen, former Ambassador to Italy, showed his famous fighting spirit today when he was confronted with hostile evidence given by his former friend and subsequent enemy, Dr. Friedrich Funder, editor of the ultra-Clerical Reichspost.

HARTFORD, March 6. -- Connecticut killed the Federal Rehabilitation Bill today, under which 200 families might have been taken from cities to rural centres and given homesteads and garden tools at an expenditure of about $800,000, when the Senate voted against the bill, 18 to 17.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A casual statement by President Roosevelt today at a White House; press conference that commodity prices had not reached the level desired by the administration caused such a flurry in domestic and international markets that the White House found it necessary to deny that the President had implied plans for further devaluation of the dollar.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 6. -- The Misses Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., and Marion Miley, 20-year-old Kentucky State titleholder, easily won their first-round matches in the Florida East Coast championship today.

Winning all six of her matches, Miss Muriel Guggolz of the Fencers Club captured premier honors in the senior women's third annual competition for the Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish medals on the strips of the Fencers Club last night. She won the gold medal.

PARIS, March 6. -- The Greek revolt has added to the difficulties faced by the North Atlantic Steamship Conference, which today put over until tomorrow its scheduled annual Spring meeting on the subject of steamship rates.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Literally hundreds of letters were received on Capitol Hill today protesting against "pink slip" income tax publicity, but Representative Millard of New York got two which he thought especially significant.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Unless President Roosevelt insists on saving the NRA as a separate entity, rapidly forming Congressional opinion on the future of the Recovery Administration may demand that the administration's functions be divided between the Federal Trade Commission and the Labor Department.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6. -- Yale evened its annual basketball series with Princeton tonight by outscoring the Tigers, 44 to 39, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

The program of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, for the transfer of supervision of water and motor truck transportation to the Interstate Commerce Commission, won the conditional approval of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York yesterday afternoon at a special meeting at the offices of the Merchants Association.

The Horace Mann School for Boys basketball team registered its fifteenth triumph in sixteen games this season, defeating the Columbia freshmen, 25 to 21, yesterday in the Horace Mann gymnasium. At half time the victors led, 13 to 5.

The Rayburn-Wheeler bill goes a long way toward bringing about a rift in the rank and file of the American citizens. It seems to be an inspiration, harebrained because of its extremeness, of Communists who, as we all know, have done their best to ruin everything for which our forebears fought and stood.

Gregory S. Mangin of New York heads the draw for the thirty-sixth annual national indoor tennis championship which will start Saturday at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Seven other players in the field of sixty-four were seeded in the draw, made yesterday at the offices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

A well-dressed young bandit held up ten employes of the Pacific Finance Corporation at 246 West Fifty-ninth Street, on the southeast corner of Broadway yesterday, and escaped into the late rush-hour crowd at Columbus Circle with $612, the day's cash receipts.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Indicating that the Treasury's refinancing program of $2,400,000,000 was proceeding favorably, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the books would be closed on Friday for the exchange of $528,000,000 of Treasury 2 1/2 per cent notes, maturing March 15, for the new five-year 1 5/8 per cent notes.

Youthful yachtsmen of Manhattan will be pleased to learn that they will no longer be in danger of a wetting when they launch their boats in Central Park. The Park Department has prepared plans for a new coping around the Conservatory Lake that will enable the young skippers to reach down to the water with ease.

From a source that may be termed authoritative it was learned yesterday that the directorate of the Theatre Guild is seriously considering, as its final production of the season, the revue entitled "Parade," by Paul Peters, George Sklar, Emanuel Eisenberg and Jerome Moross.

NEWARK, N.J., March 6. -- Reduction of at least $6,000,000 in the yearly electric light bill of customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company is asked in the brief filed today with the New Jersey Public Utility Commission by John A. Matthews, counsel for the petitioners in the rate case which has been before the commission for more than eighteen months.

A committee of the House is now struggling with a bill introduced on the initiative of the tireless captains of AAA. The general purpose of it is to "clarify" and strengthen the Government's power to license producers and processors of farm commodities.

JIMMY DURANTE'S quizzically affectionate ballad about Broadway accurately sums up the never-never land of backstage that is in Joseph Verner Reed's "The Curtain Falls" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.75). For Mr. Reed got thoroughly knifed -- he dropped $81,000 in the first year of his membership in the firm of Macgowan Reed, and he lost $40,000 a few years later on a single play.

An accounting suit, laying various acts of misconduct to officers and directors of the Cities Service Company, Cities Service Securities Company and Henry L. Doherty Co., was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Thomas I. Carter, vice president of Cities Service, filed a petition and bond for removal to the United States District Court.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A marked reaction following statement by the President that commodity prices were still too low forced the White House to issue an official denial that any further revaluation of the dollar was contemplated.

All markets were in some confusion yesterday as Wall Street impulsively placed various interpretations on what, in the light of later developments, appeared to have been nothing more than a casual remark by President Roosevelt at a press conference on the subject of the levels of commodity prices and their relation to the debt burden.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Fighting the depression is not a question of money but of its distribution, Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, declared today before the House Banking and Currency Committee in testimony on the proposed banking act of 1935.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PARIS, March 6. -- France's return to two-year military service will, it is expected, be discussed at a Cabinet meeting which will be held tomorrow at Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin's official residence in the Rue de Varenne.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1934 a consolidated net income of $5,148,252 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after allowing for participating provisions of the convertible preference stock, to $5.53 a share on 701,749 no-par shares of common stock, excluding 26,900 shares in the treasury.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Department of Justice is willing that women jurors try those brought to trial in Federal courts.

The position taken by the Transit Commission on one important feature of the city's bill to bring about transit unification is out of harmony with the city's desire to preserve local control over rapid transit fares, Mayor La Guardia intimated yesterday.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York reduced yesterday its dividend rate from $20 annually to $12 by the declaration of a quarterly distribution of $3 a share, payable on April 1 to stockholders of record tomorrow.

HOUSTON, March 6 (AP). -- Jockey H. Dabson, up on Marooned, made every post a winning one in taking the three-fourths mile Ben Milam Handicap, featured event of today's card at Epsom Downs. L.J. Marks's 5-year-old gelding won by three-quarters of a length from My Dandy, W.C. Reiehert's veteran campaigner, which took the place position from Gold Step.

A new proposal for freeing upward of $20,000,000 still tied up in Brazil was broached to exporters yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council. The organization, cooperating with the Committee on Inter-American Relations and other groups of both American and Brazilian business men, has proposed a reopening of discussions of commercial indebtedness in the hope of clearing the matter up before the reciprocal trade treaty with Brazil becomes effective.

LONDON, March 6. -- Competent authority permitted it to be known today that, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's indisposition having postponed Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon's visit to Berlin, preparations for his visit to Moscow have been taken in hand.

ATHENS, Thursday, March 7. -- Two ambitious women are behind the opposing forces in the Greek revolt. Mine. Eleutherios Venizelos. wife of the veteran statesman, who is said to be worth in the neighborhood of $15,000,000, is declared by government supporters to be financing the uprising from Crete.
HANOVER, N. H., March 6. -- The Scarsdale High School of New York was declared the winner of the Freshman Plaque for high scholarship today by Dean Robert C. Strong of Dartmouth College.

There will be a private view of paintings by Boris Chaliapin this afternoon at the Hotel Plaza. At the Midtown Galleries an exhibition of drawings and etchings by Isabel Bishop opens today. Paintings and water-colors by Helen Humphreys Lawrence are being shown in the clubrooms of the New York City Panhellenic at the Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place.

A successful operation on a ten-week-old infant suffering from congenital diaphragmatic hernia, similar in many respects to that of Alyce Jane McHenry, was performed in this city last Saturday, Dr. Iago Galdston of the medical information bureau of the New York Academy of Medicine revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Vinson bill for immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus on the plan sponsored by the American Legion was ordered reported to the House today by the Ways and Means Committee, the vote being 14 to 11.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., March 6. -- With a yield of 650 pounds of cotton per acre, an amount which local cotton experts believe to be a world record, the value of Kern County's 1934 cotton crop was set at $5,360,700 today with a production of 67,700 bales from 52,000 acres.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Four years ago, in acknowledgment of a celebration in honor of his ninetieth birthday on which he had been "listening in," Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes made his first and only radio speech.

Governor Lehman will receive delegates from the student councils of metropolitan and up-State colleges and John Lang, president of the National Student Federation of America, this morning to hear their objections to the Nunan bill, now in committee in the Assembly.

Handicaps of the higher ranked players were retained for the most part by the handicap committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America at its pre-championship meeting at the offices of the association yesterday.

Upon going to jail for contempt of the Senate, recently, William P. MacCracken Jr. summed up very nicely the procedure by which he was tried and convicted: "They [the Senate] adopted rules for the trial which made that body grand jury, prosecutor, trial jury and judge."

Controller Frank J. Taylor made public yesterday detailed reports showing the city's financial operations in January. He said he would make monthly reports within two weeks after the end of each month hereafter.

HAVANA, March 6. -- Ten persons were wounded today in five bomb explosions at the Custom House and the Treasury Department as radical students sought to force walk-outs by governmental employes in an attempt to promote a general revolutionary strike to oust President Carlos Mendieta and his Cabinet.

The knick-knack luncheon in behalf of the Nearly New Shop will take place today at the Versailles. A feature will be a fashion showing of the latest costumes for Spring wear in which young matrons and debutantes will act as manikins. Guests have been requested to bring packages of knick-knacks such as jewelry, vases, china or other household furnishings suitable for resale later at the shop.

The sale of Federal "baby bonds" in Manhattan and the Bronx since March 1 totaled $1,078,345 at 3 o'clock yesterday. With sales from other boroughs up to Tuesday night, the total sale for the city was $1,342,920.

CROYDON, England, March 6. -- Gloved bandits, who worked apparently under the very eyes of airport attendants, mysteriously removed $107,000 worth of gold from the closely guarded strong room of the Croydon Airdrome last night.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- So far as foreign trade is concerned the administration contends that the dollar has been given a definite gold value. As the balance of trade demands, gold has been both exported and imported at a flat price of $35 an ounce, to which figure it was raised from $20.67 when the dollar was devalued.

The effect of "a widespread weakening of Christian faith and of Christian moral standards," which has resulted in the surrender of individual liberty and a reversion to the tyrannies of communism and fascism, was stressed by Bishop William T. Manning in his annual Ash Wednesday sermon at the noon service yesterday in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street.

The fourth successive gain in manufacturing activity, as measured by man-hours worked, was recorded in January, the increase being 9.3 per cent over the December figures, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

A house divided against itself -- in its political sentiments, at least -- was manifest last evening at the Majestic Theatre where, for the first time during their present engagement, the Moscow Art Players offered to the general public a post-revolutionary drama with a definitely controversial theme.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 6 (AP). -- There won't be any feud this year between the National League's two most colorful and commanding personalities-Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean and George Herman (Babe) Ruth.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Early enactment of a measure establishing a State system of unemployment insurance seemed probable tonight after a long public hearing on the Byrne-Killgrew bill to set up a program to be synchronized with the proposed Federal plan.

BEVERLY, Mass., March 6. -- Citizens were in mourning here today, flags on all public buildings were at half-staff, and the North Shore city's industrial and social activities paused while preparations for the burial of its distinguished citizen, Oliver Wendell Holmes, were being made.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 6. -- A private meeting of Canadian financiers and members of the Legislature of Ontario was held tonight in Toronto in connection with a proposed reorganization of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company. R.O. Sweezey, representing the company, which for two years has been in receivership, is in Toronto and is believed to have attended the meeting, although he told newspaper men his visit there was for another purpose.

GUEVGUELI, Yugoslavia, March 16. -- Greece appears from reports reaching this frontier town to be paralyzed with fear and misgivings. Rail, telephone and telegraphic communications are cut off and normal activities are suspended.

Vincent Dailey, New York State manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, made his first public statement yesterday concerning charges that he and other officials of the HOLC were guilty of political favoritism and mismanagement of the activities of the corporation.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 7. -- The full squad of the 1935 Dodgers will go into action tomorrow morning. The second contingent reported to manager Casey Stengel this afternoon and six of them summoned sufficient energy to get into their uniforms for the afternoon workout.

Having previously rejected a suggestion by GEORGE McANENY that further large-scale, low-cost public housing projects be postponed until after another "comprehensive survey," the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday adopted a slum-clearance plan of its own.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- An increase in our foreign trade during January as compared with a year ago was shown in Commerce Department figures today. Exports for the month rose $4,002,000 and imports $21,300,000.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7. -- One of the fastest six-furlong races of the Hialeah meeting was turned in this afternoon when the Sage Stable's Bright Haven ran in front from start to finish to be clocked in 1:10 4-5. The 4-year-old son of Bright Knot was winner by a length and a half, with Bobby Merritt riding.
Business in the credit market was at a standstill, and quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Amid talk of possible war, and much mention of Japan, the Senate today added $20,000,000 to raise the Army Appropriation Bill to $400,000,000, nearly a record, and then pushed it to the point of passage.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The general level of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged during the week ending March 2, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1926 average, standing again at 79.6. On the corresponding date a year ago it stood at 73.6.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- An open-minded attitude by the United States toward joining with Great Britain in possible international efforts to assist China in that country's financial problems was expressed officially at the State Department today.
PARIS, March 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -Social leaders from many States arrived here today for the Yale junior promenade and incidental festivities which mark the annual social weekend, instead of the traditional Tuesday, on which it has been held for generations.

John D. Rockefeller 3d and Nelson A. Rockefeller were elected yesterday resident members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The brothers were nominated by their grandfather, John D. Rockefeller, and the nominations were seconded by their father, John D. Rockefeller Jr.

It would not be easy to overpraise the interpretation of Brahms's Requiem given last night by Arturo Toscanini and the chorus of the Schola Cantorum, with Elisabeth Rethberg and Friedrich Schorr as assisting artist, in Carnegie Hall. This was the third program of Mr. Toscanini's Brahms cycle.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Packers are making an effort to correct the disparity in prices between hogs and dressed pork. Fresh pork loins were advanced 1/2 cent today to 22 1/2 cents a pound, compared with 18 cents three weeks ago, while the demand for hogs was only fair and prices dropped 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight.

The members of the Amherst Association of New York, composed of alumni of the college, held their annual dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt last night. The speakers were Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads; Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn and President Stanley King of Amherst.

Louis Weber, who is said to be one of the "higher-ups" in the policy racket in Brooklyn, was one of eleven defendants to go on trial yesterday before County Judge Taylor in Brooklyn on policy charges.

Counsel for 23,000 Insull investors turned yesterday to the Irving Trust Company. It was the second among the group of banks being sued before Federal Judge. Julian W. Mack on a complaint that they got their present control of Samuel Insull's chief operating companies by permitting him to pledge illegally the stock holdings of his investment corporation.

Mme. Elisabeth Rethberg, one of the principal dramatic sopranos of the Metropolitan Opera, was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of stealing the affections and wrecking the home of one of her fellow artists, Ezio Pinza, a leading basso of the company.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 7. -- An annual per capita tax of $20 as a means of financing their intercollegiate athletic program has met with the approval of students of Cornell University.

The State of New Hampshire will open bids on next Friday on its new issue of $1,000,000 of 2 per cent permanent highway bonds dated March 1, 1935, and maturing $100,000 annually from 1936 to 1945. Charles T. Patten, State Treasurer, in a brochure outlines the State's financing position.

BEACON, N.Y. March 7. -- Although his fifteen-round meeting with Primo Camera is still a week away Ray Impellittiere has reached the point where his training routine must be cut to avoid staleness. The young Italian heavyweight displayed his wares before newspaper men today and appeared ready for his long-awaited engagement with the former world's champion.

A proposal to take the power of sentence in criminal cases away from judges and place it in the hands of a commission was made yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith at a luncheon meeting of the National Probation Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Robert Edmond Jones, whose revivals at the Central City (Col.) Opera House are a Summer event, has decided on his next venture there. Having stirred the theatrical shades of that ghost town annually since 1932, he now telegraphs from Culver City, Calif., as follows:

LONDON, March 7. -- With sterling fairly steady for the first time in a week Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said tonight he saw no reason whatever for worrying and no possibility of stabilizing now.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The President conferred with Senator Tydings on the prospects for independence in the Philippines, the Senator reporting afterward that there was "no change" in the situation.

THOMAS WOLFE'S "Look Homeward, Angel" was published in October of 1929. His mountainous 450,000-word, 912-page novel, "Of Time and the River" (Scribner, $3), is published today. Between the two dates Mr. Wolfe has grown to the proportions of an American legend.

LONDON, March 7. -- A member of the British Government in the person of Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, will presently visit Moscow and Warsaw successively to discuss there the recent AngloFrench declaration and its implications. The date of the visits has not yet been fixed.

Plans for altering the eight-story apartment house at 35 West Ninety-sixth Street into smaller suites were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee for the Van Raalte estate.

ATHENS, March 7. -- Increasing concern was felt today for the safety of fourteen American men and women and one child trapped among Venizelist revolutionaries between the Struma and Nestos Rivers in Macedonia, of whom nothing has been learned since an indirect message by way of Saloniki Monday night assured that they had not been harmed in the early skirmishes.

Office, showroom and store space in Manhattan was taken in large volume yesterday by furriers, milliners, hatters, cloak and suit manufacturers and others in the apparel trades. The leasing extended over a wide area, from Nassau Street to the midtown section.

An appeal to the medical profession to take up arms against the "unthinking" movement toward "mad nationalism" and to engage in a "sane internationalism" to ward off wars and the spread of plagues was sounded last night at a dinner meeting of the International Medical Club of America at the Lotos Club.

A decline of $33,000,000 in memberbank reserves, due chiefly to a more than seasonal increase of $36,000,000 in the amount of money in circulation, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the statement of the Federal Reserve System published yesterday.

Willie Krosmeier and Lothar Ehmer, a pair of young German cyclists making their first appearance in this country, developed into a threat last night as the twelve teams remaining in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden pedaled away toward the end of their self-imposed sentence.
CHICAGO, March 7. -- Dr. Franklin H. Martin of Chicago was one of the foremost gynecologists and surgeons of the United States and was internationally known for his writings and research.

Sir Malcolm Campbell's chief hobby is driving automobiles at death-defying speeds -- not on city streets or country roads, but on hard, smooth straightaway beach courses. Six times he has net new world's speed records for a mile, and in 1931 King George V bestowed the accolade of knighthood upon him.

LONDON, March 7. -- The unofficial World Economic Conference sponsored by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace finished its work today. It has framed a series of recommendations covering trade barriers, currency stabilization and world peace which are now being put in formal shape by a special committee and will be issued tomorrow.

In announcing the reduction of the dividend of the Guaranty Trust Company, William C. Potter, the chairman, called attention to the chief cause of declining bank earnings -"the lack of use by business of the superabundant bank credit available."

Brooklyn Prep and Loyola High were eliminated in the opening round of the first annual Jesuit prep school basketball tournament in Jersey City yesterday, Brooklyn bowing to Xavier High's quintet, 31 to 18, and Loyola losing to Fordham Prep, 28 to 25.

Establishment of the Association of American Railroads has obviated the necessity for the office of Federal Coordinator of Transportation, now held by Joseph B. Eastman, John J. Pelley, president of the association, asserted last night in a radio address.

United States Government bonds continued to work lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday, although other obligations showed rallying tendencies. Losses in government loans ranged from 1-32 to 13-32 point except the Liberty 3 1/2s and the First Liberty 4 1/4s, which were up 4-32 and 3-32, respectively.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Sharp denial of four new charges made against Postmaster General Farley by Senator Long, alleging the influencing of Department of Justice investigators in Kansas City and Tennessee, influencing the selection of all engineers on Federal public works and "hounding" witnesses against him, was made tonight by the Postmaster General.

PITTSBURGH, March 7. -- Government counsel played a strong card this afternoon in their battle to collect more than $3,000,000 from Andrew W. Mellon in additional taxes and penalties for 1931, while he was serving as Secretary of the Treasury.

The city of Newark petitioned the Trunk Line Association yesterday for a revision of practices and charges in the handling of freight which are alleged to have caused commercial traffic to be diverted to rival ports which have more favorable regulations.

An intrepid harbor seal appeared in the upper bay near the Statue of Liberty yesterday, but before the crew of the steamer Hook Mountain could come out of their igloos and bring their spears to play it had dived and disappeared.

MEXICO, D.F., March 7. -- The private secretary of Archbishop Pascual Diaz, Roman Catholic primate of Mexico, said tonight the Archbishop had been arrested today while on his way to the town of Tlalnepantla, in Mexico Federal District.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Belief that the log jam holding back the flow of private corporation issues in the capital market would soon be broken was expressed today by Joseph P.
