Kennedy, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as Swift Co. of Chicago, registered a $43,000,000 refunding bond issue under the Securities Act of 1933.

MADRID, March 7. -- Simultaneous reports from four points near Madrid today indicated a systematic sabotage of mail in the postal trains by disgruntled employes of the Ministry of Communications in protest against the recent dissolution of employes' labor organizations.

The National Life Conservation Society, which held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Room of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, adopted a resolution instructing the president of the organization, Mrs. Charles Cyrus Marshall, to write to Governor Lehman requesting that an appropriation be made to continue the nature trails and museums at Bear Mountain.
ALBANY, March 7. -- A bill aimed at rigid protection of the five-cent subway fare and backed by the New York City administration was introduced in the Legislature today.
HAMBURG, March 7 (AP). -- Both reported at peak form, Max Schmeling and Steve Hamas ended hard work today for their ten-round match Sunday.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation issued last night a statement relative to the suit brought by the Federal Government on Wednesday against it and the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation and eight individuals, alleging violation of the anti-trust laws.

LONDON, March 7. -- Three years ago Dr. Louis Leakey, a young Cambridge anthropologist, came out of East Africa with a piece of a skull and a jawbone that he declared were "the most ancient fragments of true men yet discovered." This belief has now been discredited after some of the most famous British scientists endorsed the finds as genuine.

The conditions under which the Juilliard Foundation offers the Metropolitan Opera the sum of $150,000 as partial guarantee against the deficit of next season handsomely carry out the letter and spirit of AUGUSTUS JUILIARD'S bequest by saving the Metropolitan at a crisis, expanding the operatic horizon and offering American singers unprecedented opportunities.

VIENNA, March 7. -- The trial of Dr. Anton Rintelen for treason in connection with the Nazi "putsch" of last July 25 in which Chancellor Dollfuss was killed reached dramatic heights today when four of the colleagues of the accused in the Dollfuss administration unanimously stated that Dr. Dollfuss deeply mistrusted Dr. Rintelen for his alleged intriguing and reported ambition to become Chancellor.

DENVER, March 7. -- Mrs. Elizabeth (Baby Doe) Tabor, widow of H. A. W. Tabor, spectacular Colorado silver operator of the Eighties, was found dead this afternoon in her shack home at the Matchless Mine at Leadville.

PRAGUE, March 7. -- President Thomas Garrigue Masaryk's eighty-fifth birthday was enthusiastically celebrated today by all Czechoslovakia, including the minorities, with only the Communists standing aloof.

Ravenous marlin that strike with fury, hooking themselves on the first vicious onslaught; marlin of incredible speed and strength, tearing off 500 yards of line in a single burst; marlin that leap six, seven or eight times in one dazzling series of acrobatic contortions; warriors that literally fight to the death.
Capturing six of the eight events, the Rutgers swimming team defeated New York University, 43 to 25, last night in the Park Central Hotel pool.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Reports from Manila that former Senator Harry B. Hawes of Missouri has aspirations to be Resident High Commissioner in the Philippines when constitutional government is established brought emphatic denials from Mr. Hawes today.

ROME, March 7. -- The Gavinana Division is being concentrated at Naples to embark for the African colonies. Trains crowded with troops from Florence passed through Rome all day, awaking the curiosity and enthusiasm of travelers in the station.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- A "possibility but hardly a probability" that a House vote on cash payment of the $2,000,000,000 bonus might be delayed beyond next week was foreseen today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee.

Charles Morgan, who was appointed by the late George Moore as his biographer and for several years worked with him, has announced that access to a group of letters which he and Moore regarded as essential has been denied him and that he has abandoned the biography.

Charles Francis Coe, author, has been nominated unanimously for the presidency of the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street, and will be elected without opposition March 16 at the clubhouse and assume office April 1, according to a club announcement yesterday.

Among the great contrasts in Europe today none is more remarkable than the existence of Czechoslovakia, an island of democracy, in the midst of a sea of autocracy, and the story of Czechoslovakia is in large degree the story of her President, Thomas Garrigue Masaryk.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 7. -- The annual session of the New England Intercollegiate Model League of Nations will open here tomorrow with 300 official delegates from thirty-one colleges and universities meeting under the banners of the sixty member nations of the league.

Further advances in livestock and meat prices in the week ended on Tuesday were almost entirely offset by lower prices elsewhere, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices in consequence rose only 0.1 point to 125.0 from 124.9 the Tuesday before.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -The administration's omnibus bill to strengthen Washington's control over the banking system was attacked tonight in a statement signed by sixty-six economists, most of them members of college faculties.

George A. Sloan, former president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, announced yesterday the formation of a new textile merchandising company, to be know as George A. Sloan Co., Inc., which will distribute the products of American mills in domestic and foreign markets.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Profits and rates of return for 409 cotton textile mills, including the spinning, weaving, dyeing and finishing branches, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission in the fifth instalment of its report on the textile industry.

ATHENS, March 7. -- The Greek government admitted today that the rebels had taken possession of the islands of Samos, Mytilene and Chios. Chios is the birthplace of Mme. Eleutherios Venizelos, wife of the rebel leader.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia, Fundamentalist leader on trial here before an ecclesiastical special commission, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he disobeyed and defied the higher authorities of the Presbyterian Church.

ALBANY, March 7 (AP). -- Making their final plea before the Legislature for defeat of the controversial college-oath bill, a spokesman for a delegation of 500 students told legislators today such legislation "will only serve to intensify radicalism."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
ALBANY, March 7. -- Governor Lehman will confer in Washington Thursday with Secretary Wallace in an effort to obtain Federal cooperation in meeting New York's milk-control problem.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7. -- Baseball's highest paid pitcher was on exhibition today. Lefty Vernon Gomez, four days overdue at camp, arrived last night and at Huggins Field today had on the Yankee spangles for the first time since he hung up his spiked shoes at the close of last season with 26 victories, 5 defeats and an earned run average of 2.33 to his credit.
"After Office Hours," co-starting Clark Gable and Constance Bennett, and featuring Stuart Erwin. Billie Burke and Harvey Stephens, opens this morning at the Capitol.

Although foreign selling of newcrop months depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange in the first hour yesterday, buying created resistance and left the list 3 points higher to a point lower than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- When Joseph P. Kennedy had just taken office as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission this column ventured the following prophecy:

Standard Brands, Inc., showed in its annual report for 1934, issued yesterday, a net income of $13,384,490 after expenses, depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other deductions. This is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to about $1.06 a share on the common stock outstanding.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 7. -- Troops are concentrating along the Pacific for the annual Canal Zone manoeuvres, which are shrouded in war-time secrecy, with the department commander, Major Gen. Harold B. Fiske, apparently the only person who knows when and where the troops will be sent.
Two obstructions blocked the public campaign for funds for the defense of Bruno Richard Hauptmann yesterday.

All the markets regained their composure yesterday after the unsettlement that had been occasioned on the preceding day by a misinterpretation of President Roosevelt's remarks at a press conference on the desirability of a higher price level for commodities.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7. -Diplomatic friction between Argentina and Chile is believed to have been ended by a conciliatory statement today by Foreign Minister Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal of Chile. It is hoped that the Argentine Ambassador will now return to Santiago.

The adverse weather conditions against which retailers are struggling in the development of Spring retail trade were emphasized by the snowstorm here yesterday. The interest in Spring apparel and accessories shown on the previous day disappeared entirely and most upper-floor departments of stores here were very lightly patronized.

NEWARK, N.J., March 7. -Charges that gambling flourished without interference at a roadhouse on the Palisades in Fort Lee, known as the Riviera, as well as at other places in Bergen County, were made at the first public hearing of the State Assembly committee investigating Bergen County affairs.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 (AP). -- Perhaps it isn't the smartest thing in the world to boost the other fellow's business, but Will Harridge, president of the league that lost Babe Ruth, conceded frankly today that the home-run king probably is in for a robust season as a Boston Brave.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 7. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell hitched his thunder wagon to a streak of lightning today and roared down Daytona's sands to a new world automobile speed record -- 276.816 miles an hour.
PARIS, Friday, March 8 (AP). -- A dispatch telephoned today to the Petit Journal from Guevgueli, Yugoslavia, said hospitals at Saloniki, Greece, were full of soldiers wounded in a battle with rebels.
MIAMI, Fla., March 7. -- Mrs. Alfred I. du Pont of New York and Philadelphia entertained with a luncheon today on the clubhouse terrace at Hialeah Park. Her guests were:
LONDON, March 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

TWO men were seated at a luncheon table dallying with their Lenten salads and pausing now and then to look at the whirling snow outside. "Just think of those lucky birds getting sun-tanned in Miami," said the party of the first part, who was Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, under-secretary of the New York Giants.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 7. -- All four favorites won their secondround matches today in the Florida East Coast championship for the Mrs. W. R. Kenan Jr. Cup on St. Augustine links. The successful contestants to enter the semi-finals were the Misses Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J.; Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I.; Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., and Mary Rogers of Jacksonville, Fla.
VIENNA, March 7. -- The longpromised general offensive by the Greek Government -- which was today to have rolled up the rebel army -- seems once again to have come to nothing.

Tentative rules for the registration of securities of investment companies which have been drafted by the Securities and Exchange Commission were discussed on Wednesday at a meeting of representatives of the leading investment companies with members of the commission in Washington.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 7. -- Prime Minister Bennett, who had planned to return to Parliament today after two weeks' absence because of influenza, suffered a relapse and had to return to bed. An official bulletin said the Prime Minister "had been improving daily until this morning, when he suffered a setback.

City sales tax collections totaled $13,427.27 yesterday, it was reported by City Collector William Reid Jr., the highest daily total since March 1, when collection of the tax was started. The total sales tax receipts to date are $31,495.23.

PARIS, March 7. -- Although trading remained reduced on the Bourse today, the trend was steadier. Most securities, including rentes, recovered part of their recent losses, but the close was irregular. Young Plan bonds and gold mines were firm, while Suez Canal declined slightly.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday reached a new high mark for the year, with a total of $5,947,995,000 for the twentytwo leading cities throughout the country, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The gain was 13.3 per cent from the $5,248,767,000 reported in the corresponding week a year ago and compared with a rise of 8 per cent in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- An official "outline" of the testimony of Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, before the Senate Finance Committee's inquiry into the NRA today follows:

BERLIN, March 7. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed and quiet today, certain stocks regaining their recent losses. Heavy industrials were mixed and unstable, no significant changes occurring. Potashes were slightly weaker, machines suffered some losses, chemicals showed firmness and textiles were firm but quiet.

Controller Taylor announced yesterday that he had advised J.P. Morgan Co., agents of the committee of banks which finances the city under the terms of the Bankers' Agreement, that he would have to borrow $20,000,000 on March 12. The loan, of the type provided for in the agreement, will be in anticipation of 1935 real estate taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Following is the text of the address on "Our Blundering Government and Its Spokesman -- Hugh Johnson," by Senator Long over a coastto-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company as transcribed stenographically by representatives of the National Broadcasting Company:

ALBANY, March 7. -- Letters showing that Dr. William Lathrop Love, former Brooklyn Senator, sought and obtained work as a medical compensation expert from the Consolidated Gas System while a member of the Legislature were introduced today at a hearing of the legislative committee investigating public utilities.
ALBANY, March, 7. -- The letters exchanged between former State Senator Love of Brooklyn aug officials of the Consolidated Gas system are as follows:

A message from General Hugh S. Johnson and a talk by Lowell Thomas, radio commentator, were features of the first meeting of the D.H.C. Boys Club of Hearn's Department Store yesterday afternoon in the store's auditorium, 20 West Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- A determined movement to vote for the Home Owners Loan Corporation more funds than asked by the administration developed in the House today, several speakers announcing an intention to seek a fresh grant of $2,000,000,000 instead of the $1,500,000,000 proposed in the bill.

An amendment cutting hours from forty to thirty-five a week, proposed by the Metropolitan Knitted Textile Association, was rejected yesterday by the Knitted Outerwear Code Authority, on the ground that the reduction is contrary to the best interests of the industry.

Enactment of the Economic Security Bill providing for unemployment insurance and old age pensions was urged yesterday by Senator Wagner in an address before 1,000 business men, industrialists and financiers at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

The last of the dwindling band of hurdy-gurdy men, whose Italian arias and slightly shop-worn popular ballads enlivened the metropolitan life of bygone days, will no longer have to pay a license fee to the city, and will receive their permits free -- if they pass certain requirements -- from the Department of Welfare.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -The Supreme Court indicated today that it would dismiss the appeal of Harry Semler, a dentist, challenging the validity of the Oregon law prohibiting advertising by dentists.

In issuing the annual report to stockholders of North American Aviation, Inc., J. H. Kindelberger, president, and Ernest R. Breech, chairman of the board, stated yesterday that conditions in the airtransport industry would not encourage the company to continue in it "unless more reasonable legislation is obtained."
NEWARK, N.J., March 7 (AP). -Trustees of The Newark Ledger today obtained a Chancery Court order temporarily restraining striking editorial workers from picketing and other strike activities.

Irrespective of the demerits of HUEY LONG, it is hard to be much impressed by the tardy insurrection in the Senate against the chief orator and actor in its proceedings. For four years he has cowed the most aught assembly on earth. On the Senate side the Congressional Record may be said to have become his personal organ.

In recommending a bonus bill to the House the Ways and Means Committee has plumped for the Vinson plan. It is an expensive choice. This measure not only proposes to redeem in cash, ten years before they lawfully mature, the adjusted-service certificates now outstanding.

GENEVA, March 7. -- Bulgaria's delegate to the League of Nations, M. Antonoff, handed to Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General, an aide memoire this evening charging Turkey had concentrated six divisions in European Turkey near Bulgaria's frontier, was making feverish preparations for war and was inciting the population against Bulgaria without cause.

PARIS, March 7. -- If the fall of the pound continues France will resort to an exchange surtax against British goods. Louis GermainMartin told the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee today. The question of sterling's collapse also formed the subject of conversations at this morning's Cabinet council at which it was agreed that the situation had not progressed far enough to call for any decisions yet.

MOSCOW, March 7. -- The second defeat within three days was meted out today to Mischa Botwinnik, Soviet champion and leader in the international chess masters' tournament at the Museum Beaux Arts, in consequence of which his hold on first place becomes somewhat doubtful.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 7 (AP). -- The death of Mrs. H. Bradley Davidson Jr. in her garage last week remained an official mystery today as a coroner's jury wound up its inquest with an open verdict which failed to specify whether it was accident, suicide or murder.
ALBANY, March 7. -- The Dunnigan bill, broadening the control of the State Racing Commission in accordance with the agreement with the Jockey Club, was passed unanimously in the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The army of unemployed is being "steadily" decreased by re-employment of jobless in normal occupations, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, declared today.
The long-threatened strike of elevator operators and other service employes in the Bronx went into effect at 10 A.M. yesterday with contradictory claims as to its effectiveness.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander von Dehn of Rome, who are visiting their cousins, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dehn of 510 Park Avenue, gave a reception and tea for Princess Dolly Obolensky yesterday afternoon in the Nether]and Room of the SherryNetherland.
In the Review of the Week in last Sunday's TIMES appeared the following item concerning the NRA:

Following consultation with leading specialists and floor traders, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms will forward today to the Securities and Exchange Commission its suggestions in connection with the commission's recently drafted tentative rules to govern specialists, floor traders, odd-lot dealers and short selling on Stock exchanges.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia Club and Harry F. Wolf of the New York A. C., the two men who have held the championship between them over a period of eight years, gained the final round of the national amateur squash tennis tourney yesterday.

The question asked by Mr. McBride in his letter printed in your edition of March 4 may be answered in the form of another question: How much would Mr. McBride pay for a bond which is receiving no interest at all and which, if ever restored to good standing, would probably suffer a very substantial cut in the nominal principal and rate of interest?

LONDON, March 7. -- The stock markets here were firmer today, on signs of returning confidence, although uncertain political and foreign exchange factors restricted business. British funds were fractionally better, as speculative selling fell off.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 7. -- The British Imperial Airways yacht Imperia arrived here today bringing first-hand news of affairs on the Island of Crete, Venizelist stronghold. According to the captain of the yacht two men were killed aboard the rebel cruiser Averoff when loyal seaplanes dropped bombs on her last week, but the Averoff shot down the two seaplanes in flames.

An "unholy alliance" to sovietize basic industry, the creaking burden of taxation on real estate and the possibility of reducing electric rates were emphasized yesterday at the annual Eastern Regional Savings Conference of the Savings Division of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Of all people on earth, or at least in Greater New York, the two men who should not use the words "rough guy" as terms of unmitigated contempt are Mayor LA GUARDIA and Park Commissioner MOSES. Yet that is the way they speak of Civic Virtue clubbing the sirens in front of City Hall.

The Fencers Club trio of foil wielders handed the University F. C. team a 5-to-1 defeat last night to win the national senior foils team title of the Amateur Fencers League of America for another year. A large gallery gathered at the Fencers Club for the first major team championship of the current campaign.

It is reported on excellent authority that the famous nineteenth century American artist, John La Farge, earnestly hoped none of his children would follow their father's profession. He probably wanted his sons to be regular business men. In any event, they must not mess around with paint.

The sixth annual Greater New York Safety Conference, which closed its three-day sessions yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, adopted a resolution urging public officials throughout the country to study and develop a safety program for employes of municipal and State governments.

WASHINGTON, March 7.Thepersonality and character of OliverWendell Holmes will be reflected inthe services held tomorrow for thesoldier, jurist, scholar and gentleman, to whom life was at once alyric and a high adventure and,death but its natural and restfulconclusiom

Your editorial today voices half regret, half astonishment at an ever-increasing number of homicides in this country. Various theories are advanced toward an explanation, but to me the solution is obvious.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures opened its annual convention yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 200 members attended and heard Dr. Worth M. Tippy of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America declare that the present moral code as expressed in motion pictures needs revision.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 7. -- Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie signed an order today which placed the affairs of the city of Asbury Park in the hands of the State Municipal Finance Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The Code Authority for the Domestic Freight Forwarding Industry has submitted to the NIRB a proposal that the same weekly or monthly rate of pay be maintained for a lesser number of working hours as was paid for the greater number of hours in force before the effective date of the code.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Senator Huey Long of Louisiana had his opportunity tonight to reply in kind to the bitter personal attack made upon him by General Hugh S. Johnson in the now-famous speech of the former head of the NRA.

A mistrial was declared in a case in Municipal Court, Central Jury Part, by Justice Charles Garside yesterday morning when Samuel J. Sussman of 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, attorney for the defense, disclosed that a juror had offered to "bring home the bacon" for him if it was made worth his while.

VINELAND, N.J., March 7. -- The explosion of a 1,000-gallon unlicensed still in the woods at Malaga, near here, at 3 o'clock this morning resulted in the death of one man and the critical injury of two others, according to the police.
The campaign of the Knights of Columbus to "revitalize its 2,500 units for greater service in Catholic action," received the endorsement of Cardinal Hayes yesterday.

LONDON, March 7. -- The name of John Howeson, the most important figure in the British tin industry, was linked in the House of Commons today to the gambling in pepper and shellac that shook the commodity markets of London last month.

Metropolitan Opera that will be more up to date while maintaining present high standards was promised in statements issued yesterday by Herbert Witherspoon, the newly appointed general manager, and Ernest Hutcheson, one of three new members of the board of directors representing the Juilliard Musical Foundation.

ST. LOUIS, March 7 (AP). -- The New York Americans tonight lost their last chance to get into the National Hockey League play-offs when the Eagles defeated them, 3 to 2. Outplayed throughout, the Americans suffered their fourth defeat at the hands of the St. Louis Club.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 7 (AP). -- An ever-widening field of Federal supervision over the nation's commerce, sanctioned by the courts, was predicted tonight by General Hugh S. Johnson.

PARIS, March 7. -- The stormy parliamentary career of Philibert Besson, noted process and jail dodger, was ended this morning when the Chamber of Deputies voted by 335 to 28 to deprive him of his seat and his parliamentary immunity.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Expressing his shock at murders allegedly linked with the policy racket inquiry, Assemblyman Albert D. Schanzer, Brooklyn Democrat, announced today that he was preparing a resolution calling for a legislative investigation of the police of New York City.

The DeWitt Clinton High School basketball team, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, advanced another step toward the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division P. S. A. L. title by defeating Evander Childs High, 29 to 21, yesterday in the DeWitt Clinton gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Water power provisions of the WheelerRayburn Utility Holding Company Bill now before the House Interstate Commerce Committee are "conceived entirely as a supplement to, and not a substitute for, State regulation," according to an analysis of Title II made today by Clyde L. Seavey, member of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,459,000,000, an increase of $6,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $100,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

The executive committee of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, meeting yesterday at their headquarters, 1,267 Sixth Avenue, voted to carry out "uncompromisingly" the union's demand for a $3 tax on each player in orchestra broadcasting from hotels and restaurants.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Granting of funds by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for large-scale manufacture of print paper from fast-growing Southern yellow pine is expected by Southern Senators and Representatives who have discussed the situation with Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC.

Mrs. Taber Sears gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. Childe Hassam, Mrs. F. Robertson Jones, Mrs. Edward P. York, Mrs. Ripley Hitchcock, Mrs. John Larkin, Mrs. Edward H. Denby, Mrs. Charles C. Nadal, the Misses Mary L. Pruyn, Louise Barrows, E. Mabel Clark and Neltje K. Pruyn.

LONDON, March 7. -- Arnold Ridley, author of "The Ghost Train," seems to have scored another success with "Glory Be," produced at the Phoenix Theatre tonight. The play is about an amorous Welsh revivalist and the daughter of the preacher's host.

Mayor La Guardia's insistence that the city's proposed bill for transit unification include the direction that the holders of Board of Transit Control bonds, issued in part payment for traction company properties, be given a prior lien on earnings of the lines after their purchase by the city is the real obstacle in the way of approval of the city's legislative program by the Transit Commission, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -The New Deal tonight arranged to take advantage of a little-used power to condemn land to acquire title to 5,000 acres in the Midwestern drought area -- the start of a 5,000,000 to 7,000,000-acre purchase program.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Repeal of the income publicity provisions of the Revenue Act of 1934 will be voted on by the House tomorrow or Monday, according to plans completed today, and House leaders expect the measure to pass. The Doughton resolution calling for such repeal was reported favorably today.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 7. -- John Tranum, holder of world records for parachute jumping, perished today in an attempt to better his own mark.
ST. GEORGE, Utah, March 7 (AP). -- Death and disaster ruled tonight in this little town where Brigham Young, who led the Mormons into Utah, is said to have predicted great riches.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade opened slightly higher today with aggressive selling absent, and before the close an oversold condition was disclosed. Strength in stocks toward the last brought in sufficient outside and local buying, as well as short covering, to lift wheat and corn more than 1 cent a bushel from Wednesday's finish.
Nine properties in Manhattan were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Tenement buildings formed the bulk of the improvements. Several of the parcels went to savings banks.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- NRA codes should be limited to trades and industries actually engaged in interstate commerce or those "affecting it substantially." Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, declared today before the Senate Finance Committee as it began an inquiry into the recovery program in connection with the administration's request for a two-year extension of NIRA.

The Spring-like weather of Wednesday gave way yesterday to intermittent rain and snow flurries that covered the city's streets with slush. From a maximum temperature of 68 degrees Wednesday afternoon, the mercury dropped to 31 at 6:30 o'clock last night.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7. -- The first graduating class in Max Carey's Miami baseball school took an advanced course in America's great national game today by trying its skill against Professor Bill Terry and his Giants, and for a time the young men did amazingly well.
Resales by financial institutions were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- All hope for an early adjournment of Congress, unless the administration is willing to scrap some of its program, was abandoned today by Democratic party leaders.

It is getting harder every day to tell the friends of the NRA from its foes. Senator HASTINGS challenges "anybody" in the Senate to defend the NRA, and there is silence. Is this because the NRA has no friends, or is it because Senators can no longer make up their minds about it?

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- A movement to depose their present leader, Representative Bertrand H. Snell of New York, on the ground that he "lacks aggressiveness" and "is not building up a platform for 1936" was disclosed today by a group of House Republicans.

Commodity futures were generally firm in the trading here yesterday, although price movements were narrow. As a rule the markets were more active than on Wednesday. In the cash markets, all the grains, dairy products and silk were higher, and cocoa and tin were lower.

ALBANY, March 7. -- A bill creating a State commission of fifteen members to make a thorough study of unemployment insurance was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Baldwin, Republican, of New York.

Twenty policemen will be subpoenaed in an effort to trace connections between the police and "higher-ups" in the policy racket, it was announced last night by Samuel Marcus, special Assistant District Attorney in charge of the policy investigation and counsel to the Society for the Prevention of Crime.
The regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association was set for Poughkeepsie on Tuesday, June 18, at a meeting of the board of stewards held yesterday at the Downtown Association.
ALBANY, March 7. -- The bill designed to end alleged medical abuses, such as fee splitting, under the Workmen's Compensation Law, was passed today in the Senate, 41 to 3.

Net operating income of 145 Class 1 railroads in January was $21,348,557, against $31,058,275 in the same month in 1934, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics of the Association of American Railroads. Gross operating revenues were $264,213,172, against $258,014,517, and operating expenses were $212,971,508, against $195,866,222.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7. -- Close victories and a pair of major upsets featured the first round of the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today. Three of the eight matches went the full route of thirty-six holes, with veteran teams coming out on top.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7. -Against the tropical setting of the Orange Gardens illuminated with blue and orange lights, a pageant of medieval splendor took place tonight; the eighteenth Everglades Club Costume Ball. Pages, Pirates, Oriental Potentates and figures from history, legends and ballads mingled on the dance patio.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, who turned over to the District Attorney Wednesday the names of thirteen persons allegedly connected with a vice ring operating in Women's Court, declared yesterday in an interview that the whole system of combating vice was wrong and that vice cases should not be handled in a court of law.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 (AP). -The judges had to call on the electric camera to decide that Vanita, Mrs. E. A. Gross's 3-year-old filly, won the Valley Hunt Club $1,000 Handicap in the mud today at Santa Anita Park.

LONDON, March 7. -- All church services throughout the British Empire will close with the singing of the national anthem, "God Save the King," during the celebration of the royal jubilee, it was announced here today.

Father Charles E. Coughlin was asked yesterday by Harcourt, Brace, publishers, why "almost half" of his radio speech of March 3 "contains unquoted and uncredited parallels to passages in our recent copyrighted publication entitled 'The Economic Consequences of the New Deal.'"

E. H. Boles, president of the General Alliance Corporation, which owns all of the stock of the General Reinsurance Corporation and, directly and indirectly, all but a small minority of the stock of North Star Insurance Company, reported yesterday that the surplus of each of the operating companies had been increased materially last year.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Without the machinery for adjusting labor controversies provided by the Wagner labor disputes bill the National Labor Relations Board will steadily become more ineffective, according to Francis Biddle, chairman of the board, who said today that passage of the Wagner measure was vital to continuance of the board as an effective agency.
NEW ORLEANS, March 7 (AP). -Two Brooms, a 4-year-old owned by G. Cruise, ran away from his field in the mile feature at the Fair Grounds today.
HAVANA, Friday, March 8. -The government has moved energetically to combat the spread of the revolutionary general strike movement.

DETROIT, March 7. -- Giving a great exhibition, both on the offense and the defense, the Detroit Red Wings outclassed the New York Rangers tonight, defeating them 6 to 1 and retaining a slim mathematical chance of getting into the National Hockey League play-offs.

Major J. Divine, the stocky Negro, who is Father Divine to many of Harlem's residents, let Magistrate Anthony J. Burke get a glimpse of what he held in his left hand yesterday, and it cost him $500 additional bail money for himself and Faithful Mary, a follower.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Payment to depositors in closed national banks of 60 per cent of their proved claims is provided in a bill introduced jointly today by Senators Moore and Barbour of New Jersey.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 7. -- It's the usual custom for a writer or speaker to tell how much better England or France or Zululand have handled their money than the U.S.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 7. -- The drastic decision of the dictatorial triumvirate of the Estonian Republic -- President Konstantin Paets, Generalissimo Johan Laidoner and Interior Minister Karl Einbund -- to prohibit every expression of political thought and activity is regarded as a last effort to "pacify" the nation by non-constitutional methods, which were introduced on March 12, 1934, but have still proved futile.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -The Princeton wrestling team ended its season with a 17-13 victory over Lehigh in the university gym tonight. It was the first time in over a decade that the Orange and Black had beaten the Engineers.

Operations in 1934 of the Corn Products Refining Company resulted in a net income of $9,702,696 after the deduction of interest, taxes, depreciation, provision for contingencies and other charges. After provision had been made for the regular dividend of 7 per cent on the preferred stock, the net income was equal to $3.16 a share on the outstanding common stock.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 7 (Canadian Press). -- The first Colonial cricket match between the touring Marylebone Cricket Club and a picked Jamaica eleven went to a draw today. Scores for the threeday contest were: Jamaica 305 and 146 for three, declared; M.C.C. 289 and 75 for one.

Summing up by attorneys in Mrs. Wilma E. Gould's $500,000 conspiracy suit began yesterday afternoon before Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer and a jury, after Mrs. Gould had taken the stand in rebuttal to deny the reflections upon her character made by defense witnesses.

The appointment of Harold O. Vosburgh as racing steward representing the five New York State associations during the 1935 season was regarded a practical certainty yesterday following a meeting of the stewards of the Jockey Club at which officials were appointed, jockeys and trainers licensed and other business was transacted.

Miss Elizabeth McGuirk, 21 years old, of 33 Washington Square, a nurse, was injured internally at 7:10 A.M. yesterday when the car of her sister, Margaret, also a nurse, which she was driving north on the elevated viaduct at Forty-second Street and Park Avenue, skidded on newly formed ice across the pavement, smashed through the west guard rail, and fell twenty-five feet.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- A campaign by the American Federation of Labor to organize the steel industry this Spring is now hardly a remote possibility. This is the result of the "purge" now going on within the Alamlagated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers which has resulted in the revocation of charters of eighteen local unions led by "rank and file" spokesmen.

The increasing importance of lighter steel products, such as automobile sheets, strip and wire, is reflected in the gain in steel production last year over the total for 1933, according to an analysis by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
At the first meeting, held here yesterday, of directors of the new Studebaker Corporation, Harold S. Vance was elected chairman of the board of directors and Paul G. Hoffman was elected president.

The governing committee of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association has granted charters to eight new fleets, it was announced yesterday. This is not an accumulation of applications, as four previous charters had been granted since the first of the year.

Sir MALCOLM CAMPBELL in the Bluebird skims over the sands of Daytona at the record-breaking speed of 276.816 miles an hour and risks his life. For him it is either glory or death. In the days when fifty miles an hour was regarded as miraculous the race track was the laboratory of the engineer.
PARIS, March 8. -- A rate war among transatlantic steamship companies was averted today when the Bernstein Line agreed to join the North Atlantic Shipping Conference at its meeting here.
Numerous leases to wholesale and retail firms in the midtown area were reported yesterday.

An unexpectedly high yield of $1,518,771.40 for the January instalment of the city's 3 per cent tax upon the earnings of public utilities was announced yesterday by City Collector William Reid Jr. Returns still to be filed, it was said, may increase the total by another $50,000.

TUCKER PRISON FARM, Ark., March 8 (AP). -- Mark H. Shank, 43, former Ohio magistrate, died in the electric chair at 7:14 A.M. today for the poisoning of a family of four in Saline County, Ark., in August, 1933.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- As a result of events in the Senate today administration followers there were beginning to fear tonight that the combination of Senator Long and Father Coughlin was being directed toward upsetting President Roosevelt's $4,880,000,000 work relief resolution.

Ultimate recovery from the depression depends in very large measure on the building industry, Robert E. Simon said yesterday in an address before the closing session of the Eastern Savings Conference of the Savings Division, American Bankers Association.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 8 (AP). -- Franklin of Bowdoin tonight set a new mark in the 300-yard medley swim as the fourteenth annual New England intercollegiate swimming championships began in the Wesleyan pool.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -Undaunted by recent court decisions unfavorable to NRA, the oil administration prepared today a double-edged thrust against violation of the petroleum code's labor provisions and production of illegal oil.

On Feb. 6 THE TIMES stated that the Assembly Excise Committee had reported favorably the Burke bill, which would have the State Liquor Authority retain certain political appointees, who were appointed temporarily while civil service examinations were being prepared.

Overruling an order of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins, the Appellate Division held yesterday, in a unanimous decision, that the State of New Jersey has jurisdiction over the western half and New York over the eastern half of the George Washington Bridge. The ruling would apply also to under-river tunnels.

Sidney Solomon, president of the Dieppe Corporation, which has operated the Central Park Casino since the Walker administration, testified in Supreme Court yesterday that he owned all the common stock of the corporation, but could not remember how much he paid for it.

Two men were arrested yesterday charged with homicide in the shooting of Rosario Riggio, 44 years old, Brooklyn grocer and policy slip operator, on Feb. 28 at Sixteenth Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street in Bath Beach. The prisoners said they were Joseph Margaglio, 31, of 1,848 West Eighth Street, and Bernard Cimei, 28, of 1,965 Fifty-second Street, both of Brooklyn.

Over the protests of a group of civic workers who clamored vainly to be heard the Board of Estimate approved yesterday Park Commissioner Robert Moses's plan for the purchase of fifty acres of the estate in Middle Village, Queens, of Arnold Rothstein, slain gambler.

CHALK up an error for Babe Ruth. He recently referred to himself and Rabbit Maranville as "the last of the Mohicans." He completely ignored two jolly gaffers who were around when he started and are still doing business in the big league.
Resale by an estate of a Jersey City apartment house recently in forecloseure featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday:

A strike of elevator operators and other building service employes was called in the downtown and Brighton Beach sections of Brooklyn yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, while the Bronx service employes, on the second day of their strike, continued their effort to tie up additional buildings.

If some of the fallacies involved in the plans for recovery formulated by the President could be made clear to every citizen of the United States, public opinion would demand an immediate change of procedure.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The text of the Lundeen bill is as follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8. -Columbia defeated Yale, 29 to 18, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight. The contest ended the league campaign for the Morningside Heights quintet, which won ten of its twelve games in the college circuit.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Readjustment between the prices of fresh pork loins and hogs continued today, the former advancing 1/2 to 1 cent a pound to the highest level for a March in five years, while hogs were up 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight.
A Supreme Court jury awarded $25,000 damages yesterday to Mrs. Wilma E. Gould in her conspiracy suit. She charged that she was "framed" to provide evidence on which her husband could sue for divorce.

In their outward appearance yesterday's markets were almost replicas of those of the previous day. There was much the same inertia in stock trading, with price changes confined to fractions as a rule. Early weakness in United States Government bonds produced an irregular condition in the investment market.

Prices in the commodity futures markets here were mostly steady yesterday. Trading was slow. In the cash market, dairy products, tin and rubber were higher, while wheat, corn, coffee, printcloths and cotton were lower.

By mutual arrangement with John Cameron, who is producing "Woman of the Soil," Alexandra Carlisle has withdrawn from the cast of that play. She has been succeeded by Evelyn Varden, last seen hereabouts early this season in the brief matter entitled "Alley Cat."

Four executives of European copper companies arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to participate in an international conference here on stabilization of the copper industry. None of them would make more than noncommittal comments about the purposes of their trip, nor what they expected to request of American copper interests.

The report for 1934 of the United States Rubber Company, to be given out today, shows a net loss of $543,608 after expenses, provision for depreciation, taxes and contingencies and other deductions. For 1933 the company reported a net profit of $76,913, equal to 12 cents a share on the then outstanding preferred stock.

BELGRADE, March 8. -- A serious view was taken tonight in government circles of the situation that is developing in the Balkans, particularly of the military preparations Bulgaria is believed to be making.

WASHINGTON, March 8, -- Alcohol smuggling under repeal has reached a point where the Treasury will lose more than $30,000,000 in duties this year, Secretary Morgenthau told the House Ways and Means Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Fears that the pover industry of the country might be nationalized under the Wheeler-Rayburn bill to regulate utility holding companies are unfounded, Clyde L. Seavey of the Federal Power Commission told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Improvement of New York and New Jersey channels to New York Harbor at an estimated cost of $27,000,000, with an annual expense of $195,000 for maintenance, was recommended to the House today in a report of Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The New York Opera Comique announces a season of opera in English by American artists late this Spring at a local theatre, following engagements at Hartford and Chicago. The company will open at the Bushnell Theatre, Hartford, next Thursday for four performances, and will go direct to Chicago for three weeks at the Auditorium under the management of Grace Denton.
CHICAGO, March 8. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson called upon government attorneys today to explain whether "monopolistic practices are condemned or condoned by the NRA."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- Reviving pioneer days, the Federal Government today completed plans for a sample migration from the drought-blighted Northwest to Mantanuska Valley, under Alaska's northern lights.
U.S. Department of Agriculture.

An application for a permit to solicit funds to finance Bruno Richard Hauptmann's appeal will be filed with the Department of Public Welfare in a day or two, Stanley Howe Deputy Commissioner, said yesterday, after a conference with representatives of the wife of the convicted Lindbergh kidnapper.

LAKEHURST, N.J., March 8. -- The Los Angeles, the government's only remaining dirigible, will be taken from the hangar here at sunrise tomorrow, weather permitting, to pass probably a year tied up to the field's now unused mooring mast.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- A request of the Watch Industry Code Authority for a stay in code provisions which would allow the making of January, February and March shipments with April date in connection with terms of payment was denied tonight by the National Industrial Recovery Board on the ground that it would work hardship on small manufacturers.

LONDON, March 8. -- The conclusions reached by the conference of unofficial delegates from ten nations as to how the world's economic, financial and political ills can best be remedied were made public here tonight as the fruits of a three-day session under the auspices of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

Showing no signs of abating the mad pace that they have been setting all week long, the twelve teams remaining in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden swept into the figurative last lap last night, cheered on by a crowd of 15,000 persons.

BERLIN, March 8. -- Trading on the Boerse was slightly stronger today. Heavy industrials showed an average gain of 1 point. Potashes were strong, Westeregeln gaining 2 points. Machines were stronger, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1 point.
CHICAGO, March 8. -- An opinion by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, in which he defined speculation, was recalled at the Board of Trade today.

Two daughters of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine have been under the guard of detectives whenever they have appeared outside their home in Brooklyn as the result of a telephone call two weeks ago threatening bodily harm to them, it was learned last night.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 8 (AP). -- Racing fans today laid plans for a royal welcome, with all the fanfare of a civic holiday, to celebrate the homecoming of Equipoise at the C.V. Whitney farm near here Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- An improvement in the business situation in Japan was reported today in a weekly survey of foreign business by the Department of Commerce, which said that exports in the second ten days of February gained 31 per cent compared with the same period in 1934.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Senate ended a three-day battle over armaments today by voting a near record $400,000,000 for the War Department, with authority to increase the standing army from 118,750 to 165,000. The vote on passage was 68 to 15.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Convinced by the reaction to his radio speech of last night that there was an increasing interest throughout the country in his share-the-wealth plan. Senator Long said that he planned to devote more attention to the mechanics of the scheme "as soon as I have driven the crooks out of the government."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 (AP). -- Babe Ruth will make his debut at first base tomorrow when he puts on the uniform of the Boston Braves for the first time in competition.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8. -- Following a hearing at which the names of Dutch Schultz, New York gang leader, and Arnold Rothstein, murdered gambler, were mentioned by witnesses, Arthur G. Dickson, a well-known Philadelphia attorney, was held in $10,000 bail today charged with conspiracy to bring stolen stocks from New York to this city to be sold for an unidentified client.

Marquita Lopez, 20 years old, recently acquitted at separate trials of first-degree murder and robbery in the hold-up shooting of Patrolman Peter J. Costa, was sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate term in the Westfield State Farm for Women in Bedford Hills.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 8. -The venerable Connie Mack, introducing Jimmy Foxx as his new catcher, wig-wagged his famous score card in midseason form today. But apparently it needed something more than the mere wig-wagging of a score card to distract the Giants as they set about the task of launching their 1935 exhibition campaign on Flamingo Field.

In the last two days there has been illustrated again in the foreign exchange market the sheep-like habits of commercial buyers of exchange. While the pound was falling, commercial interests delayed purchasing their requirements in the expectation of getting them cheaper and cheaper.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8. -The Yale and Harvard hockey teams expect a capacity crowd in the New Haven Arena tomorrow night when they clash in the chief athletic event of Yale's junior promenade week.

ALBANY, March 8. -- In an effort to solve the milk control problems, Governor Lehman made arrangements today for a conference of Governors of all States supplying milk to New York. He hopes to work out a program of interstate cooperation, synchronized with Federal direction.

TORONTO, March 8. -- With the aim of making the Dionne quintuplets "special wards of His Majesty the King as represented by the Minister of Public Welfare of Ontario," David A. Croll, Minister of Welfare, introduced a bill today in the Ontario Legislature regarding the famous babies of Callender.

H.G. Wells, a young-looking, ruddy-cheeked man despite his 69 years, strolled and trotted about the decks of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen early yesterday morning exchanging repartee with a trailing group of about fifteen reporters who wanted to know what brought him to the United States this time.
The La Salle Academy basketball team won the Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. championship last night, turning back the De La Salle Institute quintet, 20 to 14, at the Loughlin High gymnasium.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8. -Meriden and Warren Harding High School of Bridgeport will meet in the finals of the Connecticut basketball tournament tomorrow afternoon by virtue of victories tonight in the semi-finals. Harding was from Chapman Tech of New London, 52-35, in the first game and Meriden from Branford, 32-27, in the second.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, who complained about the activities of vice rings in the Women's Court earlier in the week, testified for fifty minutes yesterday afternoon before the grand jury investigating commercialized vice, the policy racket and associated evils.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Lundeen Unemployment Insurance and Social Security Bill, with provision for control and administration "by workers and farmers," will come before the House for action as the result of a 7-to-6 Labor Committee vote today. Chairman Connery cast the deciding vote in favor of reporting the bill.
In less than a half hour a jury before County Judge Franklin Taylor convicted ten men on charges of operating a lottery. The charges under which the men were convicted are felonies.
St. Peter's Prep and Fordham Prep survived their semi-final round games yesterday in the Jesuit prep school basketball tournament in Jersey City.

When the agitation to "do something for silver" was at its height, both branches of Congress rang with appeals for China. The American public was told that the decline in the price of silver bullion had "crippled" the purchasing power of millions, of "people in the Orient," that it had ruined their trade and destroyed their ability to buy foreign goods.
LONDON, March 8 (AP). -- The Sofia correspondent of The Exchange Telegraph this evening said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 8. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, defendant in an ecclesiastical trial in the New Brunswick Presbytery, charged the Presbytery special commission today with "ruthless unfairness" and asserted that its action yesterday at Trenton had prejudged his whole case "without even allowing me a hearing."

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments on two applications made by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, seeking to enjoin the Transit Commission from continuing with State court suits against him.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- President Roosevelt made known that five more messages to Congress would complete the formal outline of his legislative program and instructed Secretary Swanson to disregard the rulings of Controller General McCarl affecting transportation of the families of naval officers ordered home for retirement.

MONTREAL, March 8 (Canadian Press). -- Glenn Cunningham of Kansas University won the invitation mile in the Canadian indoor track and field championship meet tonight, but his time was much slower than his world record.

BUFFALO, March 8 (AP). -- Confessed killer of his father, Richard Kloes, 11, went before an Erie County grand jury today to give testimony which District Attorney Walter C. Newcomb expected would result in a first-degree murder indictment against the boy's mother, Mrs. Elizabeth Kloes, 35, called by the prosecutor the instigator of the crime.

Last night the Metropolitan Opera Association gave its first "Pelleas" of the season, with an effect of haunting beauty and intensity of feeling. The poignancy of this drama is not less because it occurs in a subjective rather than an exterior world.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 8. -- Manager Casey Stengel and the local fans who are flocking to Tinker Field each day in increasing numbers got their first look at the 1935 Dodger infield in action today, and both were pleased with what they saw.

TOKYO, March 8 (AP). -- The House of Peers enacted the 1935-36 budget today, giving final approval to the demands of Japan's Army and Navy leaders for the largest military appropriations in the Empire's history.

With $69,864,000 of new bonds and notes offered to investors this week, the new financing was the heaviest for any week this year. State and municipal floatations totaled $49,864,000, of which the New York State issue of serial bonds accounted for $45,025,000,

The Southern Pacific Golden Gate Ferries, Inc., is setting up an obsolence reserve against the completion of two bridges at San Francisco, one across San Francisco Bay and the other across the Golden Gate, at the close of next year.

The effort on the part of the Commissioner of Hospitals to provide facilities for research in chronic diseases in municipal hospitals is indeed a promising advance in medical public service. It is also gratifying to read the report of the City Planning Committee recommending the transfer of land on Welfare Island to the Department of Hospitals.

Included in next week's calendar of $21,097,087 new State and municipal bonds up for award are twenty-five issues by counties, of which twenty are Iowa primary road refunding bonds. Fifty-eight communities are represented in the list. The total compares with this week's revised figure of $52,495,824,

HOUSTON, March 8 (AP). -- Genteel Lady, overlooked in the betting, won the featured Turf Writers' Purse, five and one-half-furlong sprint, at Epsom Downs today. The 4-year-old mare was given a nice ride by Jockey J. Deering, who watched the favored Gold Step force Ima Count to set the early pace, and then brought the J.L. Roberts mount to the front in the stretch to win by a nose.

The annual oil exhibition at the Salmagundi Club opened with a stag last evening and, after a Ladies' Day reception and tea this afternoon, may be visited by the public. At the National Arts Club the annual exhibition by the junior artist members is current.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8. -- Manager Joe McCarthy's experiment at third base was interrupted today when Red Rolfe appeared in uniform, three days ahead of schedule. As a result the infield was revised.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (AP). -- Speedy Return, son of Quick Return, renewed the winning ways of the J.A. Parsons Stable at Santa Anita today by capturing the four-furlong juvenile race on the next to the last day of the Los Angeles Turf Club's sixty-five-day meeting.

Members of the Brotherhood of Utility Employes have voted by about 17 to 1 in favor of calling a strike of all the Brooklyn Edison Company generating and distributing plant workers, it was announced last midnight at a meeting of Local 102 of the Brotherhood at 207 Washington Street, Brooklyn.

Louis Hayward, the young English actor who appeared with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in the recent Noel Coward play, "Point Valaine," has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and will leave New York for Hollywood today by airplane to begin work in "The Flame Within," in which Ann Harding, Franchot Tone and Merle Oberon will appear.

West Bronx activity continued yesterday with the sale by an estate of a plot 100 by 100 feet in the Riverdale section. The property is the southwest corner of 238th Street and Greystone Avenue, near Riverdale Avenue. It was sold by the estate of Catherine O'Connell to Michael and Armino Campagna, building contractors.

LONDON, March 8. -- Stocks rallied here today in almost all departments after acute weakness for the last week. British Government securities recovered sharply on Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain's reassuring statement in Parliament last night.

J.P. Morgan, who recently sold six paintings for $1,500,000 and is offering for sale his collection of miniature paintings and thirty-one acres of his Long Island estate, disposed of his 114-foot steam yacht Navette last week, it became known yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses conferred for almost two hours yesterday afternoon. It was their first conference since the Ickes-Moses controversy entered its present acute stage. Funds for the Triborough Bridge will he exhausted any day now, but Secretary Ickes continues to insist that his Order 129 stands and Mr. Moses is equally adamant about refusing to resign.

Two men, each about 35 years old, clad in correct formal attire, presented themselves at the switchboard in the lobby of the fifteen-story apartment building at 55 Park Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, at 6:30 o'clock last night.

Prices of bonds improved moderately on the Stock Exchange yesterday as the volume of trading diminished again. The recent decline in the United States Government group was halted, with the closing 10-32 point down to 5-32 up. Some betterment among Federal loans was reported in the over-the-counter market after the close of the Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- After only two days of testimony in its NRA investigation, the Senate Finance Committee began work today on a new NRA bill.
Continued pressure on new-crop positions, particularly from foreign sources, caused losses of 2 to 8 points in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8.--Shufflin' Joe Louis, young Negro heavyweight star from Detroit who hopes to relieve champion Max Baer of his crown, made an impressive debut in this old-time fight centre tonight when he stopped Donald (Red) Barry of Washington in the third round of their scheduled ten-round bout.

A secret joy gladdened the heart of 12-year-old Alexander Iffle on Wednesday, although it may have been tinged somewhat with remorse. Morning newspapers described the blaze which had started in his school, Public School 89, Lenox Avenue at 135th Street, the previous afternoon, and caused damage set at $20,000.

MOSCOW, March 8. -- With but three more rounds remaining to be contested, Mischa Botwinnik, Soviet chess champion, continues to hold his own in the international tournament at the Museum Beaux Arts, where he added another triumph to his score today in the sixteenth round, making amends for the setback he sustained yesterday.

With the enthusiastic expectation by his admirers that he will run soundly this year and next, Mrs. Payne Whitney's Twenty Grand was shipped to England yesterday aboard the American Merchant Line's American Banker.

The rally in sterling was extended yesterday, while the gold-bloc currencies continued to decline. Apparently without the need of official assistance, the pound was buoyed up by the buying of commercial interests, which had deferred their purchases lately in expectation of still lower prices, and by a reversal of the recent movement of funds from London to Paris.

PITTSBURGH, March 8. -- The affairs of the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh, through which the government charges Andrew W. Mellon and others saved fortunes in income taxes, were kept from public scrutiny today for the week-end at least.

The General Education Board, founded by John D. Rockefeller Sr. in 1902, appropriated from its income $3,028,723 during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1934, it was revealed in the board's annual report made public yesterday.

A large housing property in the Shore Road section of Brooklyn passed to new control yesterday when an investing syndicate bought the six-story elevator apartment building at 145 Ninety-fifth Street. Harbor Heights Hall. Inc., Maurice Kamenstein, president, was the seller.

HAVANA, 4 A. M., Saturday, March 9. -- The Mendieta Government this morning established a dictatorship when the Cabinet and Council of State in joint session suspended Constitutional law, except as it affects foreign treaties and international obligations, while a "state of strike and seditious-revolutionary propaganda exists," according to an official communication published in the newspaper El Pais.

Moliere's famous aphorism, "plus a change, plus c'est la meme chose," may be said to apply in reverse to the work of several of our contemporary artists. Take Stephen Etnier, for instance, now showing at the Milch Galleries. The more he paints in his accustomed manner, the more it turns out to be something different.

Sixteen prizes and medals of a total value of $4,400 have been awarded for paintings and sculpture in the 110th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, which will open to the public Wednesday at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, following an invitation reception on the preceding evening.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn has reserved decision on a motion to vacate, as against Newel W. Tilton, Henri C. Harnickell and Charles L. Harding and the partnership of Wright, Slade Co., a $59,102 judgment obtained by Lawrence W. Waller against William May Wright and the other defendants named. The four men were partners in the firm.

LONDON, March 8. -- While talk of a "Balkan crisis" is discounted in official quarters, The Times editorially suggests tonight that early victory for the Greek Government is desirable because "it is only too clear that the outbreak of civil war in Greece has troubled those waters where unscrupulous political anglers have long been used to cast their baits."

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Strong opposition to transferring control of food, drug and cosmetic advertising to the Department of Agriculture was voiced today by Edwin L. Davis, Federal Trade Commission chairman, appearing before a Senate Commerce subcommittee's hearing on the Copeland bill.

Last evening, by some odd coincidence, was a particularly bright one in the local nocturnal haunts, so far as transformations were concerned. To mention a few of the sparklers: Billy Milton went in as the featured entertainer at El Morocco.

Retail trade here during the week was up against the combined handicap of adverse weather and unfavorable comparison with the fairly brisk pre-Easter trade during this period last year. Sales of most department stores here ran under the 1934 figures and, even making allowance for the active trade of last Saturday, a decline thus far this month of around 7 per cent was estimated.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP). -- A new American ballet, "Public Gardens" was enthusiastically received at its world premiere tonight in the Auditorium Theatre.

That extremes provoke extremes is a social rule as well as a natural law. Fresh evidence of it is adduced in Newark where in answer to the actions of the American and Newark Newspaper Guilds, the trustees of The Newark Ledger have secured a temporary injunction restraining the Guild from, among other things, circulating copies of its weekly newspaper, The Guild Reporter.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Authorization of an additional bond issue of $1,750,000,000 for the Home Owners Loan Corporation was voted today by the House.

Bank exchanges in the principal cities of the country in February amounted to $20,793,838,124. This was a decline of 18.5 per cent from January, but 1.4 per cent above February last year. The recession in check clearings last month after gains had been reported in each of the two preceding months, was ascribed to the heavy storms which effected the transportation industry and mercantile sales.

Senator LONG'S broadcast speech was not what many expected. They listened for something vituperative and abusive. Instead, he was astute enough to avoid most of that and to seize the opportunity to give his hearers a full exposition of his scheme to distribute the wealth of the country. In this there is nothing new.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers.

Automobile manufacturers in the United States produced 355,350 cars and trucks last month, the largest output for a February in the last five years, the Automobile Manufacturers Association announced yesterday. The February figure, surpassed only in 1924, 1926 and 1929, represents a gain of 48 per cent from February, last year, and of 17 per cent from January.

After many years of association with the Jewish labor movement in Palestine, David Pinski has written a play about the pioneers. It is called "The Power That Builds" and was presented by the New York Art Troupe last night a the Yiddish Folk Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street, as a benefit for the Jewish Folk Schools of the Jewish National Workers Alliance.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education, today fixed April 26, May 3 and May 10 for the observance of Arbor Day, and April 12 as Bird Day in the State. This was done by formal proclamation of the Commissioner of Education, who said in part:

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The discovery, in an airplane flight, of a new glacier fifty miles long, descending from the peak of Mount Hubbard into the Alsek Valley in Yukon Territory, Canada, and of a hitherto unrecorded mountain range between Mount Hubbard and Mount Lucania of the St. Elias range has been reported to the National Geographic Society in a telegram from Bradford Washburn.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of last week totaled 323,575,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. In comparison with the previous week, the total represents a net increase of 2,208,000 barrels, and comprises increases of 2,013,000 and 195,000 barrels, respectively in domestic and foreign crude petroleum.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Automobile workers will resent the refusal of the Automobile Manufacturers Association to confer with organized labor, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 8. -- The junior promenade, the most important social event on the college calendar, tonight opened junior week-end at New Jersey College for Women. It had a Roman setting and was attended by 200 couples.

After deliberating six hours, a jury in the Brooklyn Federal court failed yesterday to reach a verdict in the case of John J. Sullivan, former watchman in Wallabout Market, Brooklyn, who was tried on income tax charges. A new trial was set for April 2 and the $2,000 bail was continued.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 8. -Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., and Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., won their semifinal matches today on the St. Augustine links in the Florida East Coast golf championship for the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup and will meet in the eighteen-hole final tomorrow.

Two arrested "mashers" escaped from patrolwomen in the Savoy Theatre, 112 West Thirty-fourth Street, at 2:25 P.M. yesterday, when one threw Patrolwoman Mary A. Shanley, 38 years old, of 622 Columbus Avenue, down a flight of concrete steps, and Patrolwoman Lilly F. Browne of 6,020 Delafield Avenue, the Bronx, let go of her prisoner to assist her injured sister-officer.

Youth was warned yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick against freedom that is not seasoned with the ideal of a "supreme achievement." With these words he opened the three-day Metropolitan Youth Conference yesterday evening at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

BALTIMORE, March 8. -- Maryland's recalcitrant race track operators, seeking tax relief, were warned today they must file Spring dates with the racing commission by next Friday. A letter from the commission, advising the tracks to apply for dates within a week, was the first official step taken toward clearing up the unsettled racing situation in this State.
PARIS, March 8. -- A conference of gold-bloc nations to bolster their currencies in view of the decline in sterling was unofficially fixed today to take place here next week.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Regulation of the rates of the Consolidated Gas Company by the Public Service Commission, together with legal expenses, adds over a million dollars a year to the utility bills of New York City consumers, according to testimony given today before the joint legislative committee investigating utilities.

Mayor La Guardia succeeded yesterday for the second time within a week in blocking an attempt to record the sentiment of the Board of Estimate on restoration of full pay to city employes through abolition of pay cuts.

Lois Phelps, recently heard on Lincoln's Birthday as pianist with the National Orchestral Association, returned in a recital at the Town Hall last evening. Her program comprised Beethoven's sonata in F-sharp, Op. 78, and that of Chopin in B-minor, Op. 58, the Bach-Liszt G-minor fugue and Gluck-Saint-Saens "Alceste," as well as short groups from Schumann and Brahms.

In connection with sections of the proposed Banking Act of 1935, which seeks to liberalize Federal Reserve regulations as to the type of real estate loans which may be made by member banks, the current issue of the Architectural Forum contains a study of real estate loans and bank failures by Federal Reserve districts, tending to show that "realty loans and mortgages are not the villains they usually are supposed to be."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hagood Haynes of New York, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, were their guests of honor this evening at a dinner at Villa Marina, followed by dancing, for which additional guests were invited.
DURHAM, N.C., March 8. -- Making its initial appearance here, the Navy five defeated Duke tonight, 44 -- 38, in an extra-period contest. The game was witnessed by more than 3,500.

HAVANA, Saturday, March 9. -- The outcome of the present revolutionary strike in Cuba is still highly problematical today, but no one can deny it has shaken the Mendieta Government to its foundations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 8. -- The fourteen English sheep dogs, which were ordered removed from the kennels owned by Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur K. Hitchcock at Mount Pleasant, will be allowed a little more time to howl en masse, according to a ruling today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Wits-chief.

HAMBURG, March 8. -- Supremely confident he is destined to be the first man in history to regain the heavyweight crown, Max Schmeling today completed his preparations for Sunday's ten-round bout with Steve Hamas in a furious workout at his snow-locked camp near here.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight presents the second free orchestral concert of its March series, which opened last week with an attendance of 13,887, its highest record in seventeen years.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8. -- The $15,000 Florida Derby, closing-day feature of the forty-five-day Hialeah meeting which ends tomorrow, found thirteen 3-year-olds named tonight for the mile and a furlong test, which was inaugurated in 1926. The E.R. Bradley entry of Black Helen and Bloodroot, both fillies, appeared certain to rule favorite.

Your Budapest dispatch "Parliament's Life Ended in Hungary; Fascist Bloc Forming" may easily be misunderstood in this country. That there are differences between the former Premier, Count Bethlen, and General Goemboes, the present head of the Hungarian Government, regarding the electoral reform need not be interpreted that by dissolving Parliament Regent Horthy wanted to facilitate the formation of a Fascist group.

The New York A.C. won the team championship in the New York State A.A.U. wrestling meet at the Ridgewood Grove S.C. in Brooklyn last night. The Winged Foot matmen scored 27 points, three more than the West Side M.M.C.A. in second place.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

A symposium on the subject of a national, subsidized theatre in America featured the tenth anniversary luncheon of the Drama Study Club yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Assembled in the Grand Ballroom, more than five hundred members of the club.

The three-week strike of 137 employes of the Ohrbach store, 48 East Fourteenth Street, facing Union Square, was ended yesterday by a settlement brought about by the Regional Labor Board, it was announced by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, director of the board.

DETROIT, March 8. -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association today spurned a request of the American Federation of Labor for collective bargaining, and denounced the union's activities in the automobile industry.

Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Le Coq d'Or," done in the original manner by singing actors of The Art of Musical Russia, Inc., was presented last night at Mecca Temple as the third in a series of five Russian operas. Ranking easily next to "Boris," and remembered in thel etropolitan's former production as opera-ballet, the gay music drama has also been repeatedly sung here by many of its present native interpreters.
