Offering will be made today of a new issue of $3,400,000 New York City 0.80 per cent special corporate stock notes, dated March 14 and due June 14, 1935, by a syndicate composed of the Chase National Bank, Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Barr Brothers Co., Inc.

The first rivets were driven into the keel of the new 10,000-ton cruiser Brooklyn at the New York Navy Yard yesterday. In spite of the rain, more than 400 persons attended the ceremonies and cheered Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll in the role of a riveter.

The Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau has ruled that it cannot provide work on a part-time basis to enable 298 supervising engineers in the Park Department and the Queens Borough President's office to continue working full time, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- William B. Shearer, big navy advocate, today brought an abrupt end to a turbulent Senate Munitions Committee hearing by advancing with clenched fists upon a member of the committee who called him "cowardly."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12. -- The parents of 10-year-old Grace Budd identified Albert Fish today as the man they saw with their child on the day she disappeared. Fish is on trial here for the murder of the girl.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- Under the will of George Leib Harrison, retired chemical manufacturer, the University of Pennsylvania will receive nearly $2,000,000 for the establishment and maintenance of general surgical research.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- The board of directors of the Illinois Manufacturers Association today came out against extension of the NIRA "in any form" after the expiration of the present law on June 16. The board declared in a resolution that the law was "unsound in principle and impracticable in operation."
The Midland Steel Company declared a dividend of $2 on account of accumulations on 8 per cent first preferred stock, thus clearing up arrears.

ROANOKE, Va., March 12. -- Surrounded by her family and friends, Mrs. Thomas Whiffen, grand old lady of the American stage, today celebrated her ninetieth birthday on her dairy farm near Montvale, in Bedford County, not far from this city.

ALBANY, March 12. -- Governor Lehman will confer tomorrow with a group of industrial leaders who will seek to convince him that the Byrne-Killgrew bill to create a State system of unemployment insurance should be drastically amended or postponed.

HAVANA, March 12. -- The Mendieta Government, through the enactment of the severest measures in the history of the republic, appeared today to have broken the revolutionary strike movement that had paralyzed the administrative machinery and virtually tied up commerce and industry for the last few days.

ROME, March 12 (AP). -- Tullio Serafin, former conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York, said today "the Metropolitan is dying because it has not encouraged American opera or American artists."
A new policy in the choice of architects for municipal construction in which competence instead of political influence will be the deciding factor is in prospect it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- As a compromise soldiers' bonus measure, Representative McReynolds of Tennessee introduced today a bill to issue to the veterans negotiable government bonds in place of their adjusted compensation certificates.

Judge Julian W. Mack began yesterday in the Federal Court over the protest of five New York banks and the General Electric Company to receive evidence concerning a complaint that they had conspired to obtain the assets of the Insull Utility Investments Corporation during the four months before it went into bankruptcy.

A young father who had admitted breaking into a grocery store and taking food valued at 60 cents for his three small children was freed yesterday when the Bronx County grand jury failed to indict him.

Acute weakness appeared in the domestic corporation group in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with many issues losing from 1 to as much as 6 points, notably the lower grade rails. Holding company bonds were generally easier. United States Government loans closed easier.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP). -- Milwaukee is the safest city in the United States as far as traffic hazards are concerned, the National Safety Council announced today in naming the Wisconsin metropolis winner of the third national traffic safety contest.

BALTIMORE, March 12 (AP). -- A report that two bright young men from Harvard were giving Senator Huey Long an intensive course on cultural polish was brought here from Washington today by Dr. Charles A. Beard, the historian.

Formation of the New York State Committee for the Revival of Private Enterprise, as "a State-wide organization of consumers to encourage recovery through the revival of private enterprise and to oppose legislation which will strangle legitimate industry in New York State," was announced yesterday by its secretary Douglas Fisher.

The Borden Company reported yesterday that its net income in 1934 was $4,490,044, equal to $1.02 a share on the common stock outstanding, against $4,646,443, or $1.05 a share, in 1933. Net sales in 1934 were $215,723,659, against $186,301,203 in 1933.

BERLIN, March 12. -- The Boerse was firm but quiet today. Heavy industrials were inactive and irregular and potashes were stagnant. Machineries were fairly active, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1 point. Electricals were unsalable, Shuckert gaining 1 1/4 points.

PARIS, March 12. -- Broken by the defeat of his last adventure and with tears in his eyes as he prepared to leave his home in Crete for exile and an unknown fate, Eleutherios Venizelos gave a short interview just before noon today to Elvire Titayna, a special correspondent of the Paris-Soir.

OSLO, Norway, March 12. -- New territory, which has been named Ingrid Christensen's Land, has been discovered in the Antarctic by the Norwegian oil tanker Thorshavn and taken possession of in the name of Norway.

ATHENS, March 12. -- From Saloniki in the north to Sparta in the south Greece celebrated today the fall of Eleutherios Venizelos's revolutionary movement, which faded into the turbulent Hellenic past some time before noon today. At that time the cruiser Averoff, with M. Venizelos and his wife aboard, slipped from the waters of Canea Harbor, Crete, leaving to the sailors of the rebel fleet the sorry task of surrendering and pleading for terms.

MOSCOW, March 12. -- With six unfinished games pending and one more round to be played on Thursday, chief prizes in the international masters' chess tournament rest among Mischa Botwinnik, Soviet champion; Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia and Dr. Emanuel Lasker of England.

NEWARK, N.J., March 12. -- The police judge who arraigned four men arrested Feb. 9 in an Elizabeth still raid appeared as their counsel a month later when the defendants were brought before United States Commissioner J.F. Holland for a hearing, it was disclosed today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12. -- Resolutions urging Federal enforcement of anti-lynching laws and outlining a social welfare program were adopted by the National Council of Jewish Women at their triennial convention here today.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The statement that the government must act as "a compensatory agent" for the promotion of stable business conditions, full employment and restoration of the national income was made by Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, before the House Banking and Currency Committee today at a hearing on the administration's proposed banking act of 1935.

The preliminary and first rounds of the annual championship of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association were played yesterday on the courts of the Junior League. The eight seeded players advanced to the quarter-final bracket but two, Mrs. Rogers Dunn and Miss Margaret Bostwick, encountered vigorous opposition.

MEXICO, D.F., March 12. -- The Treasury Department has officially announced that the government has instituted a demand on the Eagle Oil Company for payment of 7,500,000 pesos, a little more than $2,000,000, for import taxes on machinery brought into Mexico duty free since 1906.

PROVIDENCE, March 12 (AP). -- Colonial Line officials reported to Providence police today that when the steamer Concord arrived here from New York this morning a woman who registered as "M. Pendleton" was missing.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Elimination of utility holding companies with their present powers was urged by President Roosevelt today in a message to Congress which constituted a direct reply to the efforts of such companies to defeat legislation now before Congress.
The Girl Scouts of America celebrated their twenty-third birthday yesterday afternoon by a party and radio broadcast in America's Little House, Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Consumer resistance to high prices for hog products has become so severe that Eastern packers are curtailing their purchases of hogs, according to reports in local livestock circles. An advance of a half cent a pound lifted choice fresh pork loins to 25 cents, the best figure of last Summer, but packers admit there is a limited demand for their product.

The Municipal Art Commission ended yesterday the long controversy over the final location of the Civic Virtue statue by approving the Park Department's plan to place it in Foley Square, where it will be a central feature of the Civic Centre.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 (AP). -- William B. McKechnie, manager of the Braves, wants it made clear that he is attending strictly to the business of whipping his club into shape for the National League season, without word or fear as to what will happen by 1936.
Championship dates and the draw for the Intercollegiate championship were announced yesterday by the tournament committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Newsboys and carriers last year were older, on the average, and made less money than those similarly employed ten years ago, the Labor Department's Children's Bureau reports in a study asked by President Roosevelt in connection with the proposed child labor provisions of some codes.

From Germany's beer and radishes to Mexico's red beans and tropical fruits, the tastes in food and table decoration of the nations of the world were spread yesterday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

I have before me a booklet on the outside of which is printed: "Tariff -- Grundyism Responsible for Ills of the Farmer -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's Speech at Sioux City, Iowa, Sept. 29, 1932. Issued by the Democratic National Campaign Committee, Hotel Biltmore, New York City." From the last page, giving this speech by Mr. Roosevelt, I quote the following:

New York's blizzard of last January was dismissed as "a mere flurry" at the annual luncheon and reunion of the Blizzard Men of 1888 at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Veterans of the famous snowfall of forty-seven years ago, which completely paralyzed business and traffic with drifts twenty feet high, recounted their personal experiences in the storm.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Despite delay and rebellion at the Capitol, President Roosevelt plans to leave Washington late this month for his annual fishing trip in the warm blue waters off Florida's coast.

The Federal Government filed a lien for $16,000 in income tax proceedings yesterday against $25,000 in securities which Polly Adler deposited last week to obtain the release of herself and three other women arrested on prostitution charges in her apartment in East Fifty-fifth Street, just off Fifth Avenue.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP). -- J.F. Rector's Smooth, far back in his two previous races, ran away from seven other older horses in the one and one-sixteenth miles of the headline race at the Fair Grounds today.

The Chicago Junction Railways and Union Stock Yards Company issued at the annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday a report for 1934 showing net income of $2,540,169, against $2,398,192 in 1933, and gross earnings of $5,560,460, against $5,489,824.

BUENOS AIRES, March 13. -- Twelve hundred Fascist militiamen guarded the Provincial Capitol at La Plata tonight, prepared to resist any attempt to oust Governor Federico Martinez de Hoz, against whom impeachment proceedings were begun today.

In celebration of Professor Harold C. Urey's recent return from Sweden, members of the faculty and board of trustees of Columbia University gave a dinner to the Nobel Prize winner at the Men's Faculty Club of the university last night. About 200 educators and their wives attended the "welcome back" party.

Net profit of the Phillips Petroleum Company for 1934 amounted to $5,757,308 after taxes, interest, reserves and retirements and other deductions, equal to $1.38 a share on 4,153,235 shares outstanding. In the preceding year the company reported a net of $1,500,695, or 36 cents a share on 4,154,687 shares then outstanding.

Through misunderstanding and bias, Latin-American relations with the United States are getting worse, it was asserted by speakers at a forum meeting of the Beekman Hill Neighbors last night at the Beekman Towers, 3 Mitchell Place. More than 100 persons attended.

PITTSBURGH, March 12. -- Government attorneys scored twice today in their efforts to prove that $5,000,000 of the $19,000,000 gain in Andrew W. Mellon's fortune by reason of the reorganization of the McClintic-Marshall corporation in 1931 was taxable as income.

The fourth annual surprise party of the Metropolitan Opera Association, to be entitled "Opera-Tunities," will take place this season on Sunday evening, March 31, it was announced yesterday. The event will be "a festival occasion to honor Giulio Gatti-Casazza," the departing general manager, and the proceeds will go to the opera maintenance fund.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A petition has been addressed to President Roosevelt, endorsed by 156 educators, clergymen, publicists and others, expressing "vigorous opposition" to measures recently introduced in Congress proposing the addition of two months to the Civilian Conservation Corps enlistment for training young men for enrolment in an auxiliary reserve force for a five-year period, during which they would receive $24 a year.

ALBANY, March 12. -- Robert Moses will be reappointed as head of the Triborough Bridge Authority on July 1, Mayor La Guardia said here today, ridiculing reports that Mr. Moses would be eased out of his post at that time.

An American Museum of Natural History expedition spent three months in the mountains of West China hunting giant pandas, blue sheep and other rare animals, but it was the group's success in bagging a common duck that saved it from falling into the hands of bandits.
Reports of business leases increased yesterday. The centre of activity was the midtown area of Manhattan, where fur and clothing manufacturers figured largely on the lists.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Colonel D.W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, announced tonight that Evelyn John Strachey's arrest in Glencoe, Ill., followed the receipt of numerous complaints from individuals and organizations and was based on the charge that he entered the United States in December by means of false statements.
LONDON, March 12. -- New unemployment figures tended today to confirm the impression of a month ago that British recovery had suffered a real setback in the first few weeks of the year.

Last year Jacob Lieberman celebrated his eighty-ninth birthday in an unprecedented program, including a limousine, a motion picture, champagne and a radio broadcast. Yesterday, a year and four days older, he marked the closing of his ninetieth year by going through the same motions largely, but with the benefit of experience.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12. -- Acting immediately after signing a legislative bill giving him the authority to do so, Governor Harold G. Hoffman ordered today that $2,000,000 be transferred from the motor fuel tax receipts for emergency relief purposes.

The Regional Labor Board ruled yesterday that the Brotherhood of Utility Employes, which has voted to call a strike in power houses of the Brooklyn Edison Company because of the alleged discharge of six members of the brotherhood for union activity, has failed to prove discrimination by the company in violation of Section 7a of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Wednesday, March 13. -- Chattanooga voters yesterday approved a bond issue of $8,000,000 to finance a public power distribution system with TVA current. The vote was 18,582 to 7,837, with one precinct missing, but the close of the balloting found the Tennessee Electric Power Company all set for a pronounced battle to protect its Chattanooga investment.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12. -- A high wind that touched gale proportions tempered the warm rays of the sun at Huggins Field today and made practice something of a peril to delicate Yankee arms and legs. So Manager Joe McCarthy called it a day at the end of two hours.

Public institutions will receive more than $900,000 from the estate of Miss Ione M. Spears, . who died in Brooklyn on July 20, 1932, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a transfer-tax report in Surro-i gate's Court.

The Theatre Authority, Inc., organized last year to control the Sunday night benefit problem, reported to the Equity Council yesterday that eleven Equity members had appeared in an unauthorized show Sunday night at the Imperial Theatre.

Lincoln Ellsworth, who recently returned from the Antarctic, whers continued bad weather forced him to abandon his plans for flying across the Antarctic Continent, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, of which Mr. Ellsworth is a trustee.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- An investigation into the break on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, when there were final losses of $4.80 to $5.95 a bale, will be demanded by Chairman Smith of the Senate Agricultural Committee when that body meets tomorrow.

The cry that continues to emanate from the committee now sitting in judgment on the so-called utility holding company bill calling all opposition the result of organized propaganda of the printing press variety is, to say the least, silly. I am personally responsible for some of the protests referred to and for three reasons:

A gain in the number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with listings in the preceding week. The total for the week was also well above registrations for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 12. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., won easily in her first match round of the Belleair women's championship today when she covered the first nine in thirty-nine strokes to stand 7 up on Miss K.W. Foster of Westerly, R.I. Miss Orcutt won the tenth and halved the eleventh to win by 8 and 6.

Declaring that "there is no doubt that the Board of Aldermen has the power to regulate water rates," Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin dismissed yesterday a taxpayer's suit to prevent the city from collecting the water charges under the 50 per cent increase in rates voted Sept. 14, 1933.

ALBANY, March 12. -- The Nunan bill to require students entering institutions of higher learning supported in whole or in part by the State to take oaths of allegiance to the State and Federal Constitutions was killed in committee today.

Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor and medical adviser to the New York State Boxing Commission, was struck and severely injured yesterday by an automobile as he left the State Office Building after weighing Primo Carnera and Ray Impellettiere who will fight at Madison Square Garden Friday night.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- Administration action to eliminate any possibility of further legal attacks upon the New Deal monetary system appeared tonight to be an immediate probability.

ST. LOUIS, March 12 (AP). -- In three seconds the Eagles changed a defeat into victory tonight as they overcame the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 2. The National Hockey League match, played before some 8,000 fans, closed the season here.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message indorsing the principles of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill; he conferred with Treasury and Department of Justice officials on gold legislation, offered the service of government in The Newark Ledger labor dispute and conferred with Senator Russell on the break in cotton prices.

VIENNA, March 12. -- An official statement issued tonight informed the public that Stephan Tauschitz, the Austrian Minister to Germany, had presented to the Reich Government a few days ago a protest concerning reports published by the German official news agency of declarations by Chancellor Hitler regarding Austrian internal affairs.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 12 (AP). -- Scoring games of 911, 901 and 904, Hamil Gruens of Lockport, N.Y., topped the State Booster teams in the American Bowling Congress tourney today.

Revised plans for the staging of the national amateur hockey championship were announced yesterday by officials of Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U., under whose auspices the sport is being conducted.

Alfred Byrne, Lord Mayor of Dublin, who signs his statements to the press and his admirers as "Alfie," arrived last night on the Cunard White Star liner Olympic on his first visit to America. He will attend the St. Patrick's Day parade on Saturday as the guest of Roderick J. Kennedy, the chairman.
CALLANDER, Ont., March 12. -- Annette, one of the five Dionne sisters, cut her first tooth today.
A close-up view of one of the oddest monsters of the deep, a giant manta or devil fish, gave Lou Gehrig an unexpected thrill on the last day of his recent fishing expedition at Long Key, Fla.

Tallulah Bankhead, now closing her engagement in the revival of "Rain," is virtually certain to appear this season in the Adelaide Heilbron comedy, tentatively called "Something Gay." At least, a representative of Miss Bankhead, speaking from her apartment yesterday, said that the actress would enter rehearsals on Monday under the direction of Thomas Mitchell.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- President Roosevelt's message on the government's power policy read as follows:

With the hope of building up trade with China and Japan an economic mission, organized by the National Foreign Trade Council and headed by W. Cameron Forbes, one-time Ambassador to Japan, will leave San Francisco March 22 for the Far East.

Two exhibitions opened simultaneously yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum -- the Sixth Traveling exhibition of paintings by Cleveland artists, and the forty-fifth annual of pictorial photography, put on by the department of photography of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Amendments to the Motion Picture Code designed to clarify the status and improve the working conditions of those engaged in vaudeville and acting incident to the presentation of motion pictures were approved today by the NRA.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey, British author and lecturer, who is regarded as one of the leading advocates of communism, was placed under arrest tonight in the synagogue of the North Shore Congregation Israel, Glencoe, a Chicago suburb, as an alien subject to deportation.

The sharp break in cotton, which sent prices down more than $9 a bale on Monday before support was met, has called attention to the extent of governmental interference with the natural movement of that commodity. It is well known that AAA has instituted a crop-curtailment plan which rewards with a cash bounty farmers who reduce their acreage.

LONDON, March 12. -- A "decided improvement" in Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's health was announced tonight following a day of rumors, one of which asserted that his political friends were convinced he had already decided to leave Downing Street and take a less arduous position that would enable him to remain in the Cabinet.

Miss Gertrud Hrdliczka made her first appearance here as a conductor last night, leading an orchestra of sixty men in a symphonic program at the Town Hall. The works played were Beethoven's "Die Weihe des Hauses" overture, Op. 124; Haydn's Symphony in C (B. H. No. 97), Johann Strauss's "Kaiser Walzer" and Scriabin's Symphony No. 2 in C minor, Op. 29.
TAKE two and hit to right. That's the old baseball slogan. But the situation is so confused at this time of the year that any one might be pardoned for asking: "Which way is right field just now?"

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Father Coughlin characterized Bernard M. Baruch in three ways: The master of Hugh S. Johnson; the acting President of the United States, and the uncrowned prince of Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A possible nation-wide strike of 400,000 bituminous coal miners on April 1, with a large proportion of their 2,000,000 dependents thrown on Federal and State relief agencies, was indicated today as miners and operators of the Appalachian area met here to confer on a wage agreement to replace the one expiring at the end of this month.

The State Chamber of Commerce published a report on housing which recommends a long-range program of slum clearance, with particular emphasis on the Lower East Side. Your editorial "A New Housing Plan" hails this plan with enthusiasm. At the same time, public housing agencies are spoken of slightingly as serving "to plunge the government into the real estate business on a vast scale with all the prospective evils of absentee landlordism."

The Amerex Holding Corporation, formerly the Chase Corporation and then an affiliate of the Chase National Bank, reduced its loans payable last year by $8,930,862, leaving about $11,500,000, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Chandler P. Anderson Jr., president.

BOSTON, March 12 (AP). -- The hard-driving Boston Bruins moved another step nearer their goal, a first-place National Hockey League play-off berth, by defeating the New York Americans, 4 -- 1, tonight at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, March 12. -- Great Britain intervened today to check the decline of the pound sterling. Action of the British Stabilization Fund, which apparently had not been functioning for some time, was felt immediately in international money markets.

District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday that he expected further indictments in policy and vice cases, in addition to Monday's indictments of three persons for conspiracy and perjury, as a result of the grand jury's investigation of rackets.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A list of seventeen present and proposed "service" codes was given to the Senate Finance Committee today by Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, as samples of those that would be dropped wholesale from the NRA structure under a redefinition of "interstate commerce" in his proposed revision of NIRA.

Taking issue with State officials in findings made public yesterday, the Milk Research Council, Inc., questioned the value of the $500,000 advertising campaign conducted in the last half of last year to stimulate milk consumption in the New York milkshed.

The art of Auguste Renoir is much in evidence here this month. Yesterday an exhibition devoted entirely to the work of this great nineteenth century French painter opened to the public at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street, where it will remain through March.

MOSCOW, March 12 (AP). -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, made one of the most important statements of Soviet policy in recent years when he declared today that individual tastes and needs must be respected on Soviet farms.
BERLIN, March 12 (AP). -- Evidence that a new wave of anti-Semitism is sweeping Germany is contained in weekly publications appearing on the news stands.

Playing remarkably good tennis considering his lack of competition, Sidney B. Wood Jr. joined Dr. Eugene McCauliff yesterday to defeat Lieutenant R. Morgan Watt and Irving Pratt, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, in the national indoor doubles championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 12. -- A high wind that continually threatened to reach hurricane proportions but never quite made good seriously interfered with the Dodgers' training exercises today.

A proposed rule covering the closing of entries for dog shows was approved at the meeting of the directors of the American Kennel Club yesterday at headquarters. The regulation provides for the closing of entries ten days before the date of the show.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- By a vote of 400 to 2 the House passed today the administration Home Mortgage Relief Bill to enlarge the scope of the Home Owners Loan Corporation and to amend the Housing Act. The dissenters were Representatives Andrews of New York and Merritt of Connecticut.

A six-story apartment house to be built at 209-13 West 104th Street will cost $90,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Sugarman Berger, architects, for the 209 104th Street Corporation, Samuel Ageloft, president, of 188 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12. -- In the orange gardens of the Everglades Club Prince and Princess Boris Scherbatoff were hosts today to a large company for tea as a farewell before leaving Friday for a fortnight in St. Augustine.

TRENTON, March 12. -- Investigation of the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby and the trial of Bruno Hauptmann has cost Federal and State authorities more than $1,181,000, it was estimated here today by Assistant Attorney General Joseph A. Lanigan. Mr. Lanigan made this statement while asking the joint appropriations committee of the New Jersey State Legislature to approve additional appropriations of $81,106 for expenses of the Hauptmann trial.

Charles Scribner, president of Charles Scribner's Sons, publishers, and Mrs. Scribner are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Washington of the United States Lines. Others leaving for the Channel ports on the ship are Paul Brown, artist, and:

SACRAMENTO, March 12. -- Max Baer, heavyweight boxing king will remain temporarily in California until the current furor over prospects of a title match between him and Max Schmeling of Germany takes a more definite form.
Stone Webster, Inc., reported yesterday for 1934 a net income of $90,343 after expenses, taxes and interest, in contrast with a loss of $85,907 in 1933.

Eleven Manhattan parcels, including an eleven-story loft building at the northwest corner of Irving Place and Sixteenth Street and a sixteen-story loft structure at 227-29 West Twenty-ninth Street, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The House today began consideration of the First Deficiency Appropriation Bill, proposing to grant $112,270,309 to make up deficiencies in existing and previous appropriations, and to supply supplementary funds for the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Repeal of the "pink slip" publicity amendment to the Income Tax Law, which was approved by the House yesterday, faced opposition in the Senate today as Senator La Follette moved to press for fullest publicity of every detail of income tax returns.

As soon as women can shout loudly enough to be understood over an area the size of a city block they'll take their turn with men in the umpire's high chair at tournaments sponsored by the United States Lawn Tennis Association and its member organizations.

The first two members of the crew of the disabled schooner Seth Parker to reach New York arrived here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara. They were Arthur Morgan, the diminutive Negro cabin boy christened by Captain Phillips Lord as "Worry" and assigned to do the ship's worrying, and Alex Carlson, second engineer.

Weakness developed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. A further break in prices of cotton and continued weakness in sterling were unsettling factors. The volume of trading was heavy in some commodities and moderate in others. On the cash markets butter advanced, but wheat, rye, oats, cocoa, eggs, tin, rubber and cotton were lower.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The Wagner trade disputes bill was approved in general today by Secretary Perkins and Chairman Francis Biddle of the National Labor Relations Board, but Miss Perkins opposed the provision which would make the board an independent agency, insisting that it should be created in the Department of Labor, through which it would report to the President.

Cotton again held the interest of Wall Street for a time yesterday, but the movement was much less excited than on the previous day. All markets were heavy. Speculators showed no special preference in their selling operations; they held a decided advantage at the close of the day, with stocks and commodities resting at lower levels than on the previous afternoon.

Plans to organize committees representing virtually every phase of business and industrial activity for the purpose of raising $500,000 to finance the welfare work of the Salvation Army during the coming year were announced yesterday by Richard C. Patterson, chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, at a meeting of business leaders at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Plans to organize committees representing virtually every phase of business and industrial activity for the purpose of raising $500,000 to finance the welfare work of the Salvation Army during the coming year were announced yesterday by Richard C. Patterson, chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, at a meeting of business leaders at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

While the city was receiving $42,500 in rentals from the Central Park Casino over a five-year period, the Casino grossed $3,096,155 and Sidney Solomon received $260,612 in salary and dividends, it was revealed yesterday at the trial before Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore of the Dieppe Corporation's suit to restrain Park Commissioner Robert Moses from ousting it from control of the Casino.

Aurel Joliat's goal in the closing minutes of the final period gave the Canadiens of Montreal a triumph over the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Leading the eight contract-bridge teams to qualify yesterday afternoon for the final rounds of play for the Curt Reisinger Trophy in the annual Eastern championships at the Hotel Commodore, the combination headed by Waldemar von Zedtwitz was favored to outlast the field in the three forthcoming "knockout" rounds.

The complete fields of sixteen men for the sprint and hurdles events and the seedings for these races in the sixteenth annual New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night were announced yesterday by Frank Brennan and John Downing, directors of the meet.

Yesterday's decline carried THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks to the lowest level since last Oct. 4. Brokers' spirits, however were carried much lower than the averages indicate. A visit to several offices in the financial district yesterday afternoon showed that some individuals felt worse than at any time in the last two years.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 12. -- The Giants' offensive guns were still missing and spluttering badly today, as though they had been left out in the damp last night. But excellent pitching saved them, and so it came to pass that Colonel Bill, Terry's men contrived to bring down the Browns, 1 to 0, thereby squaring the two-game series here at a victory apiece.
Under lights of varied hue and in a glittering setting, the sixth annual international figure skating carnival will be held before a capacity crowd of 16,000 at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The dispute between Japan and Russia over fisheries arrangements in the Far East is understood to centre on exchange incidental to the fall of the yen, with Japan insisting upon the present terms, which operate in her favor.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Prices in the grain pits on the Board of Board of Trade backed and filled today in a most erratic manner. The range in wheat and corn was around a cent a bushel. The market was affected at times by the actions of stocks, cotton or foreign exchange.
NEW ORLEANS, March 12. -- While the cotton market here was not so excited today as it was yes-
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Mrs. 0harleL V. Hickox gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis for the group of women in charge of the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of *'De Luxe" tomorrow night at the Booth Theatre in behalf ot the Babies I-Iospital.
ALBANY, March 12. -- On the suggestion of Governor Lehman at a long conference here today, Mayor La Guardia pledged himself to win repeal of the New York City income and inheritance taxes.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,526,400 barrels, compared with 2,473,850 in the previous week, an increase of 52,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 56,800 barrels daily in California was the most important change.

BERLIN, March 12 (AP). -- The German Government's financial troubles have proved favorable to the Reichsbank and its shareholders, according to the Central Bank's annual report, issued today. The balance showed 49,000,000 marks net surplus, of which nearly 30 per cent, or 12,000,000 marks, will be paid to the shareholders 'and 18,000,000 to the government treasury.

"It Happened One Night" has been picked by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences as the best motion picture of the year. These "official" designations of the "best" this or that usually precipitate a certain amount of dissent, which is always a healthy sign, but in this particular case the protest of dissenters is not likely to be very vigorous or widespread.

The National Academy of Design has elected fifteen new associate members from the fields of painting, sculpture, architecture and etching. The announcement was made yesterday before a reception that opened the academy's 110th annual exhibition in the American Fine Arts Galleries at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Presenting a strong attack which enabled it to hold the upper hand throughout, the Abraham Lincoln High School basketball team triumphed over Franklin K. Lane, 33 to 19, in one of the four Brooklyn P.S.A.L. encounters yesterday.
Business in money was limited to replacements. Little new funds were taken. Quotations for all classifications continued steady.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A drive to restrict President Roosevelt's work relief program in such a way that the unemployed white-collar workers in New York and other large cities may reap a greater share of its benefits was started in the Senate today by Senator Copeland of New York and other Senators representing densely populated areas.

League championships in two sports will be decided tonight when Columbia and Penn clash on the Rutgers court in New Brunswick, N.J., in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League play-off and the Harvard sextet meets Yale at the Boston Garden in the deciding contest of the Quadrangular Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- General Hugh S. Johnson will attempt to enlist "thinking Americans" in his campaign against Senator Long and the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit by taking to the radio again, probably within a week, Frances Robinson, his secretary, made known today.
ALBANY, March 12. -- Both houses of the Legislature made heavy progress on their calendars today and the leaders are hopeful of final adjournment by March 29 at the latest.

Talk of the formation of a third party for 1936 is said to be spreading rapidly in Washington. It has been heard there sporadically from the very beginning of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S Presidency. All along, in fact, men who thought themselves skilled in reading the seeds of time have predicted that the President would be found putting himself at the head of an extremely radical party.

The Merchants Association of New York expressed its opposition yesterday to pending Federal and State legislation providing for the employment of larger operating crews on railroad trains in yards and on main tracks.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12. -- Mad Beth gave Jockey Carl Hartford a double at Tropical Park today and snapped a succession of three winning favorites when she got home a half length in front of Dark War, public choice in the fourth. Hanford's first winner was Fred Almy, which began the day auspiciously for the form players.

The recent snuffing out of an alleged racketeer, whose activities over a number of years included the taxicab business, brings to light another reason why the authorities have difficulty in doing their share to control it.

Speakers prominent in Jewish affairs will open the thirty-first annual convention of the Jewish Consumptives Relief Society of Denver at the Hotel Astor on Saturday, March 23, at 8 P.M., it was announced yesterday. A sound film showing the activities of the institution will be presented and the speeches will be broadcast over Station WOE.

Restoration of international trade through the removal of excessive trade barriers constitutes an imperative step in speeding world recovery, Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador, asserted last night in an address to the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents at the Park Lane Hotel.

BERLIN, March 12. -- In a speech before the American Chamber of Commerce in Berlin today, Dr. Friedrich Bergius, Nobel Prize winner and the best known exponent of Germany's synthetic raw material industry, advanced a new concept of national political economy.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A cleavage between Father Coughlin and Senator Long was seen today in the latest renewal of the spectacular battle of epithets between them, on one side, and General Johnson on the other.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has undertaken to secure from the Board of Estimate repeal of the law levying a municipal income tax to the amount of 15 per cent of each citizen's Federal income tax. This ought to be easy. The tax was originally imposed in a desperate attempt to secure the necessary funds for relief.

Grace George is the star chosen for "Kind Lady," the Edward Chodorov dramatization of a Hugh Walpole story, which will be the final joint production by H.C. Potter and George Haight. Henry Daniell, sailing Saturday from England, also will be in it.
Conveyance of a Bayonne corner was included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

ATHENS, March 13. -- Consultation with the people to obtain their consent for the abolition of the Senate, created by Eleutherios Venizelos during his Premiership in 1928, was planned by the government today. This is to be a prelude to its offensive designed to sweep M. Venizelos as completely from Greek politics as exile and confiscation of his property have swept him and his family from Greek soil.

Retail prices on general merchandise continued their downward trend during February, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index for that month. The combined index, it was announced yesterday, declined 0.3 per cent last month and now stands at 86.6.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Standing alone in a fight he knew he could not win to block bonus legislation, Representative Lewis of Maryland, in a minority report of the Ways and Means Committee filed with the House today, denounced as "an unjust and ruinous financial program" the immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus as provided by the Patman and Vinson bills.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 13 (AP). -- Leaders of the American Bowling Congress held their positions today as pinmen from Brockport, Lockport, Albany, Rochester, Solvay and Syracuse failed to produce good scores.

LONDON, March 13 (AP). -- British official quarters and the London press viewed with quiet amusement today the threatened deportation of Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey, arrested in Chicago on charges of entering the United States by making false statements.

GENEVA, March 13. -- Uruguay astonished the Chaco advisory committee of the League of Nations today when her delegate, Alberto N. Guani, flatly said that she would not place an arms embargo upon Paraguay unless all the neighboring nations placed an embargo upon Bolivia too.

Payment of the first instalment of the city's tax of one-tenth of one per cent upon the 1934 gross receipts of business concerns must be made at an office of the city collector or put into the mails by midnight tomorrow, Controller Frank J. Taylor warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Senate today voted a Federal Trade Commission investigation of alleged nation-wide propaganda by utility holding concerns against administration plans to put some of them out of business.

BUENOS AIRES, March 13. -- Fifty-eight racing cars began leaving this city at midnight on a 12,786-mile international race over Argentine and Chilean country roads, including two crossings of the Andes Mountains.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 13. -- Colonel Bill Terry renewed his acquaintance with Joe Cronin today, but the meeting was scarcely as pleasant for the man from Memphis as the last one.

NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -- In an opinion believed to be the most sweeping yet handed down on the National Industrial Recovery Act, United States District Judge Guy L. Fake ruled today that the act was unconstitutional.

LONDON, Thursday, March 14. -- Under a headline reading "Future of the Dollar -- Effect of the Gold Decision -- Anxiety at the White House," The London Times publishes this morning a long dispatch from its Washington correspondent, who reviews a number of conferences President Roosevelt is reported to have held in the past few days with a group of his aides upon questions which the writer says were known to affect monetary policy.

You name fifteen States where the Federal Government has contributed from 90.9 per cent of the relief funds in Idaho to 99.9 in Florida, with North Dakota, South Dakota, Arkansas, Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Nevada, South Carolina, Wyoming, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina and New Mexico in between.

Striking musicians, stagehands and motion-picture operators and their sympathizers, about 300 in all, massed before the Republic Theatre, 209 West Forty-second Street, west of Broadway, for more than an hour yesterday afternoon.

Mayor La Guardia accepted the honorary chairmanship of a committee of sponsors for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America at City Hall yesterday and congratulated the Scouts for their work in public health and education.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The House bill repealing the pink slip publicity amendment of the Income Tax Law was reported favorably by the Senate Finance Committee in record time today, but the immediate reaction was exactly what leaders had expected.

The Transamerica Corporation, the Pacific Coast holding company that controls the banking enterprises founded by A.P. Giannini, has again added substantially to its investment in the National City Bank of New York, of which it is the largest shareholder, it was revealed in the annual report of the corporation for 1934, published yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 13. -- Evidence to prove that the Bethlehem Steel Company got substantially all the assets of the McClintic-Marshall Company on Feb. 10, 1931, for $21,000,000 in stocks and bonds of the former, was offered today on behalf of Andrew W. Mellon before the Board of Tax Appeals.

I HAD been reading in Harold Lasswell's "World Politics and Personal Insecurity," a book that I mean to review in the future. Then I picked up Rose Macaulay's short biography of "Milton" (Harper, $2). It seemed almost as if I were still in the modern world of Lasswell.

Echoes of the days before the era of "horseless carriages" resounded above the roar of automobile traffic yesterday, with a hit-and-run bicyclist eluding two policemen after a chase from Fifth Avenue to the Herald Square district, another bicyclist appearing in Traffic Court for reckless pedaling and a man being hurt by a horse-drawn wagon.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Reduction of compulsory NRA codes from 731 to 181 by consolidation of 537 with basic codes and outright elimination of all "service" codes was proposed today by Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, as the administration's plan for simplification of the NRA.

Arrangements for the Eastern sectional play-offs and the National amateur hockey championship were completed yesterday by the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. under whose auspices the sport is being conducted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13. -- The defense in the trial of Albert H. Fish for the murder of 10-year-old Grace Budd moved five times for a mistrial today as it objected to the display of a skull and bones found at the cottage where the girl's body was discovered.

BOSTON, March 13. -- One quick thrust by Doug Robinson, a spare wingman, brought Yale victory over Harvard in the play-off game for the Quadrangular Hockey League championship tonight at the Boston Garden.

The steamship President Cleveland of the Dollar Line, with only her crew on board, went aground at 9:28 A.M. yesterday east of Red Hook Flats while steaming from her pier in Jersey City to Pier 2 of the Army Base, foot of Fiftysixth Street, Brooklyn, to load army trucks for San Francisco.

MIAMI, March 13. -- Professor Rafael del Vizo, former member of the Cuban Congress, who has severed political ties with his native country and for years has sought to prepare impartial news broadcasts in Spanish for American stations, believes the present struggle in Cuba has developed chiefly from a desire for political power.

The railroad managements plan to move for a general reduction in wages this Spring, it was disclosed yesterday. While no formal action has been taken, it was conceded that the managements felt the current trend of their earnings precluded any alternative action.

BERLIN, March 13. -- The reorganization of German aviation was discussed at some length and with considerable candor today by the Diplomatische Politische Korrespondenz, which is commonly accepted as authoritatively reflecting official opinion.
The weekly weather report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

A further decline in activity at the steel mills is reported by The Iron Age in its midweek review. The current operating rate is estimated at 47 1/2 per cent of capacity, compared with 48 1/2 per cent a week before.

Complete fields for the four events comprising the "Iron Man" schedule in the sixteenth annual Knights of Columbus track and field games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night were announced yesterday. The four tests are the special 1,000-yard run, the Columbian mile. the Casey 600 and the special 880.
A Spring list of 104 books approved for members of the Roman Catholic Church was made public yesterday by the Cardinal's Literature Committee of the Archdiocese of New York.

Its desperate nine-point last-peri-or rally proving futile, St. Michael's High of Union City, N.J., bowed to Don Bosco Institute of Ramsey, N.J., 21 -- 19, last night at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn in the quarter-finals of the Metropolitan Catholic High Schools basketball tourney.
Sales of multi-family buildings on the East Side featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

PARIS, March 13. -- The stock market weakened throughout to day. Gold mining shares alone were actively traded. It was necessary for the government to post notices on the Bourse floor denying rumors of an intended increase in the current issue of Treasury bonds to check a selling wave in French rentes.

The apportionment report made public in Albany yesterday, if enacted into law, would go far toward ending Tammany's domination of city politics and would decrease the importance of many powerful figures in Tammany's ranks.

Mayor La Guardia clashed with Governor Lehman yesterday over the proposed extension of the city's emergency taxing powers by the Legislature, expressing disappointment at not receiving a year's more time. When the Governor heard of this he retorted that a six months' extension had been perfectly acceptable to Mr. La Guardia at their conference the day before.

The Martine Cantine Company, coated papers, and the District of Columbia Paper Manufacturing Company have rented space in 41 Park Row, which now has thirty-eight paper trade tenants, E.A. Tredwell Co., the brokers, reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 13. -- The discovery of porcelain archives almost 3,000 years old, apparently belonging to the leading Prince of Judah, was revealed here today. The find was regarded as of vast importance in corroboration of Bible stories during the pre-Solomon era.

The commodity futures markets were generally lower yesterday in rather quiet trading. A feature was the weakness and activity in coffee futures, which again established new seasonal lows. In the cash market wheat, corn, oats and tin were higher, while rye, butter, lard, printcloths, coffee, sugar, silks and hides were lower.

Production of new life insurance last month was 11 per cent greater than in February, 1934, according to figures submitted yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce. For the first two months of this year the cumulative total was 17.6 per cent above the amount for the corresponding period a year ago.
In the Central Park Zoo during the lunch hour the white-tailed gnu paused between two wisps of hay and remarked to the camel, "What is your reaction to 40 cents for a cup of coffee?"

ALBANY, March 13. -- The long-awaited measure drastically reapportioning seats in the Senate and the Assembly was introduced in the Legislature today and immediately provoked a Democratic revolt which threatens passage of the bill.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -- The suddenly ordered arrest of John Strachey today stirred up capital talk about Communists.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The American Iron and Steel Institute announced today that it had ascertained the views of the members of the industry itself on the basing point method of quoting steel prices and that "an overwhelming majority of small and large companies had given "strong endorsement" to the system.
More than 25,000 books, pictures and plates, valued at about $500,000, considered obscene by courts and police officers, will be burned this morning in the furnace of police headquarters.
Before a capacity gathering of 16,000, another gala international figure skating carnival was presented at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Whether the Treasury will call for redemption on June 15 all or part of the First Liberty bond issue outstanding remained in doubt today as officials studied market conditions and watched the progress of the refunding operation covering $1,850,000,000 of Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 per cent bonds, which have been called for April 15.

Shouted protests from a large gathering of unemployed teachers and parents to whom a hearing had been denied disrupted a meeting of the Board of Education last night and caused a near-riot that was finally quelled by a police emergency squad.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody swung her racket and raced over the tennis court today for the first time since an injury forced her out of the national championships in 1933.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York went on record yesterday as opposed to two bills in the State Senate and Assembly that are intended to alter the present method of obtaining injunctions against strikers and pickets in labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- A list of 286 NRA codes was laid before the Senate Finance Committee by Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, as among those that should be dropped.

The International Harvester Company reports for 1934 consolidated net income of $3,948,636 after charges, interest provision for inventory reserve, plant depreciation and provision for losses on receivables. This equaled $4.80 a share on 823,325 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock outstanding.

The father of JEREMIAH SMITH Jr. was known as "JEREMIAH SMITH of N.H." The grandfather, of the same name (who was a volunteer in the Revolutionary Army and was wounded at Bennington), became a United States circuit judge as well as Governor of New Hampshire and Chief Justice of the State.

As a member of the subcommittee on Federal law of the Pennsylvania Bar Association, I call your attention to an anti-administration report quoted by you under the heading "Pennsylvania Bar Association Assails New Deal."
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Yesterday Prime Minister MACDONALD'S health was reported to be improved, though still none of the best. He will hang on if he can. Meanwhile the health of the Ministry is far from robust. The hubbub about the new Unemployment Regulations has not died out.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Despite numerous major problems, the AAA today disclosed that it is worried about the horse situation, too. Experts have just added up and found a 10,000,000 horse and mule shortage.

Predicting that fifty indictments for perjury would result, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan began a sweeping investigation of bail-bond practices before the Kings County grand jury yesterday. He presented ten cases yesterday, from which, he predicted, at least seven indictments would result.

GENEVA, March 13. -- After ten years of fruitless debate among experts, there was reached here today their first unanimous agreement, both that it is practically possible to distinguish technically between military and civil airplanes and precisely how to do it.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission directed today registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $7,000,000 ten-year convertible 6 per cent debentures, due Jan. 1, 1945, and 2,800,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Studebaker Corporation to become effective upon consummation of the plan of reorganization.

Auctioneers struck down to plaintiffs seven Manhattan properties at foreclosure sales yesterday. The list included a tall commercial building and several tenement houses. Savings banks bought in several of the holdings.

Julius Seligson, national intercollegiate champion in 1928, came back into the tennis spotlight yesterday with an uphill victory over Dr. Eugene H. McCauliff of Yonkers in the national indoor championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The score was 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6, 12 -- 10.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13. -- As the United States started today to place stepping stones from the Pacific Coast to its island possessions, the mystery of a robot-controlled "mystery" plane which took off here today was explained by the news that it had made two ocean flights preliminary to a takeoff for Honolulu to map a reliable airway.

The reorganization plan of the Fourth National Investors Corporation has reached a "decisive stage" at which stockholders should indicate definitely whether they will support it, Fred Y. Presley, president, said in a letter sent yesterday to shareholders.
LONDON, March 13. -- The French decision to build two 35,000-ton battleships is deplored here as a wasteful and senseless move, for which Italy is more to blame than France.

In the first full year of operation since the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the National Distillers Products Corporation made a net profit of $11,134,768, after depreciation, interest, provision for claims and allowances, Federal taxes, and other charges, and including proportion of profits of Penn-Maryland, Inc., and subsidiaries for January, 1934, applicable to the 50 per cent outside interest acquired on Feb. 7, 1934.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 18. -- The cold weather which curtailed the Dodgers' training activities today brought forth some startling statements from Joe Gilleaudeau, vice president and treasurer of the club.

In what was probably the last interview before his death, Professor Michael Pupin, Serbian herdsboy who became one of America's leading scientists, expressed his faith in continuing existence beyond the grave. Dr. Pupin died on Tuesday and his funeral will be held tomorrow.

A sharp rise in prices of United States Government bonds under the impetus of heavy buying, which reversed the downward trend of earlier in the week, contrasted yesterday with a generally lower market for domestic corporation bonds and foreign loans on the Stock Exchange.

A plan of recapitalization for the Hahn Department Stores, providing for an exchange of cash and new securities for the present 6 1/2 per cent preferred stock, on which accrued dividends totaled $19.75 a share on Jan. 1, has been approved in principle by the directors, it was announced yesterday.

The four top seeded players in the women's division tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association came through victorious in their matches yesterday at the Junior League despite keen contests. The winners reached the semi-finals.

Felix M. Warburg, banker, is among the passengers due today from the south of France on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Others arriving on the ship from Mediterranean ports include Fulton Oursler, writer, and Edna Ferber, novelist, and the following:

The story told by Joseph Doorhey of 574 East 138th Street, the Bronx, whom a grand jury refused to indict, that he was driven to stealing groceries because his family had been taken off the relief rolls and had nothing to eat was not true, according to a statement issued yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare and chairman of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Wallace and Senators Smith and Bankhead, the conferees reporting later that he was in full accord with the cotton control program.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13. -- Resolutions opposing compulsory military training in colleges, and all forms of military education in high schools, and urging enactment of legislation to permit the President to declare an embargo on munitions and arms in times of war, were adopted by the National Council of Jewish Women at their convention here today.

The hopes of 140,000 city and county employes that a Court of Appeals decision restoring a pay cut to a Transit Commission employe might restore all pay cuts were dashed last night when Mayor La Guardia and the Transit Commission agreed that the decision applied only to the Transit Commission's employes.
Miss Dorothy Locke of Salle d'Armes Vince dethroned her club-mate, Miss Marion Lloyd, as women's individual metropolitan foils champion last night on her home strips.

TRENTON, March 13. -- A judgment for $1,328,000 obtained against Asbury Park on defaulted bonds held by New York investors must be included in the municipality's budget in equal instalments over the next ten years, Federal Judge Phillip Forman ruled today.

President ROOSEVELT makes a plausible argument for effective regulation of utility holding companies. Abuses have been notorious. Stock issues have sometimes been manipulated in the interest of minority control. Holding company structures are often so intricate that the regulatory commission finds it difficult to trace out the maze and penetrate to its central refuge.

The second annual exhibition of the work of New York artists who have participated in the Washington Square outdoor shows is on at the galleries of the Roerich Museum, 310 Riverside Drive. Some seventy-five are represented in oils, water-colors and black and white work, selected by a jury composed of Alexander Brook, Lloyd Goodrich, Yasuo Kunyoshi, Reginald Marsh, William McNulty, Henry Schnakenberg and John Sloan.

BERLIN, March 13. -- Having been barred from official careers, the arts and the professions, German Jews now are also largely excluded from manual trades, too. This exclusion was indirectly decreed in a circular issued by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, which, incidentally, announced the promotion of Jewish emigration from Germany had become, in fact, an official government policy.

Representatives of the Home for the Orphans and Aged of Woodcliff. N.J., yesterday defended the benefit show given on Sunday night for that institution at the Imperial Theatre. On Tuesday, eleven members of the Actors Equity Association who participated in the performance were charged with breaking Equity's ruling against appearing in a benefit unauthorized by the Theatre Authority, Inc.

The city of Boston, Mass., yesterday awarded a new issue of $2,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes to a syndicate comprising Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Hemphill, Noyes Co., G.M.-P. Murphy Co., Darby Co., Burr Co., Inc., and the R.F. Griggs Company of Waterbury, Conn.

The Merchants Association of New York was notified yesterday that its protest against tariff discrimination on freight imported by Canada by way of New York and other ports of the United States would be laid before the State Department by the Committee on Reciprocity Information.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- None of the ordinary symptoms which mark a fear of inflation, declared in some quarters to be hindering business confidence and recovery, has been manifested, Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today in testimony on the proposed banking act of 1935.

Harry A. Gordon, referee, allowed claims yesterday totaling $12,876 to nine holders of bonds of S.W. Straus Co., now in receivership. The claimants accused the company of fraudulent misrepresentation in mortgage bond sales.

All speculative markets improved yesterday and a more cheerful feeling was abroad in Wall Street. Cotton, upon which financial interest has been focused for several days, recovered almost $1.50 a bale of its recent losses. Grains were also higher, anywhere from a fraction to a cent a bushel.

Primo Carnera and Ray Impellittiere, who will meet in the featured ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, concluded their intensive training yesterday. Both fighters will do light work today to keep on edge and will come to New York tomorrow afternoon to weigh in at the offices of the State Athletic Commission at 1:30 P.M.

Some of the reasons why the search for the Lindbergh kidnapper and the conviction of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the crime cost the Federal Government, New Jersey, and New York City more than $1,200,000 all together, were shown yesterday here and in Trenton.

Earnings of the Chicago North Western Railway in February ran close to those of February, 1934, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday. Indications were that the company would meet its interest payments due on May 1.

DUBLIN, March 13. -- For eleven days Dublin's public transport services have been paralyzed by a strike of tramway and omnibus workers. Last night Sean Lemass, Finance Minister, intervened in the hope of ending a situation that has caused much public inconvenience.

Mrs. Dorothy Stokes Procter, former motion-picture actress, has obtained an attachment against property of her husband, Frederick William Procter, Procter Gamble soap heir, to cover her expenses since he allegedly abandoned her in Paris last June 1, it was disclosed yesterday with the publication of the attachment by order of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 13. -- A crowd of more than 10,000 persons is expected to witness the first event of the Sandhills Steeplechase and Racing Association here Saturday. Included in the gathering will be Governor Ehringhaus of North Carolina.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 13. -- Columbia had the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship won until the final five seconds of the play-off game tonight. At that point Captain Bob Freeman of Penn hit the cords from beyond the middle of the court for the winning marker.

Writers, publishers and liberals sent telegrams to Washington yesterday, protesting against the move to deport Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey. The telegrams were addressed variously to President Roosevelt, Secretary Perkins, Colonel D.W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration, and the British Embassy.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 13. -- An application has been filed with Supreme Court Justice Ralph W.E. Donges to place the affairs of Atlantic City into the hands of the New Jersey Municipal Finance Commission, which recently took over control of Asbury Park, N.J.

Operations in 1934 of the International Business Machines Corporation resulted in a net income of $6,597,362 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges and including undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries. This was equivalent to $9.38 a share on 703,345 no-par shares of capital stock.
"Die Meistersinger" will be sung at the Metropolitan today, beginning at 1:30 P.M., as the sixth and last of the special Wagner cycle.

Spring came tripping lightly into City Hall plaza at noon yesterday in the form of eight big brewery trucks and a goat with edgy nerves. Each truck bore a symbolic case of dark, equinoctial brew to be presented to the Mayor and other city officials.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Two government departments moved today toward aiding commercial establishment of a transpacific air line service, while at the same time rumors were heard that a line to compete with the proposed Pan American Air Ways Service would be established.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
ALBANY, March 13. -- Democratic legislative chiefs decided today to bring about adjournment of the 1935 session on March 29, one week later than the date fixed by the Assembly two weeks ago.
Money market was dull. Funds were in good supply but demand was light. No changes in quotations were reported.

It is trite to say that the average citizen can have no clear understanding of our present economic tendencies. His confusion of thought is caused primarily by the flood of new and proposed legislation that, under the stimulus of well-organized lobbies, engrosses the attention of our lawmakers.

BRUSSELS, March 13. -- A revision of rates and service, following their adherence to the North Atlantic passenger conference, was announced here today by F.J. Careme, director of passenger service for the Arnold Bernstein and the Red Star Lines.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey, British radical writer arrested last night after a lecture in Glencoe, Ill., on a warrant from the Department of Immigration, which seeks his deportation as an alien Communist, will have a formal hearing on the charges tomorrow morning before Fred J. Schlotfeldt, district immigration inspector.

VENIZELOS is a fugitive on the island of Rhodes under the Italian flag, and it is believed that the leader of the defunct rebellion will soon go to Paris to spend the rest of his days with his two sons. It is a fate quite in harmony with ancient Greek tradition. More than one famous son of Hellas spent his declining years in exile.

BERLIN, March 13 (AP). -- Although the German public is keen to have Max Baer, the heavyweight champion, come to Berlin to defend his title against Max Schmeling, Nazi circles tonight were in the embarrassing position of not wanting to ballyhoo the match more than is necessary.
Although still reflecting considerable nervousness, trading on the Cotton Exchange showed more demand from consumers yesterday and prices improved 21 to 31 points.

Under cover of increased weakness in the gold bloc, the pound sterling was apparently repegged yesterday, following its prolonged spasm of weakness. It held within a range of 3/4 cent and closed unchanged from Tuesday at $4.74 1/4.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 13. -- Steadfast, aged chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur B. Ruthrauff of Red Bank, N.J., and ridden by Morgan Macy of Caledonia, N.Y., won the trophy in the middle and heavyweight hunters class of the twenty-fifth annual Camden Horse Show today.

"Gold Diggers of 1935," latest of the musical films to emerge from the combined Warner Brothers-First National studios, begins an engagement this morning at the Strand. Dick Powell, Adolphe Menjou, Gloria Stuart and Hugh Herbert head the cast, aided by Alice Brady and Glenda Farrell.

LONDON, March 13 (AP). -- Mrs. Doris Draper, tall and blonde, testified tearfully today that she had lived with the late Sir Robert Peel, husband of the actress, Beatrice Lillie, for five years before he died last April.

In its debate on the President's work-relief plan the Senate has hit upon the fact that more than a billion dollars, originally put at the disposal of PWA in 1933, still remains unexpended. This does not mean that most of it has not been "allocated" to some specific project.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 13. -- Michael J. Griffin, Brooklyn lawyer; Samuel M. Stein, Bronx lawyer, and Mrs. Belle Ferguson of Brooklyn were convicted by a jury in Nassau County Court here today of attempted grand larceny and conspiracy to defraud the estate of Antonin Chapal, wealthy fur importer of Brooklyn and Central Park, L.I., of $500,000.
The forty-second anniversary of the founding of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was celebrated last night with a dinner, entertainment and dance at the hotel for employes.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 13. -- Commenting on complaints of American residents that New Cristobal lacks the proper police protection, Foreign Secretary J.D. Arosemena of Panama suggested today that perhaps the best solution would be for the complainers "and all who wish to follow them to go over into the Canal Zone, where they belong."

MIAMI, Fla., March 13 (AP). -- For the third consecutive year Captain Wirth Munroe and his sleek 36-foot ketch Melody today won the Sir Thomas Lipton Cup in the seventh annual 25-mile ocean sailing race with the best corrected time of 4 hours 28 minutes.

HAVANA, March 13. -- Commerce and industry strove today to reestablish normal activities in Cuba, following the failure of the general revolutionary strike, but the action of the government in making wholesale arrests among employes returning to work greatly hindered these efforts.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13. -- Holding that Congress has no more right to regulate production and sale of milk in Rhode Island than has the Canadian Parliament, Judge Ira Lloyd Letts granted today in the Federal court a restraining order against the licensing provisions of the Federal AAA.

ST. LOUIS, March 13. -- Flooded tributaries of the Mississippi spread havoc through Southeastern Missouri and Southern Illinois and Northeast Arkansas today as relief officials prepared for the section's worst flood in years.

Judge Julian W. Mack declared from the bench in Federal court yesterday that he had "great doubts" of the correctness of answers which were being made to him by a loan analyst of the Irving Trust Company on the witness stand concerning a $4,000,000 loan to Samuel Insull.

BERLIN, March 13. -- The Boerse was quiet and irregular today. Heavy industrials were firm but inactive. Machineries were mixed and unstable, with a tendency toward weakness at the closing. Berlin Karlsruhe nevertheless gained 3/4 point. Electricals were uneven but varying no more than 1/2 point.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- A somewhat more confident feeling toward the buying side of grains developed today on the Board of Trade, but not until after liquidation had carried rye off about 1 1/2 cents a bushel to the lowest price of the season. July oats and May barley were also in new low ground for the crop year.

Charge account collections for February showed an increase of 0.53 per cent, according to the twenty key-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The figure compares with a rise of 4.35 per cent in January over the same month a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Secretary Swanson, gravely shaking his head, said today that he was not sanguine over prospects for the future extension of naval armament limitation, a feeling apparently reflected elsewhere in near-record military appropriations.

President MACCRACKEN of Vassar is reported to have said that there are no more ladies left by now. A few examples of the species gentleman may still be found, perhaps in the more inaccessible regions.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 13. -- Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr. of Camden, Me., the defending titleholder, was forced to travel nineteen holes to register a triumph in the second round of match play for the Ormond Beach golf championship today.

Supreme Court Justice Curtis Arnoux Peters, who died on Dec. 13, 1933, left an estate of $750,457.79, it was learned yesterday when an accounting in his estate was filed in Surrogate's Court. The executor, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, showed it had disbursed $703,269.99, and had on hand $47,187.80 on Jan. 19, last.

The strike of elevator operators and other service employes in the Bronx was called off last night as a result of a truce brought about through the intervention of James J. Lyons, President of the borough. Mr. Lyons induced the owners and the Bronx organization of the Building Service Employes Union to agree to a truce until April 15, during which an effort is to be made to reach a permanent settlement.

George K. Arthur, diminutive motion picture actor, was arrested yesterday as a jewel thief when he stepped down the gangway of the steamship Columbia, which docked at Pier 59, North River, on a return trip from Nassau.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- An open threat by Senator Long to conduct an indefinite filibuster against President Roosevelt's $4,880,000,000 work relief resolution was met today by a challenge of Senator Glass for a contest of physical endurance.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -- One of the strongest denunciations of wartime profits that the Senate Munitions Committee has heard in its long investigation was delivered today by Patrick J. Hurley, President Hoover's Secretary of War.

Shamrocks brought all the way from the shores of Killarney's lakes were given to Mayor La Guardia yesterday at City Hall by Alfred Byrne, Lord Mayor of Dublin, Ireland, who is here to attend the St. Patrick's Day celebration on Saturday.

TRENTON, March 13. -- Governor Hoffman notified Governor Lehman of New York today that New Jersey would give its full support to any equitable plan to end unfair competition in the dairy industry. Governor Hoffman insisted, however, that the "welfare of the consumers and producers in New Jersey be given adequate protection."

Unfortunately there are to be two gaps in the yacht racing in Bermuda, which, it was thought, would be a continuous affair over three weeks. It was learned yesterday that the 6-meter sloops will not start their competition until April 24.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13. -- Mrs. Lucius Pond Ordway entertained tonight at her villa on Banyan Road with a dinner. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hagood Haynes and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer.
Mr. and Mrs. Brooks Palmer gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 315 East Sixty-eighth Street, to celebrate the birthday of the hostess.
