Spring football practice at Manhattan College was inaugurated yesterday when a squad of forty candidates reported to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan at Van Cortlandt Park for the initial workout of a three weeks' session.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 25. -- The Giants parted company with the Athletics today for the last time this Spring and the operation almost caused Colonel Bill Terry's expedition to part at the seams.

To those who are mourning over the absence of sustained and substantial economic recovery, some interest ought to be imparted by last week's Department of Labor report on February employment. The Bureau's monthly "employment index" is sometimes waved aside as providing no fair criterion of basic industrial conditions, because the greater increase in number of active laborers (so the argument usually runs) has occurred in public works.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Blame for the difficulties of the Aviation Corporation, which lost more than $2,000,000 last year in cantrast with a profit exceeding $1,000,000 in 1933, was placed in the lap of the Federal Administration by the company's annual report, issued today by L.B. Manning, president.

Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, said the city had gained two important legal victories yesterday after the Appellate Division had permitted new trials in two condemnation suits involving awards and interest of about $7,500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The ideals of liberty, justice and brotherhood, which have been the tradition and heritage of the Jewish religion, have been the cause of the Jews' disfranchisement in Germany today, Judge Irving Lehman of New York declared tonight before the Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

DETROIT, March 25. -- Joe Louis, the sensational 20-year-old Negro fighter, isn't a bit worried about his first fifteen-round bout, tentatively set for June 19 in New York with Primo Carnera, former world's heavyweight champion.

The Ward liner Morro Castle, built less than five years ago at a cost of about $5,000,000, yesterday attracted only four bidders. The highest estimate of her worth was $33,605. The ship was wrecked by fire Sept. 8 off Sea Girt, N.J., and now lies at anchorage at Gravesend Bay.

PARIS, March 25 (AP). -- Robert Gordon Switz, American today accused nineteen others of spying against France for Soviet Russia as he, his wife and the nineteen went on trial as spies in a police court.
VATICAN CITY, March 25 (AP). -- Pope Pius today named Mgr. Arthur Hinsley to be Archbishop of Westminster, England, succeeding the late Francis Cardinal Bourne.
BERLIN, March 25. -- The German Foreign Office and the Polish Embassy today presented slightly divergent views of a visit to the Wilhemstrasse Saturday by Ambassador Josef Lipski of Poland.
Al Jolson, having completed his work for First National in "Go Into Your Dance." in which he is costarred with his wife, Ruby Keeler, will arrive in New York this morning from Hollywood.

The right of code authorities to assess members of their industries under the State Recovery Act was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin. In support of his ruling Justice McLaughlin cited the law that permits collection of fees from dog owners to pay expenses of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 25. -- An estate with a gross value of $546,439.97 was left by Ruth Morgan, philanthropist of Hyde Park and New York, who died March 11, according to a transfer tax report filed in the Surrogate's office. Deductions were $11,885.85, leaving a net estate for distribution of $534,554.12.

Mr. ROOSEVELT, leaving Washington, richly merits the relaxation promised him by a ten-day cruise in Southern waters. The Presidency is at best an exhausting office. The strain of it is heavily increased in times like these, when leadership consists of an almost daily choice between alternatives which frequently seem to be equally difficult and every decision carries with it a graver responsibility.

Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, predicted yesterday that the New York City budget for 1936 would total $30,000,000 more than the current budget, instead of the $20,000,000 increase estimated by the Controller.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The Nerwal Realty Corporation, Jacob S. Manheimer, attorney, bought in at auction yesterday, on a $1,520,0000 bid, the sixteen-story Sears, Roebuck Building at the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Thirty-first Street, 98 by 220 feet. The foreclosure action was against the Ninth Avenue-Thirty-first Street Corporation for $113,849 due.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25. -- Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu of Rumania, accompanied by his Secretary of State and right-hand man, Savel Radulescu, arrived here this morning and was met at the station by Premier Bogolyub Yeftitch and Ministers of the Little and the Balkan Ententes.

A contractor's right to compel a judicial review of the acts of a Borough President was upheld by Justice Charles Garside in the First District Municipal Court yesterday. The ruling was in the case of Moran Brothers Contracting Company against the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Belcher case, regarded as the government's strongest test involving the constitutionality of the NRA and all New Deal legislation will be dropped, it was learned today.

Fleeing from a fire following an explosion which, however, did not endanger the apartment they had left, three persons were burned Seriously at 7:30 o'clock last night on the fire-escape of the four-story tenement at 1,114 Third Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 25. -- For a manager whose club has lost only one game in eight exhibition starts Casey Stengel today was singularly lacking in optimistic expressions that might be expected to follow such performances.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Hope that an agreement for the exchange of information between the New York City police and the Justice Department would checkmate the white-slave traffic in the Northeast was expressed today by Federal authorities.

MEXICO, D.F., March 25. -- With Federal cavalry in close pursuit, the gang of kidnappers that on March 24 captured the two Americans, Mark Fowler and Louis F. Vremsak, and Gonzalez de Leon, servant of the former, released the three men in a mountainous region of the State of Zacatecas last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 25. -- As Albert H. Fish was sentenced to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing, Westchester authorities revealed today that he had confessed to a series of other crimes in various parts of the country.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CLEVELAND, March 25 (AP). -- Bob Olin of New York, world's light-heavyweight champion, won a decision from Mickey Dugan of Cleveland in an eight-round non-title fight tonight. Each weighed 176 pounds. Olin sent a left hook into Dugan's midriff in the third round and the local battler went down for a count of nine.

While Mayor La Guardia pleaded with the spiritual leaders of more than 300,000 New York Negroes yesterday to help him remedy the social and economic evils of Harlem, the committee he appointed to investigate the outbreak of last Tuesday traced the demonstration to long-festering social and economic sore spots.

BRUSSELS, March 25. -- After two days of negotiations which until late this evening seemed doomed to failure, Paul van Zeeland, young Professor of Economics, author and vice governor of the National Bank of Belgium, succeeded in forming a government, it was announced tonight.
Money market was quiet. With new business at a minimum, only replacements being effected, quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

Hahn Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday a plan of recapitalization, offering to holders of preferred and common shares substantial equities in future earnings. The plan, it was said, would not impair the company's cash position.
Park Department engineers are investigating a report that the ornate $250,000 clubhouse at the Dyker Beach Park golf course in Brooklyn has settled twelve inches, it was disclosed yesterday.

Despondent from overstudy, Miss Elsie Pokolitsch, 22 years old, a graduate student at Hunter College, committed suicide yesterday by gas poisoning in the kitchen of her home at 133 Brown Place, the Bronx.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 25 (AP). -- A denial that he is a lobbyist for aviation concerns was issued here tonight by Elliott Roosevelt, the President's son, in reply to charges made in the House today before passage of the Mead airmail bill.
I have read your editorial in the Saturday, March 23, 1935, edition, entitled "The Bonus Bill." You have not correctly stated the facts in regard to H.R. 1, the Patman bill, in this editorial.

Led by Manager Lester Patrick, the New York Rangers departed from Grand Central Station last night, bound for Montreal, where tonight they will conclude their two-game, total-goal series with the Canadiens in the third-place playoff for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 26 (AP). -- The Daily Mail's Berlin correspondent reported today that Adolf Hitler had charged Italy with financing the Austrian Heimwehr (Fascist Home-Guard) and had demanded in his conference with Sir John Simon that Great Britain and France "tell me exactly what you mean by 'interference'" with Austria.

A small but promising delegation of American golfers will make the trip to England for the British amateur championship, starting May 20 at the Royal Lytham St. Anne's course, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25. -- The kidnapping and death of the Lindbergh baby has cost New Jersey $167,820.72 thus far, it was revealed today when Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, Superintendent of the State Police, listed expenditures of his department totaling $37,713.94.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 25. -- Clipping a stroke from standard figures with a fancy exhibition, Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N.Y., today captured medalist honors in the eighteen-hole qualifying round of the fifth annual women's Augusta invitation golf tournament.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 25. -- Distressed because his wife's opposition to a reconciliation meant that he could not be with their daughter at all times, Garth A. Jordan 29 years old, a salesman, fatally wounded the child, Linda Lee Jordan, 3 1/2 years old, in a park drive, then shot himself.

BERLIN, March 25. -- The Boerse was relatively active and slightly stronger in spots today. Heavy industrials were somewhat firmer, Rheinstahl gaining 1 3/4 points. Machineries were firm, Berlin Karlsruhe rising one-half point. Bayerische Motorenwerke, believed to be engaged chiefly in armament manufacture, advanced 1 3/8.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- President Roosevelt left tonight for a fishing cruise in Southern waters within a few hours after sudden improvement in the condition of Louis McH. Howe, his secretary and intimate friend, had removed all immediate concern over the latter's state of health.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Rexford Guy Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, is virtually assured of what may become the most important administrative position in the new work relief organization, it developed today when it became known that President Roosevelt planned to place under his control the whole land-use program, including rural rehabilitation, soil-erosion work, sub-marginal land activities and, perhaps, the Mississippi Valley development.

Moderate gains were registered by commodity futures here yesterday. The volume of trading was fairly heavy. On the cash markets, wheat, corn and rubber declined, and rye, butter, tin, silk and cotton advanced.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- While law-enforcement authorities mapped an offensive against organized crime today, repercussions following the attempt to assassinate Thomas J. Courtney, State's Attorney of Cook County, reached the White House and charges of criminal conspiracy were made against Mayor Kelly and Mr. Courtney.
Controller Taylor announced yesterday that the day's sales tax receipts amounted to $109,109, with 3,329 returns filed, bringing the total collected to date to $719,079.

The College Art Association's traveling exhibition of Mexican art opened in the galleries of the Squibb Building yesterday afternoon with a ceremony in which the following speakers participated: Eduardo Villasenor, Rene d'Harnoncourt, A. Philip McMahon, Mrs. Alma Reed of the Delphic Studios and Jose Juan Tablada.

Uncertainty over the fate of an amendment in the United States Senate to the relief bill granting the President power to suspend all processing taxes influenced sentiment yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and near months improved $1.50 a bale at one time.

Little has been written of the vital interest of the Dominion of Canada in security from possible aggression from Japan. An article in Foreign Affairs recalls the fact that at the Imperial Conference of 1921 it was the Canadian Prime Minister, Mr. ARTHUR MEIGHAN, whose strong resistance prevented renewal of the Anglo-Japanese alliance, determined on by the Government and eagerly approved by New Zealand and Australia.

More than 500 men and women prominent in business, politics and, the professions attended a testimonial dinner to Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing at the Waldorf-Astoria to honor him on his completion of thirty years' service in the State's prison system.

BERLIN, March 25. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, agreed this afternoon that at 6:30 o'clock this evening, after his day-long talk with Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler, he would receive representatives of the foreign press at the British Embassy to impart to them such information as might be fitting.
What is, in point of time, the first of the Jalna novels has been written by Mazo de la Roche and will be published by Little, Brown on May 15. Its title is "Young Renny (Jalna -- 1906)."

The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday a net profit of $14,503,247 for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 29, 1934. This was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $6.28 a share on the common stock. It compared with a net profit of $11,119,044, or $4.76 a share, in 1933.

President ROOSEVELT'S message urging the enactment of pure food and drug legislation did not specifically endorse any one of the measures introduced at this session of Congress. It was, however, a strong statement in favor of the principle of truth in advertising and its practical effect may well be to better the chances of the Copeland bill, which was favorably reported by the Senate Commerce Committee last Friday.

BOSTON, March 25. -- On the eve of their second game with Toronto in the first place play-off series for the National Hockey League championship the Boston Bruins lost Babe Siebert, star left defense man.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board today approved an amendment to the Fur-Dressing and Fur-Dyeing Code which removes the requirement that members of the fancy dressing and rabbit dressing divisions of the industry operate only from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M., with one hour off for luncheon, on the first five business days of the week.

The incomes of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company and its subsidiary, the Williams Steamship Corporation, as for this year are higher than those in the corresponding period of 1934, although deficits are still indicated by the consolidated report published yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- Mrs. George Horace Lorimer is chairman of the anniversary committee of the Charlotte Cushman Club, which will hold its twenty-seventh anniversary reunion reception on Friday afternoon in the club rooms at the Bellevue-Stratford.
Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, assured the United Parents Associations yesterday that its groups may meet in any school buildings without interference with their programs.

An exhibition of "cabinet pictures" -- all of them small and some of them tiny -- was placed on view at Knoedler's yesterday. This exhibition, which contains work by artists of six centuries, was assembled from various collections by Mrs. A. Stewart Walker and is being held for the benefit of the Country Home for Convalescent Babies at Sea Cliff, L.I.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The number of work relief jobs for white-collar workers will be doubled in New York City, from 30,000 to about 60,000, under the government's new program, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, told a delegation from New York representing six organizations of needy craftsmen that visited him at FRA headquarters today.

All last Summer my newspaper was full of accounts of the great drought. Now it is full of accounts of great floods and dust storms. I do not believe these things are any more necessary in this country than the kind of roads and highways we were accustomed to, up to, say, fifteen years ago.

The old Harriman mansion at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, one of the few remaining fashionable private homes of its era, has been sold to settle the estate of Mrs. Mary W. Harriman.

Evidence against more lawyers developed in the current investigation into the policy, vice and bail and bond rackets will be transmitted to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for possible disciplinary action, District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The expenditure of $1,000,000 in relief funds to check wind erosion and the devastating dust storms in Kansas and adjoining States was assured today by Colonel Lawrence Westbrook, Assistant Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, after a plan for Federal and State cooperation was presented to him by Governor Landon of Kansas.

A syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., the Lee Higginson Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., Field Glore Co. and the First Boston Corporation will offer on Thursday $16,000,000 Chicago Union Station Company first mortgage, Series D. 4 per cent bonds of 1963.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The men's clothing industry has made more money under its NRA code than it did previously and is in a generally improved condition, Francis M. Curlee, general counsel of the association, told the Senate Finance Committee today.

FORT LEE, N.J., March 25. -- Benjamin Proctor 3d, 27 years old, of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was killed this morning on State Highway 4 here when he was hurled from his automobile after it had been in collision with a car going in the same direction.

The sportsmen of Dover, N.J., seem to have found the answer to the problem of obtaining good public fishing and hunting. Their formula consists of two essentials -- a lively organization and a State Fish and Game Commission that provides practical cooperation.

THE TIMES published an article headed "Power Bill Joker Fought by Mayor." The joker, it seems, is a requirement in a pending State bill for a referendum before public funds are spent for power plants. The matter was so urgent the Mayor flew to Washington and was there assured that it was not the intention of the PWA that any impediments be placed in the way of spending billions for work relief.

Two hundred Staten Island school boys 14 to 16 years old, stayed away from their classes yesterday and marched defiantly in front of the school building in the second school strike in the city within a week.
MOSCOW, March 25. -- A call for increased vigilance against "enemies acting under the direction of foreign secret service departments" was published in the authoritative newspaper Pravda today.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Western Union and Postal Telegraph officials who, in the past, have frequently been at odds on communications policies in which the interests of the two companies were concerned, joined hands today to accuse the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of a monopoly threatening the existence of the telegraph systems.

Six additional members of the New York Stock Exchange have been suggested for places on the governing committee, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange's nominating committee. The nominating group will render its report on April 8.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders on pending legislation and left tonight for a fishing trip off Florida.

DENVER, March 25. -- Moldy and dust-covered remnants of the famous Tabor fortune were uncovered here today when a dozen old trunks which Mrs. Elizabeth Tabor stored for more than twenty-five years were opened by Edgar C. McMechen, administrator.

The New York County organization of the American Legion decided last night to ask for a Congressional investigation into the disciplinary proceedings brought in Federal court against Aaron Sapiro, the lawyer, who is a member of S. Rankin Drew Post, No. 340.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 (AP). -- About 250 persons were engaged in a 1924 retrospective valuation of the McClintic-Marshall Corporation which increased the concern's tangible assets as of March l, 1913, by $820,000 to $3,000,000, or so, it was testified today in the Andrew W. Mellon income tax case.
Five thousand members of the State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association lined up in defense of feminine curves yesterday as they opened their seventh annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 25 (AP). -- Bill Kline of Battle Creek, Mich., piled up a 702 total in the American Bowling Congress tonight, displacing Alex Kowalski, Chicago star. Kline registered games of 226, 211 and 265 in passing Kowalski, who had taken the lead this afternoon with 697.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25. -- The Prince of Wales colt from Comixa named Prince Comixa scored his second victory in a row at Tropical Park today. It was a program in which all races included the claiming clause, but they were contested over a fast track, and the spectators did not seem to mind the quality of the competition.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- The Middle Western tour of Mrs. Anna Hauptmann in the interest of the defense fund for her husband, Bruno, appeared today to have reached the end. City officials were prepared to halt her mass meetings if legal means could be found while Mrs. Hauptmann expressed a desire to return to Brooklyn and her infant son.

A picture of the government's better housing campaign as the spearhead of recovery, ith $312,000,000 in new business generated and 1,000,000 jobs pledged through its operation, was presented to 500 real estate leaders here yesterday by Ward M. Canaday, assistant to the Federal Housing Administration.

PARIS, March 25. -- By a vote of 453 to 125 the Chamber of Deputies this morning approved the laying down this year of one 35,000-ton battleship and two 1,700-ton destroyers and the construction after Jan. 1, 1937, of a second battleship of 35,000 tons.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- With an increase in bookings, billings and unfilled orders at the end of the year, the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported today a loss of $1,039,406 on operations in 1934. It had a loss of $2,893,905 in 1933.

A yellowed manuscript in German, for which a Yonkers second-hand dealer paid 50 cents, was announced yesterday as a hitherto unknown memento of Ludwig van Beethoven, the composer, and as such worth many times its purchase price in the market maintained by collectors.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange became wider and more irregular yesterday than on Monday, but final quotations were only 1 to 5 points lower on the day.

Barring a moderately active market in commercial paper, at prevailing discounts, there was little else of interest in other sections of the credit market. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances were dull, and quotations unchanged.

Among the exhibits which attracted a large share of interest yesterday in the Greater New York Housing, Home and Building Modernization Exposition, now in progress at the Port Authority Building, were those having to do with city planning and street improvements.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- Urging that the country be placed in "a reasonable defensive posture" as a means of "preserving peace," Secretary Dern asserted in an address here tonight that it would be "suicidal" to depend solely upon government-owned plants for military supplies in the event of war.
ALBANY, March 26. -- With Governor Lehman in full control, the Senate early tonight passed the Dunnigan-Streit bill reapportioning Senate and Assembly seats.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 26. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, disappointed in his latest speed quest, was on his way to the nation's capital tonight to receive America's token of esteem for his fifth successful assault upon the world land speed mark on the ocean beach here.
BERLIN, March 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of March 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 26. -- The trial began here today of the Russian Major General, Tolvo Antikainen, who recently was arrested on suspicion of Communist espionage. The State prosecutor charged him with a murder in 1922 during the fighting in Eastern Karelia between the Soviet Army and the Finnish volunteer corps.

PITTSBURGH, March 26 (AP). -- Winding up details of the valuation phase of the McClintic-Marshall Corporation in Andrew W. Mellon's $3,089,000 income tax hearing, Frank J. Hogan, chief Mellon counsel, called to the stand today a veteran steel man and competitor of McClintic-Marshall, Frank B. Thompson.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Chicago's Black Hawks, defending Stanley Cup champions, fell tonight before the Montreal Maroons, l to 0, in a bruising overtime battle before 17,681 spectators, largest hockey crowd of the season.

Counsel for Insull investors obtained further admissions in the Federal court here yesterday that at least the Guaranty Company knew about the $60,000,000 issue of debentures of the Insull Utility Investments Corporation, which the holders complain the Guaranty Trust and five other New York lending institutions knowingly disregarded.
Colonel William J. Wilgus's letter of resignation, which was addressed to Commissioner Hodson as chairman of the Emergency Relief Bureau, follows:

The Board of Estimate is expected to act today at a special meeting on the April appropriations for unemployment relief. The appropriations for March totaled $20,128,820 and those for April are expected to be about the same, although a movement is under way in the Aldermanic committee investigating relief to have the sum cut considerably.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, March 26. -- Accused of directing a plot to seize the former German town of Memel and return it to the Reich, four Nazi leaders, Emil Boll, Walter Preiss, Heinrich Wannagat and Emil Lepa, were sentenced by a military court today to die before a firing squad.
Does any one want a ready-made family of four healthy children? That question is being asked by the office of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A heavy blow to inflationist sentiment in Congress was dealt in the House today when the administration won a victory that sent President Roosevelt's $4,880,000,000 works relief resolution to conference with the Senate under circumstances indicating that the Thomas silver rider would be deleted.

Harry H. Weinberger, former banker of Passaic, N.J., offered a job and an automobile to John B. Hammond, former Deputy Commissioner of Banking of New Jersey, who in 1928 investigated the affairs of the Hobart Service Trust Company, Mr. Hammond testified yesterday at Weinberger's trial in Federal Court for mail fraud.

THE Giants were in last place and John J. McGraw called Bill Terry into the little private office just off the room in which the players dress in the Polo Grounds clubhouse. For years the players had been going in to see -- and hear -- John J. McGraw in that little private office. Often he had talked at length -- and fiercely. But this conversation was low and brief. Would Bill take the club?

More than 1,000 persons attended the graduation exercises of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 5:45 P.M. yesterday. Fourteen men were graduated from the Teacher's Institute and thirty-seven from the theological seminary.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Spokesmen for company unions in a large number of steel plants told the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today that passage of the Wagner Trade Disputes Bill would sound the death knell of the employe representation plan, with which, they asserted, many tens of thousands of employes were perfectly satisfied as a method of collective bargaining.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- How to aid women in finding work to which they are suited will be considered, along with the range of women's activities in public affairs, at a three-day conference beginning Thursday at the Hotel Astor in New York City.

QUEBEC, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Legislation seeking to remedy price-cutting in the newsprint industry will be introduced shortly in the Quebec Legislative Assembly, Honore Mercier, Quebec Minister of Lands and Forests, announced tonight in the Assembly in speaking on estimates for his department.

BUFFALO, March 26. -- A plan and agreement for reorganization of the Terminals and Transportation Corporation of America and the Minnesota-Atlantic Transit Company, a subsidiary, has been filed in Federal court here. The reorganization reports, presented jointly by the bondholders' committee, the debenture holders' committee and the reorganization managers, recommends continuation of the business of the two companies under a new capital arrangement.

Sergel Soudeikine, Albert Johnson and Boris Aronson, well-known scenic designers, have been engaged as art directors for the Radio City Music Hall, it was announced last night by W.G. Van Schmus, the theatre's managing director.

BELGRADE, March 26. -- The conferences of Nicolas Titulescu, the, Rumanian Foreign Minister, with Premier Bogolyub Yeftitch continued all day today. At noon he was received by Queen Mother Marie, after which he lunched with Prince Paul, the Regent, M. Yeftitch also being a guest.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Foreign trade in February again showed an increase over 1934, but a sharp drop in both exports and imports from the January totals narrowed the gap. February exports amounted to $163,006,000, compared with $162,729,000 in February, 1934, the Commerce Department announced today, but compared unfavorably with a total of $176,223,000 in January.

Although it is still too early to make any predictions regarding the prospect of favorable stream conditions for the opening of the New York trout season on April 6, indications at present provide a basis for optimism.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the New York Conference for Unemployment Insurance Legislation, defended yesterday the Byrne-Kill-grew bill, now pending before the State Senate, which provides that the cost of unemployment aid shall be borne not only by the worker but in part by industry.

Ninety per cent of the justices of the Municipal Court are "honest, conscientious and hard working" and most of the attorneys appearing before the court speak shockingly bad English, Municipal Court Justice Charles Garside declared last night.

F. SCOTT FITZGERALD has been reproached all along for wasting a glamorous style, an unsurpassed artistry, and a feeling for romantic situations and qualities, on essentially futile material. Identified with the jazz age, which he did so much to popularize, he has paid the inevitable penalty for having been at one time the fashion. Just at present his reputation is in a sort of eclipse.

No one can accuse the Port Authority of lack of enterprise. Balked in its attempt to improve rail facilities in the metropolitan area, and undismayed by the depression -- in fact, summoned to a renewed display of energy by the Federal spending program designed to halt the depression -- it has been building bridges, tunnels and terminals right and left.

Several witnesses testified before the grand jury yesterday on the bail bond angle of the current investigation into rackets. Among those who appeared were Magistrate William A. Farrell and Edward Cowing, deputy clerk of the Court of General Sessions, who explained technical points.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Applications for permanent registration on the New York and other Stock Exchanges have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Texas Corporation and eight other companies.

J.M. Wallace, vice chairman of the Chase National Bank, is among the passengers arriving today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others coming on the ship from Southampton and Cherbourg include:

Writing in The London Times, Sir ARTHUR STEEL-MAITLAND, former Minister of Labor, has appealed to the British Government to make immediate overtures to the United States for a provisional currency stabilization agreement for the pound and the dollar.

Otto Schlaaff and Robert Riotte gave a recital of music for two pianos at the Town Hall last night. The first half of their program comprised Bach-Bauer's Prelude and Fugue in C minor, Mozart-Saar's Menueto and Rondo and Saint-Saens's Variations on a theme of Beethoven.

Monroe County, N.Y., of which Rochester is the county seat, yesterday awarded a new issue of $1,500,000 of bonds to a syndicate comprising the Chase National Bank, L.F. Rothschild Co., and Kelley, Richardson Co., Inc. The bonds, consisting of $800,000 of general bonds, Series C, due on March 1, 1937 to 1945, and $700,000 of tax revenue bonds, due on March 1, 1936 to 1940, fetched a price of 100.119.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Professor Arthur H. Compton, Nobel prize winner in physics and noted for his experiments with cosmic rays, announced plans today for the most extensive project in this field yet undertaken.

Frank Lloyd Wright, one of the originators of the "modern" movement in architecture, has planned a new type of community, a model of which is to be shown to New Yorkers for the first time next month at the Industrial Arts Exposition in Rockefeller Center under the auspices of the National Alliance of Art and Industry.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The $907,000,000 Postoffice-Treasury Appropriation Bill was passed by the Senate today, with an authorization of payment of 1,200 Treasury employes who had gone payless since Dec. 1. Non-competitive civil service test for 300 of these who would otherwise face dismissal May 15 was provided in the amended bill, which now goes back to the House for approval of these and other changes.

As civic groups and property owners proceeded yesterday with plans for extending the impending water tax strike throughout Brooklyn and Queens and into Staten Island, their method of protesting increased levies was characterized as "just a gesture" by John E. Eastmond, Deputy Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity in charge of the Brooklyn office.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, arrived here yesterday morning by plane from Washington to fill engagements that will extend over several days. She went to her New York home at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

A drive for a cleaner city has been begun by the Sanitation Department, Thomas W. Hammond, Commissioner, announced yesterday. The Times Square and theatrical districts were chosen as the first point of attack.

After acquiring a prodigious reputation in special performances during the Winter, "Waiting For Lefty" has settled down to steady work at the Longacre, where it was played last evening. This is the one-act play about the taxi strike which has been written by Clifford Odets, author of "Awake and Sing" and poet laureate of the Group Theatre.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Approval of a plan to enforce price-fixing in interstate commerce in milk by exercising the licensing powers of the AAA was indicated by Secretary Wallace today, following an all-day conference between AAA officials and representatives of seven Northeastern States, headed by Peter G. Ten Eyck, New York Commissioner of Agriculture.

After a conference yesterday with officials of the Department of Sanitation, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced that a plan had been worked out for preventing any further drift of garbage in the Long Island Sound to the shores of Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Senate, after three and a half hours of talk, wound up debate today on the bill to repeal publicity on income tax returns. The vote will be taken tomorrow and Chairman Harrison of the Finance Committee, who is handling the measure, predicted that it would win.

The blue standard of Crockford's, with its Latin motto, "Fair Play and Good Fortune," fluttered mournfully at half-staff yesterday afternoon from the second-floor window of the card club at 14 East Sixty-second Street. It signified that within, Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson were getting considerably the worst of it in their 150-rubber match against Mr. and Mrs. P. Hal Sims.

ALBANY, March 26. -- New York courts, burdened with heavy calendars, received authority under new laws today to employ "blood grouping tests" as a scientific way of determining when men are innocent of certain crimes and civil offenses charged against them.
Four Interclub Class boats and their skippers and crews left for Bermuda yesterday aboard the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda.

Controller Frank J. Taylor urged the Board of Aldermen yesterday to carry out last year's pledge that they would enact new licensing measures yielding $5,000,000 in revenue to balance the 1935 budget.

The strike by about one-third of the students at the Staten Island Continuation and Vocational School, which began Monday, was called off yesterday afternoon after Borough President Joseph H. Palma had promised his support in bringing about the opening of the new continuation school at St. Mark's Place and Wall Street, St. George, S.I., as early as possible.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Many Democrats accept the story that wealthy Republicans have been contributing to help form Huey P. Long's "Share-the-Wealth" clubs throughout the country, in the belief that the stronger the Louisiana Senator in 1936, the weaker the Democratic President and presumptive party candidate for re-election.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A code for the zinc industry was approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board, effective on April 8.

A disturbance that assumed such proportions that police sent in a riot call shortly before 9 o'clock marked continuance of picketing of the Minsky burlesque theatre at 209 West Forty-second Street last night.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 26. -- Before President Roosevelt sailed on the yacht Nourmahal today for a fishing expedition he held a final conference with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, on the program to be based on the S4,880,000,000 Work Relief Bill now awaiting final action in Congress.

PARIS, March 26 (AP). -- The soft pedal has been applied, it was reported today, to talk of a Soviet spy ring at the trial of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Switz and nineteen other suspects, after a hint from the Foreign Office.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 26. -- Steel production last week was estimated here at 47 per cent of capacity, a decrease of one point from the week before. Declines in the preceding five weeks were attributed to consumers ceasing to accumulate stocks, but rather were liquidating on account of an adverse turn in general business sentiment.

Gains of 1 1/4 cents a pound and more in rubber futures dominated trading in the commodities markets yesterday. Prices elsewhere were somewhat irregular in trend, with gains and losses about evenly divided. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, tin and rubber advanced, while rye and cotton declined. All refiners yesterday advanced sugar prices to 4.70 cents a pound, up 20 points, to the highest level since Oct. 1, 1934.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today called Joseph B. Eastman, Transportation Coordinator, to testify tomorrow on the Wheeler proposal for an investigation of railroad financing, after hearing Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Corporation, say such an inquiry "might serve a good purpose."

ALBANY, March 26. -- The assessed valuation of property of the City of New York located in the town of Olive, Ulster County, should be $1,500,000 instead of $5,000,000, according to an order signed today by Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck.

A special train carrying 300 persons from Reading, Pa., Paul Althouse's native town, will make the trip to New York on Saturday for the tenor's appearance as Walther in Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" in the closing opera of the regular season.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, in her daily practice, which she has instituted after an enforced two-year absence from the tennis courts, indicated today that she might be seen in tournament play this year.

The concert conducted by Eugene Ormandy, guest leader of the Philadelphia Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall, began with a performance of the unfamiliar Chorale and Fugue in D minor of Arnold Zemachson. It is a composition clearly constructed, conservatively harmonized and of conventional hue.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The Boerse was quiet today, no significant changes in quotations occurring. The public was absent. Uncertainty over the international situation seems to have frozen the market into stagnation. Heavy industrials were inactive but firm, while pot- ashes were quiet, although Salzdetfurth gained 1 1/2 points.

LONDON, March 26. -- Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today that an official inquiry "on the broadest possible lines" would be begun immediately into the loss of a half-dozen or more British freighters in Atlantic gales of the past Winter.
The Associated Press, in sending out a news report of Father Cox's lecture, added the following comment:

Commission house brokers are wondering what, if anything, a new Stock Exchange administration could do to bring about a revival in business. All the factions now concerned in the fight for the presidency -- and control -- are interested primarily in luring the public back into the market.

LONDON, March 26. -- John Buchan, M.P., novelist and historian, who recently went to New York to receive a degree from Columbia University, is expected to be the new Governor General of Canada, succeeding the Earl of Bessborough.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Rejection of the child labor amendment by the Connecticut House of Representatives today caused its friends to concede that it would take another two years of fighting to bring about its adoption and its foes to call it definitely dead.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Establishment of a non-profit organization to conduct scientific and social research and eliminate, as far as possible, the time-lag between perfection of scientific ideas and their introduction to the general life of the country was announced today by a group of Washington scientists and laymen.
ALBANY, March 26. -- By a vote of 105 to 33 the Assembly passed the bills sponsored by Assemblyman Doris I. Byrne today, making jury service for women mandatory.

One of the most interesting exhibitions it has yet held opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum and will continue until April 29. This is an exhibition devoted to American genre: "The Social Scene in Paintings and Prints." The range covers more than a century and a quarter -- from 1800 to the present -- and the material comes from a large number of American museum, gallery and private collections.

A list of seventy-six distinguished Americans who will be eligible for the eighth quinquennial election to the Hall of Fame on the campus of New York University was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, director of the Hall.

TORONTO, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- The International Nickel Company's profit of $18,487,478 in 1934, which came within striking distance of the record results in 1929, was achieved mainly through the company's success in developing new uses for nickel and the efficiencies realized in recent years in mines and plants, Robert C. Stanley, president, said in his address at the annual meeting of shareholders here today.

Spending a beautiful Sunday seeing New York from the buses on First Avenue, Seventy-ninth Street and Madison Avenue makes one wonder whether all the changes in New York's mode of transit are for the best. There is no uniformity of operating practice. The First Avenue buses stop at alternate streets on the far corner.
Markets continued yesterday to take notice of the many uncertainties that may influence values, present and future.

Among all administrators of the New Deal in Washington, Mr. JONES of RFC occupies the unique position of taking in as much as he pays out. His latest report shows receipts last month of $68,000,000, compared with disbursements of $65,000,000. To operate in black ink rather than in red is no novelty for RFC.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The administration is resisting pressure from many sources, brought in view of the European situation, to redefine this country's neutrality policy.

Mrs. James Roosevelt unveiled a portrait which she called a "wonderful likeness" of her son, the President, yesterday afternoon at the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society, 124 East Fifty-eighth Street.

MOSCOW, March 26. -- A social event of an unusual nature -- a dinner by foreign newspaper correspondents in honor of a censor -- took place here tonight in the gaudy pre-war magnificence of the Hotel Metropole.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Loss of $133,000,000 by common stockholders in his North American Company alone and further shrinkage in all utility common stocks were predicted to the House Interstate Commerce Committee today by President James F. Fogarty if pending legislation to abolish utility holding companies is enacted.
KAUNAS, Lithuania, March 26. -- Four death sentences were passed this morning by the court that has been trying 126 Nazis accused of plotting to seize Memel for Germany.

BOSTON, Mass., March 26. -- The NRA code affecting yachtsmen does not prevent them from painting and repairing their own boats, John R. Whitney of the North Atlantic division of the Code Authority and treasurer of the George Lawley Sons Corporation, yacht builders, said today.

"Private Worlds," produced by Walter Wanger from the novel by Phyllis Bottome, and featuring Claudette Colbert, Charles Boyer, Joel McCrea, Joan Bennett and Helen Vinson, opens this morning at the Paramount.

BRUSSELS, March 26 (AP). -- Probable devaluation of the Belgian currency and possible recognition of Soviet Russia and the Japanese-advised State of Manchukuo were forecast in informed circles tonight while the new Cabinet was taking the oath of office before King Leopold.

DUBLIN, March 26. -- In the battle between the Irish Sweepstakes promoters and the British, the Irish are losing ground. This was admitted by Viscount Powerscourt at the opening draw for the Grand National sweep in the gayly decorated Plaza Hall in Dublin today.

Ruth Reynolds, mezzo-soprano, sang for the first time here at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, presenting an unhackneyed program in French, English and Italian, accompanied by John Doane. The singer proved a young artist of sympathetic voice and dignified presence, warming into communicative humor and clear diction in Parry's "Child and the Twilight," while an effective contrast was Elgar's "Where Corals Lie," of delicate melodic line.

George L. Bagby gave a reception with music last night at the Ambassador. The artist was Mme. Lotte Lehmann of the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Bagby received in the Italian Garden. Later supper was served in the ballroom of the hotel where dancing followed the musical program.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice of Montclair gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Orson D. Munn, Mr. and Mrs. Byron C. Foy, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Carney, Mrs. Vanderbilt Smith, Miss Beth Leary, Miss Eleanor Bronaugh, Gordon Sarre, John Claiborne, Alec Pagel and Jackson Reade.

MIAMI, Fla., March 26. -- Frederick M. Alger Jr., who won the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap with Azucar last month, scored a triple at Tropical Park today. Azucar was acquired from Joseph E. Widener and today's winners -- Dark Vive, Chicle Ship and Ned's Affinity -- also were purchased recently by the young Detroiter, whose horses carry the maize and blue of the University of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Automobile production, continuing to increase in early March, promises for the first quarter of the year to be the largest for any similar period since 1929, the Federal Reserve Board said today in a business review.

LONDON, March 26. -- On top of the news from Berlin of the futility of the negotiations between Chancellor Hitler and Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, London received authentic information tonight that Germany had already made advances toward Abyssinia by offering to send to that country a mission of military and air force experts.

The State Banking Act, under which the State mortgage moratorium was authorized in 1933, was held yesterday to be valid by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The effect was to reverse the ruling of a lower court last July holding the act to be unconstitutional in so far as it affected the payment of some $200,000,000 of guaranteed mortgage certificates.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 26. -- For the sake of an automobile joy ride last night Otto Blenk, 37 years old, a Sing Sing convict and former policeman attached to the Simpson Street station in the Bronx, risked spending twenty additional years in prison.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,600,000 barrels, compared with 2,608,400 in the preceding week, a drop of 8,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 26,300 barrels in the daily output of California and a gain of 10,800 in Texas were the most important changes.

Colonel William J. Wilgus, who as director of the works division administers the vast work relief machinery of the city with 120,000 employes and a monthly budget of $10,000,000, announced yesterday that he was determined to quit his post as soon as the Aldermanic committee had completed its relief inquiry.

MONTREAL, March 26. -- Reserved seats for tonight's game between the Rangers and Canadiens were sold out several days ago and a line started forming outside the Forum box-office at 3 o'clock this afternoon for the general admission tickets, which went on sale at 6 P.M.

BOSTON, March 26. -- After being held back for almost 144 minutes by the Boston Bruins, five Toronto Maple Leaf forwards swarmed in against their short-handed foes and big Charlie Conacher lashed a 30- foot drive into the cage to deadlock the National Hockey League first-place play-off series before a capacity crowd of 17,200 tonight at the Boston Garden.

EDMONTON, Alberta, March 26. -My boys and I may have been frostbitten and bruised, out on our feet and groggy, snow-blinded at times and starved, but the reindeer herd at last has just been delivered and that's the main thing, mister.

NEWARK, N.J., March 26. -- Announcing he was "seriously considering" removing the trustees of The Newark Morning Ledger Company and appointing new trustees, Vice Chancellor M.L. Berry reserved decision today on whether he would continue the injunction against activities in the strike of Newark Ledger editorial employees, modify it, or vacate the restraint on the ground the trustees did not keep their "hands clean" in the case.

SENNETERRE, Quebec, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Stanley Sistoe was born in Posen, then under German rule but now part of Poland, in 1891. He came to North America in 1907 and lived for a short time in Chicago, where he attended night school.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- A compilation from its principal lending agencies disclosed today that the government lent $2,907,000,000 more in 1934 than in 1933.

MIAMI, Fla., March 26. -- Summonses in three suits for $1,000,000 each by Mrs. Gladys T. Orr of Piqua, Ohio, involving charges of alienation of affections of her husband, Morrison Orr, were announced here today, naming two Winter residents of Miami Beach as defendants.

Tammany will not go along with the Democratic legislative reapportionment bill, the passage of which is desired by both President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman. The measure seemingly is destined to be defeated for the second time in the Assembly when it reaches that body.

A pick handle, a garden hose and a meat cleaver, three outward manifestations of Mrs. Agnes Sinatelli's indignation, according to the police, were responsible for her appearance in Flushing (Queens) court yesterday to answer a disorderly conduct charge.

For the first time in recent years New York City moved yesterday to reduce its outstanding long-term indebtedness. Controller Frank J. Taylor conferred with a group of bankers on plans to call and partly refinance an issue of $50,000,000 4 1/4 per cent bonds that are not due until 1960.

TORONTO, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- David A. Croll, Ontario Minister of Public Welfare, said today that the government has under consideration extensive plans looking toward the care of the entire family of Mr. and. Mrs. Oliva Dionne as well as their quintuplet daughters.
Another capacity gathering is assured at Madison Square Garden tonight for the staging of the second benefit figure skating carnival of the season.

LONDON, March 26. -- G. Ward Price, who is regarded here as Lord Rothermere's representative in the Hitler camp, cables to The Daily Mail that "the flow of rejoinder, riposte and repartee was often vigorous" in today's talks in Berlin.

DUBLIN, March 26. -- With unexpected swiftness the de Valera government this morning took the offensive against the Irish Republican Army and the Socialist extremists known as the Republican Congress.

The most beautiful edifice in town nowadays is the Central Park Arsenal with its face washed. The re-discovered brick surface is proof at all hours that the incumbent Park Commissioner can scrape as well as scrap.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- C.B. Nolte, for six years president of R.W. Hunt Co., was elected today president of the Crane Company, a leading Chicago manufacturing enterprise, to succeed John W. Berryman, who was elected chairman of the board of directors.

SYRACUSE, March 26 (AP). -- New York, Pennsylvania and Ohio bawlers, competing in the American Bowling Congress tournament today, were unable to create any upsets among the topnotchers in the national event. There were no changes in the standings.

LONDON, March 26. -- Sir Edward Crowe, Controller General of the Department of Overseas Trade, in addressing the American Chamber of Commerce today made a strong plea for increased Anglo-American trade for the benefit of the whole world.

Another brilliant International Ice Skating Carnival, the second within a fortnight, will be held tonight at Madison Square Garden. Tonight's event, which benefits the New York Graduate Hospital, is a repeat performance of the notable carnival held on March 13, and is expected to be equally as successful, financially and socially as its predecessor.

The New York Security Dealers Association and the Produce Exchange are investigating a situation precipitated in respect to dealings in the Alleghany Corporation's new $2.50 prior preferred stock as a result of the corporation's having filed a plea for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Law last Autumn, it developed yesterday.

Taking issue with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit radio priest, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, in an address yesterday before the League for Political Education in Town Hall, denied that Jewish banking firms were conspicuous in international finance.

Miss Rosalie Spang, last member of a prominent iron and steel family, left a net estate of $1,602,973 when she died in Nice on April 13, 1932, it was disclosed in a transfer-tax appraisal filed here yesterday. All but a few thousand dollars of the estate goes eventually to charity.

MONTREAL, March 26. -- By the slender margin of a single goal the New York Rangers eliminated the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League third-place play-off race for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.

TOKYO, March 26. -- The government released tonight its reply to the British representations made on Nov. 24 regarding the Manchukuoan oil monopoly, which goes into force next Monday. It makes the question turn on recognition of Manchukuo.

In announcing that the Anglo-German conversations at Berlin were concluded last night, neither side pretended the slightest advance had been made. The joint communique merely recorded the fact that the discussions had been conducted in "the frankest and friendliest manner."
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Roosevelt, in a letter made public in his absence, ordered a drive for enforcement of NRA codes.

The Dresden Holy Cross Choir, composed of sixty-six boys from 10 to 19 years of age, arrived yesterday from Germany on the Stuttgart of the North German Lloyd for a four weeks' engagement in the United States, starting with the concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

The North American Light and Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net deficit of $707,484 for 1934 after full preferred dividend requirements of subsidiaries, comparing with a deficit of $1,028,648 for 1933.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

As a result of the conviction yesterday of four youths for the murder of Patrolman M.J. Killion in a hold-up in a luggage shop at 548 Fifth Avenue on Jan. 18 last, the number of prisoners in the Sing Sing death house awaiting execution for slaying New York patrolmen will be swelled shortly to six.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- The directors of the Norfolk Western Railway Company voted today to call for redemption on July 1 next a $35,000,000 issue of division first lien and general mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due on July 1, 1944. More than $34,000,000 of the issue is outstanding.

The law creating the New York City Charter Revision Commission, headed by THOMAS D. THACHER, authorized the Board of Estimate to "make available" to it the sum of $25,000, or so much thereof as might be necessary. Why that limit was imposed in the first place is something of a mystery, as it would seem to be the city's business rather than the State's.

In justice to the Associated Gas and Electric System and its officers and employes, I wish to protest against THE TIMES editorial "Exhibit B." I cannot help feeling that wholly ex parte statement, even from the counsel to a legislative committee, is not in itself a fair basis for an appraisal of the purposes and accomplishments of any industry or management.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 26. -- Gar Wood roared down Biscayne Bay for a mile today in Miss America X and came back with the forecast that he would smash his own world's water speed record of 124 miles an hour.

When the Theatre Guild's "Mary of Scotland" reaches Milwaukee on April 29, it will have Ian Keith in the role created and now being played by Philip Merivale. There hasn't been any trouble about it. Mr. Merivale merely stipulated in his contract with the Guild that he might spend the Summer at home in England if he chose to, and that is what he has decided to do.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Because of the crisis in the cotton textile industry which is regarded as threatening to impede national recovery, the NIRB today authorized some branches of the industry to reduce hours of machine operation by not more than 25 per cent, and to reduce by not more than 25 per cent the machines operating in these groups or divisions.

Public offering will be made today of the issue of $43,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 3 3/4 per cent bonds of Swift Co. of Illinois by Salomon Bros. Hutzler. The bonds, dated May 15, 1935, and due on May 15, 1950, will be priced at par and interest to date of delivery, which is expected to be June 15, to yield 3.75 per cent.

LONDON, March 26. -- Although the British Government will not know the full details of the Anglo-German talks until Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon returns tomorrow, enough bulletins have come through from Berlin to demonstrate that the negotiations with Chancellor Hitler were futile.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The verdict in the court-martial at Kaunas of 126 Memel Nazis has thrust the question of Germany's "bleeding borders" into the forefront of the European problems discussed but not settled between Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler and Sir John Simon and Anthony Eden of Great Britain.

Disapproval of the method in which relief is being administered must not be made a pretext for withholding payments of the city's 2 per cent sales tax, Controller Frank J. Taylor's advisory council warned yesterday.

LONDON, March 26. -- The stock markets were brighter and firmer today, sharp rises in silver and rubber and a further advance in the base metals causing a more confident feeling. Outstanding was a sharp recovery in gold mining stocks on the announcement that the output of Rand Mines, Ltd., in March would be calculated on the basis of 146s an ounce.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 26. -- Two veterans of the fairways, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia, former national champion, and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., fell by the wayside today in the opening round of the fifth annual Augusta women's invitation golf tournament.

James J. Braddock of New Jersey, who came booming out of obscurity with his surprising victory over Art Lasky, found himself in the front rank of the heavyweights yesterday when the State Athletic Commission designated him the No. 1 contender for Max Baer's title.

Harry A. Gordon, official referee, recommended yesterday the allowance of claims totaling $22,122 after nine former customers had charged fraud against salesmen for S.W. Straus Co., mortgage bond house in receivership. The hearing was in the office of the receiver, Louis F. Schultze, 9 East Forty-sixth Street.

MONTREAL, Que., March 26. -- The body of Stanley E. Siscoe, Montreal mining executive, who has been missing since last Tuesday when his plane was forced down in a snowstorm in the Northern Quebec mining district, was found today near Senneterre, Que., and brought here by plane.
A Lexington Avenue investment purchase, sale of an apartment house site in the Dyckman section and purchase of flats to be modernized were included in the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

The annual two-day conference of the advisory council of the Milbank Memorial Fund will be held today and tomorrow at the New York Academy of Medicine. More than a hundred leaders in public health, medicine, social work, economics and education will participate.

A gain in the number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with preceding week. The total was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
The New York State Board of Censors has refused permission for the showing here of the Mexican motion picture, "Chucho El Roto," unless certain scenes are deleted, it was learned yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 26. -- Chief of Police Phineas A. Seaman of the Village of Hempstead was indicted today by the Nassau County grand jury for issuing false and fraudulent statements to obtain relief funds for the widow of a former patrolman.

Two new publications of the Viking Press have been made book club selections. The Literary Guild has picked "Catherine: The Portrait of an Empress," by Gina Kaus, for June distribution, and the Scientific Book Club has selected "Tools for Tomorrow," by Jonathan Norton Leonard to send to its members in April.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 26. -- Two ball clubs, which many folks believe will be battling for baseball's highest prize next Fall, hooked up today for their fifteen-game exhibition jaunt that will take them right into New York. And the hook-up was one not at all satisfactory to Colonel Bill Terry.

The program for the "Operatic Surprise Party of 1935," to be held at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday evening for the benefit of the Metropolitan Maintenance Fund, was made public yesterday. The first half will be devoted to an instrumental and vocal concert and the second to the surprises.

GENEVA, March 26. -- Uchiro Yokoyama, Japan's permanent delegate to the League of Nations, gave THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight a statement on Japan's policy in regard to the League after her withdrawal notice expires tomorrow.
Mervin Ash Co. have opened an office at 6,253 Hollywood Boulevard, Hollywood, Calif.

The Fencers Club trio of Hugh Alessandroni, foils; Tracy Jaeckel, epee, and Norman Armitage, saber, won the national three-weapon team fencing championship and the Calnan Memorial Trophy by defeating the New York Athletic Club's defending titleholders, 2 1/2 to 1/2, in the final round of the competition on its home strips last night.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The Wilhelmstrasse swarmed with curious people yesterday and today, police keeping them moving as they collected before the Chancellery and the Foreign Office adjacent to the British Embassy. From Unter den Linden came the thud of machines driving iron piles day and night for the new subway, incidentally revealing that Berlin is a city built, perhaps symbolically, on shifting sand.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., March 26. -- Residents of this historic village, who for a number of years have objected to the stunt flying and other activities at the local airport which attracted throngs of spectators, have purchased the airport as a gesture of civic pride, it was learned today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 26. -- President Roosevelt sailed from here this afternoon for a cruise off the Florida coast which will be devoted principally to fishing and relaxation.
The machinery for the drastic re-organization of the American Power Boat Association was set in motion at the council meeting of the A.P.B.A. at the Hotel Lexington last night.
Despite increased wages and costs, the New York Central Railroad transferred a $755,764 rise in gross revenues in February to a $698,340 upturn in net operating income for the month.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Resolutions urging peace and disarmament and pledging continued support, were adopted today by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods at the closing sessions of their five-day convention here.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- Former President Hoover was reported today to have told a friend here that he had "no aspirations" to be the Republican candidate for President in 1936.
The text of the third instalment of the report of the Mayor's committee on unemployment relief follows:

TRENTON, March 26. -- Among bills passed by the Legislature before it recessed last Wednesday until April 1 and signed today by Governor Hoffman was a measure allowing Paterson to tax property of the Society for Useful Manufactures and impose a 5 per cent gross receipts tax on the society's hydroelectric power plant at Passaic Falls.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Asserting that there is a "bureaucratic finger" in every NRA pie, Francis M. Curlee, general counsel of the Industrial Recovery Association of Clothing Manufacturers, urged today before the Senate Finance Committee that the NRA be abolished.

The intercollegiate semi-final at Squadron A tomorrow night will affect another branch of the indoor polo championships, according to an announcement from the tournament committee yesterday. This announcement concerned the draw for the senior championship, on which the result of tomorrow's West Point-Pennsylvania Military College game will have a bearing.

One of the most sensational rallies ever staged by a New York City high school basketball team featured New Utrecht High's 30-to-26 victory over Abraham Lincoln High yesterday in the New Utrecht gymnasium in the opening game of the three-cornered play-off series for the Brooklyn division P.S.A.L. title.
Central Park bade fair yesterday to supplant Winsted, Conn., as a source of amazing nature tales. Captain R. Cheyne Stout, zoological consultant, swore, however, that they were all gospel truth.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26. -- The significance of the visit yesterday of Branch Rickey and Manager Frankie Frisch of the Cardinals was revealed today when Colonel Jacob Ruppert announced the purchase by the Yankees of Pitcher Pat Malone from the Red Birds in a cash transaction.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Reserving the right to make a final decision on whether New York City shall construct its own municipal power plant with PWA funds or accept rate reductions offered by the Consolidated Gas Company, Secretary Ickes made clear today that the PWA would not lend money for municipal power plants unless it was demonstrated that municipal rates would be lower than those offered by private companies.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- A broader demand for hogs developed here today following an early break of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in the early tradings. The loss was fully recovered before the close. The top price of $9.10 was steady with that of yesterday, while the day's average also was unchanged at $8.90.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Governor Lehman today signed the McCaffrey bill bringing all occupational diseases under the Workmen's Compensation Law. In a memorandum, he wrote:

Joseph and Benjamin Adamowicz, aviators who flew the Atlantic on a trip to Poland last year, and their brother, Bronislaw, were found guilty yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, of conspiracy to operate an unregistered still. They were remanded to jail for sentence tomorrow.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 26. -- Today's ball game was marked chiefly by the fact that thirty-three athletes derived a great deal of exercise from participation in it. Shag Shaughnessey's Montreal Royals handed Casey Stengel's Dodgers their second defeat of the citrus season, 9 to 8, and Leslie Munns's attempt to be the first Brooklyn hurler to go nine innings this year was not much of a success.

An all-professional field for the semi-finals of the world's open squash tennis championship was assured last night when Joseph J. Lordi of the New York Athletic Club, the last surviving amateur, was eliminated in the quarter-final round at the Midston House.
A General Sessions jury shortly before 6 o'clock last night found four youths guilty of first-degree murder in the hold-up shooting of a policeman on Jan. 18 in a luggage shop at 548 Fifth Avenue.

Holders of securities of R. Hoe Co., Inc., yesterday received a letter from the management urging them to accept the plan of reorganization that has been approved by the directors and found to be fair by the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Roosevelt has asked the Department of Justice "to give every assistance" in maintaining compliance with NRA codes and "in advising the District Attorneys throughout the country to take prompt and vigorous action to prevent or punish such violations."

CHICAGO, March 26. -- A broader demand for hogs developed here today following an early break of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in the early tradings. The loss was fully recovered before the close. The top price of $9.10 was steady with that of yesterday, while the day's average also was unchanged at $8.90.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Governor Lehman today signed the McCaffrey bill bringing all occupational diseases under the Workmen's Compensation Law. In a memorandum, he wrote:
PINEHURST, N.C., March 26 (AP). -- A field of 103 will begin play tomorrow in the thirty-third North and South open golf tournament, one of the oldest fixtures in the country.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Little interest was taken today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Most of the business was professional. No material pressure developed, however, and scattered buying held prices above yesterday's finish most of the day.

A meeting was held yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. William Carter Dickerman, 6 East Seventy-ninth Street, when several committees were appointed for the fete which will be given April 16 in Rockefeller Center to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Bryn Mawr College.

DUBLIN, March 26 (AP). -- American ticket-holders drew the lion's share of the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes prizes today as Great Britain's new anti-lottery legislation cut ticket sales across the Irish Sea.

Two policemen and a girl were injured yesterday afternoon when a horse snapped its traces and ran through five miles of the busiest thoroughfares in the Bronx. Behind his flying heels the animal left a trail of disorganized street traffic and frightened pedestrians.

The business and executive abilities of women of 40 years and older were defended yesterday by Mrs. Loire Brophy, counselor to the New York League of Business and Professional Women, in an address at a luncheon of the Advertising Women's Club of New York at the Hotel Iroquois, 49 West Forty-fourth Street.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Two bills which, according to opponents, would deal a serious blow at civil service were defeated today in the Assembly.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Secretary Ickes has been assured that he will be the fourth man in charge of the works relief program, it was reported on good authority today.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia clashed directly today on extension of the city's emergency tax powers.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Nearing the completion of its study of the administration's social security program, the House Ways and Means Committee today reduced from $100 to $50 a month the maximum old-age annuity that might be bought by the "average man" for maturity when he reached 65 years of age.
PARIS, March 26. -- The partial collapse of the belga at one time today to a depreciation of 17 per cent below parity gave the exchange market an extremely hectic day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 (AP). -- For the second year in succession, Commodore Hugh M. Matheson's 112-foot schooner Azara, of Miami has the distinction of having led the fleet across the finish line in the Miami-St. Petersburg yacht race.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 26. -- A 20-to-1 shot, the Springhill Stable's Battling Knight, surprised form followers by nosing out L.W. Kidd's Bill Andy in the six-furlong fourth race at the Bay Meadows track today. H. Rowe's Louie Dear was third, a half length further back.

The Democratic party must make an immediate bid for the support of organized labor, Rush D. Holt, West Virginia's 29-year-old Senator-elect, told members of the Intercollegiate Democratic League of New York last night. American politics had reached a turning point, he declared, and "under the leadership of a progressive Democratic party are going liberal."

William A. Brady, 71-year-old dean of active American stage producers, called on the theatre yesterday to follow the lead of the motion-picture industry in the direction of greater "competence and intelligence."

Hitler's proposed Austrian plebiscite would result in an overwhelming defeat for the Nazis, according to the Rev. Vincent Donovan, Dominican preacher and writer, who has just returned to New York after two years spent in Europe as the American member of an international commission of five which is revising the liturgy of the Dominican Order.

ALBANY, March 26. -- If Mayor La Guardia believes there is a "joker" in the Mandelbaum-Crawford bill affecting construction of a city power plant, the Governor will be content to scrap all offending phrases, he made clear tonight.

A special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn and another in Manhattan will be called to hear evidence on guaranteed mortgage companies collected by Walter Brower, Special Assistant United States Attorney, in an investigation that began last August.

Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, placed responsibility yesterday for the international tariff competition upon the United States. Addressing the twenty-ninth annual luncheon meeting of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce of the United States, he attacked this country's tariff policy as "an affront to the intelligence of nations."

Oswald Jacoby, captain of the Four Aces contract bridge team, who was ousted on Sunday from Crockford's Club, the Culbertson-controlled card club at which the Sims-Culbertson match is now under way, issued a statement yesterday declaring that the executive committee of the club had illegally invoked against him a by-law designed to be used against "crooks."

DENVER, March 26 (AP). -- The romance of Elizabeth "Baby Doe" Tabor, who died in poverty several weeks ago, and her millionaire husband, the late Senator H.A.W. Tabor, was retold today in the faded penmanship of love letters found in some of the iron-bound trunks opened yesterday in the course of settling the estate of the one-time beauty.
LONDON, March 27. -- Sir John Simon came back to London today to tell the British Cabinet in a special session just what Adolf Hitler wants to join any European security system.

LONDON, March 27. -- The Cabinet held an emergency meeting tonight, within an hour after the return of Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, from Berlin, to hear a preliminary report of his talks with Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler. The situation was regarded as so serious that Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald went to Buckingham Palace for a conference with King George.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27. -- The fleet sprinter Captain Argo, which now bears the colors of Miss Mary Hirsch, was an easy victor in the Zephyr Purse, today's feature at Tropical Park. Under the handling of Wayne Wright he scored by five lengths in 1:10 4-5 over a fast track.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 27 (AP). -- Charging the city of Knoxville with entering into "unlawful competition" with its business, the Tennessee Public Service Company, a utility, today obtained a temporary injunction halting work on the city's new municipal power distribution system.

Three hundred years ago JOHN WINTHROP Jr. was commissioned by Lords SAY and BROOK to found a colony in Connecticut and to act as its first Governor. No ordinary adventurer was this. He had made preliminary surveys of New England with an eye to the production of salt, iron, glass, potash, tar, black lead, saltpeter, medicines, copper and alum.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- With only one accident to every 654,610 miles flown, American-operated air, passenger lines established in the last year a new safety record on a mileage-per-accident basis.

The assessment of theatrical producers and managers throughout the country for the support of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority and the enforcement of the code's provisions was approved yesterday at the regular fortnightly meeting of that body held in the offices of the League of New York Theatres.
