Mrs. T. Coleman du Pont's sixty-seven-acre estate at Irvington-on-Hudson has been deeded to Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. The property is assessed at $261,000 and was valued at $454,000 in the appraisal of the estate of the late General du Pont.

PARIS, March 28. -- Because of the critical situation abroad and especially in Germany, the French Chamber of Deputies postponed its scheduled adjournment tonight. Amid uproar three ballots were taken after midnight in an effort to fix a date for reconvening, and each time the date set was defeated.

Professor Oliver M.W. Sprague of Harvard University declared last night that the passage of the Omnibus Banking Bill, now before the House Banking and Currency Committee, would result in the "complete subservience" of the Federal Reserve Board to "the political control of the White House."

The General Electric Company was reached yesterday as the last of six defendants now being sued in the Federal court on behalf of 23,000 investors, who put $60,000,000 into the debentures of the bankrupt Insull Utility Investments Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Regulations governing the manner in which accountants shall certify data filed under the Securities Act of 1933 on forms published prior to the new modified Form A-2 were made more flexible today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Japan's chair at the council table of the League of Nations, empty for two years, has been turned to the wall. It was on March 27, 1933, shortly after the adoption by the Assembly of a report severely critical of Japanese policy in Manchuria, that Foreign Minister UCHIDA formally filed notice of his country's decision to withdraw from the League.

Once more an improvement seems to have been made in the technique of swimming. STEVE FORSYTH, coach of RALPH FLANAGAN, the 17-year-old swimmer who has established twenty-five new records since the beginning of the year, announces that his protege has been using a new stroke. It is a variation of the crawl, and its basic difference is described as a two-kick glide between pull and recovery, while the roll of the body is minimized.
The fifth instalment of the report of the Mayor's Committee on Unemployment Relief follows:

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,458,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $65,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

BRUSSELS, March 28. -- Abandonment of the gold standard, a 27 per cent devaluation of the currency and the tying-up of Belgium's franc with the British pound were understood tonight from reliable quarters to be provided in a declaration the new Cabinet will make to Parliament.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the end of last week totaled 322,556,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. In comparison with the previous week, this represents a net increase of 380,000 barrels, comprising a decline of 5,000 barrels in domestic crude oil and an increase of 385,000 barrels in foreign crude stocks.

ROME, March 28. -- General Emilio Debono, former Minister of Colonies, who, soon after the beginning of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, was appointed High Commissioner for the Italian East African Colonies, today was placed in command of all troops in Eritrea and Somaliland.
ALBANY, March 28. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill designed to end alleged medical abuses, including fee splitting, under the Workmen's Compensation Law.

West Point's indoor polo team still stands undefeated. Last night at Squadron A Armory the cadets rode through one of the fastest intercollegiate matches any tournament has produced, to turn back Pennsylvania Military College, 9 1/2 to 4, and earn the right to meet Yale in the final round of the college championship.

MOSCOW, March 28. -- The texts of the speeches made here tonight by Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff and Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, at the reception given for the British Minister, follow:

The present volume of bank reserves would support an expansion of credit that would raise bank deposits to about $80,000,000,000, compared with actual estimated deposits of $44,000,000,000 at the end of 1934 and an average of about $55,000,000,000 in 1929, says the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its report for last year, published yesterday.

Commodity futures markets here yesterday were generally steady in featureless and dull trading. The confusion over the developments in foreign exchange and the uncertaiuty regarding the steps to be ken in Washington to counteract them were. factors in the trading.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Kurth gave dinner last night at the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Rambo, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Austin, Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer E. Sprague, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Brevoort Allen, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Koeckert, Mrs. Charles Sheffield, Mrs. Amadeo Bertini, Mrs. Otto Schaeffer and Paul L. Haid.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, March 28 (AP). -- Marooned, well ridden by Hilton (Rabbit) Dabson, won the Inaugural Handicap, $2,000 added opening day feature of the Spring race meeting at Arlington Downs, today. The event was run over the Waggoner course, 150 feet less than six furlongs.

The new film opening this morning at the Roxy is "I'll Love You Always," a Columbia production, with Nancy Carroll, George Murphy and Raymond Walburn. The Salici Puppets, Italian marionette troupe, will be featured on the stage.

With twelve colleges and universities sending approximately 150 candidates, the forty-second annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association will commence today in the converted salle d'armes in the main ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Wholesale commodity prices again declined slightly during the week ended March 23, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics standing at 78.8, as compared with 79.4 for the preceding week and 73.5 for the corresponding week of 1934.

HAVANA, March 28. -- Manuel Fonseca, a 45-year-old widower with two sons, gave no sign of emotion as a court-martial sentence of death on a charge of possessing explosives was read to him at Cabana Fortress this morning. He signed with a steady hand the warrant condemning him to die before a firing squad at 6 o'clock Saturday morning.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that the plan for reconstruction of Heckscher Playground in Central Park had been modified to provide for four soft-ball and two hard-ball baseball diamonds. Earlier in the day he went over the revised plan with representatives of the West Side Boys Association, Inc.

BERLIN, March 28. -- The Boerse was inactive today because of fears of the eventual results of the belga crisis. There were notable signs of weakness. Warned by the banks, the general public disappeared from the market and speculators were more than usually cautious.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 28. -- Perhaps it's just as well that the Dodgers have seen the last of the Tigers for this season, as they're getting almost bored with Tiger-taming. Today Stengel's performers made it four straight over the American League champions.

A better market for Manhattan real estate was indicated by transactions announced yesterday. Activity was widespread, extending from the midtown area to Yorkville and Harlem and over to the West Side as far north as Ninetieth Street, where one of the largest residences in that section was leased.
Dwelling deals in various towns made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.
TOKYO, March 28. -- Japan's reply to the British protest on Manchukuo's oil monopoly closes the door to further negotiations in the view of observers here.

LONDON, March 28. -- Germany's active purchases of wool and cotton are arousing much comment among dealers in Manchester. Both commodities are indispensible to the manufacture of uniforms and explosives.

After trading had started at the lowest prices of the session on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the removal of hedges rallied the market about $1 a bale. With more than two thirds of the available domestic supply of cotton, outside of mill stocks, estimated to be tied up in government loans, the increasingly tight spot position has rendered the near months extremely sensitive to limited buying or selling.

The right to political asylum in this country will be argued this morning in the United States District Court at a hearing on a writ of habeas corpus to prevent the return to Germany of an opponent of the Nazi movement.
BERLIN, March 28. -- Italian press statements to the effect that Germany is giving active military aid to Ethiopia were vigorously denied in a statement today by the semi-official German News Agency.

VOLIN, S.D., March 28. -- A bulging-eyed farm lad with happy tears streaming down his cheeks was Leroy Johnson, 12, as Uncle Sam's gift team of army horses arrived today to help his "dad" lift the homestead mortgage.

MOBILE, Ala., March 28. -- The Giants and Indians fought each other right down to the wire today but at the finish the Giants tripped over the wire and the Clevelanders won a stirring ten-inning battle, 5 to 4, to take the lead in this touring exhibition series, two games to one.

Discrimination against non-German ship lines by the German Government was charged yesterday at the opening of the Shipping Board investigation of the New York-Rotterdam-Antwerp freight conference pool. The inquiry is based on an appeal by the newly organized Red Star Line against the decision of the conference denying the line the rights of membership.
Socialized medicine was both praised and condemned at an open forum on "The Future of Medicine" at the New York Academy of Medicine last night.
The ratio of reserve at the iNTew York bank reached a new high point for the year to date. iNTone of the items in the statement of the twelve Reserve Banks touched a new high or low figure for 1935.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 28. -- Displaying superiority over their semi-final opponents in the fifth annual women's Augusta invitation golf tournament, Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., and Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N.Y., today advanced to the final.

JACKSON, Miss., March 28. -- Two bandits, one of whom was tentatively identified as the desperado Raymond Hamilton, brought a climax to a reign of terror tonight by holding up and disarming a posse of fifteen men twelve miles north of Prentiss as Mississippi National Guardsmen were mobilized to hunt them down.

The State of Alabama has completed plans for refunding of $17,200,000 of 5 per cent warrant refunding bonds by new obligations bearing not more than 4 per cent interest. Governor Bibb Graves and his bond refunding advisory board have decided to call for bids on the new issue of bonds to be opened on April 22 at noon.

BERLIN, March 28. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, announced officially in a Nuremberg address tonight that the State would now for the third time since Adolf Hitler came into power take over all authority in the Protestant Church in Germany and impose upon pastors and laity alike its decisions as to the fashion in which Protestantism shall be organized and governed.

BERLIN, March 28. -- As predicted, German youth will serve in the future for six months or a year in the State labor service before entering the ranks of universal service in the army. Rudolf Hierl, Reich Labor Service Administrator, announced this fact officially in an address in Leipzig tonight.

MIAMI, March 28. -- Reports of excellent fishing off Great Inagua Island lured President Roosevelt and his fishing companions aboard Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal far to the eastward of the mainland tonight.

MOSCOW, March 28. -- The picture of a nervous Europe, in the midst of which stands Germany, rearmed and ambitious, was gone over in detail today by Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, and Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in the first of the conversations for which Mr. Eden arrived here this morning.

Initial steps aimed at the solution of common problems of enforcement of trade practice provisions in apparel and textile industries selling directly to the retailer or wholesaler were taken yesterday at a meeting of about fifty-five Code Authority representatives at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway. Stephen B. Mambert, assistant deputy NRA administrator, presided.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- With a working balance of $1,465,063,128 in the general fund, revenue collections exceeding estimates, and expenditures temporarily below the level expected, the Treasury decided today to restrict its weekly sale of Treasury bills to $50,000,000 for the present, or about $25,000, 000 less than maturities which they are intended to meet.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 28. -- The signing of the four $1-a-year men on the Yankee roster was announced today and the Ruppert forces celebrated with a victory over the world champions, St. Louis Cardinals, 9 to 2.
ALBANY, March 28. -- Governor Lehman called upon the Legislature today to pave the way for a $55,000,000 bond issue to meet relief needs of the State for 1936.

The increased level of wholesale activity in women's apparel and accessory lines has been well maintained this week. The number of mail orders reaching the buying offices has been large and gains have been reported in the volume of telegraph requests for quick delivery.

BERLIN, March 28. -- Details of how Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler and Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, supposedly discovered during the visit of the British here that they had faced each other on the battlefield eighteen years ago were uncovered today.
The Manhattan announces "no operas" for this week-end, as a tribute of the Thirty-fourth Street house to the farewell of Gatti-Casazza.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The utilities war resounded on half a dozen capital fronts today with President Roosevelt himself joining in the fray. The tense feeling between the administration and private utility interests was shown by several developments.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- What Congress is supposed to believe, and what its majority is pretending to believe, is that when the President gets his 5 billions for work relief he will direct the expenditure as minutely as a great industrialist runs his plant and accessories.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Secretary Wallace was assailed by Senator George in the Senate today as "unfit for a place in the Cabinet," and was attacked later by Senator Metcalf in a prepared statement as demonstrating "a colossal ignorance of conditions in the cotton growing and textile industries."

The text of "Washington's Prayer for Our Country," attributed to George Washington on a plaque on the wall of St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, is not authentic and constitutes a "religious fraud" intended to "deceive the public," the Freethinkers of America, Inc., charged in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday.
Milton C. Weisman, receiver in equity for the Fox Theatres Corporation, submitted yesterday to Judge Martin T. Manton a plan for reorganizing Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, a subsidiary.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 28. -- The automobile of Miss Mary Valentine, daughter of Judge W.A. Valentine, was bombed late today while parked on a central city street, but she miraculously escaped injury and possible death due to a business call in a bank.

BERLIN, March 28. -- Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath is apprising the diplomatic representatives of those foreign governments regarded as directly concerned of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's conversations with Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon of Great Britain.

ALBANY, March 28. -- Democratic Senators rebelled today against the Byrne-Killgrew Unemployment Insurance Bill, voting overwhelmingly in a conference against acceptance of the bill in the form in which it passed the Assembly.

When Colonel JOHN BUCHAN was here a few months ago he remarked that while the British Isles were "fairly well integrated" the British Empire was still "in the making," that there could be no closer link between Britain and America than that they should be engaged together in the great and laborious task of establishing the balance of land and liberty which is the only meaning of civilization.

Increased sales were the feature of the three department stores which have released their reports covering operations in 1934. Only one of them failed to show an improvement in income over the previous year.

The State of New Jersey has completed plans for offering a new issue of $1,846,000 of institution construction bonds on April 18, bankers were advised here yesterday. The new bonds, which will mature serially in from two to thirty-five years, are to be sold at a rate of interest to be named by the bidders at not to exceed 3 1/4 per cent.

A further shrinkage of $76,000,000 in member-bank reserves, following one of $227,000,000 in the preceding week, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the statement of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. The new decline, like last week's larger reduction, reflected a transfer of funds from the account of member banks to the account of the Treasury on the books of the Federal Reserve Banks.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The State Senate overwhelmingly rejected today Mayor La Guardia's demand for specific legislation permitting New York City to build a power plant for city purposes with PWA money without a referendum.

What a number of persons must have been waiting for -- a play in which Adolf Hitler would be the leading character -- has been completed by Paul Trivers. "A Villa in the Mountain" is its title; the effect of Hitler's regime on the German people as a race is its theme, and Berlin and the Fuehrer's mountain home are its background.

The importance of substituting cooperation for the antagonism between the various groups in the field of health, such as organized medicine on the one hand and the endowed health foundations on the other, was urged last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by Albert G. Milbank, president of the Milbank Memorial Fund.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- The largest receipts of hogs here since Feb. 7 caused a decline today of 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight in the early trading, but all interests became buyers as the market declined and part of the loss was recovered. Advance of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in wholesale prices for fresh pork loins and estimates of small arrivals of hogs tomorrow were responsible for the better demand.

The number of hospitals in the United States has decreased by 103 under the number reported a year ago. The number of idle beds in 1934 reached a record total of some 218,000, while the patient days in all hospitals were almost 303,000,000, a gain of more than 7,000,000 over 1933.

Defying the action of the Columbia College Student Board, which earlier in the day had voted to suspend publication of the undergraduate newspaper. The Spectator, for an indefinite period, editors of the publication had 2,500 copies printed last night in readiness for distribution this morning.

PARIS, March 29. -- The so-called inflationary trend was accentuated on the Bourse today, with rentes falling heavily and equities rising equally sharply. Belgium's difficulties accounted partly for the movement. Tonight's press says that purchases of French equities have come more from Belgium, Holland and Switzerland than from France.

Because of the "gross inaccuracy" of his charges that $662,000 had been wasted in relief coal distribution last Winter, Robert A. Evans, a relief investigator, was discharged last Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

The Hack Bureau of the Police Department suspended yesterday the licenses of thirty-three taxicabs for failure to have proper workmen's compensation coverage. The cabs were said by officials of the State Department of Labor to be owned by the Lindy Transportation Company, Inc., 15 Drydock Street, but to have been registered in the drivers' own names.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Social workers and public welfare officials at a public hearing before Governor Lehman today vigorously opposed the Feld-Ostertag bill to create machinery for the administration of veterans' relief by the veterans themselves.

LONDON, March 29. -- King George in the scarlet uniform of Colonel-in-chief of the Brigade of Guards and Queen Mary in a golden gown held their second magnificent jubilee court at Buckingham Palace tonight.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday ordered Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company, to pay taxes and penalties on its leased elevated lines for the first six months of 1933. The amount involved is about $900,000.
The sixth and final installment of the report of the Mayor's Committee on Unemployment Relief follows:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A bill for a two-year extension of the National Industrial Recovery Act, along the lines recommended by President Roosevelt, was rushed to the Senate today by administration leaders in a frank endeavor to mollify both labor and management reputedly coming to grips rapidly in key industries.

Advocates of a municipal lottery seem to have paid insufficient attention to the difficulties of distributing the tickets. Of the two chief methods available, one would encourage corruption of the government and the other would probably result in ineffective competition with the policy rings.

Seventy-five actors and actresses met yesterday afternoon at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church in West Forty-eighth Street to discuss details of the new Actors Kitchen and Lounge, which will serve 30-cent meals to members of the theatrical profession beginning next Tuesday night.

Mayor La Guardia stood in the centre of a spotlight last night and admitted he liked it. From the ceiling of the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, the beams of a spotlight flooded the Mayor as he appeared in a box to greet 3,000 persons attending the New York Newspaper Guild's benefit for unemployed members.
ALBANY, March 29. -- Governor Lehman signed today the McNaboe bill abolishing heart balm suits not filed within the next sixty days.
With the running of the Grand National Steeplechase in Aintree, England, yesterday, holders of tickets in two sweepstakes in New York and vicinity won a total of $1,459,646 in prizes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29 (AP). -- The charges by Federal Relief Administrator Hopkins of corruption involving Ohio relief officials and politicians brought an indictment against a former hay buyer for the State relief organization today.

Two more men were indicted yesterday on perjury charges in connection with bail bond abuses in the grand jury investigation of bonding, vice and policy rackets. The indictments were handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions and bench warrants were issued, but the names of the accused men were not revealed.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- A fundamental change in the administration's social security program was ordered today by the Ways and Means Committee when, contrary to specific recommendations by the President's Committee on Economic Security, it struck from the Wagner-Lewis bill an entire section providing a voluntary system of old age annuities.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The House today completed legislative action on the War Department Appropriation Bill carrying $401,998,179 for military and non-military activities and sent it to the President for his signature.

DETROIT, March 29. -- Joe Louis, Detroit Negro heavyweight who has made a sensational record in the Middle West, recorded his seventeenth consecutive victory tonight by defeating Natie Brown of Washington in ten rounds and proved decisively his right to be ranked among the top-notch heavyweights.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The tentative draft of a revised National Industrial Recovery Act, introduced in the Senate today by Senator Harrison, follows:

Dr. David B. Steinman, chairman of the State Board of Examiners of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors, declared last night that Wharton Green would not be permitted to serve as resident engineer for the Triborough Bridge and Midtown Tunnel projects unless he could obtain a State engineering license.

The voting trust agreement under which the class B common, or voting, shares of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation are deposited will expire on Monday, and the actual shares of the stock will be issued then upon presentation of voting trust certificates for exchange.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a balance of $998,287 for stocks of the parent company on Jan. 31 after all prior charges, taxes, depreciation, full underlying preferred dividend requirements and minority interest for twelve months.

KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 29. -- The Dodgers appear to have a minor league complex that brings them defeat by second-rate clubs. The proud leaders of the Grapefruit League, undefeated by any major team, lost a game to the Baltimore Orioles in the ninth inning today that seemingly had been safely won much earlier.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP). -- With a record throng of 21,753 spectators in attendance, Chicago amateur boxers defeated New York, 11 bouts to 5, in the eighth annual Golden Gloves inter-city tournament at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

As a cotton farmer I am greatly perplexed over the many statements in Eastern newspapers tending to persuade us that controlled production of cotton is a mistake. We are told that unless we are willing to raise an unlimited amount of cotton and sell it at 6 or 8 cents a pound, we will lose our foreign markets.

In the dispute that has developed between the Governor and the members of his own party in the Senate over the Byrne-Killgrew Unemployment Insurance Bill, the principle of unemployment insurance itself is not in question. What most of the State Senators have opposed is the adoption of unemployment insurance by New York State acting alone before the passage of the Federal Government's general bill.
The final offer of the Consolidated Gas system, cutting substantially its prices to the city for street and public building lighting current, was in Mayor La Guardia's hands yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia, Fundamentalist leader, was found guilty here today by a special judicial commission of the Presbytery of New Brunswick of disobeying the higher authorities of the Presbyterian Church.

Mayor La Guardia offered yesterday to appoint a board of arbitration to hear the complaints of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, on condition that its striking members return to work on the installation of signal equipment in five uncompleted sections of the new city-owned Independent subway.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board today extended until April 30 the emergency minimum mark-ups on cigarettes established under the wholesale and retail tobacco trade codes.

In the first pamphlet report that it has ever sent to its members on its financial condition, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday showed that it operated at a net loss of $1,060,890 last year, compared with a net loss of $199,121 in 1933.
LONDON, March 29. -- The British Government concentrated its attention on Moscow today but with none of the tense anxiety with which it watched the discussions in Berlin a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- A virtually rewritten Agricultural Adjustment Act embracing most of the farm relief proposals of the last decade, even to a combination of the McNary-Haugen and export debenture plans, was reported today by the House Agricultural Committee in the form of amendments to the organic AAA act.

A Schackno law reorganization plan for the $686,000 guaranteed mortgage covering Addison Hall, a sixteen-story apartment hotel at 451-461 West Fifty-seventh Street, was mailed to certificate holders yesterday by D. William Leider, special deputy superintendent of insurance in charge of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company.

Evelyn John St. Loe Strachey, British author of several books on Communism, was freed yesterday from deportation proceedings started against him on March 12 by the United States Bureau of Immigration.
AINTREE, England, March 29. -- "It was hard luck, Mr. Whitney, but we hope you will do it next year."

MOSCOW, March 29. -- Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, became today the first member of a British Cabinet to be received by Joseph Stalin, the Soviet leader. Their conversation in the Kremlin lasted an hour.

DANZIG, March 29. -- Sean Lester, the League of Nation's High Commissioner for Danzig, was hooted and jeered by a crowd of Nazis last night who shouted, "Get out of here, intruder!" as he left a conference with Arthur Greiser, radical National Socialist President of the Danzig Senate.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29. -- With no game scheduled, Manager Bill Terry today gave his Giants a full day of rest, their first since March 7, when they began their daily exhibition performances with an engagement against Max Carey's baseball school in Miami.

DETROIT, March 29. -- The Packard Motor Car Company and subsidiaries today reported a loss for the year ended Dec. 31, 1934, of $7,290,549. In the previous year the company had a net profit and other additions to surplus of $506,433.
Mgr. Ryan, as spokesman of the religious groups urging the National Relations Board Bill sponsored by Senator Wagner, makes the following statement, as quoted in THE TIMES:

In reference to an item in THE NEW YORK TIMES about "a rare visitor, an Arctic three-toed woodpecker," having been observed near East Varick, N.Y., permit me to quote from Elon Howard Eaton's "Birds of New York":

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP). -- Barbara Hutton Mdivani, speeding across the country in a night air journey for Reno and a divorce from Prince Alexis Mdivani, left here tonight at 9:20 o'clock after a quick relay of planes.

WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE warns the Republicans that their chances of being reborn are slim unless they put economic security into their program. This, says Mr. WHITE, means "insurance against the uncertainties of ill health, the degradation of unemployment and poverty in old age.

Prices of commodity futures were somewhat firmer in tone here yesterday. The volume of trading in general was light. The staples most subject to world price influences were hesitant. Sugar futures reflected the firm and active raw market, where a price of 3.13 cents a pound was obtained for Philippine sugar sold ex-stores to a local refiner.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Realty activity in this city yesterday was featured by the purchase of sites in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn by builders who plan to erect new apartment houses.

BERLIN, March 29. -- A number of Catholic priests, friars and nuns have been arrested for violation of the securities and exchange regulations, the official exchange control bureau announced today. The arrests, it is stated, occurred in various parts of the Reich following police search of many convents, monasteries and quarters belonging to religious orders.

BERLIN, March 29. -- Local leaders of the opposition in the Protestant Church, twenty-five in all, gathered here today at St. Paul's Church for a solemn service of protest against the arrest of three Hessian pastors at the beginning of this week.

New York City's tax of 1 1/2 per cent on the gross income of public utility corporations was upheld as constitutional yesterday in a 3 to 2 decision by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. The court dismissed a test suit brought by the New York Steam Corporation, subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company, to recover $12,100.96 paid under the tax.
From the traditions of primitive tribes to decisions in modern legal procedure evidence was drawn yesterday in the Federal court to prove the continuous existence of the right of asylum.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Temporary exemption granted to twelve securities Exchanges has been extended to July 1 by the Securities and Exchange Commission to provide time to complete hearings on applications for exemption and study the evidence taken.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 29. -- Brown Prep of Philadelphia will oppose Eastern High of Washington, D.C., tomorrow night in the Eastern States interscholastic tournament final as a result of its 28 to 27 victory over Passaic (N.J.) High in the semi-finals tonight.
John Hays Hammond, whose activities as a mining engineer have taken him beneath the surfaces of four continents and a score of countries, will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29. -- Something happened to the Yankee attack today as they clashed with the Newark Bears, Colonel Jacob Ruppert's jayvees, and it was not a rush of offensive fury.

Yankee, the America's Cup yacht which is going to England next month to race Endeavour and five other large yachts, will be sailed in all her races during the Summer by her owner, Gerard B. Lambert. While in this city for a short time yesterday afternoon Mr. Lambert was asked who the skipper of the racer would be and he said he would have her wheel in all her contests.

Perhaps as a harbinger of Spring in upper Fifth Avenue, the New York Academy off Medicine will blossom tonight with an art show that will make the monochrome walls of this sedate institution look as if they had borrowed some of the Summer coloring of Central Park, across the street.

IN 1929 -- or Gregalach's year as they speak of it at Aintree -- there were sixty-six starters in the Grand National, a record field. Ten checked in at the finish and the others fell or pulled up by the wayside.

Five thousand building service employes voted unanimously last night for a general strike in all buildings in Manhattan found to be operating in violation of Section 7a of the National Recovery Act or refusing to abide by their contracts with union labor.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The Senate debated a bill to extend the NRA for two years, rushed from committee after Donald R. Richberg painted a gloomy picture of the labor-industry situation, and recessed at 3:20 until noon on Monday.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 29. -- Premier Paul van Zeeland's very carefully worded statement of policy in Belgium today was interpreted in World Bank circles to mean he has kept his hands free to devalue indefinitely, although his figures of 25 and 30 per cent seem at first glance to follow American precedent.

A petition for the nomination as a governor of the New York Stock Exchange of John F. Murray, a partner in John F. Murray Co., commission brokers of 11 Broadway, was submitted yesterday to the nominating committee of the Exchange.

Dates of the distance races as well as the championship ones for the coming Summer were announced last night at the general meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.
Another painting has been sold by J.P. Morgan and four others from his collection are in the market, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The swift course mapped by leaders in Congress for enactment of the $4,880,000,000 relief bill was interrupted today by administration officials who contended that an obscure amendment, inserted by the Senate-House conference committee, would interfere with the program.

BERLIN, March 29. -- Official announcement of the devaluation of the belga provoked no surprise in Berlin official and financial quarters and its immediate effect, it was quite generally agreed, has been heavily discounted in view of developments of the last few days.

The prospect that Columbia College might have two student newspapers on the campus by Monday morning faded last night when the college student board postponed until Sunday a scheduled meeting to consider the future of The Spectator.

Painting a grim picture of future relief administration in New York City, Mayor La Guardia's committee on unemployment relief finished its survey yesterday with the declaration that nothing short of direct competition by the government with private industry could absorb the unemployed here.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- White House rats and mice, leaky pipes, loose cornices, rugs to be rewoven, curtains to darn and white paint persistently requiring renewal were discussed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight in a speech on problems of "Keeping House on a Budget in the White House."

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Almost all the principal dairy companies in the country are charged with unlawful restraint of trade in the ice cream end of their business, in a Federal Trade Commission complaint announced today, which for the first time in the history of the FTC charged improper legislative activity.

With $148,215,000 of new bonds placed on the market this week, refunding as well as new-money issues, the total was the largest of any week since that ended on June 26, 1931, when new issues aggregating $188,141,000 were marketed.
After an early decline had carried the October below 10 1/2 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed at gains of 2 to 6 points.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Traders in grains on the Board of Trade became more cautious today than usual as the result of the monetary developments in Europe, and operations in the pits were restricted to small lots. Some brokers estimated that the aggregate business done up to noon was probably the smallest on record.

BOSTON, March 29. -- Beginning the defense of his title at the Tennis and Racquet Club, Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., yielded a set to Malcolm Greenough of Boston today as he gained the semi-finals of the national amateur court tennis championship.

LONDON, March 29. -- Devaluation of the belga and unsettlement in foreign currencies continued today to restrict business on the Stock Exchange here. British Government issues again declined, while industrials were irregular. Leading issues like Imperial Chemical, Courtaulds and United Molasses were strong, but elsewhere the market declined for lack of support.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Demand for hogs here was not urgent today, and while some early sales were 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday's, the finish was weak to 10 cents lower on everything except light weights, which were about steady.

New York University fencers moved to the threshold of a sweep of the team titles at the forty-second annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association yesterday, the preliminaries leaving the Violet swordsmen in the lead with foils and epee and ahead for the three-weapon crown as well.

MIAMI, Fla., March 29. -- Wayne D. Wright and the brown colt Tearout proved a winning combination in the featured Okeelanta Purse at Tropical Park today. The finish was a driving one for the leading rider of the Florida season, but he had Tearout a length and a half in front as they crossed the line at the end of the mile.
Residents of Greenwich Village, led by the Washington Square Association and The Villager, local weekly, are aroused over the proposed changes in Washington Square.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 29. -- Two stakes were completed today, the first day of the ninth annual field trial meeting of the Hauppauge Gunning Club. The more important of the two -- the Open Derby -- was captured by a Long Island sportsman with a dog which he trained and handled himself.

Following the more or less static conditions of the last four weeks, industrial operations are starting to rise, as preparations are being completed for new peaks for the year in April, according to the weekly survey of business issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Colonel George B. McClellan, former Mayor of New York, and Mrs. McClellan are sailing today for Europe on the Italian liner Rex. Others sailing on the ship for Mediterranean ports are Colonel Jacques Balsan organizer of the Lafayette Escadrille, with Mrs. Balsan, the former Duchess of Marlborough, and:

Documents purporting to show the interest of Arnold Bernstein, German shipowner, in the newly organized Red Star Line were introduced yesterday at the final session of the Shipping Board's inquiry into the line's relations with the New York-Antwerp-Rotterdam freight pool.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Boerse remained inactive and unsteady today under the influence of the belga crisis. Heavy industrials opened weak and then became somewhat steady. Potashes were slightly stronger. Machines dropped slightly, Schwarzkopf losing 1/2 point.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 29. -- M.E. Smith and Ralph Bayliss, the Mississippians abducted yesterday by bandits, here today positively identified photographs of Raymond Hamilton from among photographs of several criminals, as those of one of their kidnappers.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 29. -- Playing errorless ball behind three pitchers who allowed a total of six hits, the Princeton baseball team opened its season today by shutting out Panzer College of East Orange, 12 to 0.

Domestic markets continued yesterday to "saw wood" as financial interest was focused upon the Belgian monetary situation, which seemed to be rapidly approaching a point where the policy will be definitely determined.

Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson rang out the old contract bridge scoring rules with a grand gesture on the final hand of the last rubber of the night session, early this morning, in their 150-rubber match against Mr. and Mrs. P. Hal Sims at Crockford's Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street.

New York University's student body, despite the ferments within it which attract occasional notice, nevertheless is a victim of custom as much as any more elaborately titled fraternal order, fraternity leaders admitted last night at a smoker at 33 West Eighth Street.

Yale faces West Point at Squadron A Armory tonight in the climax of the college indoor polo season, the final match for the intercollegiate championship. This game stands as the feature of another full evening of play in the national championship which will see three games played at Squadron A and three more at Squadron C in Brooklyn.

Before what was declared to be the largest audience at the Metropolitan in the fourteen-week opera season now closing, Wagner's "Tristan" was sung yesterday afternoon for the sixth time this year. It also was the third in which the Norwegian soprano, Mme. Kirsten Flagstad, had appeared as Isolde.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP). -- The spreading of what was called "propaganda" by the Tennessee Valley Authority in the public schools was sharply criticized today before the House Interstate Commerce Committee along with the Rayburn-Wheeler Holding Company Bill.

With respect to the advertisement appearing in THE HEW YORK TIMES today, "The Nearest Yardstick," the Consolidated Gas Company compares the rates charged by electric companies in Freeport and Rockville Centre with those prevailing in New York City. The company states that the Freeport and Rockville Centre plants are municipally operated and pay no taxes.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, March 29. -- The Nazi organ Volksblatt announced yesterday that a "Jew, Arthur Hellmer," proprietor and manager of the Neues Theater here, had been deprived of his concession to run the theatre. The theatre is to continue performances under provisional management until the close of the present season, June 20, it was announced.
AKRON, Ohio, March 29 (AP). -- City and county officials increased special precautionary measures tonight as several thousand Akron rubber workers prepared to take strike votes.

After the meeting of LITVINOFF and Captain EDEN at Moscow it was not necessary to issue a joint statement that the meeting had been "frank and friendly," as the Berlin conference was said to be until it suddenly blew up. One difference is that we have the actual speeches of the two chief conferees, as printed yesterday in THE TIMES.

Old proposals of Leonor F. Loree for railroad mergers, which were unsuccessful although spectacular, were recalled yesterday at the hearing on the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway bankruptcy before Van Vechten Veeder, special master, in the Bar Association Building.

PARIS, March 29. -- Nicolas Titulescu, the Rumanian Foreign Minister, arrived in Paris today and made a preliminary report to Foreign Minister Pierre Laval on the results of his tour of the Little Entente countries.

PARIS, March 29. -- Rumors of strong dissension within the French Cabinet over the policy to be pursued in regard to the general European situation have been prevalent in Paris during the past few days. It is alleged Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin and his Foreign Minister, Pierre Laval, are far from being in accord and that each has his group of supporters.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP). -- Newspaper publishers and automobile manufacturers added their voices today to industry's assertion that the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill would hinder recovery.

I am a merchant living in the Cotton Belt, and having recently read hundreds of pages of propaganda derogatory to the administration's cotton program, I wonder just how much headway is being made by cotton buyers and compress owners, spurred on by those who would wreck the Democratic cause at any price.

The flowers that bloom in the Spring will have nothing in the way of luxuriance on the posies which will burst from their buds during the coming week in the night clubs. Adjectives wither before them! What's to be said of a week which beholds the blossoming forth of Helen Morgan, Sophie Tucker, Paul Whiteman and the night-club debut of Jockey Earl Sande? Nothing! The following schedule of events will have to suffice:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 29. -- National Guardsmen and sheriffs' posses concentrated their man hunt for Raymond Hamilton, Southwest desperado, in this area tonight following the release near this city of two hostages whom the bandit and a companion had held since yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 29. -- Officers of the collapsed American Bond and Share Corporation were charged by the Federal District Attorney's office here today as having represented themselves as receiving information from Eastern capitalists which would insure their prospective stockholders of 100 per cent stock market profits.

A committee appointed by the New York Produce Exchange is seeking to determine means for closing trades in nearly 6,000 shares of Alleghany Corporation $2.50 prior-preferred stock still open as a result of a change in the corporation's plan for putting its reorganization into effect.

Wall Street is disappointed that the anxiety over the currency situation in Continental Europe has not resulted in heavier buying of American securities. The fact that there is prospect of widespread currency devaluation and that Europe is disturbed by warlike demonstrations appears to have induced transfer of a comparatively small amount of capital through the most convenient channels -- the security markets.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The best record among 366 cities in 1934 in checking fire waste and promoting fire prevention was made by Providence, to which goes a grand award and one of six plaques in the National Fire Waste Contest.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- By an appeal to spokesmen for the nation's bituminous coal operators and miners to continue from April 1 to June 16 the Soft Coal Code and the wage contract written into it, the Roosevelt Administration, through the National Industrial Recovery Board, took a step today toward cementing a truce in the most critical strike threat to the recovery program.

ARLINGTON DOWNS, Texas, March 29 (AP). -- Joe Flores, carrying top impost of 113 pounds, won the featured claiming race for 4-year-olds and upward at Arlington Downs today. Madwind was second and Dr. Freeland third.

It is getting to he a serious question when and how we can begin penalizing legislative bodies for spending large sums of taxpayers' money on "investigations" that cannot have any possible object but to advertise the legislators involved and promote their personal fortunes.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Renewed optimism in business circles in Cuba, following an easing of labor and political disturbances in early March, was reported today in the weekly survey of business by the Department of Commerce.

BERLIN, March 30. -- Despite reports of the Basle police that Berthold Jacob, refugee German pacifist journalist, was kidnapped probably by Nazi agents in Switzerland, the German government news service published today the following statement:

OSSINING, N.Y., March 29. -- Albert H. Fish, who is awaiting the death sentence for the murder of 10-year-old Grace Budd, slashed himself twice across the abdomen today in his death house cell at Sing Sing. His wounds, which are not serious, were caused by a sharpened meat bone.

Hoping to overcome the one-goal lead held over them by the Montreal Maroons, the New York Rangers will face Tommy Gorman's close checking aggregation in the second game of home-and-home, total-goal series, in the Canadian metropolis tonight.

A bored Deputy United States Marshal, sitting yesterday as a lone juror in Federal court, had the theoretical task of deciding whether the library and art gallery of the fashionable Century Club made its members followers of art and letters, or whether its bar, card tables and billiard rooms, housed in the five-story structure at 7 West Forty-third Street, made those gentlemen a convivial social group.

LONDON, March 29. -- Belgium's decision to run a managed currency until an international agreement is reached to return to gold momentarily caused sharp fluctuations in the gold exchanges today, but will not damage British interests to any great extent provided the belga is not later linked with sterling.
New Yorkers, who eat 4,500,000 meals a day in the city restaurants, will pay about 10 per cent more in most restaurants and hotels beginning on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

Women's colleges are at sea as to the technique of training character "because old principles and standards seem to have faded," Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College said last night at a meeting in the Hotel Astor of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations.
VOLIN, S.D., March 29. -- Leroy Johnson, 12, rode his new "pony" to school for the first time today.

These initials keep their beneficent distinctiveness despite the multiplication of alphabetical organizations, Though they spell no pronounceable word, they continue to express in this association a faith in the improvability of human conditions and to support a program of works consistent with that faith.

DETROIT, Mich., March 29. -- A demand was filed today in the United States District Court here by J. Walter Drake, former chairman of the Hupp Motor Car Company and former Assistant Secretary of Commerce in President Hoover's Cabinet, asking that Archie M. Andrews of New York be compelled to resign his position as chairman of the board.

Dr. Ida S. Scudder, president of the Missionary Medical College for Women, Vellore, South India, will be the guest of women prominent in foreign missionary work of all Protestant denominations in New York City at a luncheon next Saturday in the Hotel Commodore. Dr. Scudder will return in June to Vellore, where she has worked for thirty-five years.

Records were either broken or equaled in all nine running events on the program as New Utrecht High's track and field squad captured the City P.S.A.L. senior high school indoor team championship for the tenth straight year at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn last night.

Mrs. John Henry Hammond gave a musicale last night at her home, 9 East Ninety-first Street. Mrs. Hammond is chairman of the People's Chorus of New York, the Studio Unit of which participated in the diversified program. The guests included many of her friends in society and the musical world, among whom were several who are actively interested in the People's Chorus as members or committee officials.

The Democratic Assemblymen from New York City who are opposing the Reapportionment Bill are not only injuring the Democratic pary in the State, for which they probably do not care, but are weakening the influence of the local organization in the councils of the city.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 29. -- The spectacle of a city taken as a unit under the wings of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration was reviewed here today by the members of the White House group who came to Florida to establish headquarters at Miami while President Roosevelt cruised and fished in the South Atlantic.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29. -- Jack Medica, University of Washington star, carried off the major honors on the opening day of the twelfth annual swimming championships of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the Harvard pool.

MOSCOW, March 29. -- Joseph Stalin, the Soviet leader, received Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, in the Kremlin this afternoon and they discussed for an hour various phases of the international situation involving both countries.

" The annual question of early-season flies vs. the tried and true garden hackle is rapidly coming to a focus," writes Quill Gordon. "Frankly, water conditions permitting, I prefer the flies, particularly in the larger streams.

The municipal bond market will receive a breathing spell next week, when only $5,857,824 of new bonds will come up for award. The comparative lull will enable dealers to continue work on distributing this week's new awards of $59,695,327, including the $34,300,000 Port of New York Authority flotation.
ROME, March 29. -- A hint that a third division may be formed for service in Italy's colonies was given today by the Under-Secretary of State for War speaking in the Senate.

It is more than two years since Beatrice Lillie opened in a Broadway show. Now she is on the way back again. She was definitely signed this week -- and not before this week -- for the "travelogue revue" tentatively called "Not in the Guidebook," which Lee Shubert will place in rehearsal about July 1.

Oneness of style, quite as much as unity of detail and polish of performance, distinguished the two-piano playing of Josef and Rosina Lhevinne in the Town Hall last night. In the large audience that applauded the pair were to be noted musicians of eminence, including some who recently have been recitalists in the same auditorium.

Trade in the metropolitan area showed considerable improvement during the week. Anniversary sales attracted active consumer buying, and there was a spurt in the demand for women's apparel and accessories, marking the rise in pre-Easter buying.

Formation of a national committee of eighty prominent persons, under the honorary chairmanship of President Roosevelt, to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of Mark Twain, was announced yesterday afternoon by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

It is more than two years since Beatrice Lillie opened in a Broadway show. Now she is on the way back again. She was definitely signed this week -- and not before this week -- for the "travelogue revue" tentatively called "Not in the Guidebook," which Lee Shubert will place in rehearsal about July 1.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP). -- A veteran stock broker told the Tax Appeals Board today that when Andrew W. Mellon decided to dispose of his 123,000 shares of Pittsburgh Coal common stock in December, 1931, he might have caused suspension of trading in that issue on the New York Stock Exchange had it been offered on the market.

Two amendments to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange, one of which would establish a system by which absent members could vote at the Exchange's elections, and the other providing a new method of selecting a president in the event of a vacancy before an annual election, were approved yesterday by the governing committee.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 29. -- With a brilliant finishing round of 68 Paul Runyan, White Plains pro, won the North and South open golf championship today, turning in the remarkable total of 276, the lowest figures that ever have won this 33-year-old tournament.

After writing two notes, one of which dealt with the Morro Castle disaster in which 124 lives were lost last Sept. 8, George I. Alagna, 28 years old, first assistant wireless operator on the vessel, unsuccessfully attempted suicide by gas early yesterday morning, according to the police, in the apartment of friends at 35-06 Seventy-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Despite a Presidentially authorized drive for NRA enforcement, and in the face of official declarations that its code was still in effect, the Lumber Code Authority today discharged most of its employes and apparently decided to fold up its tent.
PARIS, March 29. -- Belgium's desertion of the gold bloc will not in any way affect the French franc, it was asserted here today in official circles.

Owing to interest shown in the exhibition of American Book Illustration at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, the American Institute of Graphic Arts, under whose auspices it is being given, announced that the showing had been extended for a week and would not close until April 5.
Eleven young men in a crowd of about fifty picketing the New York Curb Exchange, 78 Trinity Place, were arrested shortly after noon yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct.

HAVANA, March 29. -- Despite approval of a law with retroactive effect by the Cabinet this afternoon which automatically commuted the death sentence imposed upon Manuel Fonseca, a civilian, by a court-martial for the possession of explosives, the military authorities tonight continued preparations for his execution, which had been set for 7 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Agreement on most major points of issue in a plan to take the profits out of war as between the views of the President's committee and the Senate munitions committee was seen today as Bernard M. Baruch ended three days of testimony before the Senate group.

" Dassan," a film depicting the habits and antics of a colony of penguins, will be shown today, from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., by the Junior Film Society at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Also on the bill will be "Babes in the Woods," a Walt Disney silly symphony; "Jumping Giants" and "Mexico Today."
Lotte Lehmann, owing to a serious cold, has canceled her farewell reception today before sailing for Europe.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Merger of Boettcher, Newton Co. with Harris, Upham Co. to take place on April 8, was announced today by James A. Cathcart, senior partner in the Chicago office of Harris, Upham Co. whose name the new stock and grain house will take.
Two children were killed in Bronx streets yesterday afternoon when they were struck by wagons drawn by runaway horses.

The announcement of the Belgian Government's plan for devaluing the belga brought a fresh fall in that currency yesterday, but served to arrest the most extreme fears for its future, with the result that forward contracts in the currency were relatively improved.

The lack of "good neighboring" in government relief agencies makes additional local contributions essential, according to Frederic R. Kellogg, president of the Community Chests and Councils, Inc., who addressed the annual conference of this organization yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Agreement on most major points of issue in a plan to take the profits out of war as between the views of the President's committee and the Senate munitions committee was seen today as Bernard M. Baruch ended three days of testimony before the Senate group.

" Dassan," a film depicting the habits and antics of a colony of penguins, will be shown today, from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., by the Junior Film Society at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Also on the bill will be "Babes in the Woods," a Walt Disney silly symphony; "Jumping Giants" and "Mexico Today."
Lotte Lehmann, owing to a serious cold, has canceled her farewell reception today before sailing for Europe.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Merger of Boettcher, Newton Co. with Harris, Upham Co. to take place on April 8, was announced today by James A. Cathcart, senior partner in the Chicago office of Harris, Upham Co. whose name the new stock and grain house will take.
Two children were killed in Bronx streets yesterday afternoon when they were struck by wagons drawn by runaway horses.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- To facilitate the filing of financial statements by corporations with fiscal years ending on or after Dec. 31, 1934, who are seeking permanent registration on the Stock Exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission amended its rules today.

The announcement of the Belgian Government's plan for devaluing the belga brought a fresh fall in that currency yesterday, but served to arrest the most extreme fears for its future, with the result that forward contracts in the currency were relatively improved.

The lack of "good neighboring" in government relief agencies makes additional local contributions essential, according to Frederic R. Kellogg, president of the Community Chests and Councils, Inc., who addressed the annual conference of this organization yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.
Nothing happened in the credit . xnarket to distinguish it from preceding sessions. Turnover was small and rates unchanged for all classifications.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP). -- By a vote of 12 to 5, the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today made a favorable report on the Wheeler resolution providing $25,000 for a "thorough and complete" investigation of railroad financing.

Joseph M. Price, chairman of the trustees of the City Club and for many years active in New York Fusion movements, who returned from a trip to the Virgin Islands yesterday, praised highly the administration of Governor Paul M. Pearson in an interview last night.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- The Treasury closed its books on three-quarters of the fiscal year today with a $2,193,000,000 deficit, but gratified at a surplus for March, the first in forty-one months.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The threatened national walkout of 500,000 bituminous coal miners on April 1 was averted today when miners and operators agreed to a truce, proposed by the NIRB, extending the present wage agreement and code provisions until June 16.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A suggestion that the Federal Government might want to assert control over the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange as part of a general program to insure the security of commodity markets, was contained in a special report filed with the Senate yesterday by Secretary Wallace.

MORE ornate curtain arrangements mark a trend in interior decoration toward the elegancies of the early nineteenth century modes, such as the English Regency. New colors are seen, generally lighter than those of the past, and fabrics which emphasize sheen rather than rough texture.

For the first time in the history of indoor polo, the intercollegiate championship rests with the cadets of West Point. Last night, before a gallery that packed all the seats of Squadron A Armory, West Point turned back Yale by one-half a point, 6 1/2 to 6.

Operators on the Cotton Exchange here ignored the course of prices in Liverpool yesterday, and the market, instead of opening lower, started with a slight advance over Friday in both old crop positions. Execution of foreign buying orders was assigned to fears that the export-subsidy plan, if adopted by Congress, would tend to narrow straddle differences.

LONDON, March 30 (Canadian Press). -- Arsenal and Sunderland are battling hard for English football honors. The Gunners maintained a strong position at the top of the first division standing today by defeating Aston Villa, 3 -- 1, at Villa Park.

RICHMOND, March 29. -- Virginia's counties and cities are eyeing hungrily the first year's profits of the liquor control system. The system was begun formally one year ago, but it will not have been in full operation for twelve months until the end of the fiscal year, June 30.

LONDON, March 18. SUCH are the world's present discontents that we are more than ever inclined to regard plays whose scene is in the past as mirrors in which to discover our own faces reflected. How near or remote the historical scene may be seems to matter little.

Speaking of red-hot dictators -- Where the globe over is there another who has perfected such a deadly brand of prohibition that old soaks are drinking milk and mineral water, and the way of the transgressor is one year at hard labor?

It has often been hinted that Germany is today taking a leaf out of Japan's book. A new method, it is said, has been invented by the Japanese for violating treaties and taking and keeping what they desire, without much danger of bringing on war. Protests and appeals and remonstrances follow, but there is no declaration of war.

TWO performances will divide the interest this evening, when Tashamira makes her first appearance of the season at the Guild Theatre and Taniris and her group give their second recital at the Civic Repertory.

A meeting of persons involved in the controversy as to the settlement of dealings in securities of the Alleghany Corporation undertaken on a when-issued basis will be held tomorrow in the office of Gilman Unger, lawyers, at 48 Wall Street. The purpose is to discuss a plan to bring the controversy to a quick conclusion.
RECENTLY a trapper in remote Northern British Columbia was badly wounded. He needed a doctor's attention, but the nearest doctor was hundreds of miles distant.

Opera in English is a subject which is near and dear to my heart. I was brought up with German as my mother tongue and heard all my Wagner in that tongue. Opera sung in English is certainly not necessary for me nor for the many to whom German is as fluent as English.
LONDON, March 30. -- Max Baer vs. Max Schmeling for the world's heavyweight championship either here or in Rome sometime during August.

The teaching profession has never attracted the ablest of our young men. I state this as a fact. Probably it is unfortunate. In many years under professors I can remember out of dozens, perhaps hundreds, only two who stood out as great teachers.

FREEPORT, L.I., March 30. -- A courageous stand by the Pilgrims on the turf of the Freeport Municipal Stadium today was fruitless and the powerful Blue wave of the New York Rugby Club rolled ahead to a 38-0 victory, the greatest score even made by an American rugby club in the East.

RATS: Mrs. Roosevelt made a speech Friday night in which she revealed that rats and mice have no respect for even such an august edifice as the White House. The unpleasant rodents, she said, "like old buildings, regardless of tradition." The First Lady remarked cheerfully that she had succeeded in exterminating the pests, but she complained that "one has to keep constantly doing it."

GLASGOW, March 30 (Canadian Press). -- After a terrific tussle, Hearts and Glasgow Rangers, the cup holders, drew, 1 -- 1, in the semifinal for the Scottish Soccer Cup today. Hamilton Academicals made sure of a place in the final by defeating Aberdeen, 2-1.

Representative Wright Patman, in a letter to THE TIMES defending his soldier bonus bill, would have it appear that the $2,000,000,000 to be issued, being non-interest-bearing money, will therefore cost the country nothing.

Inspired by Dr. Goebbels and his Ministry of Propaganda, 65,000,000 Germans last week turned their faces east and uttered violent threats against 2,225,000 Lithuanians. With that move the question of Memel and of Germany's other "bleeding boundaries" was once again thrown into the whirlpool of European polities.

ALL things considered, the biennial exhibitions of contemporary American paintings held at the Corcoran Gallery, in Washington, deserve to be called the most thoroughly representative group showings of native art we have. Every two years the appointed jury of selection receives, in effect, this appeal:
HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 30. -- With a notable gallery of sportsmen and sportswomen in attendance the Long Island Retriever Club today inaugurated its first non-slip retriever trials.

I BELIEVE I can, without vanity, claim some first-hand knowledge of the particular subject which I have been asked to discuss, namely, "Popular Art and Profits." With this problem I have, literally, lived during the past two and a half years.

GOING back to Central America for a vacation visit to an old friend, Morgan Connor, Texas cowboy and a veteran of five revolutions in "Banana Land," waged over a period of eight years, told himself that "if somebody should start a Number One revolution right under the chair I'm decorating, I would simply get up with a hurt look and hunt another seat."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 30. -- University of Rochester students have long been looking forward to next week, for it will bring to the university two visitors whom the students are particularly anxious to meet.

THE annual showing of John Whorf's water-colors at the Milch Galleries is always a pleasant event. It is an added pleasure to report that the artist continues to advance. He has not been content to discover a formula and relapse into facility.

THREE-QUARTERS of a century ago this week an agile young man, similar in vision and character, in physique and courage to the night mail flier of today, climbed onto his pony at St. Joseph, Mo., and started westward. In his saddle bags he carried a little mail and a few -- a very few -- high- value packages.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Outdoor life will begin in earnest at White Sulphur this week when the Casino, headquarters of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club, opens for the season. Filled with Spring flowers and gay music, the Tangerine Room at the Casino will be the scene at noon today of numerous luncheon parties as members of the Spring colony gather after a morning on the trails or golf courses.

BOSTON, March 28. -- The curtailment plan for the cotton textile industry authorized by the National Industrial Recovery Board for an emergency period of three months is hailed with warm satisfaction by the majority of the New England mill men and is reported here to be almost unanimously welcomed in the South.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 30. -- Paul Mellon's Drinmore Lad, big brown gelding and the favorite, captured the Carolina Cup race over the historic Springdale course today in the sixth annual running under the sanction of the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

The nation-wide movement to replace high-interest-bearing bonds with new bonds of lower coupons is rapidly gaining momentum. New issues totaling approximately $150,000,000 were placed on the market last week, the largest amount for a single week in nearly four years.

HAVANA, March 30. -- Five minutes before 7 A.M., the hour set for the execution of Manuel Fonseca, civilian condemned to die before a firing squad by a court-martial, he was notified that the death sentence had been commuted to life imprisonment by military authorities.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 30 (AP). -- Three murders were pinned on the Barker-Karpis gang and a life-termer in Stillwater Prison was exonerated of the crimes in a written confession by one of the band held for the $200,000 kidnapping of Edward Bremer, it became known today.

New York University ushered in the metropolitan college baseball season by defeating an alumni nine, 10 to 8, at Ohio Field yesterday. A six-run onslaught in the fifth inning was the direct cause of the Violet victory.

The second contemporary art exhibition for the benefit of the American Colony Charities Association, Inc., will be held in the art galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, from April 10 to 12 inclusive. The exhibit will include the work of many eminent artists and on the opening day a reception will be held.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- While the importance of the meeting yesterday between Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, and Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, should not be exaggerated, there is no doubt it marks a definite step along the path toward a better mutual understanding, upon which the Soviet Union and Great Britain are now engaged.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- C.W. Muller's Don Guzman, the 5-year-old St. James gelding which has done so well during the Florida season, added another victory to his string when Wayne Wright piloted him home in an easy winner of the Everglades Handicap today.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A prediction that our export trade will have a further recession unless imports are materially increased was made by Secretary Wallace tonight.

The small net change in the prices of the general list of stocks in the last three weeks has been taken as an indication that prices have reached a level which has fairly well discounted possible unfavorable developments. However, there has been little anticipatory buying on possible favorable developments.

PARIS, March 30. -- French official circles are most favorable to the reports of the Eden-Litvinoff conversations in Moscow. It is said the French Government has been informed both by British and Russian sources that many misunderstandings have been cleared up.

The letter of Lloyd C. Crosgrave about the social science dispute among the recently assembled educators at Atlantic City leads one to ask if these educators fully realize the nature of the social science they essay to teach.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29. -- While Herbert Hoover was receiving an honorary degree at the University of California and agreeing with Frances Perkins that it was a beautiful campus, his letter castigating the Roosevelt administration appeared on the front pages of California newspapers without creating half as much discussion as the Perkins-Ijams incident.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 30. -- Sigma Alpha Mu was first in scholarship among the twenty-one national fraternities and local clubs at Rutgers University during the first semester of the current academic year, it was announced today by Luther Martin, registrar.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30. -- Showing to excellent advantage, Champagne, capable chestnut mare owned by P.B. Schwartz of White Plains, captured a pair of blue ribbons in events for hunters as the annual exhibition of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club was held in its riding hall today.

The Professional Children's School will be the beneficiary of a special performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Mme. Kirsten Flagstad, Mme. Karin Branzell and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, on the night of April 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30. -- The Princeton varsity rugby team defeated the Long Island University fifteen, 18 to 5, on Poe Field today in the season's opener for the Tigers. In a preliminary, the Princeton jayvees subdued St. John's University of Brooklyn, 8 to 0.

JUST in case another war breaks out, this hint indicating "the way to promotion and pay" should be kept secret no longer. It might be called the Schacht Plan and was used in the World War, Long Island Sound sector. Now retired from the army, ex-Corporal Al Schacht revealed it to a small but select gathering recently.

On the outer fringe of Berlin what is perhaps the world's greatest sports plant is in a process of construction. It is the Reichssportfeld that will be the scene of the games of the eleventh Olympiad in 1936. Athletic history has had many gigantic undertakings, but perhaps there never was the concentration of stadia, gymnasia, fields and halls such as is the one now mushrooming in the German capital.

The body of Daniel B. Hourihan, a 53-year-old De Witt Clinton High School teacher who disappeared more than seven weeks ago, was taken from the East River at the foot of South Third Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning.

MANILA. -- All the larger newspapers in the Philippine Islands published the full text of the recent speech of Resident Commissioner Pedro Guevara in the House of Representatives at Washington in which he declared that a protectorate for the Philippine Islands would be preferable at the present time to complete independence.
PARIS, March 20. -- Information trickling through the Suez Com

In the old days when I was a boy the efficacy of medicines was commonly judged by their vile smell and taste. The viler the better, thought our ancestors, and to get us to swallow the doses they practiced cruel deceit. They told us that the dose was delightful and not nauseating and ended up by holding our noses so that we had to take it or die of strangulation.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand. -- The most curious Governor that Britain ever sent New Zealand has at last gone home. Lord Bledisloe, former British Cabinet Minister, farm owner, wealthy Englishman, has at last left the country to make way for another British peer, Lord Galway, whose career in the Guards and general interest in sport appear to be his main characteristics.

While three of the four basic textile industries are ending one of their most disastrous quarters in recent years, executives yesterday looked for a reasonable improvement during the coming three months, which would bring the half-year figures to a more comparable showing with 1934.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The New Deal Administration is determined, so far as possible, to avoid at least until next Fall a final and authoritative decision by the Supreme Court of the United States on the constitutionality of its probably most important enactment -- the National Industrial Recovery Act. By that time, it hopes, a changed NIRA will be in effect. A bill directed toward this end was presented on Friday.

IT is quite simple to raise lilies from seed and thus at slight cost obtain a large stock of bulbs which otherwise would be expensive. Since home-raised bulbs are almost always free from disease this method goes far toward assuring healthy lilies.

Slumpkin, the young prince of the goblins, and Komodo, the many-jointed alligator, moved with a fascinating agility when Leonard W. Suib, 21-year-old marionette designer, demonstrated what his miniature robots could do as actors.

The seventh annual Army Day parade will be held on Fifth Avenue from Ninetieth to Sixty-first Streets next Saturday afternoon. This marshaling of military and patriotic units is the principal feature of the Army Day celebration, which also will be marked by reviews and dinners in the evening at which speakers will stress the importance of national defense.

EVEN veteran tillers of the soil may find useful hints in the program of the Subsistence Project whereby 10,000 vegetable garden plots in the City of New York are made available this Spring for cultivation by home relief families.

TO the crime fiction novelist who has taken the trouble to study the history of his subject, Vidocq's "Memoirs" are familiar as the inspiration of the long line of authors through whom the detective story in its present form has reached us.

Most commanders of merchant ships were born near the sea and brought up on a family tradition that carried them along in the footsteps of their fathers. Most of them, too, chose their life work when children and merely waited until they attained the right age to pack a few belongings and go out on that first heart-breaking journey.
