A LARGE sum of money was recently authorized for the completion of the new Parliament House in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, but the superstitious in that country doubt that the building will ever be finished. Its foundations were laid in 1908, but in the three decades since that time, whenever it seemed as though the structure would be finished, some untoward happening brought new obstacles.

WHAT is believed to be the most accessible example of dinosaur tracks, made 10,000,000 years ago along the banks of the Connecticut River near Holyoke, Mass., will be preserved through the development of Dinosaur Park and the acquisition of the property by the Trustees of Public Reservations.

EVERY year a large number of foreigners, including many Americans, come to the U.S.S.R. seeking for truth about this large and mysterious country. Most of them, especially the more serious-minded, are much struck by the naive pride which is constantly displayed by their guides, interpreters or other persons appointed to conduct and assist them in their search.

BERLIN, March 30. -- More than a score of Carmelite friars and nuns and a number of officials of this order in Germany tonight faced indictment for alleged violations of the laws governing traffic in foreign currencies and the transfer abroad of German currency and securities.

The listed bond market rallied mildly yesterday in the brief trading period. United States Government bonds finished irregularly higher, 5-32 point higher to 2-32 lower. The new Treasury 2 7/8s advanced 2-32 point on the day to 101 6-32.

SHERIDAN, Wyo. -- Plans for simple secession and annexation in the Black Hills of South Dakota have been expanded into a proposed three-way secession in that State Wyoming and Montana, and the creation of a forty-ninth State -- Absaroka. [Absaroka is the tribal name of the Crow Indian nation.]

In view of the recent interesting comment by Mr. Frederick Boas, authority on Shakespeare and Elizabethan drama, I thought it might be of interest to you to offer a few remarks upon an interesting experiment in Shakespeare production to be made at Stanford University during the coming Summer.

A WEEK before her wedding Gloria Sutherland was happily occupied with parties and shopping. Suddenly she received the news that her fiance had been killed in a night club in New York. He and his companion, a cabaret dancer, had been shot by the girl's jealous lover.

THE youngest university in the world celebrates its tenth anniversary next Tuesday. On that day the Hebrew University will mark not only its own progress but the advance which has been made in the reconstruction of Palestine as a national home for the Jewish people.
The signal honor accorded George T. Dunlap Jr. last year when he received a scratch rating on the Metropolitan Golf Association's honor list was short-lived.

Winning a championship they seemed fated to lose and losing another they already appeared to have won, New York University swordsmen still deftly drove their way to major honors as the forty-second annual title tournament of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association came to a close in the Hotel Commodore ballroom last night.

THE mentality and general outlook of the congenital criminal seems to have occupied of late a good deal of Mr. Phillpotts's attention. He now turns from the psychology of the habitual murderess which he presented at some length in the trilogy that closed with "A Shadow Passes" to that of the highwayman and his female accomplice.

RADIO showmen are watching with special interest the move of Major Bowes, who abandoned a local amateur revue to stage a similar performance on a nation-wide scale. It seems that the broadcasters have always believed if a program had been successful on a local station then it would also go sure-fire on a network.

DUBLIN, March 10. THE Abbey Theatre, which has played such an outstanding part in the cultural and artistic life of Ireland, is passing through critical times just now. First nights at the Abbey were always big events for drama lovers in Dublin.

A STORY of that fantastic type which must be very good indeed if it is to be any good at all, F.G. Hurrell's tale deals with a kind of dual personality. His hero, John Lillibud, an unsuccessful author, turns inventor and makes a great deal of money.

BERLIN, March 30. -- Within less than a fortnight Germany's attitude toward armaments, peace pacts, the League of Nations and her neighbors, as revealed to Sir John Simon, and her immediate intentions, as far as these have been disclosed to the British Foreign Secretary, will be laid on the council table at Stresa, Italy.

MOSCOW. WITH the close of Moscow's first cinema festival, at which foreign and Soviet pictures competed, ends the last event in two solid months of celebration marking the fifteen-year jubilee of Soviet films. Planned originally as a means of developing cultural contact with other countries and to stimulate artistic and technical competition in the international cinema, the Moscow festival has undoubtedly served as a spur to film trade between Russia and her foreign neighbors.

Copies of a new course in literature for junior high schools and the upper elementary grades have been sent to assistant superintendents for suggestions as to improvement. Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said the course, which will be introduced in September, provides "a wealth of material for selection by the teacher to meet the individual literary tastes and aptitudes of adolescent pupils."

According to Roy E. Moore, Metropolitan A.A.U. gymnastic champion, Mrs. Thera Steppich, in winning the senior all-around gymnastic title last week-end, performed about as near perfection as is possible for a woman.

THE President of the United States has gone fishing in Southern waters and the rest of the country is ready for reports about the big sailfish or marlin that got away. Most fishermen hope that the President will get his sailfish this time; if he does, his guide will be kept busy for the rest of his life answering questions about that fish.

BELL-SHAPED gauntlets bring another hint of Spring to the promenade, and play an important role in making an outfit a distinct success. Gone are the baggy gloves so reminiscent of mittens. Gauntlets and slip-ons continue to be the favored models; but they fit trimly over hands and wrists, while flaring out at the cuffs.

Marie E. Harrington, a modishly dressed woman of 35, who was said by the police to have had an income of $67,000 a year until 1925, was held without bail in Yorkville Court yesterday for examination Thursday. She is charged with passing a bad check for $20 in a hosiery shop.

OCCASIONALLY a child is born who has a vocation for medicine just us another has for religion or art. Such a child was Robert Mallory, born in a poor farmhouse in the Middle West and dedicated, in spite of environment, to the priesthood of healing. In his story Alan Hart tells the saga of the country doctor.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The following hearings were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission:

ELIZABETH SPRIGGE has followed her fine first novel, "The Old Man Dies," with a more substantial and durable work in a quite different vein. Substantial and durable may seem curious adjectives to apply to a novel as essentially romantic as "Castle in Andalusia."

Declines in retail sales volume throughout the country this month, ranging from 5 to 15 per cent, will be succeeded by April gains ranging from 15 to 30 per cent over the same month a year ago, according to estimates in well-informed retail quarters here during the week.
In a series of raids on the Italian lottery or policy game, two Assistant District Attorneys and detectives arrested sixteen persons Friday night and yesterday.

DOUBLEDAY, DORAN CO. and the English publishers Hamish Hamilton, Ltd., are jointly sponsoring an international contest for the best book having aviation as its theme. It must be between 70,000 and 100,000 words in length, but may be fiction, personal experience, biography, history, in fact, any literary form so long as the theme is flying.

THE next few months will see several of the country's fastest trains go into regular service. Beginning tomorrow, the Flying Yankee operated by the Boston Maine and the Maine Central Railroad between Boston and Portland and Bangor, Me., will start its daily schedule.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 30 (AP). -- Walter H. McGee, the first kidnapper to be sentenced to death in the United States, must pay with his life for the ransom abduction nearly two years ago of Miss Mary McElroy, daughter of the City Manager of Kansas City, the Missouri Supreme Court decreed today.

A thorough survey of the public school system would involve the study of "a tremendously complex economic, sociological as well as educational problem," according to the committee appointed a year ago by Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to make the survey.

The "Five-to-Fifty-Year-Old Fashion Show," to be held the afternoon of April 25 at Sherry's for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop, will present the latest costumes for Spring wear for those between the ages of 5 and 50.

THE Metropolitan Opera official season has ended in New York, but the company will come back for three performances in the next three weeks. On Monday evening, April 8, "Tristan und Isolde" will be sung at the Thirty-ninth Street House with Kirsten Flagstad, Karin Branzell, Lauritz Melchior, Gustav Schuetzendorf, Emanuel List, George Cehanovsky, Marek Windheim and Louis D'Angelo.

The United States Government closed its books last night on the third quarter of the current fiscal year with a deficit of about $2,200,000,000. At this rate the deficit at the end of the fiscal year on June 30 would be in the neighborhood of $3,000,000,000. This would be nearly $2,000,000,000 less than the amount forecast by the President only a few months ago in his annual budget message to Congress.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30. -- Under the protecting influence of an old-fashioned Yankee attack, the husky Charley (Red) Ruffing made his 1935 debut at Waterfront Park today in the seventh game of the Yankee-Braves series and covered himself with glory.

LONDON. THE challenge thrown down by Herbert Read in his "Sweated Author" article in The London Mercury has been promptly taken up by Geoffrey Faber, the publisher. Replying in the same magazine, he first disputes Mr. Read's thesis that the author's remuneration has declined during the last hundred years, and gives chapter and verse for his opinion.

The end of the present season at the Metropolitan Opera House marks the end of an epoch in New York's musical history. It was definitely begun with the coming of Mr. GATTI-CASAZZA as manager twenty-eight seasons ago; it is definitely concluded with his departure now.
Elaborate plans for the organization of athletic teams by the Catholic Boys Clubs of the Archdiocese of New York were outlined yesterday at a luncheon at the New York Athletic Club.
Ten matches were played yesterday in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school handball competition.

WHEREVER Franklin D. Roosevelt turns these days there falls across his path the shadow of a sturdy comrade of many Democratic wars -- Senator Carter Glass of Virginia. Although Senator Glass is the senior Democrat of the Senate in point both of age and service, he perhaps presents more effective opposition to a Demoocratic administration than does the Republican minority on Capitol Hill.

One does not look into an annual report of a philanthropic society with the expectation of discovering an oration to match the memorable speech of PERICLES. But one finds it in the Fourth Annual Report of the Pilgrim Trust. There is, to be sure, enough heroic stuff written between the lines to furnish material for a Greek tragedy.
AT the conclusion of the 1934 accident analysis summary for the State of Rhode Island, V.L. Howe, its compiler, writes:
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The conclusions of the Interstate Commerce Commission in rejecting today the railroads' plea for a general 10 per cent increase in freight rates were as follows:
CHICAGO, March 30. -- With Hitlerism and anti-Semitism as acute issues, Chicago's three-cornered Mayoralty campaign was drawing to a bitter close tonight.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- General Hugh S. Johnson fired tonight his final fusillade at the Rev. Charles Coughlin and Senator Huey Long, whom he has termed "the Pied Pipers," and concluded an address over a nation-wide radio hook-up by saying that he was "done with this controversy."

A MAN feels at times as if he had barged in on a women's tea party reading Miss Hoyt's informal biography of her sister. You can hear just so much about the fur called kolinsky and the dressmaker called Poiret before balderdash poisoning sets in.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley's special sale of ungummed stamp sheets has left him with a full cash register, but with the same old problem, the demand from collectors that he recall and destroy his gift sheets.
At last Saturday night's Metropolitan Museum symphony concert many in the audience were moved by the high standard achieved by the orchestra and David Mannes.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The supposedly free city of Danzig is being treated to a spectacle which would indicate the German Government regards Danzig's independent position as more of a formality than a reality.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- After cruising more than 800 miles from the United States on the Nourmahal in quest of game fish, President Roosevelt tonight headed westward again, prepared to begin next week with a definite working schedule to be fitted into the pleasure cruise.

MADRID, March 30. -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora today asked the veteran Republican leader, Alejandro Lerroux, whose government resigned yesterday, to form a new Cabinet, "if possible on a wider basis including representatives of the country's political Left wing as well as the same centre and Right wing elements which composed the last coalition ministry."
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at the White House today at luncheon, which was followed by a performance of "Haensel and Gretel" by the National Music League, Inc., of New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien and her son, John Heminway, who arrived last night from Princeton, N.J., entertained tonight with a dinner at Jardin Bijou. The event was arranged in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Heminway of New York, who joined today the house party at Villa del Sarmiento, where Mrs. W. Averell Harriman also is visiting. Others attending included:

A committee interested in the welfare of l'Ecole Maternelle Francaise, a French school at 346 West Twenty-eighth Street, has arranged a "Springtime in Paris" week, beginning tomorrow, at the Saks 34th Street Store to raise funds for the school.
ROCHESTER, March 30. -- This city will become a laboratory for the study of social changes in American life resulting from five years of depression.

THE ranks of American organized labor today are locked and criss-crossed in many dilemmas and conflicts. Every strike, every move, every labor congress reveals internal struggle over issues ranging from organizational structure to national and international policies.

The agreement reached last week to restrict production of copper outside the United States by 240,000 tons annually and to establish uniform marketing practices in foreign countries is considered generally in the trade to be the beginning of a new era of cooperation in the industry.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 30. -- The ninth annual field trial meeting of the Hauppauge Gunning Club was concluded today with the running of two stakes, the Cover Dog and the Open All-Age. The latter event, held during the afternoon, was won by Mike's Ghost, white and liver pointer, owned by C.H. Robbins of Islip.

Substantial improvement featured retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Consumer response to the several anniversary sales was reported good, and pre-Easter buying of apparel and accessories got off to a good start. Inasmuch as sales figures from now until Easter will compare with the less active post-Easter period a year ago, all indications are that sales volume will show extensive gains.

LIVERPOOL, England, March 30. -- Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller, whose defeat in the Grand National proved a windfall for the bookmakers, lost his own reputation as the best steeplechaser in recent years when he tossed his rider again today and threw racing circles into a deeper quandary.

ASIDE from its being the first novel of a 21-year-old author (the niece of E.V. Lucas), there is little unusual in this book, overloaded as it is with jejune philosophizing on life, love, sex, marriage and art by half-baked members of the youngest rebel generation.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- The government adopted today the Soviet equivalent of New York's Sullivan law as the latest strategic move in a war on crime similar to one the United States Government is now waging.

In a closely contested five-game match, Mrs. Rogers Dunn of the Junior League, and A.G. Thacher Jr. of the Heights Casino yesterday won the metropolitan mixed doubles squash racquets championship on the Heights Casino courts. Coming from behind with superb rallies in the second and fourth games, they defeated Miss Frida Scharman and Robert E. McCormick of the home club, 7 -- 15, 17 -- 14, 12 -- 15, 18 -- 14, 15 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- By a vote of 5 to 4, the Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected the plea of Class I railroads for a general 10 per cent increase in freight rates, but authorized emergency increases on some commodities until June 30, 1936.

BRUSSELS, March 30. -- Premier Paul van Zeeland tonight obtained a heavy vote in the Senate supporting his program for devaluing the belga. With nineteen Senators abstaining, the new Ministry received 110 votes to 20.

METRO this week approached two of its most ambitious musical films with firm step, determined that "The Great Ziegfeld" and "Broadway Melody of 1935" shall be among the more pretentious of the tune cycle. While there is no similarity in style of treatment, each will, the studio hopes, be outstanding in its type.

ISTANBUL, March 9. -- Americans visiting Turkey are justly proud to see the stately buildings of Robert College and of the American College for Girls overlooking the Bosporus, one of the world's most beautiful waterways.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 30. -- The annual horse show will be held at the indoor ring of the Round Hill Club stables on April 13. All entries will close next Saturday. The fifteen classes will include hunters, open jumping, good hands, touch-and-go sweepstakes, events for children and the championship final.

French and German operas, ringing down the curtain on Giulio Gatti-Casazza's world record of forty-two years of opera-giving, put the final international hallmark yesterday on the Metropolitan's closing season under its distinguished Italian director.

EVERY day in the year hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers take their meals in restaurants. If some of them are only dimly aware of the rising price of food it is because the restaurant owner has been doing some very close figuring in the last three months.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- After attempting for three years arbitrarily to control foreign exchange, Costa Rica has decided that it does not work and is the first Latin-American country to permit freedom in exchange transactions.

THIS book is a collection of vicious essays about amateur musicians, their music and their friends. It is all personalized and dramatized to an almost short-storyesque degree and it is told with many anecdotes. Mrs. Bowen is the youngest of a Philadelphia family of whom she and the eldest, a successful lawyer, are hard-bitten with the love of music, the kind of musical devotion that demands something be done about it, that must have expression.

UNDOUBTEDLY one of today's "trends" in gardening is toward standardization. This has the advantage, perhaps, of raising the level, in many cases, of design and of planting. But it is not without its dangers, too. And the greatest of these dangers is that the standardized garden may be planned without regard to the type of house which it is supposed to set off.

Fire of undetermined origin caused heavy damage late yesterday to a six-story apartment building being erected on Shore Road between Ninety-seventh and Ninety-eighth Streets in the Bay Ridge district of Brooklyn.

The annual dinner for employes of R.H. Macy Co. who have been with the organization twenty-five years or more was held last night in the restaurant of the department store at Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday that he would confer with President Roosevelt again before taking further action in the city's electric light and power situation. The conference, he said, would be held soon after President Roosevelt's return from his vacation trip.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A reduction of 255,000,000 bushels in the visible wheat supply of the world, compared with a year ago, was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

ALL the advance indications seem to point to the forthcoming sale of books and manuscripts from the library of John B. Stetson Jr. as the big event of the year. This is a noble array, consisting in the main of romances of chivalry, sixteenth-century French and Spanish literature, eighteenth-century French books with engravings, and rare Americana.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Because the Colonial history of Bermuda and that of the United States touch each other intimately at so many points, the loan exhibition of seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth century portraits which will be on view during the second week of April at the Town Hall in Hamilton is expected to attract Americans as well as islanders.
The Eastern racing season will open at Bowie on Tuesday, with every prospect for a successful meeting despite legislative delays over taxes and the demands for horses in many other sectors.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Joseph H. Choate Jr., chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, today said the liquor industry "has no rights," but only "privileges" permitted by the government.

PARIS, March 30. -- Instead of separating for Easter vacation as anticipated, the French Chamber of Deputies decided today to meet again Monday to discuss and no doubt adopt a bill for increasing and reorganizing the French air force, at a cost of 1,500,000,000 francs (nearly $99,000,000).

DALLAS, Texas, March 30. -- Improving business conditions are reported from all parts of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. There has been a steady upward trend since the holiday buying set in, with seasonal drops, which, however, are smaller than normal.

Unable to maintain its early lead, which stood at 10 points in the second period, John Adams High School's basketball team met its first setback of the campaign as a determined Textile High quintet triumphed, 24 to 20, yesterday at the James Madison High School gymnasium in Brooklyn.

BUDAPEST, March 29. -- Count Bethlen, the former Premier, broke through the circumspection which usually surrounds his public utterances in order to denounce in scathing terms the policy and intentions of Premier Goemboes, whom he recently supported.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Twin measures to keep the nation out of another war approaches final drafting in the Senate Munitions Committee.

The Governors of seven States have petitioned the Federal Government to step in and regulate milk. Everything else can be Planned; why not milk? All the Federal Government has to do is to say just how much production shall be, or just what prices shall be, or both.

BERLIN, March 30. -- Sir John Simon's voyage of exploration into the mind of Germany this week brought the British officially up against a fundamental contradiction perplexing to every unofficial visitor to this country.

With the markets for securities and commodities still swinging uncertainly within a narrow radius, financial interest was again centred yesterday in the much confused foreign exchange situation. The footloose belga was permitted to pursue its downward course, apparently without interference.

PARIS. PARIS couturiers are showing an extraordinary number of separate frocks for end-of-the-day wear. The ensemble seems to be fading out of the twilight style picture. The new frocks are designed to be worn on early Spring evenings with short fur capes of white or dyed ermine, sable, mink, chinchilla, or modest rabbit, dyed in green or rosy hues.

BERLIN. TWO years ago I wrote in these columns that in Germany Catholic literature has produced some outstanding spirits and masters of style. I mentioned Romano Guardini (Matthias Gruenewald Verlag, Mainz), who writes a most beautiful German which, despite its classic perfection of form, never leaves an effect of coldness or artificiality.
Students of Columbia and Oxford University held a heated debate on the future control of armament manufacture yesterday afternoon over an international radio hook-up.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30. -- A sensation was created today when it became known that Marcos Souza Dantas, former director of the Bank of Brazil and former president of the National Coffee Council, had taken the Integralista (Fascist) oath.

MANY are the books that have been written about the ships that sailed the seven seas from the ports of New England. But Mr. Kittredge, who is adept in the history of Cape Cod and has written an authoritative volume about it, says that its seafaring men have received but shabby treatment at the hands of those who have chronicled the achievements of the ships and men of other sections of the Massachusetts coast.

President Roosevelt's legislative program was attacked here yesterday by Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League. Mr. Shouse, who opposed Mr. Roosevelt's nomination for President, spoke on "Congress at the Crossroads" at the Empire State Club at a luncheon of the league that marked the beginning of a drive to increase its membership in New York City.

WASHINGTON. -- Garbed in a rumpled fisherman's costume, President Roosevelt may be fighting what he calls "the savage barracuda" in distant Bermuda waters this Sunday morning, but no nation's Chief Executive has ever been in more immediate contact with his capital while away from it than Mr. Roosevelt is at the present moment.

MOST of us have to do a lot of guessing as we go through life. We have to guess what the market will be, how the election will go, or whether some move we make will turn out well. We guess about the person we marry.

THERE are fashions in travel, as well as in clothes and cocktails. A wave of tourists to the South Seas was started, some years ago, by a best-selling novel. A handful of ukulele and guitar performers helped put Hawaii on the tourist map.

The extraordinary vitality and interest of the music of Chopin, so much more played than that of any other composer for the piano, was shown again yesterday afternoon by the proportions of the audience that gathered in the Town Hall for a Chopin program given by Ignaz Friedman.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- Swiftly moving events in the Luzerne County hard coal fields, scene of a desperate battle for supremacy between the United Mine Workers and its young rival union, the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, are causing concern.
The Columbia Spectator, which was suspended as the official student publication last Thursday by the college student board, will appear tomorrow with its status restored.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, March 30. -- An important step in the promotion of the Virgin Islands as a tourist resort will be taken on April 1 when, it was reported here today, the travel agency, National Tours, Inc., is expected to take over operation of the government-built Bluebeard Castle Hotel here.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- While some Congress members attacked the tentative bill submitted yesterday to extend the NIRA and announced that they would press for a Supreme Court argument by the Department of Justice in the Belcher lumber case, Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the NIRA, declared today that the Lumber Code Authority had no right to suspend provisions of the code because that right was vested solely in the President or his agents.

Major Gen. William C. Rivers has called attention in letters to THE TIMES to the compelling need of positive coordination of our national defense forces. The spectacular development of the air corps as a combatant arm adds to this need in no small measure.

The concert given by the New York Woman's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conductor, last night in Town Hall offered as purely orchestral works Weber's overture to "Der Freischutz," Schumann's "Spring" symphony, and Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" overture, and, for a feature involving the appearance of soloists with the ensemble, the Bach concerto for two violins.

The 100th anniversary of mutual life insurance in America will be observed at the convention of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company to be held in Boston tomorrow and on Tuesday and Wednesday. The meeting will assemble 800 insurance men from the United States and Hawaii.

Although the annual maple crop now being harvested in the State may not yield as much maple sugar and syrup as in some former years, its flavor promises to top the list of high-quality seasons, according to reports received yesterday by officials of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Boonville, an up-State New York village of 2,000 inhabitants, may soon become famous. Since 1903 it has had an electric light plant of its own. The original plant was built with borrowed funds, but extensions were financed out of earnings, and all the bonds have now been retired.

ONCE again the cities taste the bitter dust of the plains. Pitiless winds skim the precious powdered soil from the lean States beyond the Missouri River and sweep it by the millions of tons across the land. Impartially it settles on bungalow and penthouse, dropping from skies obscured by a baleful dun or orange glow as the sun's rays filter strangely through the billowing microscopic particles flung eastward from the knees of the Rocky Mountains.
The library of Americana formed by the late Lucius Lee Hubbard of Houghton, Mich., will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday afternoon.

DALLAS, March 28. -- A compact among the cotton States to unite for legislation to restore world trade and make possible the movement of a normal crop of cotton at normal prices is the goal sought in a resolution passed unanimously this week by the Texas Senate.

TOKYO. -- As Japan leaves the League of Nations [the withdrawal became effective on March 27] she takes with her as a souvenir a string of Pacific jewels -- the Mariana, Caroline and Marshall Islands. The islands were taken from Germany by the Japanese Navy in October, 1914; in 1917 the Allies agreed that Japan should get them at the peace; and in 1919 the League placed them under Japanese mandate.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Severe dust storms in Western Kansas and Nebraska, extending south into the Texas Panhandle, were reported again today on the Board of Trade. While the constant reiteration of drifting soil had some effect on sentiment and buying was sufficient to lift the price of wheat around 1 cent a bushel above yesterday's finish at the extreme, it was not enthusiastic.

AFTER all manner of rumors, promises, circulars and contradictions, Volume I of the Delius Society Series is at last an accomplished and delivered fact. Unfortunately, though we have been vouchsafed a glimpse of the records and the album containing them, the opportunity to listen to the music on them has not been permitted us as yet.

A loan exhibition of eighteenth and nineteenth century English and American portraits has been arranged at the Daniel H. Farr Galleries, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, where it will open to the public tomorrow. It is being held for the benefit of the Post-Graduate Hospital in New York and an admission fee of 50 cents will be charged.

THE old days of international opera are over; America through the modern radio is independently establishing its own opera traditions. So declared Geraldine Farrar at the conclusion of her first season as radio commentator of the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A public hearing April 18, 1935, in Room 2062, Department of Commerce Building, here, was ordered today by the National Industrial Recovery Board on two amendments to the Narrow Fabrics Industry Code, proposed by the Code Authority, which would establish open price filing and regulation of pricing practices.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 30 (AP). -- Jimmy Neilson, 14-year-old San Jose (Calif.) boy with a ruptured diaphragm, arrived here late today, full of gratitude for the folks back home who have made it possible for him to come East for a corrective operation.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., in its report for 1934, issued yesterday, shows that small companies acquired in 1914 were sold early this year to the city of Louisiana, Mo., and to the city of Mingo Junction, Ohio, after referenda approving municipal acquisition of waterworks properties, and that the sales will result in an annual decrease of about $60,000 in the gross earnings of the system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- Massachusetts colleges will join in presenting a solid front next Tuesday in protesting the move that would require an oath of allegiance to the Constitution by all school and college teachers.
The silence was broken by the White Queen who put down her morning paper and sighed.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The Boerse was active and relatively strong today. Heavy industrials were firm, Rheinstahl gaining 3 1/4 points, while Vereinigte Stahl, Klockner and Mannesmann rose 2 points each. Potashes and machineries were strong and active, Aschersleben gaining 2 1/4 points, while Schwarzkopf advanced 2 1/4.

THROUGH the recent mishap to the image of Civic Fame poised atop the Municipal Building Hew York becomes conscious of the scores of statues that surmount her lofty structures. Like sentinels they hold their stances in sunshine and in storm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- A comprehensive study and investigation of home backgrounds, migrations and health conditions of America's youthful unemployed has been started by the Harvard University Department of Sociology in collaboration with the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare.

IN the next few weeks there will be many comings and goings of diplomats between European capitals such as London, Paris, Berlin, Rome, Moscow and Warsaw have recently witnessed, but Geneva -- which not long ago was considered the logical meeting place of Foreign Ministers bent on preserving peace -- will be strangely and significantly in the background of the picture.
Federal agents arrested early yesterday a man who had been leading an apparently respectable existence as night manager for a midtown garage and a youth who was his mechanic and chauffeur.

PARIS, March 28. -- Annie Blatt is launching the season's most flattering bathing ensembles for women who have passed beyond their teens. They consist of a ruffled two-way-stretch elastic taffeta maillot with a choker front and a sunburn back; a short plain matching taffeta cape covers them.

BOYS and girls have an instinctive interest in natural phenomena; volcanoes, hot springs that boil and bubble, "shooting stars" that flash across the August and November skies stir their imagination and pique their curiosity.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Counting the cost of tuberculosis in the United States at $1,000,000,000 and 75,000 deaths annually, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared tonight that, considered solely from an economic standpoint, the pressing of a program to check the disease was highly advisable.

Colonel George B. McClellan, former Mayor of New York, who sailed yesterday for a tour of Europe on the Italian liner Rex, said he thought Mayor La Guardia was "doing well at his job," and that running the City of New York was, in his opinion, "the worst job in the United States."

IT is said that the main business of a critic is to find out what the artist has tried to do and report on his success or failure. The first part of the process is made easy in this case by the author's own statement of his purpose: "It was to be more than merely a story by an author. It was to forget that it had a writer.

ACCORDING to his publishers, Mr. Fitzgerald has chosen for inclusion in this volume the best short stories that he has written during the past decade. It is a curious and rather disturbing admission, coming as it does from a writer of Scott Fitzgerald's stature.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- Jack Medica, powerful University of Washington star, gained his third individual title in the twelfth annual swimming championships of the National Collegiate Athletic Association when he won the final of the 440-yard free style tonight.

POPULAR leisure, attributable to a shorter work-week and unemployment, has aided two "industries" usually associated with Coney Island side streets. The old-fashioned penny arcade has been modernized into a place for playing nickel-in-the-slot games; the dime museums continue as of old.

NO one who is interested in the problems arising out of Japan's administration of her mandated islands in the Western Pacific (the so-called South Sea Islands, a German possession before the World War) should miss Professor Clyde's book. It will be recalled that this mandate was allocated to Japan at the Paris Conference in 1919, and its terms were drawn up by the Council of the League of Nations.

It is pleasant to find that an effort is being made to improve the quality of books that are sold at very moderate prices. Considerable advance has been made, especially in the way of better illustrations, but there is still great need for more critical selection of both pictures and text.

MR. CAULEY is modest in his sub-title. His book does indeed offer a program for American farmers, but that program demands for its realization a pretty thorough reformation not only of our economic system but of the dominant ideals and objectives of our civilization.

MOSCOW, March 29. -- Adolf Hitler's declaration to Sir John Simon this week that Germany constitutes a bulwark against bolshevism was received here both as an opportune confession that Germany is arming against Soviet Russia and as a piece of hypocritical demagoguery.

RUTLAND, Vt., March 30 (AP). -- Freedom appeared a step nearer today for Miss Bertha Moore, 40, second cousin of Calvin Coolidge, and former village clerk at Ludlow, who has been in jail five months for failure to pay to Mrs. Albert Gilman $5,000, the amount ordered in an alienation of affections suit.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30. -- Extension of the intellectual life of Yale beyond the classroom into the nine colleges opened a year or two ago was revealed to a surprising extent in a survey of student activities, made public today. The study indicates that a wide amount of informal education is being achieved through many voluntary groups which have been formed in the colleges.

The Evander Childs and Textile High School teams annexed the titles in their respective sections as the Public Schools Athletic League's annual championship round-robin fencing tournament came to a close on the Washington Irving High School strips yesterday.

The compiler has put together in this volume symbolic tales ranging from a Dutch sixteenth-century allegory to stories by Frederic Farrar and Frederick William Shelton. There are tales taken from Mrs. Gatty's "Parables From Nature," a selection from Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress" and a new translation of Carove's "Story Without an End."

IN the rock-garden, or the intimate border, shady or sunny, certain of the wild violets will fit into crevices or may be given "pockets" all their own. Those which are decidedly shade-loving and ground-covering like the tall, leafy stemmed Canada violet (Viola canadensis) or the low creeping V. conspersa, may form a carpet under trees and shrubs.

NOT all the pedants and scholars may be found in the classroom. A few hibernate in motion-picture studios in silent contemplation of the cosmos and, at the cry of "Camera!" come forth with blinking eyes to set the supervisor and his cohorts to rights on world matters.

RENO, Nev., March 30 (AP). -- Princess Barbara Hutton Mdivani weary after an all-night flight from New York, arrived here today to await a divorce from Prince Alexis Mdivani. She was accompanied by her stepmother, Mrs. Franklyn Hutton of New York, and Millard Tompkins Jr., a New York attorney.

Lago Maggiore is a narrow and beautiful strip of water. Protected by the Alps, which keep away the chill of northern breezes, it is favored by those who seek kind but invigorating air. One can stand under a palm tree and look upward at eternal snows. Its famous salmon-colored trout make a wonderful lunch.

With sugar futures sharply higher on further advances in the spot and refined prices, commodity futures generally displayed a fairly firm tone in quiet trading yesterday, with coffee the only weak spot on the list. In the cash markets, gains occurred in all the grains, dairy products, rubber and raw and refined sugar.

BERLIN, March 30. -- Frau Charlotte Juenemann, slim, bobbed-haired young mother sentenced today to be beheaded because she left her three children to starve to death while she squandered relief money in cafes and dance halls, received the verdict apathetically.

PRINCE ALBERT, Canada. TO hold court one day in a city and the next day to fly 400 miles to hear charges against Indians and trappers in Western Canada's hinterland is no novel experience for J.E. Lussier, Northern Saskatchewan's roving judge. So frequently does he use the airplane that he is known as the "flying magistrate."

FOR the first time in many months, the current report on automobile manufacturing has shown all plants of the industry in operation at one time. This is in contrast to conditions that have prevailed in the past, when the rate of production had to be kept behind the rate at which the people were buying the cars.

LONDON. -- It can be taken for certain now that Ramsay MacDonald will resign from the post of Prime Minister very soon after the King's Jubilee, which is to be celebrated this May. The reason for this decision is that Mr. MacDonald's medical advisers categorically forbid him, under pain of fatal consequences, to work on state papers, or to expose himself any longer to the stress of debates in Parliament.

TORONTO, ONT. March 30. -- The annual report of Noranda Mines, Ltd., for 1934, indicates profits of $2.20 a share, compared with $2.15 in 1933 and $1.61 in 1932. Revenue from minerals amounted to $12,887,333, while miscellaneous income brought the total up to $13,403,454, compared with $12,912,099 in 1933.

Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, inspected the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street, yesterday and predicted that it would be "exceedingly successful" when it was opened in September.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP). -- An attempt to form a "Father Coughlin party" based on the political and economic theories of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit was blamed today by William S. Schimpf, 40 years old, for his arrest on charges of fraudulent conversion.

Uncertainty over pending Federal legislation slowed down operations in all branches of the food industry here last week. Buyers for large chain and wholesale houses held back volume orders for grocery products in the hope of getting better quotations in event that NRA restrictions are relaxed, while manufacturers delayed operation, awaiting the outcome of discussions over the Black thirty-hour week bill.

WHAT the cable from London terms "eagerly awaited" is the Strand's single premiere this week: Rodney Ackland's dramatization of Hugh Walpole's novel, "The Old Ladies," Edith Evans acting, John Gielgud directing.

DENVER, March 28. -- Asserting that 40,000 persons, approximately one-quarter of the Colorado relief load, are aliens, Governor Edward C. Johnson plans to deport them if he can on the ground that this is a burden the State should not be called upon to bear.

BRYSON BURROUGHS, we are told by his close friend, William M. Ivins Jr., had great difficulty, as a boy, in making up his mind whether he should become a professional bicycle rider or an artist. No one who examines Burroughs's paintings would be likely to suspect, from any clues they contain, that he had even been on a bicycle.

THE motor bus has invaded sections of Europe that were once either inaccessible or too far removed from available facilities to merit the tourist's attention. In some instances the motor supplements established train services, in others it opens new territory to the visitor.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 30. -- Recent gains in the volume of department and retail store trade were maintained in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. The volume of sales, according to reports from a majority of leading department stores in the district, still was substantially greater than a year ago and on a parity with those for the last two weeks.

A radio receiver using all-metal vacuum tubes of a new design will be demonstrated for the first time tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock in the House of Magic room of the General Electric Building, 570 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, March 30. -- Despite the alarms and excitements of the last fortnight, the British Government does not expect a European war in the near future. It does not think it probable for several years because it seems unlikely that Germany will be ready sooner.

With its teamwork improving as the match progressed, the New York A.C. began the defense of its national senior indoor polo championship by defeating the Boulder Brook trio, 13 to 4 1/2, as the senior title play started last night at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn.

AS soon as a Broadway producer acquires a new play he begins to moan that it is impossible to cast it because all the actors are in Hollywood. But should he desire to present an old play, to revive a drama of Euripides, Shakespeare, Moliere, Congreve or Sheridan, he might have all of Hollywood and Broadway at his disposal and still find himself in this dilemma.

SCRANTON, Pa. -- This city, which rests over millions of tons of anthracite, is about to enter into a transaction with a large coal firm in settlement of back taxes and municipal improvement obligations that is probably unparalleled in this country.

PARIS, March 30. -- While the belga sank further toward its newly determined parity, the attention of the exchange market this morning centred on the pound, which today gave an indication that it was prepared to recommence its downward trend which the belga's collapse interrupted.

IT seems that every publisher must have a Candide, for Master Sanguine is the third within a year, and there have been a few before that. Shaw's "Black Girl in Search of God" may have helped in the revival. It should be noted appreciatively that Shaw is in the tradition.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Citizens have sent $1,576,022 to the Federal Treasury since 1862 in voluntary contributions ranging from $963,391 to 50 cents.

IN the Iowa small town of Stilton, Kay Denny (The Cluck) worked as the highly efficient and personable public librarian. Still virginal at 29, she retained romantic illusions, a longing to spread her untried wings, to escape the monotony and narrowness of provincial life, to travel, adventure and love.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP). -- The railroads, largest shoppers in the country, laid $167,250,000 more on the nation's counters in 1934 than in the previous year. They spent, Railway Age reported today, $625,000,000, or 18.4 per cent of earnings, compared to $457,750,000, or 14.1 per cent, in 1933, and it appears likely that they will spend even more in 1935.

Following the arrest of thirty-one pickets in Brooklyn, the executive committee of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, deferred action yesterday afternoon until Tuesday on Mayor La Guardia's offer of arbitration in the strike of 700 men on five unfinished sections of the new city-owned Independent subway.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 30 (AP). -- Track and field stars from the Midwest, South and Southwest smashed twelve records today in the Texas relays, the first major outdoor meet of the season. Eight meet records fell in the university division and two in the college class.

MEMPHIS, March 28. -- Without aggressive leadership and lacking a definite program, the Tennessee Legislature reconvened this week after a five-week recess to face a month's battle over taxes. A deficit of $2,500,000 must be taken care of and $1,500,000 must be raised to match Federal relief funds.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 (AP). -- Racing almost bow to bow, the Haligonian, three-time winner, and A-Weigh, a newcomer from Gibson Isle, Md., headed into the Gulf of Mexico late today in the vanguard of a fleet of twenty-one yachts, starting the sixth annual St. Petersburg-Havana race.

Mme. Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan Opera soprano, sailed on the French liner Paris yesterday to recover on the Riviera from an illness which caused the cancellation of five appearances in this country. Mme. Lehmann, who could scarcely speak above a whisper as the result of a cold, said she had missed five performances, three in opera and two on the concert stage.

When Elliott Webber, 15-year-old high school boy of Salem, Mass., arrived in New York yesterday on his third runaway in the last six weeks, he fell into the friendly hands of Detective Clinton Schlunsen of the Missing Persons Bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Penn, behind the splendid pitching of the veteran Andy Barton, Lou Effinger, George Horne and George Lees, easily defeated Drexel Institute in the opening baseball game of the season on Franklin Field today, 16 to 2.

The actor and the character he plays were described as two separate entities merged into one by Walter Abel, actor, in a discussion at the opening session of a two-day conference on acting at the Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place, yesterday.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 30. -- The Laetare Medal will be bestowed this year upon Frank Hamilton Spearman, California novelist, it was announced today by the University of Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Industrial output probably has increased less than seasonally in March, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions. Production, however, still is in excess of the corresponding period of 1934.

Enough poison to kill 150 persons was extracted from eighteen cottonmouth moccasin snakes by Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of mammals and reptiles, yesterday afternoon at the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx.

When Franklin D. Roosevelt became President of the United States the first thing he had to cope with was a banking crisis. In little Belgium the story was repeated last week. On Monday Paul van Zeeland, Princeton University graduate, former professor at the University of Louvain and close student of the Roosevelt policies, succeeded in forming a Cabinet.

BUENOS AIRES. SPORTING and commercial aviation in Argentina are making rapid headway, according to the 1934 report of the Civil Aviation Department. The total flying time of airlines and of the subsidized sporting organizations, as well as private individual flights, is put at 18,641 hours.

PARIS, March 30. -- Now that the belga has been knocked off its gold perch, France, Switzerland and the Netherlands are only too well aware that critical and dubious glances are coming their way from the rest of the world.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell, Moderator of the Presbytery of New York, yesterday questioned the wisdom of disciplining the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia, Fundamentalist leader, who was found guilty by a special judicial commission of the New Brunswick Presbytery of disobeying an order of the General Assembly to resign from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- To fight tuberculosis with modern weapons, the National Tuberculosis Association tonight launched a nation-wide campaign here after Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and leaders of the medical profession had urged public participation in the drive to wipe out the disease.

A bill to legislate alcohol into gasoline and thus make the automobile owner play an unwilling part in relieving agricultural distress has passed both houses in South Dakota. Similar measures are pending in Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, Idaho and California. Evidently the overwhelming engineering and economic evidence against the compulsory use of alcohol and gasoline published by the Bureau of Standards, the American Petroleum Institute and other competent agencies is ignored.

F.A. Cauchois Sr. carried off the high-over-all scratch honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday with a card of 98 out of 100 targets and gained a leg on the scratch trophy at 149 targets by breaking 133. Cauchois Jr. took the handicap cup in Class C with a full score.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30. -- Although Coach Jack Jefferies had to use six pitchers before the game was over, Princeton defeated Vermont, 7 to 2, on University Field today for its second baseball victory in as many days.

MR. STARKIE'S new volume of gypsy adventuring is rich in interest and charm. In a former volume, "Raggle-Taggle," he told of tramping through Eastern Europe with his fiddle, and in this new book his adventures are of a similar sort, with Northern Spain as their scene.
" Old-Timer" writes to your paper asking which of the above gentlemen deserves the honor of being referred to as the dean of the American theatre. An old-timer might endeavor to answer that question.

LONDON, March 30. -- The British Government and public continue to find the utmost satisfaction in the progress of the discussions of Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, with Soviet leaders in Moscow. The reports already received from Mr. Eden are enough to show that Russia and Britain have identical opinions on the present European crisis and the measures necessary to meet it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- R.B. Miller of Bowdoin was elected president of the Swimming Coaches Association of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at the annual meeting today. Fred Cady of Southern California was elected first vice president, S.W. Ingraham of Colgate second vice president, and Henry Ortland of the United States Naval Academy was re-elected secretary and treasurer.

THE Black-and-White Room at the National Academy of Design this year is unusually interesting on several counts. Foremost comes the care for quality shown in the selection. Next, perhaps, the variety in expression on the part of the artists -- many men in many moods and with a wide divergence of liking or opportunity in choice of subject.

From the report on a comprehensive survey, carried on by the Mayor's committee on unemployment relief with the aid of the Russell Sage Foundation, New York City learned something last week of the vast relief problem it must solve.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 30 (AP). -- A "grave violation of Swiss sovereignty" was charged to Germany today as the Swiss Government sent an energetic protest to Berlin against the alleged kidnapping of an anti-Nazi on Swiss soil.

Civic leaders in Brooklyn will carry their campaign against increased water rates and the 10 per cent penalty for tax arrears into the other boroughs. This was decided yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the executive committee of the Kings County Consolidated League at 50 Court Street, Brooklyn.

FIFTEEN years ago Mr. Mervyn Davies surrendered to the hypnotic spell of Warren Hastings. With infinite labor he has learned all that there is to know about this superman of the East, and well has he earned high honors -- the Native Princes of India Prize and the gold medal of the Royal Aslatic Society.
Thank you for the mention of Mr. Lampkin's concerts in Japan that appeared in your column of the Musical Section on Feb. 10.

PARIS, March 30. -- The European gold bloc today began to feel the full effect of the Belgian defection from the gold standard as a stream of yellow metal, which experts said might become a big flow, started on its way to the United States.

The article about stamps by Clair Price in THE TIMES for March 24 was interesting. After fifteen years of writing on this hobby in America, Canada, England and Australia, I, too, am beginning to ponder, What is a postage stamp?
ALBANY, March 30. -- The battle over unemployment insurance between Governor Lehman and revolting Democratic Senators will be brought out in the open early next week, it was said here today.
